links.text: Among the throngs gathered outside Parliament House as events unfolded was TV personality Norman Gunston – the satirical alter ego of Garry McDonald – who added surreal elements to the proceedings when he attempted to elicit comments from Labor personalities.

Woody Allen and cinematographer Gordon Willis inserted their own fictional character, Leonard Zelig, into historical proceedings using blue screen technology. Combining scratched and aged footage with 1920s and 30s newsreel, they created a faux documentary that interrogated American society and individuality.

When Forrest Gump was released in 1994, CGI had developed to the point of facilitating near seamless visual effects. CGI and greenscreen tech allowed the fictional Forrest to interact with real historical figures including John F Kennedy and John Lennon.

Deepfake technology allows professionals and fans alike to recontextualise and remix moving image works. After it was rumoured that Tom Cruise may have played Tony Stark/Iron Man, Deepfake Theatre made it happen, superimposing him into iconic moments from the Marvel Cinematic Universe.

In a sobering example of how Deepfakes can create alternate realities, director Jordan Peele created a PSA from Barack Obama, seemingly making contentious comments. The video draws attention to the potential for AI to generate fake videos that could spread disinformation.

In Wearing Gillian, Wearing used deepfake and AI technology to map her own face onto volunteers who replied to a newspaper ad. The film asks us to question the tensions of living in an increasingly media-saturated world and how reality can be easily distorted.

links.text: The Wilhelm scream is a famous shriek first used in Distant Dreams, and later over 400 films, including the Star Wars franchise. Ben Burtt, the sound designer, is credited with turning the stock sound into an in-joke between sound designers.

The Wilhelm scream is basically an easter egg, a message or in-joke in a piece of media that's difficult to identify. Easter eggs are a key narrative feature of Ready Player One, which contains a reference to Star Wars.

A major plot point of Ready Player One involves locating a secret room in the 1979 Atari game Adventure, which is widely regarded as the first videogame with an Easter egg, created by Warren Robinett after being denied a programmer credit.

As well as featuring the first Easter egg, Adventure is also recognised as a predecessor of the open-world genre. It inspired a gameplay style adapted by major franchises to follow like The Legend of Zelda.

The same year, Nintendo released Metroid, another open world title that featured one of the first female protagonists in videogames. It later inspire a sub-genre of open world games called "Metroidvania", which combined its non-linear format with Castlevania.

name: The Wilhelm scream, easters eggs and open world games

links.text: Like The Great, Taika Waititi’s Jojo Rabbit plays up its fictional elements for laughs. Through this dark comedy, Waititi explores the idea that “good” people can do terrible things, if they don’t learn to think for themselves.

While Jojo Rabbit rewrote history for satire, other unhistorical narratives could have darker motives. The Call of Duty series have been criticised for promoting Western imperialism, rewriting events to make the US look unequivocally like heroes. Call of Duty: Vanguard (2021), made in Melbourne, is the latest game in the almost two-decade-old series.

Other historical epics have used fiction to illustrate the humanity in major historical moments. In Titanic the doomed romance between Jack and Rose plays out amidst a cast of historical figures; Fifth Officer Harold Lowe, who rescues Rose, was a real officer on the Titanic.

Blending fact and fiction can also be a practical concern. Costume designer Edie Kurzer used a mix of vintage fabric and garments with new designs for miniseries Picnic at Hanging Rock (2018). Mrs Appleyard's purple fete dress is one of the only garments made for the series from scratch

Historical gowns like those in Picnic at Hanging Rock (2018) are showstopping when done right. Costumes from Titanic (1997) are so popular they have a dedicated museum - the Titanic Museum Attraction, in Pigeon Forge, Tennessee.

Charli XCX & Troye Sivan appear in iconic 90s moments in the "1999" music video, including Titanic. Though Sivan was only four, fantasy is the point: “I know those days are over / but a boy can fantasise / ‘Bout JTT on MTV,” Sivan sings.

links.text: Epiphytes invites you to imagine how a plant experiences the world, while Flower lets you play as a breeze, floating through the landscape.
Flying though grasslands in the game Flower is a meditative experience; tending to a derelict garden in The Secret Garden brings healing and happiness to three lonely children.

In The Secret Garden, tending a garden is a metaphor for looking after one's spirit. In Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs, trees are given human form, with scary faces and grasping branch-hands as Snow White runs terrified through the forest.

The trees in Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs are drawn with human qualities to make them appear more scary. In the Batman Universe, Poison Ivy is part human and part plant, and can kill with her poisonous kiss!

Poison Ivy has plant and human DNA mixed, a futurist fantasy of inter-species existence. In the scorched earth future of Wall-E, one lone seedling survives, carrying the hope of all humanity in its green shoots.

links.text: Puberty Blues’ raw depiction of Australian adolescence in the 1970s explored teen social hierarchies, female friendship, peer pressure and toxic machismo in a generation-defining film. Twenty-five years later, it was given the TV treatment with a popular new series.

One of Puberty Blues’ most memorable aspects was the trash-taking dialogue that popularised getting ‘dropped’ and complaining about ‘molls’. Similarly raw, and a TV version of a movie, Heartbreak High’s crucial cultural contribution (apart from Drazic) was introducing ‘rack off’ into popular vernacular.

While Puberty Blues portrayed a particularly white teen experience, western Sydney-set Heartbreak High better reflected Australia's diversity, but it wasn't until 2015’s Ready for This that Indigenous teens were finally centrestage in an Aussie teen drama.
Ready for This star Madeleine Madden was in yet another remake/imagining/vision of classic Australian film about adolescence, Picnic at Hanging Rock, alongside Romper Stomper star Lilly Sullivan.

The series kept the dark portrait of teen life on Sydney’s surf beaches. Series co-lead Ashleigh Cummings is no stranger to raw portrayals of adolescence, having explored similar themes in another coming-of-age drama Galore, set in suburban Canberra in the early 2000s.
Galore co-stars Lilly Sullivan, who like Cummings starred in a new iteration of a classic movie, but this time the TV sequel to 1992’s Romper Stomper, where she plays a young anti-fascist activist.

Mrs. Appleyard wears this burgundy dress for the Valentine’s Day photo, contrasting the students' demure white dresses. In Cruella (2021), Estella first unveils her alter-ego Cruella in a striking red stress at the Baroness’s black and white Ball.

In Cruella, Estella uses fashion to disguise herself to pull off various thefts, grifts and other crimes. Similarly, high fashion is crucial to Anna successfully fooling New York’s elite in Inventing Anna (2022), posing as a German Heiress.
Both Hustlers (2019) and Inventing Anna (2022) are drawn from true stories. These screen adaptations were based on news articles written by the same journalist, Jessica Pressler.

Hustlers (2019) centres the relationship between Destiny and Ramona in depicting the true story of New York City strippers scamming male clients. Similarly, Bridgerton (2020) explores themes of sisterhood through many characters, most prominently Kate and Edwina Sharma in Season 2.

Bridgeton's (2020) villain is narrator Lady Whistledown – the town’s gossip columnist who is capable of irrevocably damaging peoples’ reputation. Players of Portal (2007) are similarly taunted by the omnipresent female voice of the game’s villain GLaDOS (an AI program).

links.text: Featuring a skyward shot of a plummeting city, the teaser poster for The Dark Knight Rises also revealed the outline of the Bat-Insignia. As if emerging from an underground cave and rising to the heavens, the imagery doubled as a metaphor for the film’s title.

Heavily steeped in art deco design, the poster for Metropolis also showcases a cityscape. Created by German graphic artist Heinz Schulz-Neudamm the design style took influences from Bauhaus, Cubist and Futurist design.

Malcolm McDowell leers menacing, brandishing a knife and framed by the letter ‘A’ in Phillip Castle’s poster for A Clockwork Orange. Castle’s painterly airbrushed style and hyper-pop hues against white would also feature in Stanley Kubrick’s Full Metal Jacket.

Relying on powerfully clear visual storytelling, Roger Kastel’s poster for Jaws also featured its film’s menacing anti-hero. The imagery showcasing shark Bruce’s terrifying teeth would also be used across the film’s extensive merchandise, continuing to be popular on t-shirts today.

Mitzi Del Bra dancing in the desert in a green sequined corset truly captures the glitz, glamour and spirit of this treasured Australian classic. The imagery would become the film’s visual motif, celebrating the spectacular costume design of Tim Chappel and Lizzy Gardiner

nodes.title: The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert

links.text: Tony McNamara is also credited with co-writing the screenplay for The Favourite. Both this film and The Great feature corseted strong female characters and striking dresses that hide the psychological warfare boiling under the surface.
Love triangles and power imbalances guide the central narrative of these two sapphic period dramas. The Handmaiden features intricate designs which reflect the layers of each character.

Following The Handmaiden, director Park Chan-Wook adapted the spy novel The Little Drummer Girl by John le Carré for television. The costuming included bright tones which created an authentic 70s vibe and allowed insight into the mind of each character.

Florence Pugh proved herself to be a versatile genre actress, starring in a tense spy thriller then going onto an unravelling folk horror nightmare. Set in a Swedish commune, the centrepiece May Queen dress has become an iconic Halloween costume.

Actress Ellora Torchia can be seen in these two films which feature themes of psychedelic folklore and nature. Emma Fryer frequently collaborates with Ben Wheatley to create memorable costumes which form the identity of each character.

In the Earth showcases costumes reflecting identity - but to do so, they have to stay consistent. While filming (2018), costume designer Edie Kurzer kept careful documentation of how each costume should appear in each scene, down to the last stocking and glove.

nodes.title: The Great season one costume: Catherine's pink birthday dress

links.text: Birds in cages appearing and disappearing is a recurring motif in The Prestige. Just like the illusionists of the 19th century, Christopher Nolan is fascinated by the power of images to fool, surprise, and delight us.
Making a person disappear is Hugh Jackman's obsession in The Prestige, but it's also the premise of pre-Code science-fiction hit The Invisible Man.
There's a fine line between fantasy and surrealism. Being invisible is treated sensitively in The Invisible Man, but in this Monty Python sketch leads to rampant explosions.
The Invisible Man is wrapped in bandages to reveal his shape, just like the player covers an invisible world in paint to explore it in The Unfinished Swan.
As well as borrowing a title from Monty Python, Hito Steyerl's dry and surreal humour pervades her rumination on the nature of image and privacy in the 21st Century.

Tacita Dean’s Disappearance at Sea is inspired by the true story of Donald Crowhurt, an amateur sailor who died solo sailing the world. Similarly, Robert Eggers’ The Lighthouse is inspired by a real-life 1801 incident involving lighthouse keepers Thomas Griffiths and Thomas Howell.

The romantic and maddening isolation of lighthouses is fertile ground for fictional stories as well as factual ones. One of the earliest narrative films set on one is Cape Forlorn, a 1931 story of passion and betrayal – like The Lighthouse.

Despite their purpose to save lives, stories set on lighthouses always seem to end in death. Two years after Cape Forlorn, another British film used a lighthouse as the stage for a murder mystery, Michael Powell’s The Phantom Light.

All these works are British. Robyn Ludwig proposes lighthouses symbolise anxieties and aspirations in Britain during WWII and were critical to defending the country. In The Seventh Survivor, a lighthouse crew saves survivors of torpedoed passenger vessel, but one is a spy for Germany.

Sometimes the terror in lighthouse stories aren’t symbolic of wartime anxiety. Sometimes they’re just fun. John Carpenter’s cult classic The Fog tells the story of a Californian town swarmed with ghosts who sunk at sea 100 years earlier. Much of the action happens in a lighthouse.

In the Round the Twist episode “Viking Book of Love”, a mysterious fog rolls into Port Niranda, cutting them off from the outside world. Like in The Fog, there’s something in the mist. This time, rather than ghosts, it’s Vikings trapped out of time.

The first scene of acclaimed video game Bioshock has the player swimming through the ocean after a plane crash. When they look up, they see a great, art-deco style lighthouse looming out of the water, which leads the player to the underwater city of Rapture.

Like The Great, the 1997 Disney film Anastasia is a fictional, whimsical story based on the real world events: in this case, the search for the missing Romanov, 18 year old Grand Duchess Anastasia Nikolaevna.
You can see costume designer Sharon Long's inspiration for the coronation dress in her mood boards, featuring images of the Romanovs.

The mystic Grigori Rasputin, an advisor to the Romanovs, has also been the subject of speculation and fascination for hundreds of years. In the months after his death, not one but two silent films were made about him: Rasputin, The Black Monk and The Fall of the Romanoffs.

The fascination with Rasputin that began in 1917 continues to this day. In 1978, German disco group Boney M even wrote a pop song about him, aptly titled "Rasputin". The song was featured on the videogame Just Dance 2.

People love stories about the wildly wealthy and out of touch. Succession,, about a dysfunctional media dynasty, is considered one of TV's best shows. In an era of disinformation and media corporatisation, it's weird people love it but there’s sadistic enjoyment watching terrible, powerful people flail.

Fascination with the wealthy and powerful can have a bloodthirsty edge. In her video essay ‘Envy’ YouTuber Natalie Wynn explores the dynamics of the green-eyed monster: why do we obsess over the good fortune of others, and why do people enjoy the downfall of the rich and famous?

The Great season two sketches and mood boards

links.text: After working with filmmaker Richard Lowenstein on her first feature, Strikebound (1984), the two collaborated on the cult Melbourne movie, Dogs in Space. Starring INXS frontman Michael Hutchence, the film exposed sex, drugs and rock n roll in the late 1970s post-punk scene.

Gumbainggir activist, academic, writer and actor Gary Foley was in Dogs in Space, but he’s got a number of screen credits, including A Country Practice. Foley helped shape the storylines of his character and used the show to bring broader attention to Indigenous issues.

In her first collaboration with Baz Luhrmann, Jill Bilcock won an AACTA for Best Editing when she brought the frenetic, energetic world of ballroom dancing to life in Strictly Ballroom. Bilcock later then worked on Romeo + Juliet and Moulin Rouge!.

Doubtful anyone told Bilcock she was terrible when editing PJ Hogan’s iconic comedy, Muriel’s Wedding. It was her fourth AACTA nomination for Best Editing. To date, she has 11 nominations and four wins.

While Strictly Ballroom won Bilcock’s an AACTA, it was also nominated for an Oscar and was voted as the 32nd best-edited film of all time by the Motion Picture Editors Guild – no surprise considering all the leg kicks, skirt twirls and songs.

Luhrmann isn’t Bilcock’s only key collaborator. She also has long working relationships with Jocelyn Moorhouse, Ana Kokkinos, PJ Hogan and Kriv Stenders, but also Shekhar Kapur, who directed Cate Blanchett in Elizabeth and its sequel.

With her invisible fingerprints on over 35 movies, it’s no surprise that eventually Bilcock would be pulled from the editing suite and thrust into the spotlight herself. That’s just what happened with Axel Grigor’s Jill Bilcock: Dancing the Invisible.

Rachel Griffiths starred alongside Toni Colette as fellow ABBA tragic and outcast Rhonda Epinstall. Twenty-five years after making her big-screen debut, Griffiths made her directorial debut with Ride Like a Girl, which, you guessed it, Bilcock edited.

Like editing, costume design sometimes goes unnoticed by audiences but it crucial to telling stories on screen. The bridesmaid dresses worn by Cheryl (Roz Hammond) and Janine (Belinda Jarrett) unpick their characters, stich by stich.

Flight of the Amazon Queen's evil Dr Ironstein has an underground bunker, high-tech lab, a dino-ray to create dinosaur women. The mad scientist is often attributed to Mary Shelly’s Frankenstein (1818), but it's H.G Wells 1896 novel The Island of Dr Moreau that defined many of villainous scientist tropes.

As science progressed so did the potential threat that the mad scientist could wield. In the 1950s the threat of atomic bomb created a new fear of the power of science to destroy humanity. James Bond's Dr No is the perfect villain for the atomic age.

The trope of the evil scientist is most memorably parodied by Dr Evil in the Austin Powers films. Dressed as Dr No but closer to Bond villain Blofeld, the character mocks the ridiculous egotism of the 'genius' supervillain.

Dr Evil aims for domination through machine and flesh: he wants "sharks with frickin' laser beams"! This trope explores the perceived threat of robotics to humanity, a fear has been explored across genres and in videogames by the evil Dr Eggman (Dr Robotnik).

nodes.title: Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery

links.text: Before The Great (2020), Tony McNamara wrote The Favourite (2019), a story about another fashion-forward royal - Queen Anne. For her coronation, she wore a crimson cloak over a white satin dress, later changing into a lace gown to counterbalance the weight of the Royal Jewels.

Elizabeth Taylor might not have been royalty technically, but like Cleopatra herself, she certainly had royal taste in jewels. Taylor owned one of the most famous diamonds in the world - the 70 carat Taylor-Burton Diamond, a gift from her husband, Harry Burton, which she wore to the 42nd Academy Awards.

Elizabeth Taylor was one of the first celebrities to publicly support HIV//AIDS activism. Activist organisation ACT UP adopted the pink triangle given to gay men in Nazi camps, in their protest against the government's response to the AIDS crisis. ACT UP's efforts were depicted in BPM (Beats Per Minute).

In 2021, Billie Eilish’s stunning Oscar de la Renta gown turned heads at the Met Gala - but the gown speaks to her activism, too. A passionate animal rights activist, Eilish convinced De La Renta to stop using fur in the brand.

There’s more to how people dress than just fashion. When Representative Ilhan Omar was elected to US congress, she made history by wearing a hijab in the Capitol building, ensuring that the 181-year-old rule against headwear in the House allowed for religious exemptions.
What we wear can be an expression of character - or a total deception. in Picnic at Hanging Rock (2018), Mrs Appleyard (Natalie Dormer) uses clothes to disguise her past.

links.text: John Constable’s landscapes, as well as other 18th-century paintings, were a key influence on the cinematography of Stanley Kubrick’s Barry Lyndon. These paintings inspired how shots were framed, as well as how light appeared in the film.

As Kubrick looked to 18th-century paintings for Barry Lyndon, director Todd Haynes similarly looked to female photographers of the era when making Carol. Photographers that inspired the film's visual aesthetic included Ruth Orkin and Esther Bubley.

Photography not only influenced the cinematography of Carol but is also key to the narrative as protagonist Therese is a photographer. Although the biopic, Frida focused on Kahlo’s career as a painter, she also worked in photography throughout her lifetime.

Several of Kahlo’s paintings were recreated in Frida by building sets in forced perspective and using flattened lighting. Similarly, direct recreations of Vincent van Gogh’s artworks were amongst the 65,000 oil paintings featured in the stop-motion animation Loving Vincent.
Frida Kahlo’s painting What the Water Gave Me is visually recalled in the biopic Frida and later inspired Florence + The Machine’s song of the same name.

Ukiyo-e woodblock prints were a key influence on Vincent van Gogh’s paintings, which are recreated in Loving Vincent. Similarly, the creators of Ōkami drew on the Ukiyo-e style of art to create the visuals for their videogame.

In 2019, Kanye West created a documentary of his performance of album Jesus is King at the Roden Crater, James Turrell’s large-scale artwork created within a volcanic cinder cone in the Painted Desert in Northern Arizona.

The colourful background that Drake dances in front of in the original “Hotline Bling” video is based on Turrell’s immersive artworks, though the artist wasn’t officially involved, issuing a statement saying “neither I nor my woes was involved in any way”.

Donald Trump has hosted Saturday Night Live twice. In 2015, a year before he won the American presidency on the back of his Make America Great Again slogan, he appeared in a skit for Drake’s “Hotline Bling”.

Both Kim Kardashian and Kanye West have appeared on Saturday Night Live, where the former met her current boyfriend Pete Davidson and the latter controversially appeared in a red Make America Great Again cap, apparently signalling his support for Donald Trump.

A long-time fan of Turrell’s work, West introduced the artist’s immersive artworks to his then sister-in-law Kendall Jenner, who purchased Turrell’s Scorpius, Medium Elliptical Glass (2019) for a rumoured $750,000 USD, which can be seen in this Architecture Digest tour of her home.
While married to Jenner’s sister Kim Kardashian, West would appear in their reality TV show, Keeping Up with the Kardashians.

nodes.title: Inside Kendall Jenner’s Cozy L.A. Hideaway

links.text: Sublime Light features stunning paintings by Joseph Wright of Derby and John Martin. Martin’s painting had an epic scope that not only rendered light in revolutionary ways, but had epic cinematic qualities.

Film legend Ray Harryhausen credited John Martin "one of the first art directors of motion pictures". Ray Harryhausen owns a considerable collection of engravings by John Martin. Harryhausen created the special effects for several award-winning films including Jason and the Argonauts.

In 20 Million Miles to Earth, a gigantic alien creature terrorises Sicily in Italy. John Martin also set work in Sicily, which was the scene of similar apocalyptic scenes when Mount Vesuvius erupted in 79 CE, destroying Pompeii and Herculaneum, as captured in Martin’s painting.

Peter Jackson was inspired by Harryhausen and the way Jason and the Argonauts’ stop-motion effects brought mythology to life, stating that Lord of the Rings would “never have been made” without Harryahusen’s influence.
The famous skeletons in Jason and the Argonauts have shields adorned with designs of other Ray Harryhausen creatures, including an octopus and the head of the Ymir from 20 Million Miles to Earth.

Jackson has a collection of cinema artifacts, many from films that inspired him to become a filmmaker. He’s said to own over 100 replicas of Harryhausen’s creations, and recently purchased the faceplate for the Hal 9000 from 2001: A Space Odyssey.

Peter Jackson created a remake of King Kong in 2005. Unlike the first King Kong film in 1933, Jackson brought the mighty primate to life through an actor wearing motion capture rather than practical effects – something he’d perfected with Golem in Lord of the Rings.

Harryhausen was so inspired by the effects of the original Kong that he started experimenting with marionettes and stop-motion animation as a child. Pioneer model animator Willis O’Brien, who did King Kong, hired Harryhausen as an assistant animator on Mighty Joe Young.

The most iconic scene in Jason and the Argonauts features stop-motion skeleton warriors. It took Harryhausen four months to make the three-minute scene. It was recreated as an homage in Sam Raimi’s Army of Darkness, using the Introvision process instead of the traditional rear projection.

The Lord of the rings: the fellowship of the ring

links.text: Like The Great, Hades uses historical material to tell a new story. This isn’t the game’s only distinction - Supergiant’s work is known for its unique sound. This is the work of Logan Cunningham, who has voiced an impressive six characters in Hades itself.

Supergiant Games collaborations are professional - but creative partnerships can turn romantic, too. Director Noah Baumbach met his now-partner Greta Gerwig when she was cast in his film, Greenberg. The two later collaborated on Frances Ha and Mistress America.

On top of her collaborations with Noah Baumbach, Greta Gerwig has a strong directorial style of her own. She has a close relationship with actor Saoirse Ronan, who she cast in the leading roles in her directorial debut Lady Bird and Little Women.

Decades before her role as Marmie in Little Women, Laura Dern became David Lynch’s muse. She has worked with the director many times, starring in films including Blue Velvet, Wild at Heart and Inland Empire, which she also co-produced.

Like Laura Dern, daughter of Bruce Dern, director Sofia Coppola comes from filmmaking royalty. Her directorial debut The Virgin Suicides introduced her to actor Kirsten Dunst, with whom she quickly forged a creative partnership that would continue in Marie Antoinette.

links.text: Aussie Rules Footy was the first AFL game and one of the first Australian games developed for the NES by Beam Software, who started out with a text-adventure adaptation of the Hobbit, which was developed by Philip Mitchell and Veronika Megler, and released in 1982.

Before Peter Jackson’s 2001 trilogy, other studios attempted to adapt The Lord of the Rings , to no avail. But the influence was still felt in Ron Howard’s Willow starring Warwick Davis as the titular character who was heavily inspired by Tolkein’s work.
Warwick Davis has appeared in many fantasy films throughout his career, including the Harry Potter films, where he played Professor Flitwick and voiced Griphook.

Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone received Oscar noms for Best Art Direction, Score and Costume Design. When Best Costume was introduced in 1948, it was awarded to one film black & white and one colour film. The first black and white winner was Hamlet.

Shakespeare's plays are some of the most referenced and adapted works of literature in the world. In 2002, the first-ever Maori language adaptation of a Shakespeare play was released - Te Tangata Whai Rawa o Weniti, or, The Maori Merchant of Venice.

nodes.title: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone

links.text: TV games like the Selecta-Game console on display were projects for 1970s electronics hobbyists to build. These were usually versions of the well-known 'tennis' game, resembling the famed PONG. Anecdotal reports by hobbyists indicate that building such projects was often as much fun as playing the game.

The hobbyist console builders of the 1970s morphed into micro users in the 1980s as computers entered the home. Games were often used in low end micro-computers. The claim that a computer would be 'educational' was commonly made to convince parents to purchase consoles like the Commodore 64.

Not all microcomputer users had the means to load software from a cassette or floppy disk, so they often typed in program listings from a book or magazine. Many learnt to program this way, and some went on to write their own games, selling them by mail order or in shops.

While some homebrew game developers drew themes and gameplay from games they had played in the arcades or at home, others found inspiration in popular culture, such as sci-fi films and shows like Battlestar Galactica, which featured many spin off products.

Videogames were a new cultural form, and the visual effects that players saw in the arcades began to make appearances in popular culture, including popular New Zealand Band Mi Sex, whose song "Computer Games" was played on ABC's Countdown.

Pop culture portrayals frequently manifest the cultural anxieties surrounding the uptake of digital computing. Wargames is the example par excellence where Matthew Broderick plays a hacker who unintentionally begins a 'game' of Global Thermonuclear War that very quickly gets out of hand.

nodes.title: Play It Again 2: Preserving Australian Videogames

links.text: Richmond depicts a key moment from the Judeo-Christian creation story: ‘And God made two great lights’. The newly created sun rises dramatically on the right, while delicate crescent moons shine against the darkness on the left. Depicting God was unconventional in early 19th-century British art.

In 1826, 17-year-old George Richmond submitted The Creation of Light to the Royal Academy, but it was rejected – depicting god was frowned upon at the time. 110 years later, god first appeared on screen in The Green Pastures, where he was depicted as a Black man.

The Green Pastures had a disclaimer about god appearing “in many forms to those who believe in him” and that the film’s African American god reflected how people in the Deep South would visualise god. Later American films, like The Ten Commandments, avoided controversy by depicting god as only a voice

Religious epics were the rage in Hollywood during the 1950s and 60s, particularly because they rely on their widespread social acceptance to sneak violence and sensuality past censors. While Commandments was a hit, John Huston’s flop, The Bible, signalled the end of religious epics.

According to writer Scot Hughes, the 1970s saw a more light-hearted approach to portraying god, with its first appearance in a comedy, played by Jewish actor George Burns. The film inspired two sequels and a slew of knockoffs.

One of those knockoffs identified by Hughes includes the Paul Hogan vehicle Almost an Angel. Riding on his post-Dundee fame, Hogan stars as man denied entry Heaven by god (The Ten Commandment’s Moses, Charlton Heston) who has to correct his life’s mistakes.

One of the most memorable portrayals of God in cinema is in Kevin Smith’s Dogma, when for the first time, the biblical entity is portrayed as a woman by Alanis Morissette, though Sandra Bernhard had voiced god a year earlier in One Hell of a Guy.
Four years after Dogma’s famed portrayal of god, Morgan Freeman took up the greatest role in all the heavens in a performance that’s been deemed perfect for the revered actor.

Joel Shwerwood Spring's DIGGERMODE collages archival and new footage to interrogate how First Nations stories are held in archives. The Last Angel of History follows a “data thief” who travels through time and space searching for a “crossroads”, where he makes archaeological digs for fragments of history and new sciences. The film uses archival footage to explore black creativity as a technology.

Three Thousand is a short film made by Inuk artist Asinnajaq that uses archival footage of her own people. Critical of the role institutions have in constructing and disseminating harmful representations of native peoples, it juxtaposes new footage and found archival footage to create a vision of hopeful possibility.

Jazz Money's Rodeo Baby! also reclaims images and video of First Nations people from institutional archives. Jazz reclaims these images, combining them with stills from film and TV, including The Phantom Stockman, Radiance and The Drover’s Wife to critique this colonial hoarding.

In Picnic at Hanging Rock (2018), Marion, Miranda and Irma pursue queer intimacies at the all-girls boarding school Appleyard College. Portrait of a Lady on Fire (2019) similarly situates the relationship between Héloïse and Marianne on a distant island without men.

It's the little details handled by production designers that bring Appleyard College and the surrounding bush to live in Picnic at Hanging Rock, with these intimate objects just as important to the story and developing characters as costumes.

Director Céline Sciamma was inspired by Titanic (1997) in creating Portrait of a Lady on Fire (2019). Sciamma sees Titanic as a queer love story that, like her film, is told both in the present as well as recalled as a memory.

The second half of Titanic (1997) plays out as a disaster film, centring on Rose and Jack navigating the sinking ship. The science fiction film Underwater (2020) is also a survival tale that takes place on the flooding vessel Kepler 822.

Underwater (2020) is a homage to the science fiction horror classic, Alien (1979). Alongside an ensemble cast, both films focus on a female protagonist taking down a hostile creature in a claustrophobic setting.

The antagonist of Alien (1979) is the Xenomorph; a fictional extra-terrestrial species created by artist H R Giger. The Xenomorph is exemplary of Giger’s artistic style, which combined human bodies with machines. Jess Johnson’s Webwurld (2017) similarly explores the interconnections between technology and flesh.

name: From queer period romances to surrealistic worlds

links.text: Lisa McCune’s work on Blue Heelers was recognised several times by the TV Week Logie Awards: her role as Const. Margret Doyle netting her ten awards in total, with four of them being Golden Logies.
Featuring an early role from McCune, Philip Brophy’s 1993 cult classic Body Melt views both Australian suburbia and the health industry through a gory, slimy lens.

Nicholas Ray’s Bigger Than Life also inspects medicine and suburbia, albeit with less slime and blood. The film probes the darker side of the often-idealised 1950s family home, with James Mason’s father character lashing out against his wife and son due to the psychological side effects of a miracle drug.

Considered a spiritual protégé of Nicholas Ray by numerous critics, David Lynch dug into the dark underbelly of the idyllic American suburb in Blue Velvet. The film’s wide-eyed protagonist, Jeffery Beaumont, voyeuristically peers into the criminal world of his seemingly innocent hometown of Lumberton.

Decades before Blue Velvet, Alfred Hitchcock also investigated how suburbia can make voyeurs of us all in his 1954 classic Rear Window. Trapped in his home due to a broken leg, L.B. Jefferies watches the lives of his neighbours play out through his apartment window, eventually convincing himself that one of them has committed a murder.
Marilyn Monroe's rendition of 'Diamonds Are a Girl's Best' friend from Gentlemen Prefer Blondes has been remixed across the decades by stars and celebrities hoping to capture her mythic femininity.

In Moulin Rouge (2001), showgirl Satine (Nicole Kidman) performs 'Sparkling Diamonds', an adaptation of ‘Diamonds Are A Girl’s Best Friend’, changing some lyrics to make them appropriate to the 20th century setting.

Moulin Rouge’s (2001) ‘Sparkling Diamonds’ is not the only film adaptation of the track. In the Birds of Prey (2020) soundtrack, Megan Thee Stallion and Normani's 'Diamonds' interpolates the phrase 'diamonds are a girl's best friend,.' The music video also references Munroe's original performance.

Performing 'Diamonds are a Girl's Best Friend' is something of a pop rite of passage. Kylie Minogue performs the iconic track in documentary White Diamond (2007), which documents the singer’s return to the stage after her cancer diagnosis.

Kylie is far from the only iconic diva to cover 'Diamonds are a Girl’s Best Friend'. In a 1980 episode of The Muppet Show, Miss Piggy performed a duet of the iconic broadway track with Carol Channing, the song’s original performer.

'Diamonds are a Girl’s Best Friend' has invited tributes, covers – and parodies. In an episode of Hey Arnold (1996) called ‘The Beeper Queen,’ Helga’s mother mimics Monroe’s performance in a commercial for Big Bob’s Beepers, titled ‘Beepers are a Girl’s Best Friend.’

nodes.title: Birds of Prey (and the Fantabulous Emancipation of One Harley Quinn)

name: Diamonds Are Still a Girl's Best Friend

links.text: Anna May Wong fought to play the lead in The Good Earth but was overlooked for a White actor who played the Chinese role in 'yellowface' and went on to win an Oscar.

Li Jun Li played a character inspired by Anna May Wong, Lady Fay Zhu, in the Damien Chazelle-directed film Babylon. The character was written drawing direct inspiration from the actor’s life, including her move from Hollywood to Europe due to the limitations of her career and the costumes she wears.

Michelle Kruesic played Anna May Wong in the mini-series Hollywood, which features an alternate history of Hollywood in the 1940s. The portrayal reflects the growing interest in Wong as a cultural figure, including being the first Asian American woman to be depicted on an American coin in 2021.

After leaving Hollywood for Europe due to being typecast, Anna May Wong starred alongside her rumoured lover, Marlene Dietrich, in Shanghai Express in 1932. Film historians today view her performance as upstaging Dietrich.

Gemma Chan is set to star in an upcoming biopic about Anna May Wong, as well as executive producing the film alongside Nina Yang Bongiovi. Chan paid homage to Wong in her 2021 Met Gala look, wearing a sequinned mini dress featuring a dragon motif designed by Prabal Gurung.
Gemma Chan co-starred in the romantic comedy drama Crazy Rich Asians, which broke ground in Hollywood by featuring an all-Asian cast. The film also starred Constance Wu, Michelle Yeoh and Awkwafina.

Awkwafina, who began her career by releasing rap singles on YouTube, has gone on to star in films including Ocean’s 8 and The Farewell. She now writes, executive produces and stars in the comedy series Nora from Queens, as a fictionalised version of herself.

name: Legacy of an icon: Anna May Wong

links.text: This display in Goddess honours Meena Kumari and her film, Pakeezah which took 15 years to make, with production stopping and starting during the break up of her marriage to the director.

Like Meena Kumari, Kill Bill (2003) star Lucy Liu has an offscreen creative practice. Exhibiting under her Chinese name, Liu Yu-ling, Liu's collage, photography and paintings having shown at Art Basel Miami and National Museum of Singapore, among others.

Lucy Liu’s Charlie's Angels (2000) co-star Drew Barrymore has a very different relationship with her name. Born into the famous Barrymore family of actors, her family's performance lineage traces back to the theatre stages of the 19th century.

As Drew Barrymore knows, a famous name can be a blessing and a curse. In videogame Ocarina of Time (1998), Princess Zelda realises her famous name makes her a target. She adopts the identity Sheik, posing as a boy to aid the hero, Link, in his quest to save Hyrule.

Gendered disguises like Zelda’s have a long cinematic history. In her directorial debut Yentl (1983), Barbra Streisand's starred as the eponymous Yentl, a Jewish woman who poses as a boy to study the Talmud, despite initial concerns she was "too feminine" for the role.

In Suspiria (2018), Tilda Swinton took gender play like Yentl’s (1983) to its extreme. She played three roles, including 82 year old therapist Dr. Josef Klemperer – credited to fictional actor Lutz Ebersdorf, to foreground the performance over the shock factor of the casting.

nodes.title: The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time

links.text: The Dame was Loaded map is a world building tool that helps traverse the seedy gameworld and aids solving the mystery. Stories in unfamiliar worlds like Tolkien’s Lord of the Rings use maps to evoke a sense of place and are replicated in Peter Jackson's film.

The map of Middle Earth helps the audience navigate that plot. The animated map in the title sequence of the The Game of Thrones plays as similar role refreshing viewers of the differing geolocated factions whose plotting and treachery shape the narrative.

In contrast to how maps can be used to fortify narrative they may also act as a device to launch the narrative. Robert Louis Stevenson’s Treasure Island begins with the discovery of a mysterious map and the promise of adventure. As does the story of King Kong .

The map in King Kong leads Carl Denham to the forgotten world of Kong’s islands populated by prehistoric creatures and hostile natives. The concept of maps as gateways to the unknown takes a different path in the videogame Kentucky Route Zero.
Compared to the arcane knowledge embodied in Kentucky Route Zero’s mysterious roadmaps with the film The Map Against the World, which examines the political power and authority of maps.

nodes.title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring

links.text: IN the Goddess 'Who would she be today?', the dress that Orry-Kelly designed for Marilyn Monroe in Some Like It Hot is on display.

At Warner Bros, Orry-Kelly dressed their biggest stars including golden-era darling Kay Francis. Francis left Warner Bros after the Independent Theater Owners of America published a list of actors they deemed “box office poison.” Francis revived her career in part due to extensive war-zone touring, which Four Jills in a Jeep used as inspiration.

Also labelled ‘box-office poison’, Katherine Hepburn too needed to revamp her career and would star in and importantly buy the film rights for the stage production of The Philadelphia Story. After dazzling audiences, Hepburn made a deal with MGM to shoot the film and used her bargaining power as rights owner to personally select the director, screen writer and co-stars.

Australian Cate Blanchett portrayed Katherine Hepburn in The Aviator outlining Hepburn’s relationship with the Hollywood playboy and aviation pioneer Howard Hughes. It was Hughes who aided Hepburn’s rights purchase of The Philadelphia Story.

Before Cate Blanchett played Hepburn, she was expertly edited by fellow Australian Jill Bilcock in Elizabeth. Famous for her keen eye for performance, Bilcock chose to edit the film around Blancett’s strongest scenes.

Highly sort after for her editing prowess Jill Bilcock has had a prolific career spanning international as well as locally made films. Drawing on the tropes of a Western, High Ground reimagines the events surrounding Gan Gan Massacre of 1919 in Arnhem Land and features First Nations actor Magnolia Maymuru in her second.

In her debut film, Magnolia Maymuru was awarded Best Supporting Actress at the 9th AACTA awards, for her portrayal of Lowanna in The Nightingale. An unflinching portrayal of the violence, inhumanity and genocide committed by English colonisers towards Australia's First Peoples.

Kent would go onto write and direct an episode of Guillermo del Toro's horror anthology series Cabinet of Curiosities. Paying homage to Alfred Hitchcock and his own anthology programs The Alfred Hitchcock Hour and Alfred Hitchcock Presents, del Toro introduces each episode direct to camera.

nodes.title: Guillermo del Toro's Cabinet of Curiosities

links.text: Light Music is a composition of drawings that Rhodes printed onto the optical edge of a filmstrip that are read as audio by a projector. Similarly, Len Lye also used filmstock in creative ways, painting directly onto celluloid to create A Colour Box

Lis Rhodes was motivated to make Light Music by the lack of attention given to women composers in European music. Thankfully, since 1975, women composers have gained more prominence. One is Anna Calvi, who recently scored the final seasons of Peaky Blinders.

At the time, many critics felt that A Colour Box was too experimental. Lis Rhodes champions experimental films, and as a member of London Filmmakers' Co-Op (LFMC), and its feminist spin-off collective Circles, which screened Alice Guy-Blache's A House Divided in their inaugural film program

Light Music is considered expanded cinema, which featured multi-screen projections and immersive environments that enveloped the senses. Though coined in the mid 1960s, German artist Oskar Fischinger staged one of the first multi-screen expanded cinema performances with Raumlichtkunst in 1926.

In Raumlichtkunst, Fischinger used accompaniments of avant-garde music with his colourful animation. When he emigrated to the United States, he did some preliminary work on Disney’s Fantasia, which featured classical music paired with animation. However, Fischinger’s sequence didn’t appear in the final version.

Like many expanded cinema artists, Australian Hugh McSpedden staged his colourful, projected works not in cinemas, but in the open air and warehouses. In early 1980s, his polka-dotted projection on the Royal Exhibition Building in Melbourne was the first-large scale illumination of a public building in Australia.

nodes.title: Light Music and Weights of Light

links.text: Crowe won an Oscar as general-turned-gladiator Maximus in Ridley Scott's epic. In Thor: Love and Thunder he wears a breastplate that recalls the role. Chris Hemsworth (Thor) commented that he never thought he’d see Crowe on screen ‘with hints at Gladiator imagery, yet with a wink'.

While many people recognise the influence of Spartacus on Gladiator, it also owes part of its plot to The Fall of the Roman Empire, which similarly follows a power struggle following the death of emperor Marcus Aurelius.

The Fall of the Roman Empire aimed to capitalise on the popularity of sword-and-sandal epics during the 1950s and 60s. One of the most successful was Spartacus, which was a hit, while Roman Empire was a flop – its director, Anthony Mann, was fired from Spartacus.

The climactic scene of Spartacus features the recaptured slaves claiming “I’m Spartacus!”, when asked to identify the gladiator leader. The famous line was inverted and parodied in Monty Python’s Life of Brian, where captured prisoners claim, “I’m Brian!” to be pardoned.

Life of Brian was considered blasphemous by many and banned in some countries for its parody of Christianity. Biblical epics, like Samson and Delilah, ironically gained popularity during the mid-20th century by using biblical stories to include violence and sensuality to bypass Hollywood censors.

Samson and Delilah follows Samson, a strongman who gets his power from his hair. Another famous strongman of antiquity is Hercules. The two teamed up on screen in Pietro Francisci’s Ercole sfida Sansone, when Hercules is mistaken for Samson.

nodes.title: The Fall of the Roman Empire

links.text: Maya C Rubeo is the Oscar-nominated costume designer on Marvel Studios’ Thor: Love and Thunder. It was the biggest Thor movie, costume-wise, to date, with the titular character alone having 25 outfits.

Key to the success of the out-of-this-world costumes in Thor: Love and Thunder is the continued collaboration between Rubeo and the team who had worked on Taika Waiti’s previous Marvel outing, Thor: Ragnarok.

The title of Thor: Ragnarok (spoilers!) refers to the Norse notion of the world ending. A key part of the film is the destruction of Asgard. Rubeo also worked on an apocalyptic themed film – Apocalypto – where the end of the world comes in the form of Spanish conquistadors.
Rubeo had experience when it came to making the Viking-inspired costumes of the Thor world. She had previously designed the costumes for Warcraft, which features Viking like orcs, knights and mages.
The film Warcraft is, obviously, based on the best-selling real-time strategy and massively multiplayer online game series, Warcraft.

Warcraft wasn't Rubeo's first foray into fantasy. Throughout her career she's crafted fantastical characters and journeyed to wonderful worlds. Another big CGI epic she was involved with was James Cameron's record-breaking Avatar.

Back in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, Rubeo won an Emmy for designing colourful and kitschy costumes for the hit TV show WandaVision. It detailed a personal apocalypse of sorts – stricken by grief, Wanda destroys one world to create her own.
Aside from winning an Emmy for WandaVision, Rubeo was nominated for both an Oscar and a BAFTA for her costume design in JoJo Rabbit, which was her first time working with Thor director Taika Waititi.

Yakov Protazanov’s silent-era sci-fi classic, Aelita, draws on Soviet Russian interior design from the 1920s to imagine the future. Almost a century later, Heavenly Bodies looks to retro 60s Soviet designs for its space environments.

The animation style of The Jetsons, the 60s American cartoon, created an iconic aesthetic that meshed mid-century modern and futuristic architecture, much like the influences on Heavenly Bodies. It predicted and imagined what the nuclear family unit may function like in the year 2062.

Inspired by the work of Soviet space architect Galina Balashova, the interiors of Heavenly Bodies feel inviting – colour-coding creates a sense of orientation, and the illusion of a roof and floor, despite the zero-gravity environment.

While Aelita follows a male cosmonaut travelling to Mars and freeing its people, in Barbarella, Jane Fonda plays a woman astronaut who travels back in time from the 41st century to save Earth. It was influential in the depiction of feminist narratives.

Released in 1991, The Girl From Tomorrow was Film Australia’s first sci-fi TV show. It follows 13-year-old Alana, who, after an experiment gone wrong, travels back in time (like Barbarella) from the year 3000 to 1990s Australia.

name: Retrofuturism: aesthetic impact of space design on screen culture

links.text: Jarra Karalinar Steel works with Melbourne-based videogame developers Guck, who are creating the first Aboriginal-led mobile game. Future Folklore is set in a futuristic fantasy environment inspired by native flora and fauna and First Nations culture.

Never Alone, or Kisima Inŋitchuŋa, is one of a growing number of videogames made by and about Indigenous people. A puzzle adventure based on the Iñupiaq tale Kunuuksaayuka, it tells the story of a young girl Nuna and her Arctic fox.

Thunderbird Strike is a side-swiping videogame made by developer Elizabeth LaPensée, who creates games with Indigenous futurism storylines. The game follows a mythological thunderbird across Turtle Island as it attempts to destroy oil industry infrastructure and revive wildlife.

Karrabing Film Collective make film and artworks as a form of storytelling and Indigenous resistance. In the surreal Mermaids, or Aiden in Wonderland, the titular character navigates alternate futures and pasts, slipping between time in a landscape poisoned by colonisation.

Tracey Moffatt created a surreal world in Night Cries: A Rural Tragedy, filmed entirely in a studio with painted backdrops and saturated colour, and can be read as a reimagining of the 1955 film Jedda, told from an Indigenous perspective.

Videogame easter eggs began as acts of rebellion. International Cricket has secret Sonic the Hedgehog character, the mascot of Nintendo’s greatest rival. Atari developer Warran Robinett made them famous when he hid ‘created by Warren Rboinett’ in a secret room back in 1980.

Since Adventure easter eggs have become a way for developers to leave a mark on games they create. Skyrim contains many hidden references to media, including Minecraft, Pac-Man and Portal 2. The game contains several references to Lord of the Rings and Star Wars, too.

Easter eggs have a long history in film too. Alfred Hitchcock made cameos in 40 of his films, including The Birds, where he's seen leaving a pet shop. These cameos became so popular, he started appearing earlier in the film so as not to distract the audience.

Easter eggs can also be fan service. Like Hitchcock, comic book creator Stan Lee appeared in every film in the Marvel Cinematic Universe until Avengers: Endgame, where he made a posthumous, digitally de-aged appearance as a taxi driver.

While some easter eggs generate fan interest, other acknowledge theories and interests of an existing fandom. Fans believed the 151st Pokemon Mew hid under a truck in the original game. When players found the truck in remake Pokemon FireRed, players discovered a cookie that acknowledged the conspiracy.

This room of Light explores the popularisation of electric light as an essential characertistic of modernity that revolutionised life in the 20th century and features Olafur Eliasson's Stardust Particle and Dan Flavin's ‘monument’ for V. Tatlin.

Dan Flavin worked with commercially available fluorescent light tubes to create ‘monument' for V Tatlin. Ridley Scott similarly recognised the artistic value of fluorescent lighting, featuring distinctive, handcrafted fluorescent signs throughout the dystopian cityscape of Blade Runner.
Similar to Blade Runner, red and blue neon lighting is utilised throughout the science fiction horror series Stranger Things and is a staple colour palette of the show.

Stranger Things features many references to the original Star Wars films. One of the subtler references is the show’s red and blue colour palette, recalling the red and blue lightsabers that signify the light and dark side of the force.

In the Star Wars films, the Millenium Falcon and other spacecrafts can travel faster than lightspeed. Similarly, the alien spacecrafts in Arrival gently dissipate into a misty substance and then vanish completely to travel across space.

The alien vessel in Arrival was inspired by James Turrell’s Shallow Space Constructions, such as Raemar, Blue. Similar to experiencing Turrell’s works, human characters in Arrival experience shifts in perception as they communicate with the Heptapods beyond the light screen.

Strong blue and pink lighting are distinctive features of the futuristic world envisioned by Janelle Monáe in their “emotion picture” Dirty Computer. These minimalist, monochromatically lit spaces are reminiscent of Raemar, Blue and other Shallow Space Constructions by James Turrell.

name: Expansive light in science fiction and fantasy

links.text: In Goddess, film's first women action hero Pam Grier is honoured alongside her work in the groundbreaking Blaxploitation film Coffy (1973). Jackie Brown is an homage to Grier's strong and sexy characters from the era.

Jackie Brown (1997) is a homage to Pam Grier’s performance in Foxy Brown (1974), a highly influential but controversial blaxploitation film. On its UK release, all VHS were confiscated under the Obscene Publications Act due to its perceived potential to “deprave or corrupt” viewers.

Like Foxy Brown (1974), Australian film The Chant of Jimmy Blacksmith (1978) was seized during the UK video nasty panic. Based on the true story of Jimmy Governor, a First Nations man whose experiences of exploitation and racism drove him to murder.

The Chant of Jimmy Blacksmith (1978) experience a brief UK ban but Australia has strict classification laws too – particularly around videogames. Lake (2021) is a peaceful game set about a mail carrier which was initially refused classification for a single scene involving marijuana.

Videogames can also be censored by platforms, not governments. In 2020, Taiwanese studio Red Candle Games had their first-person horror game Devotion (2019) removed from digital videogame marketplace Steam following controversy over a critical reference to Chinese premier Xi Jinping,

The history of censoring moving image works like Devotion (2019) has also inspired new work. Australian historian and filmmaker Sari Braithwaite made the documentary Censored (2018) to explore the archives of cut scenes from censored Australian films.

Interior Light is the sixth section of the Light exhibition, which explores undramatic manifestations of light in interior settings. The work Interior, Sunlight on the Floor is featured in this room alongside other artworks by Hammershøi, Rothenstein and Parreno.

Interior, Sunlight on the Floor’s original composition remains unseen after the canvas was folded over to omit the depiction of Hammershøi’s wife, Ava. Similarly, Frozone’s wife Honey remains unseen but heard after her scene was cut in Incredibles 2.

In the sequel Incredibles 2, Elastagirl takes centre stage over Mr Incredible. Similarly, the filmmakers of Everything Everywhere All At Once gender swapped the lead role to cast Michelle Yeoh after their original plan to cast Jackie Chan fell through.

As audiences see alternate timelines and universes in Everything Everywhere All At Once, players of Dream Daddy can similarly experience many different storylines in this choose your own adventure style game.
There are many endings that players can be led through to in Dream Daddy. Similarly, the ending of the film The Wrestler is left ambiguous and viewers are left to decide

Director Darren Aronofsky initially conceptualised The Wrestler and Black Swan as one film “about a love affair between a ballet dancer and a wrestler”. Aronofsky describes these two films as “companion pieces” as several character arcs echo the original project.

nodes.title: Dream Daddy: A Dad Dating Simulator

links.text: In Thor: Love and Thunder, Thor is reunited not only with his ex-girlfriend Jane Foster, but also his 'old friend' the hammer Mjölnir. While estranged from Mjölnir, Thor has been wielding Stormbreaker since crafting it in Avengers: End Game.
Thor: Love and Thunder sees Natalie Portman return to the Thor franchise as astrophysicist Jane Foster, who guides Thor on his journey to find himself by rekindling the romance between them.

The Marvel Cinematic Universe is full of fantastical devices, weapons and instruments. One of the most famous is Captain America’s star-spangled shield, which was first used by the first avenger in Captain America: The First Avenger.

The Disney + series What If presents alternative versions of Marvel Studios’ biggest characters. In one stream of the Multiverse, Peggy Carter wielded the famous shield (with a Union Jack instead of stars and stripes) as Captain Carter.
Though it's first wielded in Captain America: The First Avenger, a prototype of Captain America's shield first appears in Tony Stark's workshop in Iron Man.

The MCU version of Spider-Man is given a technologically advanced suit by Tony Stark, aka Iron Man, in Captain America: Civil War. The first Iron Man not only kicked off the MCU, but a key scene showed Stark building the first iconic Marvel instrument.

The live action version of Captain Carter appeared in Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness, directed by Sam Raimi. The film features other famous objects and devices, including the Dark Hold magic book and Dr Strange’s magical Sling Ring.

Sam Raimi is no stranger to Marvel, having directed the original Spider-Man trilogy starring Tobey Maguire. Maguire’s Spider-Man appears in Spider-Man: No Way Home after Ned uses Dr Strange’s Sling Ring.

nodes.title: Doctor Strange in the Multiverse of Madness

links.text: Christian Bale doesn't just terrify audiences as Gorr the God Butcher in Thor: Love and Thunder, but he also brings an amazing amount of pathos, with his performance aided not only by his talent but his transformation.

Before he was a villain, Christian Bale was Batman. To create the character of Gorr, Bale worked extensively with make-up designers, while for Batman, part of inhabiting the Caped Crusader involved transforming his body into that of a superhero.

Transforming into Batman wasn’t easy, particularly since Bale had cut his weight to 54kg to star as an exhausted insomniac in The Machinest. There was only five weeks between films for Bale to bulk up.
Bale wasn’t only gone gaunt (or buff) to play a character. For the role of Dick Cheney in Vice, he sported a rotund belly and gained 20kg for the role, becoming almost unrecogniseable.
Bale’s co-star, Steve Carrell, who played Donald Rumsfield, also has a chameleonic quality. To shed his comedy reputation, he wore prosthetics to play John du Pont in the drama Foxcatcher.

Starring alongside Carrell in Foxcatcher is Mark Ruffalo. Though the actor doesn't change his appearance much in the film, he's bulked up beyond most people in cinema (through CGI) to play the Incredible Hulk since The Avengers.

nodes.title: Gorr the God Butcher costume and sword

name: Physical transformation and the formation of character

links.text: NUTS uses a colourful animation style to communicate the dire need for environmental conservation. Similarly, kids’ show The Animals of Farthing Wood deals with the stark realities of land clearing, forced removal of animal habitats and the effects of development and urban sprawl on entire ecosystems.

Weathering with You follows a school boy who befriends a young woman who can control the weather. Like The Animals of Farthing Wood , it uses a child-friendly narrative and animation style to address global warming and climate crisis anxiety.

Ice Age also deals with environmental issues by focusing on the migration of a species at the brink a new ice. As in Weathering with You despite being marketed to children, Ice Age directly addresses extinction or survival in the face of a large-scale climate event.

Large-scale climate events are dealt with in cli-fi, a sub-genre of science fiction. One great example of a cli-fi film is Snowpiercer , Set in the year 2031 which depicts an experimental climate control strategy gone wrong.

Twister is a formative example of the cli-fi genre, made in 1996, it paved the way for films such as Snowpiercer . Set in Oklahoma, Twister , sees a couple on the verge of divorce, have to set their marital issues aside to combat a series of highly destructive tornadoes and save the day.

name: Make it cute, make them think

links.text: He-man is the alter-ego of Prince Adam in popular cartoon He-Man and the Masters of the Universe (1983). Like Thor, he is defined by bulging muscles and bright blond hair – the strongest man in the universe, and a textbook eighties hunk.
He-man and the Masters of the Universe was inspired by another popular comic: Conan the Barbarian. Running since the seventies, The Conan franchise’s first feature film released in 1982.
The dramatic combat scenes in Conan the Barbarian were influenced by the iconic action choreography in Akira Kurosawa’s Seven Samurai.

Actor Toshiro Mifune worked with Akira Kurosawa on 16 films across two decades, including Seven Samurai. Known for his magnetic, expressive performances, he also had success in Western cinema, starring as Commodore Akira Hayashi in The Bushido Blade.

What is an action hero without an antagonist? Before James Earl Jones starred in The Bushido Blade, he voiced Darth Vader in the Star Wars sequels: the perfect, inhumanly evil counterpart to our daring heroes Luke, Leia and Han Solo.

nodes.title: He-Man and the Masters of the Universe

links.text: Although the song was a political commentary on the state of current affairs at the time, 'Horror Movie' by Skyhooks became an unintentional Halloween classic after it was included on Elvira: Mistress of the Dark actress Cassandra Petersen’s compilation album Haunted Hits.

To coincide with the release of Elvira: Mistress of the Dark, Elvira started releasing compilation albums with songs that would go on to become Halloween staples – like 'Horror Movie' and a song by The Cramps named after the film I Was a Teenage Werewolf

The 1950s cult horror film I Was a Teenage Werewolf kickstarted an entire trend of genre films that featured ‘teenage’ in the title, which continued right up until the 90s. The original title of Clueless was I Was A Teenage Teenager.

The teen classic Clueless was a remake of Jane Austen's novel Emma. Set in the 90s and examining key pop cultural moments from the decade, characters watch episodes of Beavis and Butt-Head in the film.

A seminal 90s TV series, Beavis and Butt-Head (1993–2011) was the brainchild of Mike Judge who not only created, wrote and directed the show, he voiced the two central characters. He appeared as Donnagon in Spy Kids.

Mike Judge played Donnagon in Spy Kids and the two sequels in Robert Rodriguez’s first child-friendly franchise. A genre specialist, the filmmaker followed up the trilogy with the completion of another: Once Upon a Time in Mexico.

nodes.title: Once Upon a Time in Mexico

name: Horror movie right there on my TV

links.text: In The Catacombs of Solaris Revisited (2021), game developer Ian MacLarty captures the disorienting quality of Andrei Tarkovsky’s Solaris (1972). Like the film, the game’s slow visual pacing and sudden perspective shifts contribute to a sense of doubt in what the audience perceives.

Solaris (1972) created a distinctive visual language that contemporary films continue to draw on. Lars Von Trier’s Melancholia (2011) includes Bruegel’s The Hunters in the Snow, (1565) which features in Tarkosvky's film, as well as adopting Solaris’ (1972) two-part narrative structure to tell its own story.

Films like Melancholia (2011) demonstrate the cultural impact of Tarkovsky’s Solaris (1972) on film history, but it’s not the only film adaptation of the novel. In 2002, Steven Soderbergh adapted Lem’s novel for US audiences.

Stanislaw Lem was critical of both film adaptations for failing to adequately capture the novel’s thematic interest in the limits of human intelligence – so it’s hard to imagine how he would respond to Atari’s Solaris, a space-themed shoot-em-up released in 1986.

Despite Lem's disappointment with direct adaptations, the spirit of Solaris (1961) exists in other media. Legendary Anime director Katsuhiro Otomo’s 1995 science fiction animated anthology, Memories, also uses science fiction as a vehicle to explore grief, alienation, and the way the past inhabits the present.

Inside Out and Unpacking both centre around a young woman who we learn about through their journey of moving house. In Inside Out each of the main character's emotions are embodied as individual characters to help illustrate the complexities of moving to a new city.

As in Unpacking, i The Virgin Suicides gives us an intimate snapshot in to the bedrooms and lives of the four main characters. With a focus on young women, a use of soft dusty colours and the depiction of private/intimate space The Virgin Suicides speaks to a specific experience of adolescence.

Toy Story is an animated classic which, while framed through the lens of toys that come to life, and similar to Unpacking is centered around the process of packing, moving, the intimacy of personal and domestic objects and what we can glean from the characters through their possessions.

Céline Sciamma’s Tomboy is framed by moving house. Ten-year-old Laure, who is gender non-confirming, moves to an apartment on the outskirts of Paris during the summer. Laure, who adopts the name Mikael, confronts formative ideas of gender expression, approaching teenhood and the complexity of friendships.

Euphoria is a highly stylised, high-drama and high-level violence coming-of-age drama set in California. Similarly to Tomboy, the slightly older teenage characters grapple with ideas of queerness, trauma, substance dependence and ruptures in family, friendship and romantic relationships.

name: Unpacking: domestic intimacy and the coming-of-age film

links.text: In Heaven, Tracey Moffatt surreptitiously films surfers changing in and out of wetsuits at beachside car parks. Acting as a voyeur, she films from behind cars and with a zoom lens, and then flirts with and teases the surfers into performing for the camera.

Also flipping the gaze, in the video artwork Observance Julie Gough capture groups of tourists hiking across the Bay of Fires in Tasmania. The artist turns the camera on the hikers, interlopers to her Country.
Like Thor: Love and Thunder, Australian indie film Malcolm is a quirky, comedic romp with heart. The film is dedicated to director Nadia Tass’ late brother, John, who inspired the titular character.

Malcolm draws from director Nadia Tass’ own life, but it’s not her only film about grief. Amy tells the story of a girl who becomes mute after the traumatic death of her father, able to communicate only through song.

In the same year that Amy was released, Elton John expressed the cultural grief over the death of Princess Diana by performing a rewritten version 'Candle in the Wind' from Goodbye Yellow Brick Road at her funeral.

Musical tributes like 'Candle in the Wind' can help us process grief – and so can videogames. Spiritfarer is a gentle, meditative game about the afterlife, giving a player the opportunity to help a lovable cast of ghostly characters find their final peace.

While a lot of the action in Prisoner happens between the inmates, there’s plenty of drama between the convicts and prison officers (lovingly known as ‘screws’). These two costumes represent the two sides of the prison system and are on display.

The popularity and international reach of Prisoner was such that it was parodied on Saturday Night Live. In 1980 an SNL episode featured a sketch in which spoiled debutantes complained about the living conditions in prison.

Prisoner is an Australian soap opera set in a fictional women's prison. It became an international hit with a decades-long afterlife. Foxtel, which began screening Prisoner re-runs since the late 1990s, commissioned the Prisoner reboot, Wentworth.

A hugely successful German version of Prisoner, Hinter Gittern was produced by UFA Grundy TV, attracting audiences through sensational storylines and inspiring a similarly scandalous rival Die Rote Meile in the same timeslot on a different channel.
Katy Karrenbauer is known for her role as prisoner, Christine "Walter" Walter, in Hinter Gittern. In Die Spezialisten, she is on the right side of the law, playing a high ranking police officer.

Pamela Rabe won her second Logie award for most outstanding actress in 2018, the year Zanny Begg premiered her true crime video work about the disappearance of community activist Juanita Nielsen. The Beehive features Rabe as the 'Beekeeper'.

The SNL sketch featured Teri Garr (who was also guest host) as the spoilt rich girl felon Bitsy. Garr reenters the world of crime when she voices the character of Madame Cassandra in the true crime videogame Black Dahlia.

nodes.title: Die Spezialisten – Im Namen der Opfer

links.text: Iconic cyberpunk film, Tron has greatly influenced the visuals of much screen culture since. The use of neon lights in particular are a direct reference for cyberpunk games like Umurangi Generation.

Umurangi Generation is a Māori cyberpunk photography game set during a climate apocalypse in futuristic Tauranga. Another dystopian story set in Aotearoa, Creamerie a TV series about a pandemic that kills 99% of the male population.
Kaneda's bike in Akira was actually inspired by the Light Cycles of the original TRON.

Soon after cyberspace and artmaking collided, feminist collective VNS Matrix devised their 1991 collaborative manifesto. First published on the web, it appeared in many forms, includ-ing a magazine and billboard. VNS Matrix coined the term cyberfeminism.

Ten years after Tron, another influential sci-fi film was released, Lawnmower Man. While Tron imagined a digitised world, Lawnmower Man considered, and contributed to, early ideas of virtual reality (VR).
A key part of Ready Player One's plot is the use of VR to escape an apocalyptic world into a digital one, where people interact with famous characters from film, TV and videogames.

Julian Rosefeldt’s 13-channel work, Manifesto, explores cultural and cinematic movements by reassembling famous historical manifestos. The work stars Cate Blanchett, who performs each manifesto as monologues. It premiered at ACMI in 2015.

In Ready Player One, the character Art3mis rides a futuristic motorcycle that's based on Kaneda's red motorcycle from the groundbreaking anime 1988 Akira, which imagines a futuristic Tokyo, set in 2019.

nodes.title: VNS Matrix: The Cyberfeminist Manifesto for the 21st Century

name: Future forward; cyberpunk manifestations, fantasy and world building

links.text: Like Zoetrope to Cinemascope, Play School taught kids through fun and engaging entertainment. Its iconic songs, nursery rhymes, storytelling, art and craft, and those iconic windows, were a winning formula for its multi-generational success with its diverse stories showing the ever-changing Australian family.

The Book Place was an educational reading program that featured the talking puppet ‘Bookworm’, who helped read recently published children’s books to the audience. Similar to Play School, the show also included songs, dances, poems and documentary material showing children and activities.

After being picked up by the UK version of Play School, the Bananas in Pyjamas were also adopted Down Under. The characters appeared on Play School before embarking on their own live action show that made B1 and B2 household names.

The Book Place was one of the first children’s shows to feature the Kaurna language, with Alice Rigney singing Kammammi’s Lullaby. The first Indigenous animated series, Little J & Big Cuz also teaches language and culture with episodes produced in different Indigenous languages.

Lift Off also fostered children’s early development through animation, drama, performance, puppetry and documentary. It showed a wide variety of different environments, worlds, peoples, animals and plants all presented as accessible and exciting but requiring understanding, empathy and care.

Lift Off was written by some of Australia’s best writers, illustrators and animators including Paul Jennings, whose writing also featured prominently in Round the Twist. His works are displayed alongside storyboards and props in The Story of the Moving Image.

Bluey also uses animation and discovery to bring its characters to life. Bluey, an inexhaustible six-year-old Blue Heeler pup and her family’s extraordinary adventures are aimed at developed children’s imaginations as well as mental, physical and emotional resilience.
One of Marlene Dietrich's iconic white tuxedos is displayed in Goddess. It's from her personal collection, but she also wore a black one when she shared cinema's first lesbian kiss in Morocco.

The thirties was an exciting time for gender play on screen, from Morocco (1930) to German film Victor/Victoria (1933). Victor/Victoria was remade in English in 1982, starring Julie Andrews as a cisgender woman who poses as a male drag queen, leading to queer romantic confusion.

The drag performance in Victor/Victoria (1982) has a local analogue. Carlotta (2014) is based on the life story of legendary trans actress and singer, Carlotta, who came to fame as the star of Sydney cabaret drag act Les Girls, a largely male troupe of ‘female impersonators.’

Performances like Carlotta's draw on decades of creative gender performance by Black and Latinx LGBTQIA+ communities. Pose (2018) celebrates New York's drag and ballroom culture of the 80s and 90s, breaking ground with the largest ever cast of trans actors on a scripted TV show.

Pose’s (2018) groundbreaking inclusive casting paved the way for opportunities for trans actors worldwide. In The Politician (2019), trans non-binary actor Theo Germaine was cast as James, a male character whose gender identity is not a feature of his storyline.

Unlike their performance in The Politician (2019), Theo Germaine’s role in Work in Progress is deeply invested in trans experience. The series is a love story between two gender non-conforming characters: a trans man called Chris (Germaine) and an older, self-identified fat queer dyke (Abby McEnany), exploring the contours of queer gender dynamics.

nodes.title: Flipping gender codes and gender expectations

links.text: Banned in the UK, pre-code film Red-Headed Woman had it all. A brilliantly clever yet somewhat wicked lead character, comedy and snappy dialogue not to mention premarital sex, attempted murder, marriage break-down and the original blonde bomb shell herself, Jean Harlow.

A love story set against the backdrop of war and the Great Depression, The World Moves On was the first film to receive the official production seal of approval under the Hays Code (MPPDA Certificate No. 1) in November 1934.

With the code restricting what could be shown on screen, filmmakers began to rely on innuendo to illustrate lust and passion. Lauren Bacall and Humphrey Bogart's famous whistling scene oozes sexual chemistry with Bacall's silver-tongued banter. “You know how to whistle, don’t you Steve? You just put your lips together, and blow.”

Perhaps no other filmmaker pushed the code as much as producer Howard Hughes with The Outlaw. Held up for years by the code's approval process the film was completed in 1941 yet without a wide release until 1946 with the Hays Office taking issue with the sexualisation of Jane Russell and the marketing focus on her chest.

Bogart would redefine his career and create an all new style of shady hero in The Maltese Falcon, considered by many to be the first noir film. Bogart's detective would be wooed by duplicitous femme fatales yet get by with his wits and ability to hide in the shadows.

With an illustrative black and white design, dynamic lighting and camera angles, classic noir-esque dialogue and charismatic flawed hero, Nintendo's Hotel Dusk: Room 215 was clearly inspired by film noir using the genre to great effect in its point and click adventure game.

The Janitor Always Mops Twice in season 14 of It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia. The episode appears in black and white and even has a jazz inspired score as we see Charlie became a hardboiled detective / janitor trying to clean up the seedy underbelly of Philadelphia.

By the 1960s the production code's decline was in earnest with Warner Bros. Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf the first film to receive a 'Suggested for Mature Audiences' label. New Motion Picture Production Association President Jack Valenti introduced the Film Rating System in November 1968.
The 'Fragile females' display features early stuntpeople like the Helen Hazards and Fearless Nadia, a Bollywood superhero who was born Mary Evans in Perth, Australia.

Stunt Double Kitty O'Neal was known for her death defining high falls with one of her most impressive captured as part of Wonder Woman episode “Phantom of the Roller Coaster". Jumping 12 stories from the Valley Hilton hotel onto an airbag positioned on the pool deck, O'Neal set a new high-fall record in the process, which she broke the following year)

Also performing Wonder Woman's stunts Jeannie Epper would go on to amass over a hundred film and tv appearances for her stunt work, including the legendary, spectacular, drag-out cat fight between Alexis and Krystle on Dynasty.
