Similarly Debbie Evans has appeared in countless films and television series for her unbelievable stunt work. Especially talented on motorcycle, Evans played Trinity in The Matrix Reloaded as she masterfully zig-zagged through traffic on a Ducati 996 in the film's famous freeway Chase scene.

Renae Moneymaker has appeared throughout both the Marvel and DC extended universes performing as stunt double to Brie Larson in Captain Marvel amongst many others. Trained in gymnastics and martial arts, Moneymaker has emphasised the possibilities of her role in stunts, “You’re not put in a humanoid box. You can fly,”

Originally from New Zealand, Zoë E. Bell has doubled for Cate Blanchett, Uma Thurman and Lucy Lawless to name but a few. Famously, Bell was cast as herself in Quentin Tarantino's film Death Proof and was filmed clinging to the hood of a speeding 1970 Dodge Challenger.

Zoë E. Bell's high-octane stunt work is one of the videos featured in the 'Taking control' display in Goddess, where it appears alongside clips that show women fighting back against gender expectations, the justice system and discrimination.
Bell would continue to work with Tarantino in Once Upon a Time in Hollywood, hilariously playing the same role in the film, as she was to complete while making the film - stunt coordinator.

nodes.title: Once Upon a Time… in Hollywood

links.text: Like the women in this audio experience, Sue Maslin's Brazen Hussies (2020) uses archival material to allow the women of Australia's Women's Liberation Movement to represent themselves in their own words.

Brazen Hussies (2020) looks at feminist history, but On The Record (2020) is grounded in the now. This award-winning documentary highlights sexual abuse and harassment allegations towards Def Jam co-founder Russell Simmons, and explores the erasure of Black Women's voices during the #MeToo movement.

On the Record was a platform where Black cis women could speak openly about their erasure from the #MeToo narrative. Disclosure (2020) provided a similar platform for trans people, particularly trans women, to discuss the portrayal of transgender people onscreen.
From Orange is the New Black to Disclosure, Laverne Cox has been one of the leading voices in the fight for trans representation and equality, both on screen and behind the scenes.

Like Disclosure (2020), The Watermelon Woman (1997) considers erasure and marginalisation in film. Director Cheryl Dunye uses autofiction to consider how the lack of Black women & Black lesbians in film history impedes her ability to imagine the future of Black lesbian filmmaking.

Fiction is also writer-director Leah Purcell's path to truth-telling in The Drover's Wife: The Legend of Molly Johnson (2021).This revisionist retelling of the Henry Lawson story, using fiction to reveal a deeper, untold history of First Nations women during the 19th century.

nodes.title: The Drover's Wife: The Legend of Molly Johnson

links.text: Butterflies must've inspired early filmmakers with their vibrancy because two of the first hand-coloured films were Annabelle Butterfly Dance and Metamorphoses du Papillon.

Metamorphoses du Papillon is a hand-coloured 'trick' film that used the early colour method of dying important objects in the frame. Almost 30 years later, Fiddlesticks used the more advanced two-strip Technicolor process to produce the first colour cartoon.

The three-strip Technicolor process replaced the two-strip process and became popular in Hollywood during the 1930s. The Wizard of Oz (1939) was one of the most successful and iconic films to use Technicolor.

Unlike highly saturated colours in The Wizard of Oz, Martin Scorsese de-saturated colour in Taxi Driver, particularly the brightly coloured blood, making it less prominent in order to get an "R" classification.

Manipulating colour lends symbolism to Schindler's List. The film was shot on black-and-white except for sequences featuring a little girl in a red dress, which was shot in colour and then de-saturated, and represents the innocence of the Jewish people.

The 'Breaking the binary' display in Goddess features the costumes that Tilda Swinton wore in her binary-busting portrayal of the gender-fluid, time-travelling nobleperson. The film was a landmark of LGBTQIA+ 90s cinema and queered the British costume drama.

In Luca Guadagnino’s Suspiria, Tilda Swinton plays both female and male roles. She was transformed into the 82-year-old male psychoanalyst through prosthetics in a makeup process that took four hours a day. Critics praised Guadagnino for casting a woman as the film’s only significant male role.

Almost three decades after appearing as the Orlando in Sally Potter’s 1992 British period drama fantasy film based on Virginia Woolf’s novel, Tilda Swinton entered the Marvel Cinematic Universe as an androgynous Celtic version of the traditionally male character Ancient One.

Swinton’s first film was Caravaggio, made with the Derek Jarman, the English filmmaker, artist, author and gay rights activist. Swinton collaborated with Jarman continuously over the next eight years, appearing in all his subsequent films until his death from AIDS related complications in 1994.

Tilda Swinton has curated an exhibition of photography inspired by Virginia Woolf’s book Orlando, which has inspired Swinton since she starred in the film. It features 11 artists including trailblazing multimedia artist and activist Zackary Drucker, who also worked as a producer on the award-winning Transparent.

Transparent was criticised for casting Jeffrey Tambor, a cisgender, heterosexual man, as a trans woman. However the film also featured several transgender actors such as Trace Lysette (“Shea”) who came out publicly through her role and made her major feature debut in Hustlers.

Both Zackary Drucker and Tracey Lysette feature in the groundbreaking documentary Disclosure, which takes in-depth look at Hollywood's depiction of transgender people and the impact of their stories on transgender lives and American culture.

Guadagnino’s introduction of Swintons’s Dr. Josef Klemperer is one of several changes made to Dario Argento's original Suspiria, the film follows a ballet student who enrols at a dance academy run by witches. Argento wasn’t impressed by the remake, saying it “it betrayed the spirit of the original film”.

The femme fatale is a trope as old as the sirens of Greek mythology. On screen, it can be traced back to silent era ‘vamp’ – a dangerous, sensual vamp that come from The Vampire Theda Bara plays in A Fool There Was.

A Fool There Was’ sexual ‘vampire’ was a threat to traditional gender roles of the era. So was the femme fatale, who appeared in 1940s cinema after women gained independence during WWII. Mary Astor’s character in The Maltese Falcon was one of the first.

Sometimes the femme fatale isn’t even human. In Fritz Lang’s masterpiece Metropolis, the dangerous woman is an android called Maria, who appears in human form as a vampish dancer, and exhibits similar qualities.
The sexual and dangerous ‘fembot’ trope is seen throughout cinematic history, from Maria in Metropolis to Pris (Darryl Hannah) in Blade Runner to Ava (Alicia Vikander) in Ex-Machina.

Robotic women often represent men's desire to control women and reduce them to literal objects. In the 1980s two 'nerds' gain popularity when they use computers to create 'the perfect woman', who ends up teaching them to respect women.

Though most popular in the 1940s, the femme fatale returned in the 1980s. This time they embodied fears about career-minded, financially secure and sexually assertive women, like Alex Forrest (Glenn Close) in Fatal Attraction (1987).

The opera Madame Butterfly is the soundtrack to Alex’s (Close) affair with a married man. The ‘Butterfly’ is a trope of a subservient woman, which Anna May Wong played in The Toll of the Sea. She’s famous for playing ‘dragon ladies’ similar to the femme fatale.

The dragon lady is a deceitful, domineering and hyper-sexualised character that exoticised East Asian women. Wong’s role in Daughter of the Dragon made it famous and now it’s a visual shorthand for dangerous, powerful women, as seen in Glen Close’s costume from 102 Dalmatians.

Indigenous peoples have spiritual connections with animals they live in relation to. Just like the dolphin in Hepi’s artwork, in the children’s TV show Molly of Denali we follow the adventures of a young native Alaskan girl and her dog Suki.

Amrita Hepi's work explores how scientists tried teaching dolphins English to help NASA communicate with extraterrestrial life. Why not? Dolphins commonly appear in sci-fi and one famous story is The Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy, which was made into TV series in 1981.

Scripture for a smoke screen uses the metaphor of scientific observation to consider how First Peoples have been surveilled in Australia. Avert similarly interrogates this aspect of First Nations people's lives, aiming a camera at the viewer of the work.

The dolphins in The Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy tried to save the planet, but humans misinterpreted their warnings. In Jupiter and Mars, two dolphins are on a quest to save the planet from sea-levels rising due to climate change.

Non-human creatures save the day once again in Indigenous-made videogame Thunderbird Strike. The mythical creature Thunderbird destroys infrastructure and equipment that is extracting oil from native lands, and revives native animals who have been killed.

Capitalism’s extractive practices are under the microscope in Thunderbird Strike. Joel Sherwood Spring’s DIGGERMODE makes us question the ethics of data storage and access to collections via online platforms, and the environmental damage caused by making new technologies.

Molly of Denali is accompanied by her trusty dog Suki, and in the videogame Never Alone (Kisima Ingitchuna), a young Iñupiat girl’s companion is an arctic fox, and they journey to uncover the source of an ongoing blizzard.

nodes.title: Scripture for a smoke screen: Episode 1 – dolphin house
Hitchhiker's guide to the galaxy. - Volume 1.

name: Scripture for spiritual connections and sci-fi futures

links.text: Like Colin Friels’ Malcolm, Jerry Lewis’ Lester in It’s Only Money (1962) is a quirky handyman who is thrust into a plot with a fortune at stake.
Lewis first rose to fame alongside suave straight man Dean Martin on The Colgate Comedy Hour (1950-55), a variety show which introduced the duo to a wide television audience.

An ardent admirer of Lewis’ directorial style, French New Wave director Jean-Luc Godard’s Bande à Part (1964) adopts the comedian’s cinematic playfulness to tell a story of cinephile thieves conspiring to commit a spectacular heist.

Directed by Agnès Varda, another champion of the French New Wave, Uncle Yanco (1976) is a portrait of her long-lost relative Jean Varda. Endearingly called ‘Uncle Yanco’ by the hippies of San Francisco, he is a vibrant artist residing in an ‘aquatic suburb’ that floats on the bay.

Both the hippie movement and San Francisco play a role in Forrest Gump (1994), Robert Zemeckis’ highly acclaimed retelling of twentieth century history through the eyes of the low IQ but high-spirited Gump.
Promising Young Woman director Emerald Fennell also created Killing Eve, a wry and comic take on a female assassin who kills without remorse.

Butterfly Kiss is a road movie of immense bleakness. Shy Miriam falls for Eunice who seeks release from her psychic pain through violence on the dank highways of northern Britain. As in Thelma and Louise, one world-weary woman enables a more naïve one to find her voice on the road.

For all its gentle humour and vicarious fine dining, The Trip and its sequels tread a fine line between sending up the egos of Steeve Coogan and Rob Rydon’s on-screen personas and reinforcing the misogyny and elitism that drive the characters in Winterbottom’s much earlier road movie, Butterfly Kiss to acts of desperation.

Killing Eve’s sociopathic killer Villanelle (Jodie Comer) dresses in high style – a sign of her independence and confidence. The impossible glamour of the show, like the comic book visual energy of Birds of Prey are keys to understanding the characters, while also signalling both films are elaborate fantasies.

Harley Quinn expresses her extreme individuality through her glam grunge outfits, while Ellie from The Last of Us favours survival-grunge jeans and hoodies. Their looks may not have much in common, but Ellie is a rare woman character in a major commercial videogame who isn't only fully rounded but fully clothed.

nodes.title: Birds of Prey (and the Fantabulous Emancipation of One Harley Quinn)

links.text: Jazz Money’s Rodeo Baby! reclaims images of First Peoples from screen archives. One such image is from Rachel Perkins’ film Radiance, which depicts a scene when the three female leads burn down their family home.

Radiance portrays the power and resilience of Aboriginal women. Leah Purcell tells a story of Aboriginal women’s strength in her directorial debut The Drover’s Wife: The Legend of Molly Johnson. Both films began as stage plays and were transformed for the screen.

Leah Purcell's film is a Blak Western set in the 19th century in the high country. Shadow of the Boomerang is a Christian Western shot in the outback that depicts racist views of cattle station owners toward Aboriginal people.

Yorta Yorta man Jimmy Little wrote and performed the song "Shadow of the Boomerang" for the film of the same name. In the film, Jimmy’s performance of the song was a catalyst in changing the heart of the racist protagonist.

nodes.title: The Drover's Wife: The Legend of Molly Johnson

links.text: This display features toys, games, posters and other memorabilia of Humphrey B. Bear, who was the star of the children's television series Here's Humphrey (1965).

Australian icon Humphrey B. Bear has a Disney counterpart, Humphrey the Bear, who was the main character in the short film Hooked Bear (1956) and has made several appearances throughout Disney films and TV episodes.

Like Humphrey the Bear, Banjo the bear from the single-player videogame Banjo-Kazooie (1998) makes vocal sounds to convey dialogue and emotions instead of speaking. Banjo and other characters' voices are subtitled to make the videogame available in multiple languages.

Banjo is one part of the bear-bird fighting duo Banjo-Kazooie, who rely on combined attack moves to save Banjo’s sister Tooty. Similarly, Po the Panda Bear fights alongside the Furious Five to protect the Valley of Peace in Kung Fu Panda 2 (2011).

Jennifer Yuh Nelson made her feature-length directorial debut with Kung Fu Panda 2 and later went onto direct the Love, Death & Robots (2019) episode 'Kill Team Kill', which featured a cybernetically enhanced grizzly bear fighting US Special Forces operatives.

The extreme and gruesome bear fight sequences in Love, Death & Robots(2019) episode 'Kill Team Kill' are reminiscent of the pivotal bear attack scene in The Revenant (2015), which also relied on CGI to realistically create the mother bear that mauls Hugh Glass (Leonardo DiCaprio).
Following the attacks on the World Trade Center, the anthology film 11‘09”01 September 11 (2002) premiered and featured directors from different countries exploring international reactions to 9/11.

Australian artist Elvis Richardson’s work Now 7 Years Later explored the collective experience of people who had watched the events unfold on television, prompting them to recall their memories seven years later.
Michael Moore’s documentary Fahrenheit 9/11 (2004) also explored the effects of the 9/11 attacks, critiquing George W. Bush’s presidency, the war on Iraq and coverage in the media.

Laura Poitras’ informal trilogy of documentaries on a post-9/11 world began with My Country, My Country (2006), which chronicled Iraq under US occupation. Other films in the trilogy include The Oath (2010) and Citizenfour (2014).
Paul Greengrass’ drama United 93 (2006) chronicled the events on board United Airlines Flight 93, which was hijacked during the attacks and crashed into a field following a passenger revolt.

Spike Lee’s drama 25th Hour (2002) was in its planning stages when the September 11 attacks occurred, so the director decided to incorporate it into the script, with a pivotal scene taking place at Ground Zero, the destroyed site of the World Trade Center.
Directed by Sarah Gavron, Brick Lane (2007) is set against a socio-political background that includes the September 11 attacks and follows a period of heightened racial tension in the UK.

“Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon” is an idiom from Chinese poet Yu Xin, which is believed to mean a place or situation full of hidden masters, or an expression about the emotions and passion beneath polite society. The film also features in Analects of Kung Phu.

One of the film’s Jason Phu has remixed into Analects of Kung Phu is Yuen Woo-ping's 1978 Hong Kong action-comedy martial arts film Drunken Master, starring Jackie Chan as Wong Fei-hung, who learns the drunken fighting style of Beggar So.

Drunken Master didn’t just spawn a slew of imitators, including The Shaolin Drunken Monk (also in Analects of Kung Phu), but also videogames. The Tekken character Lei Wu Long uses the “Drunken Fist” style from Drunken Master in Street Fight X Tekken.

Almost a decade after Drunken Master combined comedy with wuxia action, A Chinese Ghost Story added horror to the mix. Like many films featured in Phu’s work, it’s inspired by classical Chinese stories, in this case Strange Tales from a Chinese Studio.

Two years earlier, comedy and horror were combined in Mr. Vampire, a cult-classic based on the jiangshi, a hopping corpse that features in Chinese folklore. Like the ‘drunken master' genre, it inspired a range of imitators and established a genre.

Over the Tekken series, Lei Wu Long used a bunch of Jackie Chan’s stances from films, beginning with the Snake style used in Yuen Woo-ping's Snake in the Eagles Shadow, but Lei Wu Long is a Hong Kong cop based on Chan’s Police Story films.

While filming Hong Kong action films, Michelle Yeoh realised martial arts was choreographed like dance, which she’d studied. She was soon doing her own stunts, including an iconic motorbike jump in Supercop 3 before later starring in films like Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon.

Mr. Vampire was produced by Sammo Hung, a director, actor, choreographer and martial artist, who directed Michelle Yeoh in her first film, The Owl vs Bombo, where she appeared as a damsel in distress before Hung inspired her to learn martial arts.

The costumes that Michelle Yeoh wears in the iconic showdown with Ziyi Zhang in Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon is displayed in the 'Stunt superstar' display in Goddess. The film took home four Oscars. in 2023, Yeoh was the first Asian actor to win the Best Actress.

nodes.title: Analects of Kung Phu: Book 1, The 69 Dialogues between the Lamp and the Shadow

name: Jason Phu and genre-bending kung fu films

links.text: Out of Bounds is part of an online culture celebrating the bugs, glitches and hidden areas in videogames. Youtuber Boundary Break built a career on revealing the hidden areas in videogames that players are never meant to see, including a video on Red Dead Redemption 2 (2018).

Glitches take on a mythological dimension. In 2010, Reddit user Jadusable created Ben Drowned, a series of posts in which he described buying a haunted second-hand cartridge of Legend of Zelda: Majora's Mask (2000). The malevolent ghost reveals himself through scary glitches.

Commercial videogames sometimes use glitch aesthetics for narrative purposes. Inspired by posts like Ben Drowned, Inscryption (2021) sets the player up to expect a straightforward card game – expectations which are subverted through purposeful “glitches” that reveal a larger, darker story.

Other artists use glitch to explore the limits of their practice. In photographer Thomas Ruff's series Jpegs (2004), he prints compressed files at huge scale, distorting the images beyond recognition. This draws attention to the materiality of the digital images we view and share every day.

Like Thomas Ruff, curator Legacy Russell is interested in the materiality that glitches reveal in digital artefacts - and in their subversive power. In her manifesto Glitch Feminism (2020), Russell considers the emancipatory power of the glitch in a digital culture driven by a voracious appetite for our images.

name: The radical power of the glitch

links.text: One of the deadliest natural disasters in living history, the Indian Ocean tsunami has been represented in pop culture through various books, television shows and films such as Clint Eastwood’s ensemble fantasy drama Hereafter (2010).

In Hereafter (2010), Cécile de France’s character plays a journalist whose life is forever altered after she survives the Indian Ocean tsunami on vacation. It was the first narrative film to feature the disaster, followed by The Impossible (2012).

The Impossible (2012) was based on the true story of the Álvarez family, who were separated and eventually survived the Indian Ocean tsunami. The technology needed to recreate the surges of waves on film was incredibly expensive, with wave VFX first perfected on The Perfect Storm (2000).

Also based on the true story of a natural disaster that had tragic consequences, The Perfect Storm (2000) broke ground with its VFX of the gigantic wave that eventually dooms the crew. Weta’s Christopher White worked on that sequence, along with the tornados from Twister (1996).

Academy Award-nominee Christopher White brought the digital tornadoes in Twister to life by studying footage of real-life ones. Twister was written by Anne-Marie Martin and her husband Michael Crichton, who was also involved in the CGI-heavy classic, Jurassic Park.

nodes.title: Phi Phi Island after the Indian Ocean tsunami

links.text: Peter Waples-Crow’s Ngaya (I Am) critiques the conflicting narratives of Ngarigu country in mass media in his signature style, from skiing commercials to hunting videos, asking, whose mountain is it anyway? Goa-Gunggari-Wakka Wakka Murri woman Leah Purcel's The Legend of Molly Johnson is also set in the region and reclaims the bushranger through an Indigenous lens.

The bushranger is essential to the construction of Australia's national identity. Kirk Dougla’s character exemplifies this in The Man from Snowy River with his rugged battle against the natural world. The mountains and bush are something to be tamed, a triumph of strength and masculinity - something that The Legend of Molly Johnson tries to counter.

In Jindabyne, an Indigenous woman's body is discovered by a group of fishermen, who delay reporting the crime to the police. Jindabye is filmed entirely on location in the town of the same name, situated right next to the Snowy Mountains, and also features Leah Purcell as Carol.

The The Silver Brumby is set in the “Victorian High country”. Based on an old fable about the prince of the brumbies, the film follows one man’s impossible wish to tame the young stallion, Thowra. Like The Man from Snowy River is represents how settlers have tried to control the environment.

The natural world as something to conquer and a signifier of progress is also captured in documentaries. The Snowy: a Dream of Growing Up tells the story of the 100,000 mostly immigrant workers who constructed the Snowy Mountain Hydro Scheme, one of the largest engineering feats in the world today.

nodes.title: The Drover's Wife: The Legend of Molly Johnson
The Snowy : A Dream of Growing Up

links.text: FX studio Animal Logic use CGI to recreate the feel of hand-animated LEGO videos, such as The Magic Portal, an Australian film whose director Lindsay Fealy went on to work at Animal Logic.
Whereas The Magic Portal took five years and over $10,000 to make, modern software allows stop-motion LEGO films (like viral hit 'Death Star Canteen') to be made much more easily and cheaply.
'Death Star Canteen' animates the audio of an extended Star Wars riff from Eddie Izzard's stand up special Circle.
Izzard's flights of surrealist fantasy are a trait shared with Science of Sleep protagonist Stéphane, although Izzard's are narrated and Stéphane's visualised through stop-motion dream sequences.
Both films' lead characters use daydreams as a way of escaping the isolation of their everyday lives, charmingly rendered in hand-crafted styles.

Mad Max was one of the biggest films of the Australian New Wave cinema movement, which Australian stories making an impact overseas. Released the same year, Gillian Armstrong’s My Brilliant Career is another key work in the movement.

Like Judy Davis, My Brilliant Career's other star, Sam Neil, went on to enjoy an acclaimed international career. Fourteen years after, in the same year he starred in Jurassic Park, Neil appeared alongside Holly Hunter in Jane Campion's The Piano.

My Brilliant Career also launched star Judy Davis’ career. After next staring in other Australian New Wave films, she went on to roles in Hollywood and round the world, earning praise and numerous major awards. Most recently Davis was back in Australia screens in Mystery Road.

Twenty five years after George Miller helped establish Australian cinema as a global contender, James Wan and Leigh Whannell stunned the world with the low-budget hit, Saw. The film’s premise was inspired by Mad Max’s final scene, where a character is placed in a similarly dire situation...

Yankunytjatjara artist Kaylene Whiskey has been inspired by the Mad Max films, particularly Beyond Thunderdome and Tina Turner. The landscapes in the films remind her of her community in Indulkana, which she celebrates in her new work Ngura Pukulpa – Happy Place

After Saw, Wan kept making horror films, including establishing The Conjuring universe, but he also helmed Aquaman, one of the only critically acclaimed adaptations of a DC Comics property, which also has an Australian connection from being filmed on the Gold Coast.

Wan’s take on Aquaman, who he thought people saw as a “kind of joke”, gave him a lot of freedom to imagine the hero how he wanted. Whannell took inspiration from this approach when making The Invisible Man, about another less popular character from Universal’s monster pantheon.
Elizabeth Moss may best be known for playing Peggy in Mad Men and Offred in The Handmaid's Tale, but another masterful turn on the small screen was in Jane Campion's series Top of the Lake.

There's a reason Australia adopts talented New Zealanders as their own and you only need to look at director Jane Campion to see why. Campion's The Piano nabbed three Academy Awards, while the Emmy and Golden Globe-nominated Top of the Lake reunited Campion with Holly Hunter and starred Elizabeth Moss.

The eerie sound accompanying the alien invasion in The Day the Earth Stood Still (1951) is almost more iconic than the flying saucers themselves. Composer Bernard Hermann created those otherworldly vibrations with duelling theremins.
Before the theremin became tied to sci-fi, composers like Miklós Rózsa experimented with it for horror and thriller films like <I>Spellbound<i>
Spellbound's soundtrack inspired Jerry Goldsmith to be a film composer. Among other credits, he scored 50 episodes of The Twilight Zone.
Charlie Brooker's Black Mirror pays homage to, and updates, The Twilight Zone's structure to explore different worlds, stories and sci-fi possibilities in each episode.
Bernard Herrmann not only defined the melody of mystery with The Twilight Zone theme, he made showers terrifying with his most iconic score in Psycho.
While Black Mirror often uses 80s nostalgia in its musical choices, Strange Days uses music from international cultures and genres to suggest a multicultural, globalist vision of the future.

nodes.title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

links.text: During the time of the protests, many late night TV shows reported on the protests, including The Daily Show while Jon Stewart was host. During the segment, Samantha Bee took a humourous approach and satirised participants.

Dun, dun. It didn't take long for the Law & Order TV franchise to create an episode around a crime at the Occupy Wall St camps. While they prepared the set and created a fake camp nearby the real camp, protestors occupied the set and #mockupy started trending.

Much of the Occupy Wall St footage captured by news outlets featured the famous Charging Bull statue in Wall St protected by police. This Wall St symbol of inequality also appears in Mr. Robot, when revolutionary hacker Darlen Alderson castrates it. Generally, Mr. Robot shares many of the concerns of the Occupy Movement.

While Mr Robot takes a dystopian approach to protest and resistance, Jeffrey Walker’s Riot tells the true story of the fight for LGBTQIA+ rights in Australia, specifically Sydney, where the Mardi Gras was established to fight for rights and showed protesting can be a form of celebration.

While real-life protests were used as inspiration for Riot, the opposite exchange happens with The Handmaid’s Tale. The show’s iconic blood red costume and stark white hood have been adopted by real-life protestors, particularly those fighting for reproductive and women’s’ rights in America.

After 12 years as a correspondent on The Daily Show, Samantha Bee created her own late-night show in 2016, becoming the first woman to host a late-night satire show, which has been critically acclaimed. Aside from skewering political and cultural moments, Bee also uses the show to fight for women's rights.

nodes.title: Occupy Wall Street protestors in New York City

links.text: Bwana Devil was the first 3D colour film. 3D technology developed to keep cinema audiences interested after TV arrived in the US during the 1950s. Gimmicks evolved with time such as "Smell-O-Vision" in Scent of Mystery, which released scents through seats during key moments.
Heavily inspired by Scent of Mystery, John Waters' Polyester (1981) was presented in “Odorama”. Audiences were given scratch n’ sniff cards revealing plot-related smells at key moments.

John Waters paid homage to William Castle in Polyester. He revisited the master of gimmickry when he made a cameo as the filmmaker in TV series Feud (2017), where Castle gave audience members novelty axes before Straight-Jacket (1964).

Feud details the rivalry between Joan Crawford and Bette Davis. In Mommie Dearest, Crawford is played by Faye Dunaway, and in the film's most memorable scene, furiously declares "No! Wire! Hangers!... ever!"
The legacy of William Castle lived on during the theatrical release of Julia Ducournau’s Raw (2016). Instead of axes, ushers at a Los Angeles theatre handed out vomit bags prior to the screening.
The VCS3 was instrumental in creating a sense of dread in the seminal electronic soundtrack by Delia Derbyshire
The retro-themed aural stabs and atmos in Stranger Things also utilised sounds from the VCS3 synth, and was inspired by Legend of Hell House.
The band Survive, who scored the iconic title music for Stranger Things, were heavily influenced by the band Goblin, in particular their work on Dario Argento's iconic and hallucinatory Suspiria.
Clock Tower creator Kono stated that he wanted to create a playable version of Dario Argento's films, specifically Suspiria and Phenomena. And boy did it pay off!
Scissors are used to horrific effect in The Clocktower videogame, but one of their most iconic uses in horror was in Alfred Hitchcock's Dial M for Murder.

nodes.title: VCS1 and VCS3 Synthesiser, from Don Banks music studio

links.text: Adapted from the novel by German writer, Thea von Harbou – the filmmaker’s then wife – Metropolis was Fritz Lang’s silent masterpiece. A pioneering work of imagination, it set the template for cinematic representations of future utopian/dystopian megasocieties beholden to technology and repressive class systems.

Metropolis was set in 2026, with elements of the film’s production design going on to influence other genre classics Frankenstein and Blade Runner. The android Maria was one of the silver screen’s first robots and served as inspiration for C-3PO in Star Wars.

George Lucas' uptight C-3PO become one of pop culture’s most enduring robots. When Madonna’s video for 'Express Yourself' (1989) came out a decade later, visions of C-3PO were invoked with both Lucas and Madonna drawing inspiration from Lang’s Metropolis.

David Fincher directed 'Express Yourself', which was inspired by the set design of Metropolis and reflected the German Expressionist cinema of the 1920s. Walter Ruttman’s Berlin: Symphony of a Metropolis is an excellent counterpoint to Lang’s expressionistic narrative drama.

nodes.title: Berlin: Symphony of a Great City

links.text: In Nakkiah Liu’s Kiki and Kitty, costume designer Amelia Gebler draped Elaine Crombie in shimmering sequins that not only embody the sauciness and sassiness of Kitty – Kiki’s fairy god-vagina – but are perfectly colour coordinated to match a pink martini.

The stunning form-sitting, blue sequin dress worn by Julie (Jessica Mauboy) and designed by Tess Schofield features prominently in The Sapphires, particularly during the climax of the film – proving that style and surviving a warzone don’t have to be mutually exclusive.
Costume designer Tess Schofield has quite the creative range, having designed the shimmering, glamorous costumes in The Sapphires and the gritty, period-accurate costumes in The Drover's Wife.

The Sapphires director Wayne Blair and star Miranda Tapsell reunited on another beloved Australian film Top End Wedding, with Tapsell co-writing this Indigenous rom-com about a runaway bride reuniting with family and finding Country.

Costume designer Heather Wallace collaborated with Tiwi Designs on the stunning wedding dress that Lauren (Miranda Tapsell) wears in Top End Wedding, which marries silver-screen glamour with authentic Tiwi Island style.

In series finale of Get Krack!n, Nakkiah Liu and Miranda Tapsell (as themselves) take the morning show over from ‘The Kates’ and use the platform to criticise racism and barriers faced by First Peoples in the screen and media industry.

Kiki and Kitty creator Nakkiah Liu is one of the many writers and stars of ABC’s hit Black Comedy, the first Indigenous sketch show since Basically Black (1973). While Black Comedy enjoys mainstream success, Basically Black was censored for being too political.

Miranda Tapsell’s sunny demeanour in Get Krack!n! deteriorates when white ‘experts’ on racism finally push her too far. In The Sapphires, Tapsell plays a Cynthia, who similarly faces overt discrimination and racism from white Australians.

Nakkiah Liu’s most recent TV show Preppers follows a TV morning show host who joins a band of Indigenous doomsday preppers after a personal and professional breakdown (perhaps mimicking Get Krack!n’s storyline).

nodes.title: Molly Johnson (Leah Purcell) costume from The Drover's Wife

links.text: The Blind man of Siloam is a magic lantern show created by the Salvation Army in Melbourne. The familiar biblical story was made by printing photos on magic lantern slides and hand-painting them. Similarly, Ferdinand Zecca's Samson et Dalila featured hand-painted frames.

Cecil B. DeMille also adapted biblical stories for the screen. The Ten Commandments was lauded for its early special effects depicting the parting of the red sea and its use of the Technicolor 2 Process in some scenes.

Though rationing during WWII meant less biblical epics were made in Hollywood, DeMille returned with the blockbuster Samson and Delilah in 1949. Biblical epics were popular in early Hollywood as they could bypass the Production Code to include violence and sex.

While religious stories helped studios avoid censorship in early Hollywood, religious beliefs have led to censorship on TV. South Park episode 201 controversially featured a depiction of the Prophet Muhammad and was censored by Comedy Central.

Religious considerations can also affect videogames. The Church of England took offense when the real world Manchester Cathedral appeared in first-person shooter, Resistance: Fall of Man. The church took legal action against Sony for "digital desecration", who initially pulled the game from shelves.

nodes.title: The Blind Man of Siloam lantern slides

links.text: Hideaki Anno's cult classic anime took similar themes from the original Devilman, like humanity and Christianity. The classic shot of the Red Sea in The End of Evangelion pays homage to Devilman. The rebooted Devilman Crybaby also ends with a shot of a Red Sea.

Adventure Time, although an animated children's show, includes a subtle visual reference to Neon Genesis Evangelion in the episode “Jelly Beans Have Power”, with the antagonist behaving almost identically to one of the angels in Neon Genesis Evangelion.

In the episode “A Nightmare on Facetime” the children of South Park celebrate Halloween by dressing up as pop-culture icons, this includes a character in the background that’s dressed as Finn from Adventure Time.
The creators of South Park, Trey Parker and Matt Stone, took inspiration from the animation of the short, animated skits created by Monty Python and used a similar animation style for their show.

The Witcher 3 is a role-playing game created by CD Projekt that subtly references a Monty Python skit from The Holy Grail, the skit being about a small, killer rabbit. In The Witcher 3 players, can, indeed, be unexpectedly killed by a small, white rabbit.

nodes.title: Neon Genesis Evangelion: The End of Evangelion

links.text: Around the early 1970s, Chapman ran the Filmmaker’s Cinema above a socialist bookstore in Sydney, which screened works by directors who would form the Australian New Wave, including Gillian Armstrong, who made The Last Days of Chez Nous, which Chapman produced.

Two years after being nominated for the AFI Award for Best Picture with Chez Nous, Chapman received the Academy Award nomination for Best Picture at the 1994 Oscars, for Jane Campion’s classic The Piano.

The Last Days of Chez Nous was written by celebrated Australian author Helen Garner. Ten years earlier, Garner’s novel Monkey Grip (1977) was adapted for the screen by director Ken Cameron. It follows a group of young artists through Melbourne share houses in the 1970s.

Like Monkey Grip, Dogs in Space is a film that follows the exploits of artists and drug users through share houses and the post-punk music scene in Melbourne, during the same period of the late 1970s. It starred INXS front man Michael Hutchence.

The soundtrack to Monkey Grip was produced by the rock band Divinyls, with lead singer Chrissy Amphlett appearing in a small role in the movie. Eight years after recording the film's soundtrack, the band released their most popular single 'I Touch Myself'.

Curiously, the music video for 'I Touch Myself' was directed by none other than explosion aficionado Michael Bay. Like many directors, Bay started his career directing music videos. When producers Jerry Bruckheimer and Don Simpson noticed his work, they had him direct his first feature: Bad Boys.

Jan Chapman ran the Filmmaker’s Cinema with her first husband, Phillip Noyce. A filmmaker himself, Noyce’s debut film was Backroads, which starred Gumbainggir activist, academic, writer and actor Gary Foley, who also appeared in Dogs in Space.

After decades forging an acclaimed career, director Jane Campion returned to New Zealand (where The Piano is set) to make another acclaimed work, the TV series Top of the Lake, a story about a missing young girl and the community’s reaction to her disappearance.

nodes.title: The Last Days of Chez Nous

links.text: James Wan brought one of DC Comics most laughable characters to life with serious success in Aquaman (2018), starring Hawaiian actor Jason Momoa as the title character. Playing his father was Temuera Morrison, who was the breakout star of Once Were Warriors (1994).

Morrison’s performance in Once Were Warriors (1994) was so powerful that he became one of the most successful Māori actors ever. As well as critically acclaimed fare, he regularly appeared in sci-fi blockbusters like the Star Wars prequels (1999 - 2003) and Green Lantern (2011).

Considered a massive flop, Green Lantern (2011) featured two prominent Māori actors who both went on to work within the Star Wars universe: Morrison, of course, and Taika Waititi, who directed an episode of The Mandalorian (2019) and voiced the character of IG-11.

Sure, The Mandalorian (2019) gave us Baby Yoda, but more importantly it also gave us Star Wars' first female director in 42 years. Deborah Chow directed two episodes on the series and got her start working on short films like La Cerca (2005).

The award-winning short La Cerca (2005) was written and directed by prominent Latino filmmaker SJ Main Muñoz and narrated by Edward James Olmos. An Oscar nominee and Golden Globe winner, Olmos is perhaps best known for his TV work including Battlestar Galactica (2004 - 2009).

Apart from playing Admiral William Adama in Battlestar Galactica (2004 - 2009), Olmos is credited with doing much to boost Latino representation on screen and behind the camera. He also appeared in Selena (1997), a biography of the Mexican American singer of the same name.

Selena (1997) was the breakout movie for Jennifer Lopez, who received a Golden Globe nomination for her portrayal. Some 22 years later she starred in the critically acclaimed Hustlers (2019), directed and written by Lorene Scafaria.

An award-winning screenwriter, director, and playwright, Hustlers (2019) filmmaker Lorene Scafaria was also briefly a singer/songwriter. Her track 28 appeared on the soundtrack for Drew Barrymore's directorial debut, Whip It (2009), about an aspiring roller derby player.
The 1953 film House of Wax, which was one of the earliest examples of 3D filmmaking, was based on the 1933 film Mystery of the Wax Museum, one of the last films to use two-colour Technicolor.

The production of The Wax Mask was directly influenced by earlier wax museum horror films. Writer Dario Argento screened copies of Mystery of the Wax Museum (1993) and House Of Wax (1953) during production.
In 2005 House of Wax was released, a loose remake of the 1953 classic. It was filmed at Movie World in Queensland and starred Paris Hilton and Jared Padalecki.
The 'Fallen Idols' episode of Supernatural revolved around mysterious murders in a town with a wax museum. It starred Paris Hilton and Jared Padalecki, who also appeared together in House of Wax.

During their tour to Australia in 1964, The Beatles were mobbed by thousands of hysterical fans. This type of event was becoming  commonplace for them, and formed the comic opening scenes to their hit film 'A Hard Day's Night'.

Iconic prog-rock band Yes inspired devotion in its fandom. Steven Soderbergh, director of this 1985 documentary / concert recording, was personally an avid fan of Richard Lester (director of A Hard Day's Night), and cites him as one of his primary influences on this film.

Joss Whedon, whose works have large and passionate fandoms, was himself a huge fan of Yes, and created many musical episodes and specials. This including the award-winning 'Dr Horrible's Sing-Along Blog'. His production company, Mutant Enemy, was also named after a lyric from the Yes song 'And You And I'.

In creating 'Dr Horrible's Sing-Along Blog', Joss Whedon was hugely influenced by award-winning web series 'The Guild'. Created by and starring Felicia Day (also a star in Dr Horrible), 'The Guild' explores fandoms of massive multiplayer online games (MMORPG). The score for both was also written by Joss' brother Jed Whedon.

'The Guild' follows Cyd Sherman (Felicia Day) and her obsessive experiences with an MMORPG called The Game. Day created the series after her own experiences with addiction to 'World of Warcraft', on which The Game is based, and it presents a satiric look at some of the negative effects of fandom. 'World of Warcraft' itself has a large international fandom, with international conventions (Blizzcon) dedicated to it.

Celluloid is the material used to create the first mass-produced motion pictures. Notoriously flammable and prone to combustion, celluloid film was iconically weaponised in the climax of Quentin Tarantino's Inglorious Basterds.

Quentin Tarantino continues to champion using traditional film stock, while most filmmakers use digital cameras and projectors. Side By Side documents the respective histories of analogue and digital film, with many filmmakers, including Tarantino, giving their opinions on the two formats.

Martin Scorsese is a film legend who has embraced digital filmmaking. After Avatar (2009) spawned a 3D film resurgence, Scorsese's Hugo was one of the first films shot in digital 3D format. While it uses digital techniques, it's a love letter to the early days of analogue filmmaking.

Martin Scorsese founded The Film Foundation, which is dedicated to preserving motion picture history, including Ida Lupino's The Bigamist (1953). Lupino was a trailblazer for women in the film industry, and The Bigamist was the first film that she both starred in and directed.

Hugo features an automaton, an antique machine that's programmed to perform an activity like drawing. Philippe Parreno's artworks explore similar emulations of real life, featuring a stock character purchased by Parreno, who in 'Anywhere Out of the World' hauntingly reflects on being a digital puppet.
Portal 2 features the voice talents of Stephen Merchant and is a humorous take on science fiction tropes. Merchant also plays a key role in horror / supernatural spoof Garth Marenghi's Darkplace.
To promote the move of nostalgic supernatural adventure Super 8, an interactive teaser level of the train sequence from the film was included in Portal 2.
After playing one of the intrepid kids who discover the alien in Super 8, actor Elle Fanning evolves into playing extraterrestrial life in punk sci-fi comedy How to Talk to Girls at Parties.
The Mighty Boosh is another surreal and comedic British supernatural series, featuring much of the same cast as Darkplace, including Noel Fielding, Julien Barret and Matt Berry.

nodes.title: How to Talk to Girls at Parties

links.text: Flower, created by Jenova Chen and thatgamecompany, puts the player in control of a petal on the wind. Likewise, participants in teamlab's installation interact with a sea of falling flowers in real time.

The flowers with teamlab's installation merge and shift into living creatures, including butterflies, and appear to breathe. This technique was used to great effect in Ari Aster's folk-horror Midsommar, where flowers and nature constantly shift in breath-like motion.
Similarly to Aster's Midsommar, the video clip for Iyla's song 'Flowers' overwhelms the viewer with hyper-saturated imagery of flowers, in this case to comment on male/female relationship cliches.
The theme of bringing flowers to life is explored in breathtakingly rendered detail as blossoms join a ballet to Tchaikovsky's 'Waltz of the Flowers' in the Disney masterpiece Fantasia.

The use of hyper-saturated flowers is also used as an aesthetic technique and metaphor in Bryan Fuller's short-lived comedy-drama series Pushing Daisies to accentuate the quirky atmosphere of the town, and counterpoint the series key theme of death.

nodes.title: Floating in the Falling Universe of Flowers

links.text: The video for the Jonas Brothers' 'Sucker' was clearly inspired by The Favourite. Not only was it filmed at the same location (Hatfield House), it includes a number of direct nods to the film and its production design.
The music video features the three brothers Jonas, and their respective spouses, including Sophie Turner, most famous for her portrayal of Sansa Stark in Game of Thrones.
Sophie Turner's Game of Thrones co-star Charles Dance is a stalwart of period films, including 2016's shlocky Pride and Prejudice and Zombies, which was also filmed at Hatfield House.
Pride and Prejudice and Zombies star Lily James portrays Mrs. de Winters in the 2020 film Rebecca, which was also filmed at Hatfield House.
Rebecca (2020) is a remake of the classic thriller Rebecca (1940), based on Daphne Du Maurier's novel Rebecca (1938).
Three years after Jedda, Charles and Elsa Chauvel produced this popular 13-part TV outback travelogue for the BBC.

Artist Tracey Moffat reworked elements of Jedda in response to Charles Chauvel's film. Night Cries imagines the future of a character like Jedda – an Aboriginal child adopted by a white woman – caring for the white woman at the end of her life.

While the depiction of First Peoples in Jedda reflects colonial views of the times, actor Rosalie Kunoth-Monks was inspired to become an activist by the experience. She made a memorable Q&A appearance, where she declared "Don't try and suppress me and don't call me a problem, I am not the problem."

In pre-production on Isle Of Dogs, Wes Anderson and the storyboard artists drew inspiration from Japanese auteur Akira Kurosawa's Seven Samurai. Kurosawa believed that detailed storyboards for each of his movies made the filmmaking more "precise".
The most well-known of Kurosawa's films is arguably Seven Samurai, which has gone on to influence legions of filmmakers and films including Mad Max: Fury Road.
Riley Keough – who played Capable in George Miller's Oscar-winning Mad Max: Fury Road – went on to appear in indie drama American Honey, written and directed by Andrea Arnold.

Arnold – who won an Academy Award in 2003 for her short Wasp – predominately focuses on centering the female narrative in her work both in film (Fish Tank, Wuthering Heights, American Honey) and television (Transparent, Big Little Lies).
Meryl Streep – who joined the second season of Big Little Lies and is a legendary Academy Award-winner – voiced a key character in Wes Anderson's first animated feature, Fantastic Mr. Fox.

The trend of films being built around a star’s special skill did not start with Henie, Australian swimmer Annette Kellermann who made a number films during the silent period featuring her performing in the water

Films built around the swimming skills of its leading lady hit their peak with Esther Williams' “aquamusicals”. Always on the outlook for plots that provided opportunities to swim, Million Dollar Mermaid is a biopic of Annette Kellermann’s life.
Rather than focusing on humans who can swim like a fish, Miranda is the story of a mermaid who is caught during a fishing trip and the chaos that ensues trying to keep her watery identity a secret.
Unlike Miranda who is most definitely a mermaid, mystery surrounds Marina the marine biologist in Local Hero whose webbed feet and swimming prowess hint at something fishy in her DNA

name: Ice queens and sirens of the sea

links.text: Bill Onus was a Yorta Yorta activist, artist and entrepreneur who campaigned for Aboriginal rights and was active in the film and TV industry. Episode four of Alcheringa featured Onus making and demonstrating throwing boomerangs.
Mad Max 2 features a notorious death by lethal metal boomerang in one of its most iconic scenes.
Artists Soda_Jerk sampled this famous scene from Mad Max 2 in their 2018 ACMI Commission TERROR NULLIUS, which remixed iconic moments from Australian cinema and TV to question the national character.
TERROR NULLIUS sampled heavily from the Australian New Wave and, in particular, Ozploitation films like Razorback. Ozploitation films were characterised by exploiting colloquial Australian culture.

Before he made Razorback, director Russell Mulcahy directed the first film clip to appear on MTV - 'Video Killed the Radio Star' by The Buggles. Lighting, special effects and editing techniques he learned on music videos informed the style of Razorback.

nodes.title: The Buggles: Video Killed the Radio Star

links.text: Shuang Hu, who plays Candy in The Family Law, starred in the TV series Ronny Chieng: International Student. Created by Australian-based Malaysian comedian Ronny Chieng, the series is partly based on Chieng’s experiences as a law student in Melbourne.

Ronny Chieng went on to star in the box office hit Crazy Rich Asians alongside an all-star cast. The film grossed over $238 million worldwide, making it the highest-grossing romantic comedy in a decade.

When released in 2018, Crazy Rich Asians was the first big Hollywood film starring a majority cast of Asian descent in a contemporary setting since The Joy Luck Club. Noted for its distinctly female lens, 50 of the film’s 60 speaking parts are female.

The animated film Mulan features the first, and currently only, East Asian female lead to be part of the Disney Princess franchise. Mulan is voiced by Ming-Na Wen who also stared in The Joy Luck Club. The live action adaptation of the film stars Chinese-born actor Liu Yifei.

Liu Yifei attended the Performance Institute of Beijing Film Academy. So did Chinese contemporary artist, filmmaker and activist, Ai Weiwei. Alison Klayman's documentary Ai Weiei: Never Sorry follows the artist preparing a series of exhibitions amid increasing tensions with the Chinese government.
One of the most essential parts of Edie Kurzer's process is to have the rights tools for creating her amazing costumes and artworks. You can see them on display in our Fed Square foyer.
Before working on Judy & Punch, Edie Kurzer designed costumes for the TV series adaptation of Picnic at Hanging Rock.
The TV series of Picnic at Hanging Rock is a direct adaptation of the same novel as Peter Weir's iconic 1975 film version.

Natalie Dormer called the tiny sunglasses she wore in Picnic at Hanging Rock as her 'Gary Oldman glasses', in reference to the similarly fashionable glasses worn by Gary Oldman in Bram Stoker's Dracula.

While the tools Edie Kurzer uses to fashion her amazing costume are displayed in our Fed Square foyer, you can find costume sketches, continuity photos and other design materials in The Story of the Moving Image.
In 2018, a direct TV sequel to 1992's Romper Stomper premiered, following a new generation of ultra-right activists and anti-fascist counterparts that starred Toby Wallace and Lily Sullivan.
In the same year, two contemporary TV revivals of these classic Australian films premiered on streaming services.

nodes.title: Picnic at Hanging Rock (2018) burgundy Valentine’s Day dress and picnic dresses design materials

links.text: Before becoming an acclaimed director, Nadia Tass had a small role as Tessa Zervos in cult classic TV show Prisoner.

Nadia Tass’ first feature film is the cult classic Australian comedy Malcolm, which she made with her husband David Parker. The film won the AFI Award for Best Film, along with seven other awards including Best Director and Best Script.

While Malcolm revolves around a tram enthusiast, transportation plays a key role in another Tass film, the Australian teen comedy The Big Steal. Featuring Ben Mendelsohn in his first starring role, it follows a young man trading in his family’s Nissan Cedric for a Jaguar.

In Malcolm, Colin Friels’ portrayal suggests that Malcolm has high-functioning autism or Asperger syndrome. Another iconic character interpreted to have the same condition is Forrest Gump. David Parker has said he and Tass received the script for Forrest Gump but passed because “We've already done this.”

After The Big Steal, and her two previous Australian comedies, Tass directed the American film Pure Luck, a vehicle for Martin Short about a clumsy, luckless man tasked with finding a similarly luckless woman who has been kidnapped.

Tass has since commented that the film is not “satisfying”, pointing out the differences in Australian and American humour, and that she and Short’s co-star, Danny Glover, wanted to do something different. Glover got his chance in another mismatched buddy movie with an Australian, Lethal Weapon with Mel Gibson.

The kidnapper in Pure Luck is Frank Grimes. If that name sounds familiar, it’s because of The Simpsons’ episode ‘Homer’s Enemy’, where a new employee to the power plant, Frank Grimes, suffers because of Homer’s carelessness and clumsiness, much like the Grimes in Pure Luck.
In crafting the characters of Katie and Samantha in Gone Home, the team were very influenced by the realistic portrayal of 1990s teen life in short-lived drama My So Called Life.

Gone Home is set in Portland, 1995, and features zines and Riot Grrrl music. Miranda July moved to Portland in 1995, and began Joanie 4 Jackie initially known as 'Big Miss Moviola', a feminist film project featuring artists and bands from the area.

July featured in 2018's Madeline's Madeline, an experimental film exploring teenage actor Madeline (Helena Howard), who experiences the blurring of boundaries between real life and the characters she inhabits.
Claire Danes, fresh from her role on My So Called Life, would go on to play Juliet in Baz Lurhmann's take on the Shakespearian teen tragedy Romeo + Juliet.
Just prior to taking up the role of Romeo, Leonardo DiCaprio played a teen of a different kind in his frank portrayal of teen heroin addict in The Basketball Diaries.

Just ahead of the 1956 Melbourne Summer Olympic Games, TV arrived in Australia. Dominated mainly by factual programs, Graham Kennedy’s variety show In Melbourne Tonight was a welcome change and inspired by US and UK shows.

Melbourne Tonight was one of the first original Australian programs and also launched Bert Newton, who appeared as a presenter. While the local industry established itself, the bulk of the programming was filled with syndicated US show like I Love Lucy.

Considered one of the seminal sitcoms, I Love Lucy starred Lucille Ball and her real-life husband Desi Arnaz as a married couple. The pair established a production company that was behind another period defining show, Star Trek.

Star Trek was considered a failure at the time and was cancelled, but became a hit later due to syndication. Lucille Ball was instrumental in getting the pilot made, with her American housewife sitcom being a precursor to The Donna Reed Show.
Gilmore Girls frequently referenced The Donna Reed Show, with even a whole episode named after it.

In Gilmore Girls , Rory (Alexis Bledel) dresses up as a 50s housewife in the episode 'That Damn Donna Reed'. Pleasantville also saw the merging of modern teen values with the world of a 50s sitcom in Pleasantville.

During the making of Gods of Tiny Things, Kelly and her collaborators watched Hayao Miyazaki’s Princess Mononoke for inspiration. Both works deal with the environmental destruction brought by humans on the natural landscape and feature fantastical characters.

Both Deborah Kelly, and Jess Johnson and Simon Ward create immersive, speculative worlds in their works. Gods of Tiny Things sees Kelly create beautiful and grotesque creatures who create a symbology for a precarious world, while Johnson and Ward’s practice meshes cultural symbology, humanoid clones and messianic figures to question the future.

In Princess Mononoke, demonic boars terrorise human interlopers. Fans have likened the characters to aggressive, radioactive boars spotted around Fukushima, Japan since the 2011 tsunami/earthquake caused a nuclear disaster at Daichi power plant, drawing a parallel between the film’s message and real-world concerns.

The Clone Wars character Ahsoka Tano was directly inspired by San from Princess Mononoke, according to Clone Wars creator Dave Filoni. Ahoska moves like San, has an affinity with wolf-like creatures, is fiercely independent and is spiritually connected to nature.

The computer-animated science-fiction world of The Clone Wars (and Star Wars more generally) represents the kinds of futuristic world-building that Jess Johnson explores in her practice, harnessing both 3D animation techniques and sci-fi influences.

Seven years before the devastating 2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami, another earthquake with a magnitude over 9 on the Richter scale was recorded and led to the 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami and earthquake. News footage of the disaster was widely captured on amateur video and used by media outlets to document the disaster.

nodes.title: Phi Phi Island after the Indian Ocean tsunami

name: Speculative futures, sci-fi worlds and environmental disaster

links.text: Storyboarding is typically a time-consuming process undertaken by a team of people. Studio Ghibli's Hayao Miyazaki, director of Ponyo, chooses to personally draw all the storyboards for his films.

The comedy that comes from giving sea creatures human qualities was central to the unforgettable characterisation of the Gingerbread Man as an agonised torture victim, which features in The Pitch segment on Shrek.

ABZU projects a mysterious and poetic sense of the light, atmosphere and ecology of the ocean world. In contrast, DreamWorks Animation’s Shark Tale uses cartoon-like graphics to turn the creatures of the sea into comical human-like characters.
Kellerman’s fantastical underwater performances connected to the mystery of the ocean, which is also at the heart of the experiential videogame ABZU.
Ponyo is an adaptation of Hans Christian Anderson's classic story The Little Mermaid, the same story served as the inspiration for the Pokémon episode 'The Misty Mermaid'.

The underwater ballet in 'Misty Mermaid' was inspired by a dance form made famous by Australian movie star, Annette Kellerman, the first actor to wear a swimmable mermaid costume on film. You can see her underwater dancing in this newsreel.
The Celebration, also known as Festen, was the first film of the Dogme 95 movement, and shot on a Sony handheld camera.
Continuing in the Dogme 95 tradition, which amongst other things stipulated the use of handheld camera and natural lighting, The Idiots was one of Lars Von Trier's more controversial films.

Baker was influenced by Von Trier's early work in the creation of Tangerine, which was shot on an iPhone. He was specifically impressed with the director's ability to tell an impactful story on standard definition video.
Years before contributing to the Dogme 95 movement, Von Trier shot this ambitious one-take music video for Laid Back on handycam featuring the musicians playing their instruments while skydiving.
Another key influence on Baker's creative process was Spike Lee's Red Hook Summer, which featured numerous sequences shot by one of the young characters on iPad in the final edit.
Realising the potential of smart phones as photographic devices, musicians Grimes and Hana created a series of seven music videos utilising their iPhones for capturing all footage.
Bridget is a video artwork by Scottish artist Charlotte Prodger, and won the 2018 Turner prize. The piece, which explores themes of class, gender and sexuality was shot on an iPhone.

Dissolving magic lantern slides showed the gradual transition from one projected image to another like landscapes dissolving from day to night. The Wolf Man used dissolves to depict Lon Chaney Jr's character Larry Talbot transformation from man into beast.

Using dissolves on a grander scale to The Wolf Man, husband and wife team Charles and Ray Eames short documentary Powers of Ten used them to depict the relative scale of the universe to the power of ten.

Computer technology gave the dissolve technique new life and allowed for more elaborate uses. Directed by John Landis, "Black or White" has a sequence where people of different races, nationalities and genders morph into one another.
In the 2004 episode, "The Ziff Who Came to Dinner", the opening couch gag zoomes out from the couch into the galaxy only to end back in the couch, referencing Powers of Ten.

"Black or White" singer, Michael Jackson, underwent an animation transformation to appear in an iconic episode of The Simpsons, "Stark Raving Dad", where he lends his voice to a patient in a mental health facility, as well lending his voice to the famous song "Lisa It's Your Birthday".

The kind of digital trickery in "Black or White" is now easily accessible and on our phones. FaceApp is a mobile app that uses artificial intelligence to generate highly realistic transformations of faces in photographs.

nodes.title: Day/Night Dissolve Set, Loch Eck, Scotland, Circa 1903

links.text: Fantastical Victorian-era inventions play a key-part in Tim Burton's Sleepy Hollow, including a common thaumatrope.

In Sleepy Hollow the thaumatrope represents illusion plus science vs magic. Bioshock Infinite has similar themes, particularly the use of "vigors", tech that gives supernatural powers. The bird and cage thaumatrope imagery also appears in Bioshock Infinite but as two separate images representing "choice".

Bioshock Infinite explores themes of choice, fatalism, predeterminism and the multiple worlds theory. Twelve Monkeys explores similar themes, arguing particularly for hard determinism, the belief that our lives are prewritten and inescapable. Both works feature time traveling to avoid fate.
Twelve Monkeys was heavily inspired by French science-fiction featurette La Jetée by Chris Marker. Both films explore the nature of time travel and its consequences on free will and fate.

Dark delves into the problems and intricacies of time travel, and how it negates ideas of free will. Many characters are trapped in predetermined loops that they participate in either actively or inadvertently through what they perceive as free will.

Stevie Knicks' dreamy, melancholic vocals made it perfect for a TikTok that took people out of their dreary year (we see you, 2020). The song has appeared in over five screen works, including Big Little Lies, when it features in a limousine sing-along.
What better movie to feature 'Dreams' than Eat Pray Love? A film about a woman following her dreams in order to rediscover herself.

Ryan Murphy co-wrote the screenplay for Eat Pray Love with Elizabeth Gilbert, who adapted it from her memoir. Ryan Murphy also created American Horror Story with Brad Falchuk. Stevie Nicks appeared as the white witch in season three and eight of the show.

Stevie Knicks performs 'Gypsy' in a season eight episode of AHS, which also features Fleetwood Mac's 'Gold Dust Woman' on the soundtrack. 'Gold Dust Woman' also features in The Americans, as does 'Tusk' and 'The Chain' in memorable scenes.

'Dreams' also features in the first episode of Hulu's short-lived TV remake of High Fidelity, featuring Zoe Kravtiz, who apart from playing record store owner Rob Brooks, stars as Bonnie in Big LIttle Lies.
Zoe Kravitz's mother, Lisa Bonet, starred in the original film adaptation of Nick Hornby's book High Fidelity as one of Rob Brooks' (John Cusack) love interests.

John Cusack starred in the independent comedy Adult World with Evan Peters and Emma Roberts, two actors who have had recurring roles in American Horror Story. Emma Roberts is also the niece of Julia Roberts who starred in Eat Pray Love.
Both Närhinen's work and David Attenborough's documentary warn of the dangers to marine life from waste plastics.
The Blue Planet explores the majesty, and fragility of ocean life. In ABZU, you play as a diver in a vast oceanic world interacting with marine animals to restore life to the planet.

The fragility of the ocean was apparent when it literally caught fire after a gas leak. Films like The Blue Planet communicate the negative environmental impact of humans on the ocean, but fossil fuel companies don't seem to have watched any.

ABZU's main character is a diver but the most iconic diver would have to be Jacques Cousteau, who along with filming some of the earliest marine documentaries, also helped to advance and design diving equipment.
In Wes Anderson's The Life Aquatic, Bill Murray plays Steve Zissou, a documentarian modeled after Jacques Cousteau.

Echoing the captivating translucence that Cameron discovered in many of the deepest sea creatures, Tuula Närhinen's work uses plastic recovered from the ocean to mimic these otherworldly forms of life.
Like Steve Zissou using a submarine to track down the elusive Jaguar Shark, James Cameron ventured by sub to the Mariana Trench to capture previously unseen marine life on film.

nodes.title: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou

links.text: Scientific Light is the second section of Light, which is dedicated to pioneering works by JMW Turner. Light and Colour (Goethe’s Theory) is indicative of the theoretical understanding that every colour is a unique combination of light and dark.

Light and Colour (Goethe’s Theory) is exemplary of Turner’s innovative painting techniques, which drew on colour theory to capture the atmospheric effects of light. Magic lanterns similarly created immersive visual sensations through revolving kaleidoscopic slides known as chromotropes.

Magic lantern projection introduced the wonder of light and illusion. Colourful slides called chromatropes revolved to create kaleidoscopic effects. Kaleidoscopic movement and colour continue to fascinate and are used in the mesmerising title sequence of Queen Sugar.

The titles of Queen Sugar interconnect the abstraction of the kaleidoscope with narrative elements. In 2001’s Stargate sequence, the voyage to Jupiter breaks away from the narrative to present a purely immersive experience formed out of pattern and distortion, light, colour and movement.

Slit scan photography was used to create the patterns in the Stargate sequence. This painstaking mechanical animation technique had previously been used in the Vertigo title sequence as a prelude to the psychological turmoil into which the main character is drawn.

A similar sensation of being drawn into a vortex is created within this videogame that uses kaleidoscopic colour, disorienting perspectives and optical illusions to build gameplay around the navigation of a maze-like world of tunnels and rooms.

The hallucinatory visuals of Catacombs of Solaris are reminiscent of Rainbow Road, the final track in Mario Kart 64, with its vibrant luminous blocks of rainbow colours placed against a black background to add intensity to the rapidly moving gameplay.

Whereas the rainbow stripes of Rainbow Road add to the frenzied excitement of the race, the saturated hues of Colour Bars slowly drip onto a black background to gradually emerge as blocks of colour alluding to the television test pattern.

nodes.title: Light and Colour (Goethe’s Theory) - the Morning after the Deluge - Moses Writing the Book of Genesis

links.text: Channel 6 News's reporter April O'Neil could be always found with the news van ready to film exclusive footage the of turtles and their encounters with Shredder. Headstrong and passionate about her work O'Neil was also a vocal champion for the heroes in a half-shell.

In artist and costumer designer Edie Kurzer's display in the Federation Square foyer is a vintage Nagra audio tape used by Channel 7 News in the 1960s and 70s, when vision was synched with sound in the editing room before airing.

Editor of the Junior Gazette, Lynda Day is headstrong and opinionated yet beneath her tough exterior she is also sensitive. Raw and emotionally honest, the tone of Press Gang could effortlessly go from farce to tragedy as it details the young lives of the students who ran the paper

Fellow comic book character Lois Lane was first introduced in 1938 alongside Superman. In the 90s TV version, Lois was ambitious, intelligent, kind and brave, she led rather than followed and always got the story.

Similarly, Gail Weathers always ensures she’s gets the scoop even becoming an integral part of ending the slasher spree in Woodsboro. Eager to uncover the truth, albeit for personal gain, Weathers gatecrashes the party where the identities behind Ghostface are finally revealed.

With her own afflictions to contend with, reporter Camille Preaker moves to her hometown to similarly investigate a series of murders. Praised for its dark atmosphere, direction and performances, Sharp Objects is both a mystery and a portrait Camille's inner demons.

nodes.title: Lois & Clark: The New Adventures of Superman

links.text: Most commonly associated with the capture of news and current affairs due to its design, which made it quieter and less invasive on sets and in the field, the Mitchell Newsreel Camera was also seminal for sitcoms such as I Love Lucy (1951–57).

I Love Lucy pioneered the multi-cam sitcom, having three Mitchell Newsreel Cameras set up to cover the action. It made it historically one of the most important shows and a precursor to other genre entries like Mork & Mindy (1978–82)

In the Happy Days spin-off, star Robin Williams was known to be so active with his performance in Mork & Mindy that a fourth camera was added to the sitcom's set-up. This idea was credited to Garry Marshall, who directed Pretty Woman (1990).

Director Garry Marshall is considered one of the most influential rom-com filmmakers, not just because of Pretty Woman (1990) but a legion of other films within the genre that star, are made by and targeted at women like The Princess Diaries (2001).

Pretty Woman (1990) was the breakout film for Julia Roberts and another Marshall vehicle became the breakout for another future Oscar-winning brunette with a megawatt smile: Anne Hathaway. The Princess Diaries (2001) was produced by Whitney Houston, who had established a solid working relationship with Disney after Cinderella (1997).

Although rarely credited for it, superstar Whitney Houston – through her company BrownHouse – was an incredibly important producer and helped re-establish Disney’s live action brand with co-producing and co-starring roles in Cinderella (1997). It featured Disney’s first black princess with Brandy playing the title role, based on their animated feature of the same name.

Disney was on the verge of bankruptcy when they released Cinderella in (1950), which became their biggest hit since Snow White in the 1930s. Animators used real actors performing on a soundstage as reference to bring the characters to life, a technique not dissimilar to Andy Serkis as Gollum on the set of The Lord Of The Rings (2001–03) trilogy.

nodes.title: 16mm news camera with Cosmicar zoom lens used by GTV-9
The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring

links.text: Director Dorothy Arzner specifically created the boom mic so Clara Bow could move freely during filming of The Wild Party. It was Bow’s first talkie, and the star was having trouble adapting her energetic, vaudeville-inspired silent-era style to a world with sound.
Clara Bow was the inspiration for The Artist's main female character, Peppy Miller, and actress Bérénice Bejo invoked many of Bow's screen mannerisms.

The Artist was promoted as the first silent film to win the Best Picture Oscar since Wings (1927), which coincidentally starred Clara Bow. Technically though, because of small sound snippets, The Artist was a 'part-talkie', a hybrid film that bridged the transition from silent to talkies.

The Academy had definitely transitioned to full talkies by the time it awarded The Broadway Melody the second Best Picture Oscar in 1929. It was Hollywood's first all-talkie musical and is considered the template for the musical genre.
It only took 15 years for the musical format to hit TV. It's widely agreed that The Boys From Boise, a TV musical about showgirls stranded on a ranch, was the first TV musical.

Today many popular TV shows use the musical format, perhaps inspired by the success of sci-fi and fantasy shows that have featured special one-shot musical episodes, which first happened in Xena: Warrior Princess in 1998.

The New Zealand film and TV scene loves genre. It's not just The Lord of the Rings, but Xena, which is celebrated by artist Edie Kurzer in her Aotearoa (New Zealand) diorama in our Fed Square foyer display.

nodes.title: Dorothy Arzner and the boom mic

name: Boom mics, Clara Bow and musicals

links.text: The earliest types of cellulose nitrate film were highly combustible and could deteriorate quickly with variations in temperature. This is a key plot point in Quentin Tarantino’s film, Inglorious Basterds.

The character of Shosanna uses a huge pile of the highly flammable nitrate film to burn down a theatre full of Nazi officers – including Hitler – in Inglorious Basterds. She splices footage of herself into the reel of film before the event, which is similar to key events in All About Evil.

Natasha Lyonne plays a librarian who inherits a theatre in All About Evil and after footage of her committing a murder is accidentally spliced into the film playing that night, she becomes a serial killer who shoots riffs on well-known movies such as War and Peace.

Based on Leo Tolstoy’s famous novel, Audrey Hepburn and Henry Fonda vehicle War and Peace was produced by legendary Hollywood producer Dino De Laurentiis, who was responsible for more than 500 feature films over his 60-year career including Manhunter.

Michael Mann’s Manhunter was the first cinematic appearance of Hannibal Lecter – played by Brian Cox in this film – and De Laurentiis famously passed on producing the sequel, The Silence Of The Lambs, which is considered one of the greatest films of all time.

The Silence Of The Lambs follows FBI-agent-in-training Clarice Starling as she interacts with serial killer Hannibal Lecter. It started a wave of media that followed the conceit of a young, capable woman navigating their way through a high-stakes government agency like the TV series Alias (2001–06).

The breakout for not just star Jennifer Garner but filmmaker JJ Abrams, Alias (2001–06) followed a female double agent. A dedicated lover of film and film history, Abrams made a whole movie based on his love of home moviemaking as a child with Super 8.

name: Splicing history and silencing the lambs

links.text: Like Ada in The Piano, only to comic effect, Harpo Marx did not speak while in character as one of the Marx Brothers. In A Day at the Races, he begins playing a piano, only to pull out the strings and use them as a harp!

The Piano's Ada can’t speak but reveals her inner lyricism through the music she plays. In Paris, Texas, damaged outsider Travis can’t put his pain into words. Ry Cooder's slide guitar on the soundtrack expresses the character's longing and vulnerability.

The main theme of the Paris, Texas is based on Blind Willie Johnson’s “Dark was the Night, Cold was the Ground”. The lyrics, are about the Crucifixion, which is featured in Pablo Pasolini’s The Gospel According to St Mathew.

Harpo often whistled or honked a horn instead of talking. His on-screen persona was so connected to these sounds that many people assumed he couldn't speak. Likewise, Super Mario's jaunty theme is hardwired into our brains and always conjures that iconic plumber.
While the Super Mario Bros. theme invokes memories of happy adrenaline, John William's iconic shark theme in Jaws put a shiver down the spines of a generation of film-goers.

The repetitive, deep sawing sound created by Williams recalls Bernard Herrmann's stabbing strings in the infamous shower scene from Hitchcock's Psycho. Both are two of pop culture's most terrifying sounds.

Bob Connolly started his career as a journalist for the ABC, where he met his wife and future filmmaking partner Robin Anderson. Together they made First Contact, a documentary about gold-prospecting Australians who explored the New Guinea highlands in 1930, which was nominated for an Oscar.

Thirteen years after First Contact, the duo made the award-winning Rats in the Ranks, a documentary that followed the inner workings of the Leichardt council during Mayoral elections. Incumbent Larry Hand fights for re-election while other councillors vie for his job.
