Larry Hand may not have been so popular with his fellow councillors, but he was popular with audiences. In Grass Roots, a satirical look at local government, the lead character of Col Dunkley (Geoff Morrell) is based on Hand.

The bureaucracy, backstabbing and petty politics of a local council are prime material for satire. Those kinds of absurdities also exist at the federal levels of government and are ridiculed in Utopia, a satire set inside the fictional Nation Building Authority department.

Utopia is one of the latest satirical programs produced by Working Dog Productions, who have also made sports, variety and game shows to name a few. One of their first critically acclaimed projects was the current affairs program satire, Frontline.

In Frontline, The D-Generation (the influential sketch show that preceded Working Dog Productions) co-founder Santo Cilauro starred as weatherman Geoffrey Salter. In episode eight of season four of Rake, Cilauro makes a cameo as a weatherman.

In Rake, Richard Roxburgh plays the… well, rakish criminal defence attorney Cleaver Greene, in one of the most iconic performances of the actor’s career. Another is as former Prime Minister Bob Hawke, who he starred as in the TV miniseries Hawke, and later reprised in The Crown.

Abra Cadabra was the world's first animated feature in stereoscopic 3D, but filmmakers had been creating animated 3D shorts since the 1950s, like Famous Studios’ Boo Moon, which featured Casper the Friendly Ghost appearing to fly into the audience.

The hauntingly beautiful Coraline also employed 3D to construct a greater sense of wonder and depth into the mysterious 'other world'. Caroline's real world appears slightly flat and cramped while the other world is glossier and endless heightened by incorporating 3D technology.

Adam Elliot’s Mary and Max similarly used stop-motion animation, which he described as a “clayography” (clay biography) and drew upon his experience writing to a penfriend in New York for over 25 years to sensitively depict mental health issues.

Soon after the theatrical release, D3 Publisher released an adventure game based on the film. Coraline the videogame saw three main actors reprise their roles but the videogame received negative reviews with many suggesting it was both too hard and scary for children.
In 2005, Dakota Fanning voiced Satsuki in the English version of Hayao Miyazaki beloved classic from 1988, My Neighbor Tortoro. Her sister Elle Fanning was also cast as Mei Kusakabe.

Also using stop-motion techniques, TV show Pingu centered around the lovable but naughty penguin Pingu and his family. The charming series used the fictionalised Penguinese, which was designed to sound like a real language but was basically gibberish.

Stop motion techniques had previously been used in cinema but Ladislas Starewicz took them to new heights in 1912 with his story of insect adultery. With incredibly detailed gestures and props, Starewicz was able to bring his dead bug collection to life.

In the 1980s Australian TV emulated its international counterparts, which had programs across all different genres and formats. The game show was one of the most popular models in the US and UK particularly, with Sale Of The Century becoming the homegrown answer.

Sale Of The Century was a staple in Australian households, with the show even living on through merch, like a popular boardgame. It paved the way for other local gameshows like Perfect Match, which was a riff on the American version The Dating Game.
In the 1980s, many board games were based on TV game shows, whose quiz format easily translated into at-home entertainment. You can see one from The Price is Right in our display in the Fed Sq foyer.

Perfect Match introduced the beloved robot Dexter, who mathematically matched contestants with a compatibility score. Love was at the forefront of viewers mind in the 80s, with it being one of the central themes of enduring Aussie soap Neighbours.

The residents of Ramsay St in Neighbours lived on despite a shaky start. First cancelled by Seven, it migrated to Channel Ten with a more youthful approach. A massive international success Home And Away followed in its footsteps just a few years later.

Trading the suburbia for the beach, Home And Away became a launchpad for some of Australia's biggest stars like Chris Hemsworth and Heath Ledger. So too was Acropolis Now, which kickstarted the careers of Nick Giannopoulos, Mary Coustas and even Russell Crowe.

Following the lives of the owners and workers at a Greek cafe in Melbourne, Acropolis Now was one of the first examples of Australian immigrant stories in mainstream pop culture. It debuted the same year as Fast Forward, which also had a four-year run.

Prior to Man with a Movie Camera, couple Dziga Vertov and Elisaveta Svilova made a series of newsreels entitled Kino-Pravda. Meaning film-truth, their methodology espoused the ability of the camera to capture the truth of everyday life.

In the 1960s, the concept of Kino-Pravda, or "film truth" inspired the cinema verite movement, which described an observational or 'fly-on-the-wall' style of filmmaking, as seen in Jean Rouch’s Chronicle of a Summer.

With a revitalised interest in Vertov's work (and Svilova's contribution overlooked), the Dziga Vertov Group was founded in 1968. Letter to Jane is a cinematic essay exploring a photograph of Jane Fonda protesting the Vietnam War.

In the US, Direct Cinema grew out of a similar methodology. Brothers Albert and David Maysles were key proponents of the style and their film Gimme Shelter (co-directed with Charlotte Zwerin) chronicled the Rolling Stones' concert tour that culminated in the disastrous Altamont Free Concert in 1969.

The Maysles brothers' follow up, Grey Gardens (co-directed with Ellen Hovde and Muffie Meyer), is a well-known example of the fly-on-the-wall style of filming, prompting the film's eccentric and insightful subjects to reveal a portrait of themselves.

In The Mood For Love hinges on the vulnerable performances of its two leads, with star Tony Leung becoming the first Hong Kong actor to win Best Actor at Cannes. Leung also starred in Wong Kar-wai’s cult classic Chungking Express.

Lost In Translation won Sofia Coppola an Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay and in her acceptance speech, she thanked Wong Kar-Wai for his influence on the film which has a similar ending to In The Mood For Love.

Based on the John Grisham novel of the same name, The Rainmaker was directed by the legendary Francis Ford Coppola. His daughter Sofia went on to become a filmmaker too, with Lost In Translation her most critically acclaimed feature.
The Departed featured an against type performance from Matt Damon, who played the villainous role originated by Andy Lau in the Hong Kong feature. Damon also appeared in crime drama The Rainmaker.

Considered one of the most important modern auteurs, Wong Kar-wai has had an enduring relationship with Leung who he has cast repeatedly in his films including Quentin Tarantino favourite Chungking Express. Leung was one of the co-leads in Infernal Affairs.

Complex crime drama Infernal Affairs was a critical and commercial hit at the time of its release, so much so Martin Scorsese would later remake it with The Departed, which saw Leung’s role played by Leonardo DiCaprio.

Philip Noyce's 1978 film, starring Bill Hunter, follows the lives and misadventures of two brothers working for rival newsreel companies in competition to capture the best and most sensational stories, in the period just prior to the emergence of television.

Newsfront uses archival newsreel footage alongside dramatic sequences. Orson Welles's lauded film opens with a newsreel obituary of the newspaper magnate Citizen Kane, in a program called News on the March (a take on US newsreel The March of Time).

By the 1990s, the newsreel format had long been surpassed by television and the nightly news. Australian comedy series Frontline satirised the dramas, machinations and under-handed tactics of reporters and producers behind current affairs programs such as Today Tonight and A Current Affair.
Many of the storylines in Frontline were taken directly or obliquely from the long-running series Media Watch, which analyses journalistic behaviour and misconduct.

The Aaron Sorkin HBO drama also explored behind the scenes of a nightly cable news program, News Night, and its staff as they navigate corporate, ethical and personal difficulties alongside political events and stories.

Khalil Joseph's video work BLKNWS reimagines the aesthetic of a cable news network, combining footage from news sources and social media with staged anchor segments, and has been exhibited at the 2019 Venice Biennale and as pre-feature newsreel in cinemas.
Aaron Sorkin is famously a fan of Network, the 1976 searing satire about a fictional television news network and its veteran anchor, Howard Beale.

The RCA Victor Sound 16mm Camera was introduced in 1934, five years after Hollywood’s conversion to sound pictures. The RCA Sound camera was the world’s first 16mm sound on film camera and was marketed towards amateur film makers.

Amateur filmmaker Archie Stewart used an RCA Sound Camera to document family life from 1935. A member of the Amateur Cinema League, in 1937 he published one of the first articles on amateur sound, 'A Talkie Movie Maker Speaks', in the league’s magazine.

You wouldn’t consider him an amateur now, but director Christopher Nolan never studied film. His debut Following, was produced with almost amateur production values. Shot on black-and-white 16mm film that intensified the grittiness, scenes were heavily rehearsed to reduce takes.

Kelly Reichardt also used 16mm to shoot Certain Women. Originally intending to shoot the film digitally, Reichardt and her DP Chris Blauvelt decided to use 16mm for Certain Women to capitalise on its warm grain and texture.

The opening credits of Dawson’s Creek were also shot on 16mm. The TV debut for creator Kevin Williamson was the breakout role for Michelle Williams, who’s since often worked with Kelly Reichardt and other indie filmmakers.

A top 10 hit for PNAU, the video for 'Go Bang' continued the act’s reputation for pushing boundaries. The glow-in-the-dark effects and aquatic aesthetic are not dissimilar to the introduction of Tamatoa in Moana .

In the animated Disney film Moana, the plot is an amalgamation of traditional Polynesian myths and legends. Jemaine Clement voices Tamatoa, whose musical number is evocative of a scene within the world of Pandora which Clement shall appear in for Avatar 2 .

James Cameron’s intergalactic nature parable Avatar is set to continue with the sequel, Avatar 2 . The look for the world was inspired by the filmmaker’s fascination with deep sea exploring like what was documented in Aliens of the Deep.

Both in space and under sea, James Cameron has worked extensively with NASA like he did in his documentary Aliens of the Deep which was shot for IMAX. This relationship first started during research for his film Aliens .

The sequel to Ridley Scott’s 1979 classic, Aliens follows a ragtag group of space mercenaries as they’re deployed to battle the deadly xenomorphs. Among them is Vasquez, played by Jenette Goldstein who also appeared in Near Dark .

Filmmaker Kathryn Bigelow was married to James Cameron during the making of her vampire western Near Dark and they frequently shared performers, such as Jenette Goldstein and Bill Paxton who also popped up in True Lies.

While Tru-Vues and View-Masters give people new ways of seeing, the German sci-fi film Die Welt ohne Maske (The World Without a Mask) features an invention that lets people see through walls, which criminals hope to exploit.

Kale (Shia LeBouf) can’t see through walls but he’s got a criminal suspicion. After being put on house arrest and having his internet cut, the bored teenager spies on his neighbour with binoculars, soon becoming convinced there’s a killer next door.

Disturbia was loosely based on Hitchcock’s Rear Window, which also explores the isolation of its main character Jeff (Jimmy Stewart), confined to his apartment suffering a broken leg. Watching his neighbours regularly he soon believes that one of them is a murderer.

Rachel is also convinced she has seen something suspicious from the window of the train she rides daily. Believing the perfect couple she watches are involved in a crime, she tries to intervene but nothing is what it seems.

Like Jeff in Rear Window, Ray (Tom Hanks) becomes suspicious of his neighbours after hearing odd noises and seeing strange things next door. As he continues watching, he starts to believe that his new neighbours are part of a murderous Satanic cult.
Walt Disney Animation Studios have used their Steamboat Willie flipbook for their animated logo since 2007. 3D computer animated film, Meet the Robinsons was the first to show this new logo.

Toy Story was the first film to fully use 3D computer animation with the new software developed for filming lending itself to geometric objects, like blocks and balls, the very things found in Andy’s toybox.

Famously Toy Story’s Pizza Planet truck has appeared in every Pixar film to date except The Incredibles, however it does make a cameo in The Incredibles videogame and appears also in The Lego Movie videogame.

Johnson and his friends are another group of toys that come to life when their owner Michael leaves the room. The live action TV show explores the lives of the toys while also delivering an educational message for its young viewers.

The Lego Movie’s VFX company Animal Logic also oversaw the visual effects and animation on Peter Rabbit. The film features both live action and animated characters and stars several Australian actors including Rose Byrne, Margot Robbie and Sia.
You can find out more about Animal Logic by visiting artist and costume designer Edie Kurzer's display in the Federation Square foyer.
Sia also starred as Songbird Serenade in My Little Pony: The Movie with her character’s animated design reflecting Sia’s real life onstage persona, complete with large black and white wigs.

name: Flipping through the evolution of animation

links.text: Biopunk science fiction film Gattaca examines the grim possibilities of genetic engineering. In a future where society is dictated by eugenics and children are conceived through genetic selection, Vincent Freeman goes to extreme lengths to hide his natural origins and chromosomal inferiority.

Open-world, action-adventure Cyberpunk 2077 takes place in the future megalopolis of Night City, where body modification has dramatically altered the way its inhabitants live. Cyberware implants and customisation shape the narrative, as outlaw V attempts to find the one-of-a-kind upgrade for immortality.

Performance and body artist Stelarc has had a long career investigating “alternate anatomical architectures” or the relationship between the body and technology through human/machine interfaces. His mechanical prostheses extending the possibilities and limits of the body and science.

Examining the robotic experiments of tech genius Nathan Bateman, programmer Caleb is brought in to administer the Turing Test to Bateman’s humanoid protype Ava. While determining if Ava is truly self-aware or a perfect simulation, Calab discovers Bateman’s dark ulterior motives.

Similarly exploring the confluence of human consciousness and artificial technology Westworld too uses the Turning Test as a means to confirm fidelity amongst the copied robot humanoids. For the central characters in the park, the next stage of human evolution lies in their emancipated digital code.

nodes.title: Dream a Little Crazy – Architecture in Helsinki

name: Dream A Little Crazy: The next stage of human evolution

links.text: Like Louis Le Prince, who was inspired by paintings, Stanley Kubrick drew upon the paintings of 18th century artists Gainsborough and Hogarth to develop the intensely visual Barry Lyndon. Precisely composed frames and static blocking of actors recall large painted canvases.

Similarly, director Reed Morano draws upon formal compositions to create the strictly controlled world of Gilead with the uniformity of costumes assisting to create structured, symmetrical shots. Morano contrasts this with the use of intimate, hand-held shots to create emotionally rich scenes with Offred.
Alfred Hitchcock also drew upon paintings for the visual inspiration in Psycho, specifically using Edward Hopper’s House by the Railroad, as the basis for the Bates house.

In the ‘Crows’ episode of Akira Kurosawa’s Dreams, an aspiring artist finds himself inside a world of van Gogh’s paintings and soon encounters the artist himself, played by Martin Scorsese. Kurosawa’s narrative is strikingly visual with brightly coloured landscapes transforming into paintings.

11-11: Memories Retold provides insight into the stories of soldiers who fought in WWI. Without a map or icons urging objectives, it focuses on experiences, atmosphere and conversations. Painterly in its aesthetic the visuals draw upon the work of Turner and Monet.

Inspired by exotic locations like many artists, Tarsem Singh draws upon vibrant landscapes to create a painterly, visual feast partway between reality and dreams in The Fall, an adventure fantasy film that interrogates storytelling and features over 20 sumptuous landscapes from around the world.

The zoetrope and praxinoscope used sequential pictures to produce the illusion of movement. It was one of the first animation techniques and inspired animation master, Studio’s Ghibli’s Hayao Miyazaki to commission a zoetrope for the studio’s museum using characters from My Neighbour Totoro.

The 3D My Neighbour Totoro zoetrope demonstrated the principals of early animation to museum visitors. It was the first time the device had been recreated on the scale with modern characters. It even inspired Pixar to make their own using Toy Story 2 characters.

Several versions of Pixar's zoetrope toured the world, appearing in museums and theme parks. In 1999, the same year Toy Story 2 came out, a zoetrope appeared in a key scene in horror film House On Haunted Hill.

Zoetropes aren’t just loved by animation studios, they’re also loved by horror filmmakers. In House on Haunted Hill, an amusement park mogul gets stuck in a giant zoetrope, while Daniel Radcliffe’s character in The Woman In Black also encounters a zoetrope in a haunted mansion.

In The Woman In Black, solicitor Arthur Kipps peers into a zoetrope. While watching, a ghostly eye appears and provides a startling jump scare. Australian filmmaker James Wan uses a zoetrope in another famous scene in The Conjuring 2.

In The Conjuring 2, paranormal investigator Ed Warren discovers a zoetrope spinning on its own – always a bad sign – which depicts a demon marching, before it physically manifests! It’s just one instance of cinematic devices appearing in Wan’s films, including Annabelle Comes Home.

A key scare in Annabelle Comes Home involves a rotating magic lantern, another pre-film animation devices that was particularly popular with children. In The Babadook, another seemingly innocent device – a children’s book – invites evil into the home.

Due to its lightweight and dependable nature, this model of camera was standard issue for combat photographers embedded with troops during various conflicts such as WWII. Replicas are depicted being carried in the background of Band of Brothers (2001) for this reason.

Considered one of the greatest mini-series ever made, Band of Brothers (2001) followed the real-life exploits of Easy Company during WWII. Tom Hanks directed one of the pivotal episodes of the series after making his directorial debut with That Thing You Do (1996).

The period musical comedy follows a band propelled to stardom following a hit song, which is also the title of the film – That Thing You Do (1996). The track was nominated for an Oscar and penned by Adam Schlesinger, who was also behind the music for Josie and the Pussycats (2001).

A commercial and critical flop at the time, Josie and the Pussycats (2001) went on to become a cult classic in the decades following its release. It was based on the Archie comic book of the same name, which was also the basis for the 70s cartoon series.

Arriving just on the other side of the Civil Rights movement in America, Hanna-Barbera’s Josie and The Pussycats (1970–71) animated series featured the first black character on a Saturday morning cartoon ever – Valerie. The original songs were made by the same team behind the hits on The Partridge Family (1970–75).
Footage of the Vietnam War, known as the Television War, features prominently in the Spectacle section of Moving Minds in The Story of the Moving Image.

Front Line chronicled the career of combat photographer Neil Davis, known for his intrepid reporting on conflicts such as the Vietnam War. The war was the first time that people saw scenes from the front on their television screens.

In the aftermath of the Vietnam War, popular culture focused on the horrors of the conflict. Francis Ford Coppola's loose interpretation of Joseph Conrad's book Heart of Darkness, transposed onto Vietnam, replicates and critiques the insanity of war.

Films about the Vietnam War in the 1970s also tended to focus on the trauma of returning veterans. Neo-noir psychological thriller Taxi Driver follows the story of a lonely taxi driver's descent into madness in New York City.

Inspired by the real life experiences of Adrian Cronauer, Good Morning, Vietnam stars Robin Williams as an unorthodox and irreverent radio DJ stationed in Saigon in 1965, providing entertainment and music for the American troops.

The Vietnam War famously clashed with the counter-culture years of the 60s. Based on the 1968 musical, Hair is an anti-war film about a draftee who befriends a group of hippies and is introduced to hallucinogenics and draft evasion.
Julie Taymor's musical drama is a romance set to songs by the Beatles, against a backdrop of the Vietnam War, anti-war demonstrations, and counter-culture movement.

Visionary director W.I.Z. (Andrew Whiston) payed homage to Salomé in the music video for 'Stand Inside Your Love' by The Smashing Pumpkins. Stark black and white photography is used to reference Aubrey Beardsley who illustrated Oscar Wilde's Salomé.

Magnolia’s memorable opening vignette is shot in black and white, within a 4:3 frame and with visual effects implying film degradation and a significant flicker. This aesthetic is used to articulate a temporal shift to the audience.

Many silent films were shot on hand-cranked cameras causing variable speeds. In the opening sequence of Magnolia, the film is sped up to signify the silent era, however in Sissy-Boy Slap-Party this is further exaggerated to reference slapstick.

Guy Maddin similarly uses unpolished stylistic techniques to reference the rich history of horror during the silent era. In Dracula: Pages from a Virgin's Diary the film is mostly shot in grainy black and white and very shadowy perimeters of frame.

Michel Hazanavicius' mostly-silent film The Artist marked a significant shift from this aesthetic being used as a referential touching point or avant-garde experiment to a work with more of a mainstream appeal. Stylistic nods to the era are more polished.

The Artist relies on similar silent era visual cues as Sissy-Boy Slap Party – similar lighting, and variable speeds - however they are less exaggerated and create a very different mood throughout the film.

nodes.title: Dracula: Pages from a Virgin's Diary

links.text: In Phoenix, the double identity of Nina Hoss's character is implied by splitting her reflection across shards of broken mirror. Visually the audience understands that she is split between roles, hiding her true identity as Nelly a Holocaust survivor.

Harry travels with a broken mirror in Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, turning to it when he believes all hope is lost at the Malfoy Manor. Seeing the other half of the in fact two-way mirror, Aberforth is able to send Dobby to the rescue.

Mirrors also play an important role in the character arch of Travis Bickle in Taxi Driver yet rather than saving Bickle, encapsulating his decent into violence. Bickle appears fractured between the macho man in the mirror and his real self who is instead lost and lonely.

The final scene in Twin Peaks similarly portrays a dramatically fractured character with the much loved Agent Cooper smashing his head into the bathroom mirror to produce the twisted visage of evil Bob and Cooper. This duality plays out 25 years later in Twin Peaks: The Return.

Harpo too, smashes a mirror in Duck Soup but not wanting Groucho to discover it he cleverly mimics everything Groucho is doing as if in reflection. The hilarious scene is an iconic example of physical comedy highlighting the talent of the Marx Brothers.

nodes.title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1

name: Reflecting duality and revealing new realities

links.text: Hacknet features gameplay from terminals based on realistic Unix/Linux systems, similar to how much of the accurate hacking is completed in Mr Robot.

The music video for 'Whispers Under the Moonlight' claims to be the world's first Trojan Horse music video, a hacking technique used in the game Hacknet. The download file installs photos, emails and wallpapers to the user's computer as part of an interactive experience.
In the memorable ending to Independence Day, the team manage to hack their way into the alien spaceship utilising a Trojan Horse virus – enabling them to save the day.

The season two premiere features a nod to 1995's Hackers, including a line of source code from real-world hacking tool Social Engineering Program that states 'Hack the Gibson', a reference to one of Hackers' most infamous scenes.
Hackers features a character known as Phreak, so named from his ability to 'phreak' or manipulate landlines. Matthew Broderick's character in WarGames also phreaks public phone boxes.

Fritz Lang’s M features in the Arrival of sound, despite lacking a film score. Lang instead used the leitmotif, pioneering the use of associating a character, place or situation with a recurring musical piece, which was most common in opera.

The leitmotif is also used to great effect by composer Ennio Morricone in Sergio Leone’s The Good, the Bad and the Ugly. Morricone would later say, “Music in a film must not add emphasis but must give more body and depth to the story”.

Similarly, to M sound is used remarkably in A Quiet Place. Utilising very little dialogue, sound is keenly employed to intensify tension and is even stripped away completely to portray the perspective of deaf character Regan.

Sound is likewise carefully balanced in tour-de-force film The Tribe. With no spoken dialogue or any subtitles to translate, the narrative unfolds entirely in Ukrainian sign language with even small noises resounding poignantly.

Composer Ramin Djawadi relies heavily on the leitmotif as a story device to strengthen plot points that are not overtly clear through dialogue. House themes in Game of Thrones are often employed to give greater insight into the shows many political threads.

The Legend of Zelda also makes frequent use of leitmotifs to articulate characters, locations and concepts. Musical themes are used to give greater awareness of story development like the use of Ganondorf’s theme, which represents Ganondorf or one of his alternate forms.

nodes.title: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly

links.text: After beginning his career producing narrative shorts and documentaries, Tony Ayres’ first feature Walking on Water debuted in 2002 and won five Australian Film Institute awards and a Teddy Award at Berlinale.

After Walking on Water, which followed two friends processing their grief after the death of a friend from AIDs, Ayres turned his attention to the autobiographical Home Song Stories, about his family’s migration to, and new life in, Australia.

Home Song Stories is one of the few Australian films to explore the Asian Australian migrant experience and was groundbreaking for the Australian screen, as was The Family Law for the small screen. Ayres executive-produced the show based on Benjamin Law’s life.

While Ayres didn’t direct episodes of The Family Law, he has worked in the TV industry for many years. One of the most acclaimed instances was The Slap, an adaptation of Christos Tsiolkas’s acclaimed novel about the social fabric of Melbourne.

Ayres was also involved in the adaptation of another beloved Australian book, Tim Winton’s The Turning. Like the episodic structure of The Slap, or chapters in a book, The Turning consisted of a series of shorts helmed by different directors.
Kimie Tsukakoshi stars in the lead role of Kyra in The Bureau of Magical Things, after starring in The Family Law as Heidi Thomson.
Like The Bureau of Magical Things, Nowhere Boys is another hit Australian TV show that follows teenagers who have discovered they possess magical powers. It was created by none other than Tony Ayres.

The Favourite hinged on the incredible performances of its three heroines: Queen Anne (Olivia Coleman), Lady Sarah (Rachel Weisz) and Abigail (Emma Stone). Weisz also starred in Rian Johnson's sophomore film The Brothers Bloom.

Writer/director Johnson paid tribute to some of the classic con capers from the 50s in The Brothers Bloom. Alongside Weisz, Japanese actress Rinko Kikuchi played Bang Bang: an explosives-loving associate of the brothers. Kikuchi played the title character in Kumiko, The Treasure Hunter.
In the highly original Kumiko, The Treasure Hunter, a jaded Japanese woman (Kikuchi) discovers a secret VHS copy of Fargo, which she thinks is a treasure map leading to a suitcase full of money.

The Coen Brothers black comedy Fargo was groundbreaking at the time, winning two Oscars including one for Best Original Screenplay. Nearly 20 years later, it became the basis for anthology series Fargo.

Each season of Fargo focuses on different tales of murder and mayhem in frozen Minnesota, including the one that was the basis for the 1996 film. Dearbhla Walsh is the only woman to have directed on the series. She also sat in the director's chair on Marvel's The Punisher).

Despite the hyper-masculine nature of the character, Marvel's The Punisher series on Netflix featured several female filmmakers including Walsh, Kari Skogland, Meera Menon, Salli Richardson-Whitfield, Stacie Passon Aussie Jet Wilkinson. It came almost a decade after Punisher: War Zone.

Coincidentally Punisher: War Zone was the first comic book movie to be directed by a woman in Lexi Alexander. A former stunt woman and professional fighter, she was nominated for an Academy Award for her short film Johnny Flynton.

nodes.title: Lady Sarah (Rachel Weisz) costume from The Favourite

name: Powerful women in the frame and behind the scenes

links.text: The road movie Backroads (1977) was directed by Phillip Noyce and features Gary Foley alongside Bill Hunter and Zac Martin. Foley was heavily involved in determining the film’s portrayal of Aboriginal characters and experience.
Gary Foley later appeared in Dogs in Space (1986), Richard Lowenstein’s cult classic film about Melbourne’s post-punk music scene in the late 1970s, starring Michael Hutchence of INXS fame.

The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith (1978) starred Tom E Lewis in his first acting role, as the titular character. Unlike Backroads, the film was controversial for its portrayal of Aboriginal people and culture.

Tom E Lewis also appeared in the TV series Wrong Kind of Black (2018), a comedy-drama about an Aboriginal DJ in Melbourne’s disco scene of the 1970s, narrated by and based on the life of author Boori Monty Pryor.
Lisa Flanagan also appears in comedy series Kiki and Kitty, which was written by and stars Nakkiah Lui as Kiki.

Lisa Flanagan appeared alongside Tom E. Lewis in Wrong Kind of Black (2018) and is well known for her roles on Australian screen, including in Redfern Now (2012–15), following the lives of contemporary Aboriginal Australians in the Sydney suburb of Redfern.

Nakkiah Lui is also a writer and star of ABC sketch comedy series Black Comedy, which follows in the tradition of Basically Black, starring Gary Foley and Bob Maza and based on the theatre production of the same name.

The Sony Betamovie BMC-100P was the first consumer camcorder, including both camera and recorder in a single unit that would become standard in the following years. The accessibility of camcorders saw their popularity and use rise, represented in the iconic Reality Bites (1994).

Ben Stiller’s directorial debut, Reality Bites (1994) was a romantic comedy that featured characters filming video testimonials on handheld camcorders like the Sony Betamovie BMC-100P. It’s an element that would be adapted for The Blair Witch Project (1999) a few years later.

Twisting the non-fiction documentary format with a fictional storyline, The Blair Witch Project (1999) featured characters filming the terror on camcorders as they experience it. It became the most financially successful independent film until another found footage film, Paranormal Activity (2007).

Dethroning Blair Witch, Paranormal Activity (2009) became a massive box-office success, kickstarted a found footage horror franchise and began the dominance of production company Blumhouse. It also reignited the genre, with Chronicle (2012) arriving shortly after.

Chronicle (2012) was the first found footage superhero film in the genre, with the characters superpowers meaning phones and camcorders were able to be moved to angles previously unrealistic for the scenarios. Director Josh Trank made his directorial debut on the movie after short Stabbing at Leia’s 22nd Birthday (2007).

Stabbing at Leia’s 22nd Birthday (2007) was one of the first longer form viral videos, with the found footage short film written and directed by Josh Trank gaining traction on YouTube. With a catchy title, it was actually a bait and switch riff on Star Wars (1977) at a regular house party.

name: Found footage and the first camcorder

links.text: Murawarri activist and filmmaker Essie Coffey was one of the first Indigenous people to document the blak experience on film. Through My Survival as an Aboriginal she exposed how First Peoples were marginalised in all aspects of their lives, from school to wider society.

Continuing in the documentary tradition, Rachel Perkins is known for the TV series First Australians, which features ground-breaking research and use of documentary as a tool for education on First Peoples history.

Also directed by Rachel Perkins, Mabo is a docudrama following the successful legal battle waged by Torres Strait Islander man Eddie Koiki Mabo to bring about native title legislation. His wife, activist Bonita Mabo, is played by Deborah Mailman.

Teaming up again for Total Control, Rachel Perkins and Deborah Mailman create a powerful political drama centred around the character of an Indigenous senator. The series engages with issues of Aboriginal deaths in custody, land rights and women in politics.

Deborah Mailman appeared in the documentary Black Chicks Talking, written and directed by Leah Purcell. Purcell interviewed five prominent Aboriginal Australian women, exploring topics of identity and reclaiming their culture.

Art Calls is an interview series by visual artist Tracy Moffatt, featuring interviews conducted over Skype, including with artist Destiny Deacon who discusses her multi-disciplinary practice and how it speaks to racism within Australia.

Destiny Deacon's artwork Forced into Images is a Super 8 film featuring the artist's young niece and nephew donning an array of masks with various adult faces. The work reflects the disconnect between Aboriginal identity, representation and societal expectation.

When Queen Elizabeth II visited Australia in 1954, she was the first reigning monarch to do so. The tour was followed closely by newsreel crews and crowds and was the subject of the first colour documentary film made in Australia.

Historical drama series The Crown includes dramatised scenes of the royal tour, including a reportedly real-life argument between the royal couple caught on camera by a newsreel crew – though the film was quickly handed over and destroyed.

Also written by Peter Morgan, The Queen explores the aftermath of Princess Diana's death (in a car accident while being chased by photographers), through intense media scrutiny, public reaction and the televised funeral.

Set at the end of WWII, romantic comedy A Royal Night Out is an imagined account of the teenage Princess Elizabeth and Princess Margaret escaping the palace for a night out in London during the peace celebrations.

The Queen is well known for her affection for her pet corgis – this animated comedy film starring Julie Walters as Queen Elizabeth II follows the adventures of a royal corgi named Rex who gets lost and tries to find his way home.

Royal weddings have long held a public fascination, from Prince Charles and Lady Diana's in 1981 to Prince Harry's wedding to actor Meghan Markle in 2018. The ceremony was televised and livestreamed from the Royal Family’s YouTube account.

British sitcom The Windsors is a parody performed through the lens of a soap opera, trivialising the lives and loves of the royal family with occasional real life inspiration for its raucous storylines.

nodes.title: Royal tour of Queen Elizabeth II
The Wedding of Prince Harry and Meghan Markle

links.text: While Jedda was the first Australian-funded colour feature shot in the country, US production Kangaroo was the first to be shot in Australia in 1952. The American western starred Maureen O'Hara and Peter Lawford, as well as Indigenous actors Clyde Combo and Henry Murdoch.

Bruce McGuinness' Blackfire is the first film ever directed by an Aboriginal person. Made in 1972, the film reveals the state of Indigenous politics and society in Melbourne and features appearances by country and Western legend Harry Williams and his son Bertie, who was one of the original founders of the 1972 Aboriginal Tent Embassy.

The Homesteader was the first film made by an African American filmmaker. Oscar Micheaux wrote, directed and produced the silent picture in 1919 and went onto make a total of 44 films in his prolific career.

My Survival as an Aboriginal was directed by Essie Coffey and is the first documentary directed by an Aboriginal woman. This importantly enabled her to decide how she and her community would be represented on screen.

Redfern Now was produced by Blackfella Films and included Aboriginal directors, producers and actors. The series explores the contemporary lives of Aboriginal Australians living in the urban neighbourhood of Redfern in Sydney.

Cleverman is an Australian television drama created by Ryan Griffen that re-imagines stories of the Aboriginal Dreamtime in a contemporary superhero context, which uses the dominate cultural narrative of its time – the superhero film – to address racism, immigration policy and border protection.

name: Jedda: Uneven ground, the road to on-screen diversity

links.text: Director Paul Drane not only made 'It's A Long Way to the Top' for Countdown, he's also directed countless other film clips and concerts. And he's still going strong in the music biz, since 2005, he's directed episodes of music trivia show RockWiz.

One of the most iconic Australian rock anthems of all-time, the music video followed the band playing down Melbourne’s Swanston St on the back of a truck. Permission was revoked but the rockers did it anyway. Director Paul Drane shot the video to appear on Countdown.

The story of Countdown's iconic, Stetson-wearing host, Ian 'Molly' Meldrum was dramatised in the miniseries Molly (2016), which charts the groundbreaking show's rise and decline, along with Molly's personal life.

Hosted by Ian ‘Molly’ Meldrum, this weekly music show launched the careers of countless Australian musicians and hosted international guests. One of those bands was glam-rockers Skyhooks, whose ‘Horror Movie’ went to number 1 after being performed on the show.

‘Horror Movie’ reflected the pessimism of the 1970s with the nightly news likened to a horror movie. No wonder the band filmed part of the video in a happier place – Melbourne's Lunar Park, which also appeared prominently in The Secret Life of Us.

The real suburb of St. Kilda was intrinsic to the success of The Secret Life of Us, with the show's stories given a unique sensibility based on the location. Similarly, Redfern Now follows the lives of people living in the real Sydney suburb of Redfern. Both series also star Deborah Mailman.

Molly was played in the miniseries by Samuel Johnson, who also starred in The Secret Life of Us, providing voice-over for most of the episodes, except sections performed by Deborah Mailman as the character Kelly Lewis.

While The Secret Life of Us put the suburb of St. Kilda on the TV map, it's also the home of The Esplanade Hotel, known commonly as The Espy, where episodes of Rockwiz were filmed in The Gershwin Room.

nodes.title: Long Way to the Top – AC/DC

name: The secret life of suburbia and music videos

links.text: Alfred Hitchcock uses the evocative symbolism of saturated colours in Vertigo to give greater insight into the narrative. Red and green are heavily contrasted between the main characters: red represents caution and danger for Scottie while green embodies illusion and desire for Madeline.

Peter Greenaway also uses highly saturated colours to highlight character development and to represent different locations. Blue for outside, green for the kitchen, red for the dining area and white for the bathroom, while Georgina’s clothing changes to symbolise her character’s growth.

Wong Kar-Wai’s In the Mood for Love is a sumptuous romantic melodrama that relies on a deep colour palette to depict raw emotions and is often bathed in rich reds and oranges. The colour system is then broken when the romance disintegrates.

Spike Lee uses a similar colour palette in Do the Right Thing, yet here such colours are employed to intensify the heat wave central to the story, with even buildings being tainted red and orange to illustrate the stifling New York summer.

To replicate the bold graphic novel the series is based on, director Marc Munden and colourist Aidan Farrell used the Technicolor palette of 1950s Hollywood for TV thriller Utopia, dressing the set in rich hues before emboldening them in post-production to create the sci-fi world.

In contrast, Sofia Coppola colours her films with subdued pastels, most evident in Marie Antoinette. With the Palace of Versailles as the backdrop, Coppola incorporated a luscious yet dreamy palette highlighting the opulence of the young Queen’s life.

nodes.title: The Cook, the Thief, His Wife & Her Lover

links.text: In Red Dead Redemption 2 players can don Ned Kelly's famous armour, which in the game draws on the visual power of the armour itself as much as the Australian outlaw mythology.

The Story of the Kelly Gang is inspired by Edwin S Porter's The Great Train Robbery. However, where as the former focused on the aggression of the outlaws, The Story of the Kelly Gang tapped into Kelly's status as a folk hero.

Unlike the rebellious Ned Kelly, the central characters in Red Dead Redemption 2 seek redemption in the tradition of Seven Samurai's Ronin (masterless samurai), who try to regain honour by defending a small village.

Akira Kurosawa's classic kickstarted a cinematic cultural exchange, staring with the loose US remake of Seven Samurai, The Magnificent Seven. This western/samurai film exchange is referenced in Westworld, where characters escape robotic cowboys only to encounter AI samurai.

Westworld applies an Orientalist lens to expose the limitations of representation for samurai. VR game Ned Kelly suggests the limited scope of the colonial perspective by liming the player's POV to the rectangular slit of Kelly's helmet.

The limited perspective in Ned Kelly is similar to a scene in Sweet Country when The Story of the Kelly Gang is screened to Australian settlers who cheer for the folk hero while baying for the blood of Aboriginal outlaw protagonist Sam Kelly.

nodes.title: The Story of the Kelly Gang

links.text: Featuring Kylie Minogue battling with different versions of herself that were represented in the tabloids, 'Did It Again' is now considered one of her most iconic videos. The concept for the video was inspired by the film The Usual Suspects.
Ian 'Molly' Meldrum helped launch the careers of countless Australian stars, including the Princess of Pop, Kylie Minogue.
Considered a classic of the crime thriller genre, The Usual Suspects. It was written by screenwriter Christopher McQuarrie, who went on to make his directorial debut with The Way of the Gun.
A critical and commercial flop at the time, The Way of the Gun went on to gain a cult following. It would be 12 years before Christopher McQuarrie would direct again with Jack Reacher.

Jack Reacher marked the beginning of one of the great actor/filmmaker partnerships between Christopher McQuarrie and Tom Cruise. They would go on to do several films together, including Mission: Impossible - Fallout .

The sixth film in the $3.5 billion-dollar series, Mission: Impossible - Falloutwas one of the biggest theatrical hits of that year. The film franchise is based on the popular 60s television series Mission: Impossible.
The TV series Mission: Impossible was one of the last productions from Desilu, the company founded by husband and wife team Desi Arnaz and Lucille Ball of I Love Lucy fame.

Co-directed by Simon Ward, Aroha Bridge explores the multicultural melting pot of New Zealand through the characters of the Hook family. The hand-drawn animated series navigates the complex and hilarious circumstances growing up in a bicultural community.

Jim Henson's Labyrinth, based on conceptual designs by fantasy illustrator Brian Froud, is set in a fantastical world of goblins, castles and all kinds of strange creatures. Starring David Bowie as the nefarious king, Henson modeled the film's final sequence after Escher's staircases.

Set in a city where the wealthy live above and underground workers tirelessly power the city above, Metropolis is visually breathtaking. Detailed backdrops create an immersive futuristic environment, reinforced by the synchronized mechanical movements of thousands of extras to create the dystopia.

Based on Frank Herbert's novel Dune, Dune II is one of the most influential real-time strategy games, establishing the format. Dune II draws on Herbet's complex world-building, depicting the feuding families once again at war over the precious spice melange on the planet Arrakis.

Admired for exceptional visuals, Akira is set in the futuristic cyberpunk Neo-Tokyo where similarly to the plot of Dune, humans have acquired telekinetic abilities. Much of the character and setting designs were adapted from the original manga comic with the film utilising hand-drawn cel-animation.

Originating from an animated parody of Back to the Future, Rick and Morty is a sci-fi sitcom that follows an eccentric mad scientist Rick and his naïve yet kindly grandson Morty. Set across a multiverse, characters frequently travel between dimensions meeting alternate versions of themselves.

nodes.title: Dune II: The Building of a Dynasty

links.text: At the heart of the murder plot documented in Assassins are two women – aspiring actresses Siti Aisyah and Doan Thi Huong – who are duped into performing the assassination. Fellow documentary feature Catfish also deals with identity distortion.
Not only did it coin a new phrase, Catfish the film became such a phenomenon it was adapted into a long-running MTV show of the same name, which is a documentary television series like The Keepers.

Netflix true-crime series The Keepers looked into the unsolved murder of a nun, who was the high school teacher of director Ryan White‘s aunt. He also helmed Visible: Out On Television about the importance of gay representation on TV.

Visible: Out On Television featured interviews with several prominent LBGTQIA+ celebrities, including Jonathan Groff. Better known for his film and television work, Groff is also famous for originating the role of King George III in the stage production Hamilton.

Considered one of the most complex recordings of a live, Broadway musical, Hamilton was released as the jewel in Disney+’s crown. Cast member Groff experienced success on another streaming service with David Fincher’s Netflix drama Mindhunter.

Mindhunter was based on the true story of the FBI’s Behavioural Sciences Unit, which was set up to investigate serial predators like Ted Bundy, who was the subject of documentary Ted Bundy: Falling for a Killer.

Directed by Trish Wood, Ted Bundy: Falling for a Killer reclaimed the narrative by hearing directly from his many female victims and survivors. Through the story of Michelle McNamara, I’ll Be Gone In The Dark attempted to do the same.

While hunting the Golden State Killer, filmmaker Liz Garbus set out to reframe true crime stories – which often depict women as victims – with a female lens in I’ll Be Gone In The Dark. She also directed What Happened, Miss Simone?

nodes.title: Ted Bundy: Falling for a Killer
I'll Be Gone in the Dark

links.text: Film-noir crime drama Repeat Performance gives lead character Sheila the ability to relive a year in her life in the hopes that she will not repeat her past mistakes which saw her kill her husband. Yet in this world fate finds its own way of repeating itself.

High schooler Makoto Konno is similarly given the power to time travel and uses it to fix past mistakes, but soon discovers her actions can adversely affect others leaving Makoto to choose how to use her final time leaps wisely.

The lopping multi-generational timelines in Dark also interrogate the implications of trying to fix the past mistakes of time. Existentially questioning fate and choice, the first-ever German-language Netflix original focuses on how the past affects the future, and importantly, how the future affects the past.

Wait a minute, Doc, are you trying to tell me that my mother has got the hots for me? 1980s classic Back to the Future also explores the implications of time travel with drastic multi-generational ramifications!

Rian Johnson's Looper also has a time loop and sees "present-day" contract killers assassinating targets who have been sent back from the future. Known as 'loopers', the main character Joe must one day close the loop, liquidating his older self who appears as his next target.

Claude is also caught in his own loop in French sci-fi Je T'Aime, Je T'Amie. After agreeing to an experimental time travel study he's supposed to be sent back one year for a minute, but gets stuck in an endless loop with death his only escape.

nodes.title: The Girl Who Leapt Through Time

name: Obviously the time continuum has been disrupted...again and again and again!

links.text: With two battling theremins, composer Bernard Herrmann created the eerie sounds used in The Day the Earth Stood Still. The newly invented theremin, an electric sound instrument which harnesses frequency, with its other worldly sound, soon became intrinsically linked to the sci-fi in the 1950s.

Composer Peter Best also used newly invented electronic instruments for the haunting soundtrack of Gillian Armstrong's High Tide. Relying on the Fairlight CMI, the first digital synthesiser and sampler, the film's score was one of the first produced entirely with a sampling synthesiser.

Kyle Dixon and Michael Stein wanted to tap into a similar 80s sound for their scoring of sci-fi mystery TV series Stranger Things. With nods to Carpenter, Tangerine Dream and Goblin, the synth-dominated soundtrack is both nostalgic yet modern.

Charles Bernstein previously harnessed the eerie and menacing quality of electric sound instruments in his score for A Nightmare of Elm Street. Using acoustic instruments, reverb and synth, he created the perfect soundtrack for a horror movie that blurs the line between nightmares and reality.

Disasterpeace called upon the 1980s slasher sound trope to create a retro-minded synth score for the 2015 supernatural psychological horror It Follows. Similarly incorporating the odd and eerie sounds of electronic music, Disasterpeace created a soundtrack that echoed the narrative's killer.

Red Hot Chili Peppers drummer Cliff Martinez is also a composer and the soundtrack of Drive is a career highlight. Borrowing from a 80s sound aesthetic, Martinez blends classic instrumentation with retro synth to produce a nostalgic-feeling accompaniment to Nicolas Winding Refn's stylized filmmaking.

nodes.title: The Day the Earth Stood Still

name: Electric sound supercut: composers and their distinctive other worlds

links.text: Weta Digital were hired to animate the monkey butler Pogo on the back of their previous successes using motion capture to animate apes, chimps, and monkeys in the Planet of the Apes trilogy and King Kong.
King Kong was Peter Jackson's ambitious attempt to remake of 1933's King Kong, using state-of-the-art digital effects to replace the practical effects of the original.

King Kong pioneered a number of special effects to combine live-action actors with animated backgrounds, including a variation of rotoscoping, a technique invented by animator Max Fleischer, utilised in a number of his films such as Snow-White (1933) featuring Betty Boop.
Fleischer's animation style was a key reference for the 2017 videogame Cuphead, which used hand-drawn animation for all of its characters.

Fleischer's use of rotoscoping to appropriate dances from performers of colour such as Cab Calloway has a 21st-century parallel in smash-hit videogame Fortnite, which has received numerous lawsuits from artists and performers claiming that the game has used their dance moves without compensation or credit.

Although Fleischer was a rival of Disney's, Walt Disney eventually started using rotoscoping in his films as well, such as in Alice in Wonderland, where live-action performances were drawn over to create the final animations.

Louis Le Prince recorded the first motion pictures like Roundhay Garden Scene using his single-lens camera long before better-known pioneers like Thomas Edison and the Lumière brothers. The French filmmaker's mysterious disappearance, however, meant that he’s often been overlooked.

The technology that Le Prince used in Roundhay Garden Scene laid the groundwork for later films like Neptune's Daughter, which was one of the first feature length films and starred Australian swimmer and actress Annette Kellerman as the title character.

Annette Kellerman was also one of the first women to wear a one-piece bathing suit, which she campaigned for publicly. Her life was immortalised in the biopic Million Dollar Mermaid (1952), which followed her quest to swim the English Channel.

Million Dollar Mermaid was called that because Kellerman appeared in the first million-dollar production, A Daughter of the Gods (1916). She was one of many pioneering women in film, like Alice Guy-Blaché, whose story was told in Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché.

Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché shed light on the first recorded female filmmaker, but Alice Guy-Blaché wasn't the only pioneer to get a documentary, with the Lumière brothers spotlighted in Lumière! (2016).

Lumière! showed how the Lumière brothers understood the potential of the theatrical experience. They worked with Léon Gaumont, who supported his secretary – Alice Guy-Blaché – to make films and had the first production company, Gaumont, which still exists and made Léon: The Professional.

nodes.title: Be Natural: The Untold Story of Alice Guy-Blaché

links.text: Elevators, dumbwaiters and funiculars feature prominently in Wes Anderson’s Grand Budapest Hotel. The lavish red elevator perfectly frames hotel staff who appear in purple velvet uniforms. While the wealthy Madam D also in red seems to disappear into the backdrop.

John McClane (Bruce Willis) makes a perilous drop down an elevator shaft in his attempt to traverse the Nakatomi building undetected by terrorists. The action sequence is heightened by the real fall of Willis’ stunt double which was edited into the finished scene.

While no dialogue is spoken the silence of the elevator scene in Bombshell speaks volumes. Tightly confined, it’s the only time in which Kayla, Megyn and Gretchen, who have all experienced harassment, appear together. While physically close they are emotionally distanced, all feeling powerless.

Examining racism and historic prejudice, in ‘Who’s Afraid of the Big Black Man’, Dre has a predicament: help a toddler alone in an elevator or back away so that he's not accused of a dark ulterior motive.
Alfred Hitchcock injects comedy into the suspenseful thriller North by North West when Roger Thornhill finds himself in an elevator with his mother, and the two men who are trying to kill him.

The 1983 action platform arcade game pits players against a 30-story building full of enemy spies. Starting on the roof, players use elevators to make their escape, collecting secret documents and fighting foes.

name: Elevator Operator: Up and down, the on-screen gift of elevators

links.text: First used by Robert Paul in 1901, the wipe transitional effect was used throughout the silent era and into the 1930's as a method of propelling the pace of scenes. Within Flying to Rio, horizontal wipes are used to add momentum and heighten comedy while attention passes between multiple characters.

Horizontal wipes were again popularized in the 1970s with The Sting, again ultilised as a method of increasing the pace of action. The heist film, set in the 1930s, also uses title cards to create distinct chapters of the narrative as well as a nod to early cinema.
George Lucas created a distinct style across the Star Wars franchise through the use of his iconic opening crawls, leitmotifs and wipe transitions with 42 appearing in The Empire Strikes Back alone.

Editor Jill Billcock designed the hyper-stylised opening sequence in Romeo + Juliet leading one critic to dub her a "Russian serial killer on crack". Rapidly incorporating multiple horizontal and square iris wipes together with zooms and tightly cropped shots, Billcock set the energetic tone for film.

George Lucas was inspired to use wipes in his Star Wars films by Akira Kurosawa. This form of cinematic punctuation is closely tied to the Japanese director who himself was inspired by films of the silent era which employed wipes for visual effect and pace.

Similarly using wipes in the form of shapes for visual drama and energy, episode 5 of Broad City uses the silhouette of a foot wearing a high heel shoe to step across the screen, transitioning into the next scene of main characters Abbi and Ilana shopping.
From Super Mario 64 onward many of the videogames in the series have included a Mario/Luigi-shaped iris wipe or a Bowser-shaped iris wipe depending on if the player has won or lost a level.

In Flight of the Amazon Queen, protagonist Joe King dons a pair of fake breasts and borrows a dress from Lola the Showgirl in order to escape the gangsters holding him captive. Cross-dressing has been a significant feature of Australian comedy for over 60 years. Barry Humphries' comedy persona, Dame Edna Everage was an early example, first performing as the Dame in 1956.

Barry Humphries is a straight man cross-dressing as a woman when he plays Dame Edna Everage - but Australia has a long history of queer drag, too. In 1994, drag road-trip film The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert, became a surprise international hit. The film’s irreverent, Aussie sense of humour paved the way for a story about queer life to enter the mainstream in a conservative time.

Trans cabaret performer and actress, Carol Byron, was one of the biggest inspirations for The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert. She performed under the stage name 'Carlotta' with iconic Sydney drag cabaret showcase, Les Girls, starting in 1963. In 1973, Byron became the first trans actor to play a trans role in the world, when she took the role of showgirl Robyn Ross in Australian soapie, Number 96.

While drag is sometimes associated with only gay cisgender men, its history is much more complex and diverse. Drag performance has a distinct cultural history that is fundamentally interwoven with ballroom culture, and the trans community, as explored by the groundbreaking 1990 documentary, Paris is Burning.

Paris is Burning also shows that drag has its ties in Black and Latinx culture. Drag has its roots in Black and Latinx culture. Adrian Russell Willis' documentary Black Divas, which follows six Aboriginal drag queens who competed in the first First Nations beauty pageant, explores the fact that drag in this country has a Bla(c)K history, too.

nodes.title: Flight of the Amazon Queen for DOS
The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert

links.text: Director Sari Braithwaite would go onto to direct Censored, also compiled from archival footage. Using unseen clips removed by the Australian Film Censorship Board from 1951 to 1978, the film expertly examines the implications of government restrictions on-screen.

Asif Kapadia’s heartbreaking documentary similarly uses a collection of archival footage to chart the life and untimely death of singer Amy Winehouse. Collected from home-movies, newsreels and TV shows, Kapadia portrays the dizziness heights and devastating lows of pop mega-stardom.

Kirsten Johnson employs the same college technique in her autobiographical film documenting her career as a cinematographer. A tapestry of intimate private moments at home juxtaposed with footage shot in Johnson’s working life, the film integrates the relationship between image makers and their subjects.

Presenting a rich college of archival footage and based on the unfinished manuscript of James Baldwin, Raoul Peck examines the history of racism in the US through Baldwin’s memories of civil rights leaders Medgar Evers, Malcolm X, and Martin Luther King Jr.

Re-contextualising archival footage, the opening credits for The Americans contrasts and subverts both Soviet and American propaganda from the Cold War era. Superimposed graphics and diagrams further emphasise the impending threat of the lead characters' hidden sleeper agent identities.

name: My Hometown: Archives woven into new narrative

links.text: From the 1930s, Bill Onus, a Yorta Yorta activist, artist and entrepreneur had roles in several Australian films and in 1962 he hosted Alcheringa. Onus was a staunch advocate for Aboriginal self-determination and self-representation on screen.

Lousy Little Sixpence was a landmark series that looked at the effects of the Stolen Generations on Aboriginal communities, exposing a history ignored by mainstream audiences. Documentaries share stories that need to be heard to penetrate the Australian conscience.

The Sapphires uses a true story as inspiration. In a time where Australian government policy enforced Aboriginal children being taken away from their families, the Cummeragunja Songbirds, also known as The Sapphires, travelled to Vietnam to sing for the troops during the war.

Larissa Behrendt is a Eualeyai/Kamillaroi lawyer and filmmaker whose films expose the holes in Australia’s legal system. Innocence Betrayed follows a 23-year long fight for justice of the families of three murdered Aboriginal children, the killer of whom has never been convicted.

Beneath Clouds follows two young people as they hitchhike through regional NSW. Vaughan has just escaped juvenile prison, and Lena is running from home. The two grapple with issues faced by many young First Nations people; identity, belonging and navigating colonial systems.
Before making Assassins, Ryan White created the Netflix True Crime series The Keepers which looked into the unsolved murder of a nun, who was the high school teacher of the director’s aunt.

In The Keepers, an answer is searched for where there wasn’t yet one, Making a Murderer which also premiered during the height of true crime’s popularity on streaming platforms sought to overturn the conviction of a man who had already once been falsely convicted of a crime.

The huge appetite for long-form True Crime series was born out of the phenomenal success of the Serial podcast in 2014. The true story behind the podcast was later adapted into a True Crime series called The Case Against Adnan Syed in 2019.

Series like The Case Against Adnan Syed are largely indebted to the ground-breaking podcast Serial, whereas I’ll Be Gone in the Dark turned the True Crime genre on its head by taking a meta- approach.

I’ll Be Gone in the Dark uses highly stylised images of creeping shadows to create a haunting atmosphere. 32 year earlier, The Thin Blue Line revolutionised documentary film by incorporating highly stylised re-enactments, controversially blurring the line between fact and fiction.

nodes.title: I'll Be Gone in the Dark

links.text: Although an observational documentary, The Guardian compared Collective to Spotlight due to its exhilarating storyline and high-stakes setting, which led to governmental changes and sweeping reform.

Winning the Best Picture Oscar, Spotlight followed investigative journalists who discovered widespread child sexual abuse in Boston by the Catholic Church. Like All The Presidents' Men, it was also based on a true story.

All The Presidents' Men dramatised the events surrounding Watergate which saw reporters Woodward and Bernstein break one of the biggest stories of all time. It was directed by Alan J. Pakula, whose film The Pelican Brief also featured an investigative journalist.

The Pelican Brief sees Denzel Washington plays a fictional reporter who uncovers a government conspiracy, not unlike the character of Mikael Blomkvist in another fast-paced thriller: Sweden’s The Girl With The Dragon Tattoo.

The Girl With The Dragon Tattoo’s intrepid reporter Blomkvist was said to be inspired by the author of the original novel, Steig Larsson. The Swedish journalist spent much of his career uncovering Neo-Nazis and was featured in documentary White Terror.

Larsson appears in White Terror, which follows journalists as they investigate an extremist network across Europe, Russia and the US. He spent much of his career reporting on the spread of white supremacy, as shown in documentary Die Stieg Larsson Story.

nodes.title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo
Stieg Larsson: The Man Who Played with Fire

links.text: In Sue Ford’s Egami, Melbourne landmarks are reinterpreted through a sci-fi and colonial lens, with the Shrine of Remembrance rebadged "New Settlers’ Temple of Wars”. Similarly, Cleverman reimagines the government and corporations as oppressors of First Peoples.

Alongside the treatment of First Peoples, Egami also explores feminism and capitalism, with the voice over wondering if mannequins are women for sale in storefronts. In Blade Runner, pleasure model replicant Pris is built for this exact purpose and hides among mannequins.

Sue Ford's Low deposit, easy terms screens alongside Egami in The Story of the Moving Image, which interrogates Australia’s obsession with car culture, revealing inner-city car dealerships, home garages and junkyards where life struggles to grow.

Car wrecks area given new life in Bush Mechanics. This Warlpiri-language miniseries owes its popularity to its distinctive cultural world of Warlpiri humour, music and experience, where nyurulypa (good tricks) are used to keep wrecked cars on Outback roads.

The treatment of female characters in Blade Runner has come under scrutiny, and so did its sequel, which featured a highly sexualised holographic AI assistant, Joi. Director Dennis Villeneuve defended the film, stating sci-fi is about our world and our world is unkind to women.

For many First Peoples, colonialism is seen as an apocalyptic event leading to dystopian experiences, like those told in Cleverman. Martu Elder Nyarri Nyarri Morgan’s first encounter with white people was witnessing a test of an atomic bomb, which audiences can experience via VR in Collisions.

Lynette Wallworth, who made Collisions, next made VR artwork Awavena, a stunning tale of metamorphosis in the Brazilian Amazon that guides audiences through a portal to another way of knowing by interacting with Hushuhu, the first woman shaman of the Yawanawa.

With his non-fiction storytelling over the past 40 years, David France has become one of the preeminent voices documenting the global LGBTQ+ experience, whether that’s with Welcome to Chechnya or The Death and Life of Marsha P. Johnson.

Documentary The Death and Life of Marsha P. Johnson shined a spotlight on black gay rights activist and Stonewall veteran Marsha P. Johnson. She was a key figure referenced in Disclosure, which looked at pop cultural representations of transgender identity.

Netflix documentary Disclosure examined historical media depictions of the trans community and how that has evolved. Actress and activist Laverne Cox featured heavily in the film and served as executive producer. She also appeared in Promising Young Woman.

Promising Young Woman explored female rage in a candy-coloured revenge thriller. The Night Of The Hunter – another movie that toyed with the fox-in-the-henhouse idea – is watched by a character, and the lullaby "Pearl's Dream" is used in both.

Considered a crime genre classic, Robert Mitchum’s ‘love’ and ‘hate’ knuckle tattoos in The Night Of The Hunter became pop-culturally iconic. Marion Cotillard’s Rust and Bone character pays homage to them with ‘right’ and ‘left’ tattooed on her legs.

nodes.title: The Death and Life of Marsha P. Johnson

name: Welcome to Chechnya: tales through time

links.text: Using newly declassified documents, MLK/FBI examines the attempts to undermine the Civil Rights leader through secret tapes. Some of these recordings were referred to in a scene between Dr King and his wife Coretta King in Selma.

O.J.: Made In America tied the superstar athlete’s rise and fall with the story of race in America. Archival producer Brian Becker helped bring that tale to life by sourcing rare footage like he also did in MLK/FBI.

Denzel Washington was nominated for an Oscar for his performance in Malcom X, controversially losing to Al Pacino at the time. In another controversial victory, O.J.: Made In America won the Oscar for documentary feature, just before the rules were reshaped to exclude multi-part series.

In Selma, director Ava DuVernay chronicled the events leading up to Martin Luther King Jr’s march from Selma to Montgomery, Alabama. He was also one of several key Civil Rights figures referenced in the documentary I Am Not Your Negro.

Along with Dr King, the documentary I Am Not Your Negro featured author James Baldwin’s recollections of his friend and activist Malcom X. Legendary filmmaker Spike Lee also charted aspects of his life in biopic Malcolm X.

In True History Of The Kelly Gang, Alice Babidge brought the outlaws to life with her period costumes. The film was directed by Australian writer/director Justin Kurzel, who she also collaborated with on Snowtown.

Following the true story of the 'bodies in the barrels' murders, Snowtown was Kurzel's breakout film. He went on to direct the big-budget Assassin's Creed, based on the popular video games of the same name.

Considered one of the best video game to movie adaptations, Assassin's Creed continued more than a decade's worth of world-building that started with the games and carried on with novels, short films, comic books, boardgames and sequels like Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag.

Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag was the sixth game in Ubisoft's hugely popular gaming franchise and featured real-life pirate Anne Bonny as a character. She also appeared in television series Black Sails.

Clara Paget played a dramatised version of Anne Bonny in Black Sails, who was arguably history's most famous female pirate. German director Uta Briesewitz was the only woman to direct an episode of the TV series. She got her start in the business as director of photography on The Wire.

One of the greatest television shows of all time, The Wire took a multifaceted look at crime in Baltimore. Oscar-nominated filmmaker Agnieszka Holland directed pivotal episodes across three seasons as well as the Polish feature Spoor.

Spoor follows the mysterious deaths of several hunters and the elderly woman who knows why. Holland wrote and directed the film, which won the Golden Bear at the Berlin International Film Festival. A HBO veteran, she also helmed several episodes of Treme.

The heavily music orientated series Treme charted the lives of New Orleans residents post-Hurricane Katrina. The songs of Elvis Costello featured heavily in the show, with the singer/songwriter also appearing as himself in - of all things - Spiceworld: The Movie.

nodes.title: True History of the Kelly Gang

name: Alice Babidge and True History of the Kelly Gang

links.text: Robert Connolly’s blockbuster adaptation of Jane Harper’s bestseller The Dry stars the director’s longtime friend Eric Bana as Detective Aaron Faulk. Alongside Bana, the film stars John Polson as Scott Whitlam, who starred in the first film Connolly produced, The Boys.

The Boys is based on a horrific true crime and helped popularised Australian social realist cinema. Both these films feature criminals returning home from prison and tragically disrupting the family dynamic, with Animal Kingdom also inspired by the real-life murders of two police officers.

Animal Kingdom director David Michôd and actor Joel Edgerton next collaborated on the dystopian drama The Rover, starring another Animal Kingdom alum, Guy Pearace and Robert Pattinson. Edgerton worked on the story while Michôd directed.

Australian cinema's love of true crime goes right back to the beginning of cinema, when the world's first feature-length film was produced in Melbourne in 1906 – The Story of the Kelly Gang – based on the infamous bushranger.

In Warwick Thornton's Sweet Country Sam Kelly is condemned by the same white townsfolk who idolise another outlaw, Ned Kelly. The Story of the Kelly Gang is screened in the town in the same spot where Sam stands trial in this true story based on Willaberta Jack.

Six years earlier Nash Edgerton’s Australian neo-noir film The Square debuted and was written by his brother Joel. It was Joel's first feature-length script, followed by his directorial debut The Gift, and another Michôd collaboration The King.

The Rover, The Square, Animal Kingdom, The Gift and The Square were all made by film collective Blue-Tongue Films, which includes Michôd and the Edgerton Brothers. Another member is Mirrah Foulkes, who directed Judy & Punch.

nodes.title: The Story of the Kelly Gang

links.text: Ana Lily Amirpour's black and white feature has been described as an 'Iranian vampire Western'. Paying homage to classic horror narratives it is rich with dramatic shadows. It also features cinematography reminiscent of a spaghetti western yet ultimately turns into a love story of sorts.

When a demon compels all of Sunnydale to break into song to express their feelings, audiences are dazzled with a vampire horror musical that melds film, television and music genres taking inspiration from Disney, West Side Story, 1950s sitcoms and epic rock operas.

Often depicting cartoon versions of characters from film and television, PEZ have also infiltrated pop culture, appearing in shows such as Buffy The Vampire Slayer. You can see a bunch in Edie Kurzer's display in the Federation Square foyer.

A Greek tragedy, thriller and a black comedy, Yorgos Lanthimos’s The Killing of a Sacred Deer examines power, success and personal sacrifice. Confounding the black and white of science with the murky grey of the supernatural.

Valkyria Chronicles features two playing modes, Command Mode with a strategic overhead map as well as Action Mode allowing for control of individual characters on the battlefield. Combining traits of a RPG turn-based strategy together with a third-person shooter.

The ultimate genre blending cocktail from Nicolas Winding Refn, The Neon Demon serves up horror, inspired by The Texas Chainsaw Massacre and Suspiria; surrealism like that of Bunuel and Dali, and dark satire interrogating the model industry.

nodes.title: Wild Stallion Mountain – The Bombay Royale
A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night
The Killing of a Sacred Deer

links.text: Starring Douglas Fairbanks, this fantasy extravaganza opened in New York with an original score played by a 100-piece orchestra, but the cue sheet score composed by James Bradford offered a more practical musical reference for most cinemas of the time.
Music-based stages in Rayman Legends challenge players to match their character’s actions to musical cues based on changing rhythms.

Music played as a synchronised live accompaniment to silent films had the capacity to fill the theatre space in a way that looks forward to surround sound technologies used to great effect in films like House of Flying Daggers.

The House of Flying Daggers engages with and transforms the soundscape conventionally associated with martial arts films. In Kung Fu Panda, these sound conventions are used to comic effect in the dumpling chopstick fight scene.

As in the Kung Fu Panda dumpling scene, Untitled Goose Game sounds more serious and intense than it looks. The antics of the mischievous and cartoonish goose are accompanied by incongruously refined piano music from classical composer Debussy.

The Untitled Goose Game uses simple Foley sounds to highlight the goose’s unstoppable determination to wreak havoc. Julian Rosefeldt’s The Soundmaker lays bare the process of Foley sound creation as part of a meditation on failure and futility.

Shirin Neshat’s Turbulent also links sound and image across separate screens. On one screen, men applaud a male singer; on the other, a woman bides her time before overwhelming the other screen with the defiant power of her voice.

Based in Central Australia, where Aboriginal broadcasting was born, Green Bush follows a local radio announcer and DJ named Kenny during his shifts at the radio station, which is a hub for the community to gather.

Also set in a remote radio station in Alice Springs, 8MMM Aboriginal Radio is a TV comedy written by Trisha Moreton-Thomas. The staff in the station discuss topics that are important to community, including self-determination, housing, health and culture.

Another work by Trisha Moreton-Thomas, this mockumentary investigates the modern phenomenon of lesbianism in Alice Springs. Moreton-Thomas acts as our host, Destiny Attenborough, to understand why queer women are so attracted to Alice Springs.

Queer Indigenous identities are underrepresented on our screens. Transblack explores the intersection of being transgender and Indigenous. Each episode introduces us to a new person and unpacks the challenges and the beauty of being trans and Black.

Peter Waples-Crowe’s artworks challenge heteronormativity by placing queer Indigenous identities at the centre. His film Budjerri Dyillagami: Peggeralin, created in collaboration with Glynn Urquhart, is an imagined queer creation story where genderfluid people are born from asteroids in a futuristic landscape.
