Steven Oliver addresses the underrepresentation of queer Indigenous stories in this first for Australian TV. It’s a light-hearted romantic comedy set in a dingy cabaret club, that allows the love between two Black men to blossom.

Shari Sebbens stars in both A Chance Affair and in The Heights, which is set in the fictional Arcadia Towers social housing complex. The Heights looks at the relationship between the tenants while under the constant threat of gentrification.

While Fischinger staged some of the first multimedia projections with live musical accompaniment, Wassily Kandinsky used colour and form in operatic compositions that share a similar visual poetry with Fischinger, who was inspired by the Russian artist. Kandinsky's Swinging is in Light and Colour in Light.

During the 1920s, Moholy-Nagy (along with Kandinsky) was an influential teacher at the Bauhaus, an avant-garde art school in Germany, where he screened Fischinger's abstract and experimental films in connection with his lectures. Moholy-Nagy's work features in School of Light in Light.

Just as Taree McKenzie explores colour in abstraction, Walter Ruttman’s Lichtspiel Opus I also uses colour without reference to any representational imagery. This was the first abstract film to be publicly screened.

Taree Mackenzie uses a ‘Pepper’s ghost’ technique that employs light, reflection and glass to create a seemingly three-dimensional sculpture. This reflective technique is used in the original Space Invaders console to make the graphics appear against an illuminated moon backdrop.

This simple adaptation of the game console to produce an unearthly effect can be compared to the use of reflective glass as a practical effect in Home Alone to create the illusion that Harry’s head has been set alight.

In Lichtspiel, animated colours move to a musical score. For artist Oskar Fischinger, colour has the ability to create its own visual music. His lumigraph played coloured light and is used in a dazzling scene in the sci-fi film The Time Travelers.

Oskar Fischinger staged some of the very first multi-media performances in history. Raumlichtkunst, a reconstruction of his multiple-screen film events, first shown in Germany in 1926, was restored by the Center for Visual Music (CVM) in Los Angeles and shows in Gallery 2.

This focus on colour as something with its own character and magical qualities inspired the videogame Hue where a grayscale world becomes transformed through the discovery of colour and its capacity for transformation.

nodes.title: Pepper's ghost effect, triangles, cyan and red

links.text: People working on screen often respond creatively to technical constraints of the time. In 1975, the first colour program aired on Australian TV: a special ep of Aunty Jack, called Aunty Jack Introduces Colour, which features the cast fighting off the intrusion of colour into black & white Wollongong.

Aunty Jack Introduces Colour is a creative piece of TV history, but not all responses to changing tech worked so well. In the 90s, Brilliant Digital developed 3D choose-your-own-adventure multipath movies in game engines that were compressed enough to share online. The Xena: Warrior Princess on was critically panned.

Videogames were also grappling with technical constraints. In response to graphics limitations, some developers used footage of real actors in games. Night Trap was one, using real footage instead of 3D renderings, a technique intended to create empathy and connection between the player and the game.

Due to its real footage and allegedly violent themes, Night Trap was brought before the US Congress for the first hearing on videogame violence, a sign of games entering cultural consciousness. Sci-fi TV show, Crash Zone, which followed a “high tech whizz kids”, did this too, featuring game development and the internet.

Many 90s videogames and TV shows, like Crash Zone, speculated what games and the internet might look like. Now, some contemporary games look back like Sam Barlow's Her Story, which uses footage of real actors to present players with a police procedural mystery.

nodes.title: [ABC TV News: First Bulletin in Colour for 1st March, 1975]
Xena: Warrior Princess: Girls Just Want to Have Fun multipath movie

links.text: The Magnavox Odyssey was the first home game console, featuring Tennis as one of its playable games – the game was created by three square dots on a CRT screen.
Released the same year as the Odyssey, Pong was a game that took arcades by storm and helped launch Atari's success in the industry.
Adapted from a manga, Ping Pong uses the sport as a mechanism to explore a story of friendship between two high school students.
'Pong', by German cyber-goth band Eisenfunk, uses samples from the game Pong while presenting a hyper-stylised version of the game in its video clip.
Top Spin echoes the drama of Ping Pong as it follows the real-life trials and tribulations of three high school students as they compete to earn a place on the 2012 US Olympic table tennis team.
The installation artwork The Art of Ping Pong records and utilises player data from games of ping pong to create evolving multimedia artworks.
Part of the brief behind the creation of The Art of Ping Pong was to encourage young people to take up the sport.

name: The first home console and the art of ping pong

links.text: Before writing the screenplay of the 1979 breakthrough film My Brilliant Career, Eleanor Witcombe had successfully adapted another novel, Ethel Turner's Seven Little Australians, as a 10 TV part mini-series in 1973.

By 2011, when she appeared in the cinema adaptation of Patrick White's novel The Eye Of The Storm, Judy Davis had at least 50 professional screen credits to her name and had been performing on-screen for more than 30 years, launching her career in 1979 in My Brilliant Career.

Eleanor Witcombe (1923–2018) wrote the script of My Brilliant Career (1979) based on the 1901 novel written by the feminist Miles Franklin (1879–1954). Earlier in the 1970s, Witcombe also scripted two episodes of the sexually frank Australian soap opera Number 96.

Pat McDonald became a TV icon playing Dorrie Evans in Number 96, one of the few actors to appear in both the first and last episodes of the series. She made her screen debut in the early Australian feature film adaptation of Seven Little Australians.

In the 1939 film of Seven Little Australians, Pat McDonald launched her on-screen acting career playing Esther Wolcott. When Seven Little Australians was adapted as a 10-part TV mini-series in 1973, the young Elizabeth Alexander launched her on-screen acting career with the same character.

Almost 40 years after her screen debut, Elizabeth Alexander, now a veteran of film and TV, played a minor character in another major literary page-to-screen adaptation: The Eye of the Storm. The screenplay, adapted from Nobel Prize-winner Patrick White's novel, was scripted by Judy Morris.

The Wizard is a road movie about three children trying to attend the 'Videogame Armageddon' championships, and features abundant product placement from Nintendo - including the now infamous Powerglove.
Kung Fury, a cult over-the-top homage to 80s action flicks features the character of Hackerman. One of his essential pieces of equipment is the Nintendo Powerglove.

One of the main characters in Kung Fury is Triceracop, a dinosaur police officer. This is a reference to mid 90s flop Theodore Rex, a buddy cop movie featuring Whoopi Goldberg and her dinosaur cop partner.

The third season episode of Regular Show, 'Video Game Wizard', directly references The Wizard. Main characters Rigby and Mordecai compete for The Maximum Glove, with an advertisement in show quoting a line virtually identical to that of the character Lucas.
In perhaps the most memorable scene in The Wizard film, villain Lucas plays the Nintendo Entertainment System racing game Rad Racer and says, 'I love the Power Glove. It's so bad.'
Costume Designer Alice Babidge got her start at Sydney Theatre Company, where she was mentored by Fiona Crombie, production designer on The Favourite.

Justin Kurzel, director of True History of the Kelly Gang, has experience in dark retellings of the story of mythic figures - his previous major independent film was Macbeth. He employed many of the same team for both, including his brother Jed Kurzel, who composed the music.
True History of the Kelly Gang stars Babadook lead, and Australian legend, Essie Davis as Ellen Kelly.
Jennifer Kent followed up her iconic horror debut The Babadook with moody chase revenge film The Nightingale.

Because of the size of the Australian film and tv industry, production crew often find themselves working together. This happened to costume designer Heather Wallace and set decorator Jennifer Drake, who worked together on both of these films.
Released in the same year, both featuring extended hunts for revenge, Sweet Country and The Nightingale  can be seen as sister films, part of contemporary Australian canon.
Damon Herriman, who now works in both Hollywood and Australia, was in both of these Australian titles
When Michael Fassbender signed on for the blockbuster film Assassin's Creed, he used his star power to convince the studio to hire Justin Kurzel, the director of his previous film, Macbeth.
The Assassin's Creed film is a loose adaptation of the Assassin's Creed videogame franchise.

Production designer Fiona Crombie and art director Alice Felton met while working on Macbeth. They went on to work together again on The Favourite, for which they were nominated for an Oscar, and David Michôd's The King.

links.text: In Orwell, the player controls a governmental surveillance system that spies on its citizens, much like the NSA and other agencies illegal use of wiretapping and surveillance infrastructure exposed by Edward Snowden in Laura Potiras' award-winning documentary Citizenfour.
While in exile in Russia for the events taking place in Citizenfour, Snowden co-created the music video Exit that expounds on the dangers of surveillance culture.

Trevor Paglen's ongoing video work Code Names is a scrolling list of words that designate classified military programs, and includes many coded names from the Snowden NSA leak. Paglen also was one of the key cinematographers for Citzenfour.
In the same year, Oliver Stone released feature-length film delving into the details of Snowden's leak of NSA documents and subsequent exile.

nodes.title: Orwell: Keeping an Eye on You

links.text: Gillian Armstrong’s My Brilliant Career and Oscar and Lucinda both have their origins on the page —My Brilliant Career was based on a Miles Franklin (Stella Maria Sarah Miles Franklin) novel and Oscar and Lucinda was based on Peter Carey’s Miles Franklin award-winning novel.
In 1986 Brian Trenchard-Smith made Dead End Drive-In which was adapted from Peter Carey’s short story 'Crabs'.

Drive-in cinemas were one of the most popular forms of entertainment from the 1950s. At their peak, there were over 330 across the country and their place in pop culture was cemented by Dead End Drive-In

'Crabs' was first published in 1972 in the literary journal Overland, which continues to publish a quarterly print journal and has also published special online editions of digital art and literature. Jim Andrews’s 'Aleph Null' was published in the 2013 electronic Overland issue.
While an accomplished poet and artist Jim Andrews also worked to update and make accessible renowned Canadian experimental poet bpNichol’s (Barrie Phillip Nichol) 'First Screening: Computer Poems'.

Though better known as an experimental poet, bpNichol also worked as a writer on children’s television. Initially writing for Jim Henson’s Fraggle Rock he would go on to write for shows such as Care Bears and Babar.

Biunial magic lanterns projected different images through two lenses in a repetitive loop to suggest movement, much like GIFs, which use timed delays to loop images in a web browser and were first supported on Netscape Navigator 2.

When the GIF patent expired in 1998, the format was open to the public domain, where it was adopted by artists like Olia Lialina, whose first GIF was an eerie monochrome window and part of her browser-based artwork My Boyfriend Came Back from the War.

GIFs aren't only made by artists, but also to highlight artistry. Cinephiles make GIFs called cinemagraphs,  which frame film scenes like paintings, popular on Tumblr sites like 'If we don't, remember me'.

However, many GIFs used across social media now recontextualise popular film and TV texts to reconfigure meaning, represent emotions and reactions, and find unlikely humour. Often these moments cross countries and cultures, with many reproduced in languages other than English.
One of the most used texts for reactions is HBO's Game of Thrones, a cultural phenomenon that ran for eight seasons and was lauded for its revisionist fantasy narrative... until it wasn't.

Artist Xanthe Dobbie repurposes heroines from cult shows like Game of Thrones, infusing still photos with symbolic GIFs that channel early internet aesthetics to recontextualise pop culture history through a playful, feminist lens.

links.text: In 1888, Charles-Émile Reynaud patented the Théâtre Optique, which featured film perforation and sprocket technology. The Lumière brothers had studied Reynaud's invention and in 1895, patented their "cinematographe", an early camera-projector that advanced this technology, and produced La Sortie de l'Usine Lumière à Lyon.

One hundred years after the Lumière brothers' first film, German artist Harun Farocki revisited its themes in Arbeiter verlassen die Fabrik, expanding the Lumière's 45-second home movie into a 37-minute cinematic essay on politics and industrial power.

Unlike Farocki's sober and rigorous cinematic essay, the 1980 Hollywood comedy 9 to 5 also examined workplace politics but grossed more than $100 million at the box office by exploiting the theme as popular entertainment.

Jane Fonda not only co-starred in 9 to 5 but originated and steered the project through her production company IPC Films. Two years later, the first of her Jane Fonda's Workout videos sold more than a million copies on the relatively new home VHS format.

The 1979 film Jesus lost $2 million on its cinema release. But thanks to the same VHS technology exploited by Jane Fonda it was distributed internationally in more than 1,000 languages and has been watched by an estimated 3 billion people.

In designing costumes for The Favourite, Sandy Powell found herself unconsciously quoting her previous work on Sally Potter's Orlando. No surprise, as both were filmed at Hatfield House and feature early to mid-18th century fashion.
Orlando wasn't the first time Tilda Swinton and Sandy Powell had worked together, they both had their film debuts in Derek Jarman's Caravaggio.
In these two films, Sandy Powell designs costumes for two very different versions of Queen Elizabeth I, played in Shakespeare In Love by Judi Dench, and in Orlando by Quentin Crisp.
Sandy Powell went from designing costumes from a film about Shakespeare, to a film (based on a play) written by Shakespeare.

In Derek Jarman's biopic Caravaggio, the artist's work is described by Giovanni Baglione as "unbearable, a fingernail scratched along a blackboard", a dig at film critic Vincent Canby who used the same line about Jarman's adaptation of The Tempest.
Sandy Powell's punk-infused designs for Julie Taymor's production of The Tempest echoed the punk sensibility of her friend Derek Jarman's 1980s adaptation.

Justin Kurzel's 2020 film True History of the Kelly Gang gives the Kelly gang a gritty, rockstar quality. The same effect was attempted in 1970 with the casting of the Rolling Stones' Mick Jagger as Ned.

The Story of the Kelly Gang was loaned Ned Kelly's original armour to use during filming. 112 years later, museum conservation processes have improved, and True History of the Kelly Gang's costume designer and blacksmith were only allowed to study the original armour from behind a glass case.

Sweet Country's Sam Kelly is condemned by the same white townsfolk who idolise another outlaw, Ned Kelly. The 1906 film The Story of the Kelly Gang is screened in the town in the same spot where Sam stands trial.

Neither of these films contain a musical score. Sidney Lumet left a score out of Dog Day Afternoon to increase the tension of the heist. Warwick Thornton didn't use a score as the music was provided by the land he filmed on in Sweet Country.

Both films cast a music star as a criminal. Director Tony Richardson sought out Mick Jagger for the Ned Kelly role, but Jennifer Lopez was so keen to portray Ramona in Hustlers that she worked for free, and brought her own production company on board.

Australian screen stalwart Frank Thring appeared in the Ned Kelly biopic, and then six years later appeared in another bushranger flick, Mad Dog Morgan, the story of Irish outlaw Daniel Morgan, who was idolised by the real-life Ned Kelly.

These are both crime films based on news reports of true stories. Dog Day Afternoon is based on a LIFE magazine article called 'The Boys in the Bank', while Hustlers is based on 'The Hustlers at Scores', which appeared in New York magazine.

links.text: Shadow puppets and play sets have helped shape our imagination for thousands of years. For centuries these puppets have danced across screens and told stories, teaching philosophical, moral and aesthetic values through indigenous myths, ancient Indian epics and local legends.

Wayang shadow puppetry is a traditional method of storytelling originating in Java and India, dating back centuries. Jumaadi's installation draws on this tradition to tell the true story of a deaf musician who teaches his blind son the art of wayang kulit.

Prince Achmed is the first-ever feature animation using cut-out silhouette puppetry. Its creator, Lotte Reiniger, began telling stories using shadow puppetry from a young age, a creative practice that influenced her animation style.

Initially inspired by Reiniger’s art style, Projection drew on a wider culture of shadow puppetry for subsequent iterations of the game. The game developers also drew on the themes and morals explored in traditional shadow puppet narratives.

Like Projection (and many works inspired by shadow puppetry), Ivan Tsarevich draws on folk tale conventions. Using CGI, Ocelot has created characters and sets with the traditional look of silhouette animation set against vividly coloured backgrounds.

Woody and Buzz engage in a shadow puppet contest. As in Ivan Tsarevich, computer animation is used to represent the analogue form of shadow play. Renowned for technological innovation, the Toy Story franchise builds narratives around nostalgia for simpler times.

links.text: This Soviet director and film theorist pioneered the use of montage, believing that juxtaposing different film shots created meaning and communicated ideas through visual metaphors. His second film, Battleship Potemkin, was made up of over 1,300 shots.

Always actively engaged with innovation in moving image storytelling, Eisenstein admired the fluidity of movement that characterised Disney animation and the imaginative freedom it offered American audiences living in an oppressive capitalist society.

Disney's innovative and shapeshifting animation has been influential across cultures. Japanese manga and anime artists have cited Disney's style as a key inspiration including the magisterial Osamu Tezuka, creator of the iconic Astro Boy, the first TV anime series.

Astro Boy's graphic simplicity appealed to Stanley Kubrick when he was in the process of developing 2001: A Space Odyssey. He asked Tezuka to manage the art direction but Tezuka refused due to his many pre-existing commitments.
In her documentary Disaster Playground2001.

Videogame designer Hideo Kojima's love of cinema influences the design and detail of his games. Metal Gear Solid contains references to his favourite film 2001: A Space Odyssey including character names: Hal Emmerich and Solid Snake's real name, David.

The neo-noir cityscape of Blade Runner was a key influence on Pokémon Detective Pikachu. To achieve this, cinematographer John Mathieson, who had previously worked with Ridley Scott, shot on 35mm film, and used as many practical effects as possible.

The flames seen over the Los Angeles skyline were actually filmed by VFX supervisor Douglas Trumbull while working on Antonioni's Zabriskie Point. As the fireball footage never got used, he had them in his archives ready to add to Blade Runner.

Roman Coppola, who directed 'Gangster Trippin'', went on to work alongside his cousin Jason Schwartzman, and director Wes Anderson, as scriptwriters on a number of Anderson's projects, including <I>Isle of Dogs<i>.
The slow-motion exploding furniture at the end of Zabriskie Point were a clear inspiration for the music video of Fatboy Slim's 90s hit 'Gangster Trippin''.
Acclaimed character actor Ken Watanabe appears in Pokémon Detective Pikachu as Lieutenant Hide Yoshida, and lends his voice to stop motion film Isle of Dogs.

Little J & Big Cuz is the first Indigenous animated children’s series, with specific episodes adapted into language. Disney's Moana was also adapted into several different First Nation languages, including te reo: the traditional language of New Zealand's Māori people.

Moana featured key Polynesian myths and legends. Taika Waititi consulted on elements of the story and also produced the te reo version, which screened for free in New Zealand. One of his first forays into filmmaking was Tama Tū.

Tama Tū took a serious subject – World War II – and added a comedic riff by following Māori troops in Europe entertaining themselves before battle. Starring as one of the soldiers was veteran actor Taungaroa Emile who appeared in Whale Rider.

Whale Rider (2003) saw its star Keisha Castle-Hughes become the first indigenous actress to be nominated for an Academy Award in the Best Actress category when she was just 12-years-old. The next time an indigenous actor was nominated was Yalitza Aparicio in Roma.

Alfonso Cuarón won Academy Awards for Best Directing and Best Cinematography with Roma. He's a member of a group of friends known as the Three Amigos, which includes fellow Oscar-winning filmmakers Guillermo Del Toro, and Alejandro Iñárritu. Del Toro directed Blade II.

The success of Blade II was considered Del Toro's breakthrough into Hollywood. Playing Snowman in the film and choreographing key fight scenes was Chinese star Donnie Yen, who's best known for Ip Man.

Donnie Yen became one of the most accomplished martial artists in the world. Often showcasing his skill in films like Ip Man, he also frequently works as a stunt and fight choreographer like he did for Onimusha 3: Demon Siege.

name: Little J & Big Cuz to Blade

links.text: Sweet Country was based on the true story of Wilaberta Jack, who director and cinematographer Warwick Thornton had made a documentary about 10 years earlier. The feature was in competition at the Venice International Film Festival alongside The Shape Of Water.

A monster film with a romance at its core, Guillermo Del Toro referenced another film with many of those same elements in The Shape Of Water. The Amphibian Man is tortured and chained on a circular platform that invokes a key scene with Quasimodo in The Hunchback Of Notre Dame.

The Hunchback Of Notre Dame was one of the first classic Universal monster movies, with the Lon Chaney vehicle a huge hit for the studio. It was based on Victor Hugo's 1831 novel, which was also the basis for the Disney musical The Hunchback Of Notre Dame.

The Hunchback Of Notre Dame was Disney's 34th animated feature. The inclusion of three comedic gargoyles in the film - voiced by Charles Kimbrough, Jason Alexander, and Mary Wickes - was said to be due to the popularity of another Disney animated property at the time: Gargoyles.

Despite being target at children, a cult fandom among adults has developed for Gargoyles due to its dark themes and high-concept premise. So much so, Get Out filmmaker Jordan Peele is developing a live-action reboot.

Although better known for his sketch comedy, Peele became one of the most important filmmakers of his generation with Get Out. The film analysed race and racism in America, much like the predecessor to Candyman, whose sequel was written and produced by Peele.

Candyman was directed by Nia DaCosta and follows in the legacy of the cult original, which featured a haunting score from composer Philip Glass. He evoked a surreal world of nature and humanity with his music on the film Koyaanisqatsi.

Dragon's Lair was the first videogame to feature extensive animated sequences on LaserDisc. Animated by industry legend Don Bluth, game creator Rick Dyer was inspired after seeing Bluth's film The Secret of Nimh.
The opening sequence in the second season of supernatural series Stranger Things sees the young cast battling it out on an arcade cabinet of Dragon's Lair.

The Duffer Bros directly and indirectly reference many classic films from the 1980s. In a series two episode, Eleven sits in a darkened room in front of a static filled television, visually recreating the memorable shot from Poltergeist.
The young cast of Stranger Things reference the 1984 film as they dress up in the iconic suits of the Ghostbusting team for Halloween.
Internet comedy creator Neil Cicierega's video/audio remix is a hilarious meme-inspiring take on Ray Parker Jnr's classic 'Ghostbusters' theme.

Prior to starting his own studio, Don Bluth worked for Disney on several films, as well as contributing art and animation to other studios, including this film loosely based on the sequel to L Frank Baum's 'The Wizard of Oz'.
Dorothy was voiced by Liza Minelli in this animated film. The role would most famously be played by her mother Judy Garland in the 1939 classic.
Minelli was close friends with musician Michael Jackson, who played the character of the Scarecrow in this 1978 re-imagining of the Oz story - and which famously flopped at the box office.
Jupiter & Mars tells the story of two dolphins who inhabit the planet after humans have gone extinct. This is in stark contrast to Flipper, the heartwarming series about a boy and his dolphin friend.
Arguably the most famous game to feature a dolphin is the Sega classic Ecco the Dolphin, which after its initial ocean levels told an increasingly strange tale about alien invasion.
ECCOS is a six hour video installation work that utilises slowed down footage from Ecco the Dolphin to create a hypnotic and surreal visual experience.

Sadly the idyllic nature of Flipper didn't translate to real life. Trainer Ric O'Barry became an activist after one of the dolphins died in his arms. He was one of the main protagonists of award-winning documentary The Cove, which uncovered Japanese dolphin hunting practices.
The series received a reboot in 1995,  which was largely filmed in the Gold Coast, Australia, and was one of the earliest roles for actor Jessica Alba.

links.text: Rowan Atkinson's documentary on slapstick includes a sequence demonstrating how hitting different fruits can produce different sounds for punching. One, a watermelon, is also used by Toby Jones' character in the 2012 horror/thriller about a Foley artist, Berberian Sound Studio
Rowan Atkinson's physical comedy was enormously influenced by Jacques Tati, and Atkinson includes a number of Tati clips in his documentary on slapstick Funny Business.
In the middle of the century, Foley artists were in-demand experts travelling from studio to studio, like Toby Fox's character in the film Berberian Sound Studio.

Foley artists on classic films like Spartacus were never credited, making it hard to trace a history of the craft. One of the first people to be credited for making sound effects for a film is Benjamin Burtt Jr for Star Wars, but it would be decades before all Foley artists were regularly credited for their work.

The sound of laser blasters in Star Wars is so iconic that many Star Wars cast members now have difficulty not making 'pew pew' noises themselves while filming. In fact, Laura Dern can be seen in the finished cut of The Last Jedi mouthing 'pew' while firing her blaster.

The art of Foley is named after Jack Foley, who started out making live sound effects for radio. He later transferred his audio trickery to films, including on Spartacus, where he created the sound of an army on horseback using a set of keys.

Tacita Dean's installation artwork features the work of sound effects creator Beryl Mortimer, known in the industry as 'Beryl The Boot' for her ability to mimic footsteps. Although she is regarded as a legend of the field, most of her work (including her iconic work on 2001: A Space Odyssey) went uncredited.

Stanley Kubrick's 2001 and Jacques Tati's Playtime were both captured on 70mm film, which in addition to creating a spectacular image, gave more space on the filmstrip for the soundtrack, allowing them to include richer and fuller soundscape.

Though Ms. Pac-Man came first, the most famous woman in early videogames is Princess Peach from Super Mario Bros. While Peach wasn't just a reskinned character, she had no agency and perpetuated the damsel-in-distress trope that proliferated videogames for decades.

Metroid's Samus Aran definitely isn't a damsel-in-distress. While the bounty hunter plays as genderless during the game because of her armour, at the end of the game she's revealed to be a woman – the first empowered female protagonist to achieve widespread fame.
The personality, grit and bad-assery of Samus Aran was modelled on one of cinema's greatest female protagonists – Ellen Ripley (Sigourney Weaver) in Ridley Scott's Alien (1979).

However... if you finished Metroid in under an hour, Samus appears in a bikini when she takes off her armour. Entering a cheat code also allows users to play Samus, scantily clad, much like a cheat in Tomb Raider (1996), which rendered Lara Croft naked.

The overt sexualisation of Lara Croft, particularly her anatomical exaggerations, dogged the character for over 10 game titles and 17 years before the character was rebooted in 2013 with a less sexualised representation.

The focus on Lara Croft's physicality directly translated to the film starring Angelina Jolie. It’s been hotly debated about whether the film represents the character as an empowering female lead or object of the male gaze, with Lara often wearing a push-up bra.

By the time the Tomb Raider film franchise was rebooted in 2018, there was less focus on the character's sexual physicality and more on her athleticism and determination, with Alicia Vikander cast in the lead role.

By the time a new Tomb Raider movie was made five years later, the representation of Lara Croft reflected the most recent games' focus on Croft's ability, skills and athleticism rather than her body. It also followed the game's storyline.

In 2013, there was another milestone character in the representation of women in videogames – Ellie in The Last of Us (2013). Resourceful, brave and wise, Ellie quickly became one of the most iconic female videogame characters.

The Black Lives Matter movement exemplifies image contagion, where visuals spread with enormous impact. It began as a social media hashtag in response to the acquittal of George Zimmerman, who shot Trayvon Martin. Stay Woke: The Black Lives Matter Movement documents the movement's beginning.

The documentary follows the Black Lives Matter movement’s founding, including the birth of the phrase “stay woke”, which refers to a continuing awareness of social and racial justice. The Hate U Give deals with similar themes and was inspired by Black Lives Matter.

The Hate U Give was adapted from Angie Thomas’ novel based on her life. The title refers to rapper Tupac Shakur’s tattoo, which stood for “The Hate U Give Little Infants F**ks Everybody”. Tupac’s group Thug Life released Cradle to the Grave.

Tupac was also an actor and activist. Cradle to the Grave commented on racial politics and mass incarceration by drawing visual parallels between jail bars and a baby’s cradle. Thug Life explored similar themes as N.W.A., the subject of Straight Outta Compton.

Straight Outta Compton charted N.W.A.’s rise to fame and was critically acclaimed. It’s exclusion from major categories at the Oscars contributed to the #OscarsSoWhite movement. Ava DuVernay being overlooked for Selma the year earlier was also a catalyst.

Selma chronicled the lead-up to Dr. Martin Luther King Jr’s march from Selma to Montgomery during the Civil Rights Movement. Director Ava Duvernay also helmed 13th, an exploration of the legacy of slavery on mass-incarceration in America.

Ava DuVernay championed African American filmmaker Ryan Coogler's debut, Fruitvale Station. The film recounts the true story of Oscar Grant, an unarmed black man shot by police. The protests following Grant’s death contributed to establishing Black Lives Matter.

nodes.title: Stay Woke The Black Lives Matter Movement

links.text: Hollow Knight features a silent protagonist and uses written text for interactions with non-playing characters. This pays homage to older role-playing games which were made before recorded dialogue was possible. The creators wanted to “replicate the... wonder and discovery” of games like Faxanadu.

Faxanadu featured a nameless character just like Limbo, which helped popularised the side-scrolling genre. In Limbo, players must navigate the game without any spoken or written words. Unlike Faxanadu, this was a choice rather than the result of sound chips not being available.

Players learn Limbo's mechanics through trial and error; the story world communicated through visuals, sound effects and player interactions. The first 40 minutes of Wall-E has no dialogue, instead, the bleak vision of future Earth is communicated entirely through clean-obssessed Wall-E's actions.

Pixar may have taken some inspiration from Wallace and Gromit’s A Grand Day Out, where the duo encounters a silent, clean-obsessed robot on the moon. Gromit also doesn't speak, with the animators relying on character design and animation to express Gromit’s feelings.

This sitcom used food, family and traditions to call out existing racial stereotypes and redefine who we saw on Australian tv and how we related to them. Reality cooking shows like MasterChef reflect the diversity of Australian society with their contestant’s families and traditions celebrated in their food.

Like the MasterChef contestants the brothers in Big Night, set in 1950s New Jersey, cook beautiful traditional Italian dishes but the American diners expecting spaghetti and meatballs and it is a struggle to keep the restaurant open.
With beautiful shots of food being prepared, these two films have chefs who are masters of their craft who express themselves through their food but have difficulty understanding their families.
A traditional meal, be it the weekly banquet or an annual holiday feast, is the reason for families to gather and exchange news

What’s Cooking? uses the preparation of Thanksgiving dinner in four families to reflect the tensions between cultures and generations. Moonstruck links Important family conversations and incidental encounters by the routines and rituals of cooking and eating.

Food is also important to another American Italian family in GoodFellas, which features numerous scenes of the gangster characters cooking at home and jail, with a special cameo by director Martin Scorsese's own mother, who feeds the main characters in a critical scene.
The Sony DCR-VX100 was typically paired with a fish eye lens, which Yorgos Lanthimos uses throughout The Favourite frequently.
Both The Favourite and The Revenant contain almost no artificial lighting. Both films were lit predominantly with whatever light was already present.

Leonardo NoOscaro finally got his Oscar for The Revenant, which featured a brutal scene of his character being mauled by a bear. Tekken players could sympathise with him since the fighting game also contains a playable bear as one of its characters.

The Tekken series also has a playable kangaroo. While its kangaroo is alive and well, Wake in Fright features a controversial scene of real kangaroos being shot by real hunters. Animal rights groups endorsed the scene, hoping it would inspire banning roo hunting.

"We ain't huntin' him, he's huntin' us!" Wake in Fright director Ted Kotcheff went all-in on hunting when he directed the first film in the Rambo series, which featured Sly Stallone as a former Green Beret using guerilla tactics to outwit red necks.

The Bolex pillar H-16, which features in the Film cameras display, is particularly popular with home movie enthusiasts, who in 2005 found a new home to host their films with  YouTube. The first ever uploaded was of co-founder Jawed Karim's trip to the zoo.

YouTube was the by-product of accessible and affordable video cameras, as well as the popularity of DIY video. Likewise, the low-fi, found film phenomenon was an unexpected side effect of the 90s amateur movie making equipment, exemplified by The Blair Witch Project.

Like The Blair Witch Project, Iranian director Jafar Panahi's Tehran Taxi blurs the lines between reality and fiction when he pretends to be a taxi driver in Tehran. It's filmed clandestinely using cameras mount on the car's dash.

Searching uses footage filmed entirely from built-in computer cameras, screen captures and smart phones. Reflecting our times and lack of privacy left in the world dominated by cameras and digital platforms to share footage.

Tangerine is short entirely on an iPhone 5s and captures the life of a transgender sex worker using the 'home made' look of the cinematography to communicate the harsh reality, as well as the energy, of life on the streets.

name: Home movies, fiction and reality blurred

links.text: By breaking down movement into increments of time, Muybridge provided a new understanding of movement. His photographs formed a moving image sequence, an innovation that inspired the Edison Manufacturing Company’s Kinetoscope projector and their early experiments in film called Monkeyshines.

Fascinated by innovations in moving image technology, French film director Georges Méliès created fantastical films using special and theatrical effects. His most celebrated film is A Trip to the Moon.
Méliès's work inspired Martin Scorsese to create Hugo as a homage to Méliès and a celebration of the wonder of early filmmaking.
The automaton featured in Hugo was designed by celebrated props maker Dick George who began his design career working on Star Wars stormtrooper helmets at Shepperton Design Studios.

Star Wars productions have pushed innovation in moving image creation and special effects and are also renowned for practical effects relating to props, make-up and puppetry. In The Mandalorian, the beloved Baby Yoda is a (highly sophisticated) puppet.

Similar to each new Star Wars narrative, the numerous versions of King Kong have employed special and visual effects that build on a history of creation. The original movie is renowned for complex stop motion, in-camera effects and rear projection.

name: Innovation, technology and design: Edweard Muybridge

links.text: The Cuphead zoetrope merges the early moving image zoetrope technology with the 2017 videogame's beloved characters and animation style, which were inspired by early 20th-century animation aesthetics.
Cuphead's retro style was added into decades of videogame animation designs and fashions when the Cuphead characters joined other iconic videogame heroes in Super Smash Bros. Ultimate.

Cuphead's charming, early 20th-century style of animation has proved so popular that the game has been adapted into an animated Netflix series that proved the old-school aesthetic has lasted the ages.

It's fitting a Cuphead TV show has been made, with the series' style heavily inspired by animation pioneers Fleischer Studios, whose Out of the Inkwell (1918–27) film series established their animation aesthetic.

Out of the Inkwell introduced the famous Koko the Clown and Fitz the Dog characters, who later appeared in Fleischer's Talkartoons series. Betty Boop first appeared in the Talkartoons film, Dizzy Dishes with Fitz the Dog, who was renamed Bimbo.

Betty Boop became a legendary character, though in Dizzy Dishes she was originally a dog! In 1932 she evolved into a human, who Helen Kane – the performer who played in Nothing But The Truth – claimed was based on her... and she was!

Scottish filmmaker John Grierson coined the term documentary, but in The Drifters he used fictional filmmaking techniques and staged scenes. Likewise, Luis Buñuel took a surrealist approach to his study of people living around La Alberca in Spain and also staged scenes.

Not only did Errol Morris' seminal crime documentary also stage scenes, but it popularised the use of highly stylised reconstructions in true crime TV shows and docuseries, which are now a trademark of the genre.

Reconstruction is used with a difference in Ari Folman's Waltz with Bashir, which uses a dream-like animation style to reconstruct the director's experience as a soldier in the 1982 Lebanon War from a unique documentary perspective.

In this haunting documentary about participants in the Indonesian mass killings of 1965–66, perpetrators recreate their experiences in the style of their favorite film genres, blurring the line between fact and fiction, in what director Joshua Oppenheimer called "a documentary of imagination".

With a distinctly 'of its time' aesthetic, Basketball was also the first sports game where the pixelated sprites players controlled actually looked like people. In the classic comedy film Airplane!, flight controllers are seen playing the game in the background of a scene.

Airplane! was the product of trio Jerry Zucker, Jim Abrahams, and David Zucker who were known collectively in the business as ZAZ. They all went on to have successful solo filmmaking careers outside of their comedy films, with Jerry producing My Best Friend's Wedding.

The success of My Best Friend's Wedding – which hit during the rom-com genre's final hurrah – established the partnership between PJ Hogan and Jerry Zucker, with the latter also producing the director's dramedy Mental.

PJ Hogan wrote and directed this twist on Marry Poppins – Mental – which stars Toni Collette as a wild nanny who comes to shake up a family's life. Hogan's wife and longtime creative partner Jocelyn Moorhouse produced the film. Together they made The Dressmaker.

Based on the best-selling book of the same name, The Dressmaker followed a woman who returned to a small Australian town armed with her sewing machine and knowledge of haute couture. It stars Kate Winslet, who won an Academy Award for her role in The Reader.

The Reader follows the trial of a woman played by Winslet who is being prosecuted for war crimes she committed while working as a Nazi. It featured German actor Matthias Habich who starred in another well-known film about World War II: Downfall.

The classic backstage musical 42nd Street from 1933 similarly uses the kaleidoscope visual effect to convey the fast-paced energy of a Broadway production. Dancers kick and bob in complex dance routines choreographed by the legendary Busby Berkeley.

Busby Berkeley’s first picture in colour, The Gang’s All Here, is a bombastic wartime morale booster staring the Brazilian bombshell Carmen Miranda. The famous dance number 'The Lady in the Tuttie-Frutti-Hat' provides viewers with an escape far from the realities of wartime anxieties.

Featuring a similar stylised set is the spectacular dance number from Bollywood action thriller Pukar. With playful yet intricate steps lead actress Madhuri Dixit, who is trained in Indian classical dance, literally dances her co-stars off the screen.

Staged like a Berkeley musical, the ‘Gutterballs’ sequence from The Big Lebowski features Jeff Bridges and several Viking-clad Julianne Moores. Not only giving insight into The Dude’s electrifying subconscious, the scene also puts the Coen stamp on the classic noir troupe of the dream sequence.

Alfred Hitchcock hired surrealist artist Salvador Dali to create an architectural sharpness in his dream sequence for psychoanalytic thriller Spellbound. Staring Ingrid Bergman and Gregory Peck, the sequence likewise employs complex visual patterns to illustrate the main character’s inner workings.

Featuring in the Palais’ opening night program, the silent comedy Rough House Rosie starred Clara Bow, the silent-era 'It' girl who was one of the more successful stars to make the transition to talkies in the late 1920s and early 1930s.
Bow’s first talkie was The Wild Party directed by Dorothy Arzner, who eased Bow’s transition to sound by attaching the distracting microphone to a boom.

Dorothy Arzner created the boom mic when Clara Bow found the standing mic too restrictive. Designed to get the mic out of the way, the boom mic can sneakily appear in a shot, such as in an episode of The Mandalorian.

The Wild Party marked Clara Bow's successful transition to talkies, but many silent stars were not so fortunate. Singin' in the Rain’s story is inspired by the negative response audiences sometimes had to hearing how their favourite silent stars sounded.

In Singin' in the Rain, when the studio decides to make a musical, the atonal silent star Lina Lamont is dubbed with Kathy's tuneful voice. In the real-life production of My Fair Lady, Audrey Hepburn had her singing voice dubbed.

Debbie Reynolds, the talented singer Kathy in Singin' in the Rain, is the mother of Carrie Fisher, Princes Leia in Star Wars. While Fisher doesn't get to sing in Star Wars, she sings beautifully in The Star Wars Holiday Special.

Many critics felt Hepburn's performance of Eliza Dolittle was inauthentic because she didn't sing. Candice Breitz, in her multi-channel video work, explores the idea of authenticity and stardom by substituting her voice for the voices of famous female leads.

A barely visible boom-mic blooper is trifling. More significant is The Mandalorian's compelling soundscape, including the distinctive sound of the darksaber. The changing pitch of the original lightsaber in Star Wars came from recording the sound with a moving mic.

Like Jane, Ellen Ripley (Sigourney Weaver) was also an ordinary woman who rose to meet extraordinary circumstances, taking down both extraterrestrials and gender stereotypes. Though the role was originally written for a man, it's hard to imagine anyone but Weaver kicking alien ass.

Howard Hawks’ screwball comedy also benefited from switching title roles from male to female. With a spirited performance by Rosalind Russell, the character of Hildy thrived as an independent working woman able to take on a male dominated world with wit, glamour and a take-no-prisoners attitude.

Peggy Olson similarly triumphed in the traditionally male dominated world of 1950s and 60s advertising. Starting the series as a shy secretary bewildered by the flashy Madison Ave agency, Peggy blossoms over the series into a headstrong creative genius.

Deborah Mailman’s likewise delivers a powerful and spicy performance in Total Control. Her straight talking attitude allows her to sharply navigate her new political environment which is white, often racist, and almost wholly male.

The heroes in Hustlers were similarly underestimated and undervalued by the men around them. Tired of being pushed around, objectified and used, single mothers Romana and Destiny spearheaded a plot to take care of themselves and their families one greedy sulky man at a time.

Total Control star Deborah Mailman features in Sydney artist Heather Mitchell's toast portraits of famous Australian faces, which also includes Lee Lin Chin, Josh Thomas, Hunter Page-Lochard, Kath & Kim, and our own Katrina Sedgwick.

Costume designer Edie Kurzer's sketches and inspiration for Judy and Punch are displayed in The Story of the Moving Image. Kurzer often explores mood and atmosphere with images instead of using them as direct influences and also finds inspiration in objects.

Rather than draw what the finished costume should look like, True History of the Kelly Gang costume designer Alice Babidge uses sketches to distil various reference images into one thought. For Babidge, drawing helps “refine an idea”.
Costume designer Alice Babidge got her start at Sydney Theatre Company, where she was mentored by Fiona Crombie, production designer on The Favourite.
True History of the Kelly Gang stars Babadook lead, and Australian legend, Essie Davis as Ellen Kelly.
Director Jennifer Kent followed up her iconic horror debut The Babadook with moody chase revenge film The Nightingale.

Because of the size of the Australian film and TV industry, production crew often find themselves working together. This happened to costume designer Heather Wallace and set decorator Jennifer Drake, who worked together on both of these films.
Before working on Judy & Punch, Edie Kurzer designed costumes for the TV series adaptation of Picnic at Hanging Rock.
The TV series of Picnic at Hanging Rock is a direct adaptation of the same novel as Peter Weir's iconic 1975 film version.
Edie Kurzer's design materials, including costume sketches, mood boards and continuity photos have been displayed alongside the iconic costumes in The Story of the Moving Image.

links.text: The first film to feature synchronised sound was Don Juan, which featured an integrated score and sound effects with sword fighting.

The Jazz Singer not only featured synched music and sound effects, but the first recorded dialogue, with Al Jolson improvising many of the film’s lines, including 'You ain't heard nothing yet!', which seemed quite fitting for the groundbreaking film.
The Jazz Singer helped end cinema’s silent era and some silent stars had trouble making the transition to talkies because of their voices, which is spoofed in Singin’ in the Rain.
The choreography, costumes and production design featured in the "Boy with Luv" music video is heavily influenced by Singin’ in the Rain.
Singin’ in the Rain was a major inspiration for La La Land, another musical that explored the live of performers navigating the LA entertainment industry.

The opening sequence of La La Land looks like one seamless long take of people dancing on a freeway. Another acclaimed opening long take features in The Player, which also explores the Hollywood industry.
Halsey also has a cameo as herself in A Star is Born, another film that chronicles life in the entertainment industry.

We’ve been studying the stars for as long as humans have looked skyward. It’s no surprise that once magic lantern slides and projectors were used to educate people, one of the earliest uses were to teach people astronomy and bring the heavens to earth.

In 1902, magician and film pioneer Georges Méliès used his remarkable imagination and mastery of early special effects to take audiences on a fantastical trip to the moon where astronomers encounter cave-dwelling aliens after crashing their rocket into the Moon’s surface.

Liliane Lijn’s Liquid Reflections manifests the artist’s interest in astronomy and physics, and the relationship between art and science, with the rotating balls seen as lenses. These astronomical lantern slides are also lenses, and similarly express humanity’s curiosity in science and its expression as art.

It would be over 65 years until humans actually did land on the Moon's surface, when the Apollo 11 spacecraft touched down and united the world with an estimated 500 million people watching the moment Buzz Aldrin took one giant leap for mankind.

In 2019, the first-ever image of a black hole 55 million light-years away was captured by Katie Bouman and the Event Horizon Telescope, an astronomical event that captured imaginations like the first moon landing.

Many conspiracy theorists have claimed that the footage of the moon landing was faked in order to win the Space Race between the USA and the USSR, with further claims it was shot by Kubrick following his work on 2001.

Tarkovsky's Solaris was partly inspired by his disdain for other speculative fiction films, in particular Stanley Kubrick's 2001, which he described as 'phony on many levels' and 'a lifeless schema with only pretensions to truth'.

The bad guys in Bioware's sprawling space opera hide out on the event horizon of a black hole – with visual designs based on scientific predictions that turned out to be amazingly similar to actual black hole images captured in 2019.
There are many references to Andrei Tarkovsky's work throughout Mass Effect, including planetary bodies that mirror the oceanic world of Solaris and the name of the largest armour corporation.

links.text: Motion graphics studio Antibody created the mind-bending mix of divinity and depravity that features in the American Gods title sequence. They also applied their otherworldly aesthetic to cosmological horror show Lovecraft Country, which reimagines HP Lovecraft’s monsters to reframe race relations in 1950s America.

While Lovecraft takes a surreal approach to racial injustice, When They See Us focuses on the five defendants – all young men of colour – who are railroaded into a false conviction for the 1989 Central Park jogger attack. Michael K. Williams is in both shows.

One of the best TV shows of 2019 Watchmen similarly used a fantastical concept – superheroes - as a way to interrogate intergenerational trauma, institutionalised racism and American identity, in a story that features interdimensional squid attacks, catapulting clones and chemical time travel.

Watchmen was created by Damon Lindelof, who along with Tom Perrotta, also created The Leftovers, based on Perrotta’s novel. Dealing with a rapture like event that sees millions of people around the world disappear, it also uses fantasy to explore grounded themes like grief and existentialism.

The biblical rapture story hasn’t only inspired TV showrunners, but videogame developers too. The Chinese Room’s Everbody’s Gone to the Rapture lets players explore a small town where everyone has also mysteriously disappeared.

When They See Us was created, co-written, and directed by acclaimed filmmaker Ava DuVernay for Netflix. Her previous work for the streaming platform was the documentary 13th, which looks at the legacy of American slavery and the intersection with the mass incarceration of African Americans.

Tony Krawitz’s The Tall Man, based on Chloe Hooper’s book, explores the death of Indigenous man Cameron "Mulrunji" Doomadgee, who died in police custody on Great Palm Island in Queensland. Like 13th, it aims to expose the racist policies of police through documentary.

Legendary Yolngu actor and dancer David Dalaithngu has a career spanning five decades. His first role was in Nicholas Roeg’s Walkabout, where he starred as a First Nations teen leading stranded white children to safety in the Outback.

Five years after wowing audiences with his performance in Walkabout, Dalaithngu starred in the beloved Australian film Stormboy, where he once again serves as a friend and mentor to a young boy and helps him navigate life.

Dalaithngu reportedly learned English while making his first film, adding the language to the list of Indigenous languages he already spoke. Thirty five years after learning English, he narrated Ten Canoes, which is otherwise entirely in the Yolŋu Matha language.

Ten Canoes is the second collaboration between Dalaithngu and Rolf de Heer, the story of which was suggested to de Heer by Dalaithngu after the latter discovered ethnographic photos of his country in Arnhem Land. Their first collaboration was The Tracker.

The Nightingaleis set in Van Diemen’s Land, now known as Tasmania, and features the Palawa Kani language, a near extinct language never before spoken on film. Like Ten Canoes, the film attempts to preserve Indigenous culture through language.

Jennifer Kent’s follow-up to the critically acclaimed The Babadook, follows an Irish immigrant and Indigenous teen who track down racist colonial police in a brutal revenge drama that resists the dominant narratives of colonialism.

In The Tracker, Dalaithngu plays the titular character, who is forced to help a racist colonial policeman track down the alleged killer of a white woman. It, and Sweet Country, are ‘meat pie westerns’, which use western genre conventions to re-examine race relations.

Rolf de Heer and Dalaithngu's third collaboration, Charlies Country, was screened in the Un Certain Regard section of the Cannes Film Festival, which won Dalaithngu the Best Actor award for his portrayal of Charlie, an Indigenous man lamenting the loss of his culture.
The video that Celeste Barber is parodying in her Catch of the day video is of Russian influencer Anna Kanyuk closing her car boot with her foot.

Since 2015, Celeste Barber’s resisted the swarm of air-brushed and unattainable images of the Insta-famous with her #celestechallengeaccepted project. Instagram users upload their own pics to the hashtag, which often take aim at the Kardashians.

HBO's teen drama Euphoria could never be accused of featuring the types of perfect, athletic white teens that soaps from the past like Beverly HIlls: 90210 or The OC celebrated, with a cast that reflects society's diverse racial and gender identities, sexualities and body types.

While Keeping Up with the Kardashians has kept up with the rich, famous and aesthetically augmented for over 13 years, Australia's own answer to a wealthy reality-TV family premiered 15 years earlier with Sylvania Waters.

links.text: Cinematographer Robert Yeoman incorporated whip pans into Wes Anderson’s The Grand Budapest Hotel. The distinctively Anderson-esque camera move is often used to change from one character to another with a huge 180-degree pan and mimics the mechanism of panoramic slides.

The supreme 360-degree bullet shot was famously combined with slow motion, gun fights and time slice effects in The Matrix. To achieve the complex set-up, rigs of 360 still cameras were used to deliver lighting fast and seamless full 360-degree shots.

Complex camera set ups aside, the simple yet effective push-in shot used in Wings achieved a similarly immersive impression, not only giving audiences short vignettes of other characters in the film but drawing them into the dizzying inner world of a drunken Jack Powell.

Cinematographer Mandy Walker also relied on photography to explore Mia Wasikowska’s physical and emotional journey in Tracks, often using a close focus, low depth of field lens to separate Wasikowska from her environment and blur the background to pull audiences into her inner emotional state.

Director Reed Morano used a similar shooting methodology on The Handmaid’s Tale. As a cinematographer herself, Morano had a specific idea for incorporating handheld camera work. This placed viewers as close as physically possible to Offred, offering greater insight into her emotional state.

links.text: The documentary Chauka, Please Tell Us The Time was shot by refugee journalist and filmmaker Behrouz Boochani on an iPhone from inside the Manus detention centre. Artist Hoda Afshar worked with Boochani in the creation of her installation work Remain.

Iranian filmmaker Jafar Panahi was placed under house arrest and banned from filmmaking. The film was smuggled out of Iran in a cake, echoing Boochani's covert sending of footage for Chauka out of Manus Island detention centre.
Chasing Asylum explores the impact of Australia's refugee policy, focusing on the practice of offshore detention.
Musician and asylum seeker Mostafa 'Moz' Azimitabar shot the music video for his song All The Same from inside the Manus Island detention centre on a mobile phone whilst being detained.
While Chasing Asylum explores Australia's refugee policies, Ai Weiwei's documentary Human Flow explores the impact of the current explosion of refugees from a global perspective.
Weiwei's installation work Law of the Journey continues his exploration of the refugee crisis, and features excerpts from Human Flow, along with a 60 meter inflatable sculpture.

nodes.title: Chauka, Please Tell Us The Time

links.text: In 1963, the assassination of JFK was captured by amateur videographer Abraham Zapruder on an 8mm Bell & Howell home movie camera. The iconic footage has been shown, recreated and reinterpreted in numerous films including Jackie, starring Natalie Portman.

The film also faithfully recreates the First Lady's tour of the White House, which was broadcast on television in 1962, and offered audiences a glimpse into the private lives of the couple's highly publicised personas.

Widely known for his obsessive pursuit of Jackie Kennedy Onassis, tabloid photographer Ron Galella is often referred to as the 'godfather of paparazzi'. The title of the documentary refers to Onassis's directive to her security guard to 'break his camera'.

The term paparazzi comes from a character called Paparazzo, an invasive news photographer played by Walter Santesso in Federico Fellini's lauded film. The director compared the name paparazzo to a term for an oversized mosquito.
Lady Gaga's music video 'Paparazzi', starring Alexander Skarsgard and directed by Jonas Akerlund, was inspired by celebrity experiences with intrusive photographers, including Princess Diana.

La Dolce Vita and Michelangelo Antonioni's L’Avventura both premiered at the 1960 Cannes Film Festival. While the former received the Palm d'Or, the latter was booed. Six years later, Antonioni released this film about a fashion photographer who believes he's captured a murder on film.

links.text: The Larger than life display features Bill Hunter's jacket from Strictly Ballroom, alongside the famous Wattle Dress from Priscilla.
When the long-running BBC show Come Dancing relaunched in 2004, the word 'Strictly' was added, as a reference to Strictly Ballroom, to give it a competitive edge.

Strictly Ballroom was the big break for director Baz Lurhmann and costume designer Catherine Martin. It became the first in the 'Red Curtain Trilogy', their next two collaborations Romeo + Juliet and Moulin Rouge completing the trilogy.

Bill Hunter, who plays Barry Fife in Strictly Ballroom, also appears in Priscilla. These two films, along with Muriel's Wedding (which also features Hunter) are key films in the early '90s Australian film scene, known collectively by critics as 'The Glitter Cycle'.

Priscilla and To Wong Foo have suspiciously similar plots - three drag queens are on a road trip when their vehicle breaks down - but remarkably there was no plagiarism. To Wong Foo was well into production in 1994 when Priscilla was released.

Bill Hunter, who plays bus driver Bob in Priscilla, was inspired to start acting when he was an extra in On The Beach. Legend has it he saw one of the leads need 27 takes to get a line right, and decided he could probably do it better.
In the 90s John Leguizamo had a wide array of roles, playing to and against type in such films as Romeo + Juliet, To Wong Foo, and the ill-fated Super Mario Bros movie.

Strictly host Bruce Forsythe was inspired to start dancing aged 8, when he saw a Fred Astaire dance film. Astaire would later try to expand his reputation beyond the dance films that made him famous by appearing in dramas like On The Beach.
