To Wong Foo, Thanks for Everything! Julie Newmar

links.text: The Cleaners and Black Mirror both deal with the darker side of new technology. By merging sci-fi and horror, Black Mirror often introduces new technology to the audience only to undermine it with an inherent danger.

Kathryn Bigelow’s Strange Days merges elements of film noir, new technology and a Rodney King-influenced narrative to portray technology as a weapon but also as a device that can bring about significant cultural change.

Prior to writing Black Mirror, series creator and writer Charlie Booker wrote the mini-series Dead Set. In a not-so-subtle critique of Reality TV’s mass appeal, the set of a Big Brother-style show comes under threat after a zombie outbreak outside.

Televised social experiment Big Brother foresaw our willingness to surrender privacy on social media. Featuring strangers who live together under the watchful eye of the titular Big Brother, it is also one of the first reality TV shows.

Thirty years before Strange Days, Jean-Luc Godard incorporated elements of film noir with science fiction in Alphaville. Science fiction noir would often juxtapose technological advancement with social decay.

Giovanni Pastrone was a director, producer, actor and inventor who pioneered the use of diffused lighting, panoramas, grandiose sets, miniature models and a moving camera. Cabiria contains extensive uses of tracking shots and moving camera techniques.

In Cabiria, Pastrone popularised the use of the tracking shot, creating a dolly to move the camera through a scene. One of the most ambitious use of this technique is Russian Ark, which is comprised of a single 96-minute tracking shot.
In Phantom Ride, Crooks seamlessly stitches together a series of slow, mesmerising tracking shots that appear as a single continuous loop, echoing the one-shot tracking technique of Russian Ark.
Hudson's video for Bonobo's 'No Reason' contains similar framing motifs to Crook's Phantom Ride, but was shot in a single take using custom-built sets and cameras.

Contrasting to Hudson's use of a single tiny camera and customised sets, DoP Rachel Morrison utilised high-tech 'descender' rigs - cameras mounted on wires - and clever edits for the iconic multi-story tracking shot of a fight in Black Panther.

Much as the camera follows behind Okoye in Black Panther's fight scene, Resident Evil 4 is one of the first games to employ a permanent 'over the shoulder' camera technique, turning much of the game into a digital tracking shot.

Edwin S Porter pushed the boundaries of editing and helped develop techniques like cross-cutting and interlinked scenes which feature in The Great Train Robbery. The film ends with a bandit firing a gun direct to camera, breaking the fourth wall.

In both Goodfellas and The Great Train Robbery, outlaws pull off an incredible robbery. Goodfellas director Martin Scorsese makes the connection explicit by emulating the bandit scene with Tommy (Joe Pesci) reenacting it.

The final scene of The Great Train Robbery directly influenced the famous 'gun-barrel' openings of the James Bond films, beginning with Dr. No in 1962. The gun-barrel openings break the fourth wall and place the viewer in the perspective of a would-be assassin.
While viewers were placed in the perspective of someone aiming at Bond in the gun-barrel openings, the videogame GoldenEye put players in the perspective of Bond himself.

Like Goodfellas' gangsters, Ferdinand and Marianne in Jean-Luc Godard's Pierrot le Fou live outside the law. While on the run from hit-men, they often break the fourth wall and directly address the audience.

While Ferdinand escapes his stagnant life by going on the run with his mistress, Fleabag explores how the titular character escapes tragedy through casual relationships, often breaking the fourth wall to hilarious effect.

name: Gunslingers, good fellas and flea bags

links.text: Cleverman (2016) took the conventions of superhero storytelling and put them through an Indigenous lens, a move that was considered so groundbreaking it was nominated for a prestigious Peabody Award in 2017 alongside Beyonce's Lemonade (2016).

Beyonce's second visual album, Lemonade (2016) combines poetry, dance, and the moving image in order to tell stories about the lives of women of colour by women of colour. Melina Matsoukas - who directed Queen & Slim (2019) - was behind segments Formation and All Night.

The critically acclaimed Queen & Slim (2019) was a romantic crime drama that also examined racial politics and police violence in America. Matsoukas, who directed and produced the film, also worked on Lemonade (2016) with Lords Of Chaos (2019) filmmaker Jonas Åkerlund.

Better known as a music video director, Jonas Åkerlund brought his decades-worth of experience to Lords Of Chaos (2019), which was based on the true story of the Norwegian black metal murders. It was a busy year for Åkerlund, who also directed Polar (2019).

Based on the graphic novel Polar: Came From The Cold (2012), the highly-stylised action movie starred Mads Mikkelsen as a retired assassin marked for termination. Arguably Denmark's most prominent actor, Mikkelsen also appeared in the debut film from another Danish creative: Pusher (2016) by Nicolas Winding Refn.

Mikkelsen is considered a muse of Nicolas Winding Refn's, starring in four of his early films including his first, Pusher (1996). Groundbreaking Japanese video game creator Hideo Kojima also looked to Mikkelsen for character inspiration in the game Death Stranding (2019), in which he plays a pivotal role.

To bring the beloved children's characters to life in Peter Rabbit, Animal Logic used both practical and digital effects. It's the kind of process that has made them world-renowned since their early days working on films like House Of Flying Daggers.

House Of Flying Daggers was the highly anticipated follow up to director Zhang Yimou’s Hero, which Animal Logic also worked on. It starred Zhang Ziyi, who also plays a recurring role in the current Kaiju films like Godzilla Vs. Kong.
Godzilla Vs. Kong was directed by Adam Wingard, who is better known as a writer, director, editor, producer, cinematographer and even composer on lower-budget genre movies like The Guest.

A riff on the 'super soldier' trope, The Guest was the brainchild of Wingard and his frequent collaborator Simon Barrett and tapped into the aesthetic of 80s action flicks. It starred Dan Stevens, who would go on to spearhead the mind-bending Legion.

One of the most unusual and trippy television shows in recent years, Legion took a hard-left turn from conventional storytelling in the X-Men universe. Carlos López Estrada directed an episode from the final season, a year after the release of his film Blindspotting.

Mexican American filmmaker Estrada Blindspotting is a modern examination of race and racism in Oakland. Both the film and TV series The Good Lord Bird featured Daveed Diggs, one of the breakout stars of the musical Hamilton and conceptual rap group Clipping.

The Good Lord Bird follows freedom fighters crossing America to end slavery in the 1850s. The first female filmmaker in Saudi Arabia, Haifaa Al-Mansour, directs a pivotal episode and made her debut with the documentary Women Without Shadows about the female role in Saudi society.

Ana Kokkinos started filmmaking because to tell stories that represent Australia’s cultural and sexual diversity. Her first film, the Sundance Audience Award-winning Only the Brave, explored those themes through the story of two young Greek Australian girls growing up in Melbourne’s western suburbs.

Kokkinos’ second film and first feature was an adaptation of Christos Tsiolkas’ novel Loaded. Like her first film, it deals with a queer Greek Australian character, Ari, “rebelling against the conditions and constraints his culture has placed on him”.

Acclaimed Australian film editor, Jill Bilcock not only worked on Baz Luhrmann's Strictly Ballroom (1992) and Romeo + Juliet (1996), PJ Hogan's Muriel's Wedding and Shekhar Kapur's Elizabeth during the 1990s, she also edited Kokkinos' Head On in 1998.

Head On star Alex Dimitriades worked on another Christos Tsiolkas adaptation, the TV mini-series The Slap, which also surveys class in suburban Melbourne and the migrant experience. The Slap follows different characters and their perspectives in the fallout of one incident.

Effie (Mary Coustas) stole the show in Acropolis Now with her comedic timing and trademark phrases "Hello! Good thanks" and "How embarrassment!", the latter of which a Greek Australian character in Head On recites to Ari (Dimitriades), demonstrating the cultural impact of the show.

While The Family Law is the first Australian sitcom about a Chinese Australian family, it’s not the first Australian sitcom to tell non-white Australian stories. It follows in the footsteps of hit sitcom Acropolis Now, which like Kokkinos' work, surveyed the Greek diaspora in Melbourne.

The Slap showrunner Tony Ayres has worked across a number of Australian film and TV properties, including another Tsiolkas adaptation, Baracuda (2016). He was also executive producer of The Family Law, another show that explores the immigrant experience in Australia.

Like The Slap, Seven Types of Ambiguity is based on an Australian novel (by Elliot Perlman) and presents different perspectives of a crime while exploring middle-class Australia. Kokkinos directed the last two episodes of the mini-series, which also starred Dimitriades.

When Will Smith assaulted comedian Chris Rock at the 2022 Oscars, Australian meme-makers quickly drew comparisons to the TV adaptation of Tsiolkas' novel. Ironically, Tsiolkas had just published a piece in The Saturday Paper about Oscar scandals.
Though not commonly used in feature filmmaking, the lightweight GoPro was used in a custom head-mount to film Hardcore Henry (2016), which was shot entirely in the first-person point-of-view (POV).

Prior to GoPros, the lightweight Red HD camera gave filmmakers flexibility and made POV shots easier. While filming Slumdog Millionaire (2008), camera operators captured frenetic action by running through Mumbai with equipment in their backpacks.

Hardcore Henry’s use of POV borrows from first-person shooter videogames like the landmark GoldenEye 007 (1997), notable in the genre for its realistic and cinematic style inspired by the James Bond film it was based on.
GoldenEye 007 is a descendent of Maze War (1973), a computer game developed by Steve Cooley for NASA which is considered one of the original first-person shooters.

Before more portable digital cameras, director Kathryn Bigelow spent over a year preparing the high-action POV sequences in Strange Days (1995), customising 4kg, 35mm handheld cameras to capture POV shots that would’ve been impossible with standard cameras.

Before Strange Days, POV shots were slower and less dynamic because of the size and weight of 35mm cameras. But they were still effective and terrified audiences in Peeping Tom, one of the first films to show a killer’s POV.
When Alexandre Volkoff brought the story of history’s greatest lover to the screen in Casanova (1927), he definitely needed colour, which he achieved through stenciling.

Casanova was coloured by Pathé Frères’ stencil process, which used a template for each colour and applied it frame-by-frame. Almost 20 years earlier, the British Kinemacolour system used red and green filters to colour A Visit to the Seaside.

Kinemacolor was an important influence on the popular Technicolor system, which went through several developments. The first, Process 1, used red and green filters like Kinemacolor. The only filmed produced in Process 1 Technicolor is The Gulf Between.

Invented in 1906 by film pioneer George Albert Smith, Kinemacolor achieved the illusion of colour by capturing and projecting black-and-white film through alternating red and green filters. The first Kinemacolor film was A Visit to the Seaside.
The three strip Technicolor method added a blue filter to the red and green system, bringing further depth and colour saturation. Becky Sharp was the first feature filmed in three-strip Technicolor.

Technicolor’s popularity declined from the late-1950s because it took longer to make prints than it did from the one-strip colour processes that had been developed. One of the last Hollywood hits printed with Technicolor was The Godfather: Part II.

When the British Technicolor factory shut down, its equipment was shipped to China, where filmmakers used Technicolor in the 1990s. Zhang Yimou used the process in Ju Dou, with the vibrant colours rendered in Technicolor intrinsic to the film's symbolism.

Technicolor discontinued its process again in 2002 after being bought by French company Thomson. But Thomson renamed itself Technicolor SA and is still involved in media production, helping make videogames like Capcom's Resident Evil 2 remake.
The first live-action feature to be filmed in Technicolor was Becky Sharp, an adaptation of William Thackery's acclaimed novel Vanity Fair.
When most people think about Technicolor, they think about The Wizard of Oz. As Dorothy steps out of her dreary sepia life and into Munchkinland, she’s enveloped in glorious Technicolor.

One of the first and most iconic films released in Technicolor was The Wizard of Oz, though the three-strip Technicolor process was first used by Disney for their animated short film Flowers and Trees.
The Wizard of Oz embraced the effect of Technicolor to portray a dream-like fantasy world. Suspiria went a different way, using Technicolor to create a heavily saturated, nightmarish atmosphere.

While Suspiria was one of the last films to be made before the Technicolor process was phased out, The Aviator digitally emulated the look of Technicolor films between 1927 and 1947, which is the period the film is set.

Flowers and Trees helped define the visual style of early animation. Videogame Cuphead uses an animation style that pays homage to this Technicolor era, even using many of the animation techniques that appeared in Flowers and Trees.
Cuphead's charming, 1930s style animation has proved so popular that the game was adapted into an animated series.

This videogame supercut demonstrates that emotion is just as important to contemporary videogames as action. One of the most prominent games to embody both is Naughty Dog’s acclaimed The Last of Us 2.

Bioshock Infinite, like The Last of Us: Part 2, exemplifies how far videogames have come to include emotion and human elements in their far-fetched and fantastical stories. It's also in the videogames supercut.

In an alternate universe opened by the character Elizabeth in Bioshock Infinite, there is a Parisian cinema showing "La Revanche du Jedi", French for "Revenge of the Jedi", the working title of Return of the Jedi.

Open world videogames inspired Westworld, particularly Bioshock Infinite. When creator Ken Levine told Westworld creator Jonathan Nolan how much effort went into the dialogue for non-playable characters, Nolan saw humans tragically ignoring the AI personalities – something Westworld visitors do.

During the opening act of Return of the Jedi, fan favourite character Boba Fett is given a graceless goodbye when he hurtles into the mouth of the Sarlaac, where he stayed for over 20 years before reappearing in The Mandalorian, set five years after Return of the Jedi.

Before The Mandalorian, Boba Fett did turn up a child in the prequels and in the Clone Wars show, but he was believed dead those 20 years. He also turned up in the videogame Star Wars: Battlefront, but it focused on action rather than narrative.

According to the original actor to play Boba Fett, Jeremy Bulloch, the cult favourite Star Wars character is based on Clint Eastwood's anti-hero gunslinger, the Man with No Name, who first appeared in Sergio Leone's A Fistful of Dollars.

Videogames are becoming more like film and TV, with writers and actors turning up to work on games. Westworld actors Shannon Woodward and Jeffrey Wright both voice characters in The Last of Us 2, while writer Halley Gross was narrative lead for Part 2.

nodes.title: The Last of Us Part II

links.text: The titular characters of Judy and Punch make a living performing with marionettes. Jim Henson’s The Muppets combine traditional puppetry forms and it’s believed their name is a combination of marionette and puppet.

A young Jim Henson admired ventriloquist Edgar Bergen, a radio star who went on to appear in film and TV with his “dummy”, Charlie McCarthy. The duo appeared on The Muppet Show and made their final appearance in The Muppet Movie.

While Charlie McCarthy was cheeky but benign, the dummy Hugo in Dead of Night (1945) is murderous. The horrific scene where the ventriloquist dummy strangles a character paved the way for many more malevolent onscreen dummies and puppets.

Doctor Who has featured several mechanicals toys coming to life but one of the creepiest is the Smilers, who appear in the episode 'The Beast Below'. Resembling carnival amusements, their smiling faces rotate into ghoulish grimaces just before the worst happens…

Chitty Chitty Bang Bang reverses the concept of living puppets, mannequins and dolls with Dick Van Dyke and Sally Ann Howes disguising themselves as mechanical toys to get into the castle to rescue the children.
Like the actors in Chitty Chitty Bang Bang, NSYNC appear as toys in their music video for 'Bye Bye Bye'. As dancing marionettes, they’re manipulated by a puppeteer, who begins to cut their strings.

nodes.title: Judy (Mia Wasikowski) puppeteer costume and double's duplicate

name: Like a puppet on a string

links.text: Like The Last Emperor, costume colour is intrinsic to The Favourite’s themes. While crimson and orange represent the majesty and innocence of the Emperor’s childhood, the black and white costumes in The Favourite represent courtly intrigue and symbolise chess pieces.

The Last Emperor costume designer James Acheson won an Academy Award for his work on the film but is no stranger to extravagant costumes or accolades, also winning another Oscar a year later for period drama Dangerous Liasons.

The seductive tale of backstabbing set among high society was transported from pre-Revolution Paris to Manhattan in 1999 American teen movie update, Cruel Intentions. Actor Swoosie Kurtz also appears in both films.

Though the Stephen Frears's Oscar-winning 1988 version of Dangerous Liaisons is the most famous, the first adaptation of Choderlos de Laclos' novel is Roger Vadim's French version from 1959, starring Jeanne Moreau and Gérard Philipe.

Both Les Liaisons Dengereuses and Cruel Intentions transport the time period of the source material to a contemporary era and scene - the French bourgeois milieu of late-1950s France and New York's Upper West Side in the late 1990s.

Cruel Intentions is considered an R-rated (in America) b-grade or cult masterpiece depending on who you ask, but its influence is undeniable. The dark drama portrayed teens as being amoral, predatory and sexual, qualities that modern shows like Riverdale explore.
While Olivia Coleman won an Oscar for her portrayal of Queen Anne in The Favourite, her next royal role would be as Queen Elizabeth II in season three and four of Netflix’s The Crown.

Make-up artist Ivana Primorac helped actor John Lithgow transform into British Prime Minister Winston Churchill in The Crown. She also transformed Gary Oldman into Churchill in Darkest Hour and won a Best Make-up BAFTA for her effort.

name: Power and privilege, monarchy and make-up

links.text: The actors playing the Kelly Gang formed a punk band, wrote an album and performed live before filming started. Similarly the cast of the band Sex Bob-omb in Scott Pilgrim vs. the World rehearsed songs for weeks before filming.

The fight sequences in Scott Pilgrim vs. the World reference a number of videogames, most notably including classic arcade franchise Street Fighter – Scott uses a Shoryuken attack during his battle with Matthew Patel.

The 1 vs 1 battle structure in Street Fighter II is borrowed by NZ arts collective FAFSWAG in their interactive documentary fafswagvogue. Viewers choose a dancer to vogue in a one-on-one battle, and a venue, just like in Street Fighter.

The vogue battling depicted in Pose has been adopted by queer communities around the world, including FAFSWAG, a collective of queer Maori and Pasifika activists in New Zealand. Their practice crosses theatre, film, community events, and interactive digital media, such as their documentary FAFSWAGVOGUE.COM
Both series deal with historical pioneers of gender fluidity; Gentleman Jack in 1830s York, Pose in the New York ballroom culture of the late 1980s and early 1990s.

Through Alice Babidge's costumes, a softer genderfluidity and queering of a hypermasculine Australian icon – Ned Kelly – is presented. Gentleman Jack is based on Anne Lister, a 19th-century landowner whose masculine appearance and rejection of gender roles caused a ruckus.

True History of the Kelly Gang

links.text: Tony Thorne was inspired by the colour palette of Steven Universe's background art when creating Little J and Big Cuz'. Like the latter, the first Australian animated series for First Peoples children, Steven Universe is acclaimed for leading mainstream representation of queer and gender-expansive characters.
Steven Universe showrunner Rebecca Sugar nearly wore out the tape of their VHS copy of Russian animated film The Snow Queen as a child, which became a major influence on Steven Universe.
In the early 1960s, Princess Mononoke director Hiyao Miyazaki, was disillusioned with animation, and was about to quit until he saw The Snow Queen, which has since become one of his favourite films.

Just as Never Alone's Nuna and her white fox are assisted by local Iñupiat spirits, in a retelling of the traditional story Kunuuksaayuka, Princess Mononoke's San and her wolf familiar work alongside forest spirits to help restore balance to the world.
Never Alone's main character Nuna and her white Arctic fox trek through the Alaskan snow, not unlike Lyrsa and her familiar Pan, who trek through snowy landscapes in His Dark Materials.

Little J and Big Cuz ceebrates First Peoples traditions, culture and stories, and has been translated into local languages. Similarly, Never Alone (Kisima Inŋitchuŋa), made by Alaska's Iñupiaq people, passes down traditional oral stories through a new medium.

Child star Harry Melling, who portrayed Dudley Dursley in the Harry Potter series, has gone on to a range of interesting roles, including the Coen Brothers' The Ballad of Buster Scruggs and the HBO series His Dark Materials.
Before creating Little J and Big Cuz, Tony Thorne worked as an animator on Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets, most notably animating Malfoy's snake in his face-off against Harry.

Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets

links.text: The first objects that visitors encounter in The Story of the Moving Image trace the evolution of stereoscopic viewers, from the antique to the easy and innovative, like Google Cardboard.

Stereoscopic viewers gave users an immersive connection to new and different places. With the invention of the cinematograph, the Lumière brothers transported viewers by projecting images of the world onto a screen in a darkened room.

In 1934, the Lumières experimented with a 3D version of The Arrival of a Train. In the 1950s, television’s popularity encouraged filmmakers to develop the immersive possibilities of 3D. House of Wax was made in 3D colour with stereophonic sound.

Along with 3D, the film industry also competed with TV by developing spectacular screening formats. Made using the three-strip Cinerama process, How the West Was Won was projected onto a huge curved screen, transporting the audience into another world.

While the film industry was experimenting with cinematic spectacle, Tru-Vue and Viewmaster offered TV viewers a transmedia experience. Viewing cards offered 3D images of an episode relating to popular television series, such as The Adventures of Wild Bill Hickok.

Stereoscopic viewers gave TV audiences a chance to perceive popular characters and events within a (static) 3D environment. In the VR version of Minecraft players can enter the familiar Minecraft world and see it from an entirely different perspective.

nodes.title: The Arrival of a Train at La Ciotat
The Adventures of Wild Bill Hickok

links.text: By the time the 60s rolled around, TV had embedded itself into the hearts and homes of Australians, but most of the shows were syndicated from overseas with government bodies pushing for more local shows like Skippy The Bush Kangaroo.

Skippy was like many popular shows at the time about animals helping their owners. It had a massive international audience of 300m viewers per week but eventually ended, unlike Four Corners, which also started in the 60s and still runs.

Four Corners has been exposing scandals, triggering inquiries, firing debate and confronting taboos since it debuted. Homicide debuted a few years later and was one of Australia's first crime dramas targeted at a mature audience.

Homicide became a TV phenomenon, airing 509 episodes. It also became a training ground for a whole wave of Australian filmmakers who got their start directing on the program, such as George Miller, Colin Eggleston and Simon Wincer who was behind The Phantom.

The Phantom was a comic book blockbuster and the first film shot at Village Roadshow Studios on the Gold Coast. Star Billy Zane fell in love with the character after being introduced to The Phantom comic strip while on the set of Dead Calm.

Phillip Noyce had been working in industry since the 60s when he had his breakthrough with Dead Calm, which helped launch the careers of Billy Zane and Nicole Kidman, who also starred in police drama Destroyer from Karyn Kusama.

With more structures to support the local industry, Australian productions started to push the boundaries in the 70s, particularly the adults-only Number 96, which featured saucy storylines, satirical humour, and scandalous nudity.

Number 96 was one of the first Aussie shows to tackle themes like sex, adultery, racism, drug use, homosexuality, and more. Meanwhile on ABC, Countdown became essential for anyone wanting to be 'cool' as Ian 'Molly’ Meldrum covered the latest music news.

For 13 years Countdown featured live performances from local and overseas acts, not to mention helping launch the careers of the likes of Skyhooks, Kylie Minogue, AC/DC and INXS. Minogue got her start on TV in the 70s with The Sullivans.
Kylie would later go on to star in more popular Australian soap Neighbours and many films over her career, including her friend and frequent collaborator Nick Cave's 20,000 Days on Earth.

20,000 Days on Earth, which is a blend of doco and feature. Cave has worked in film throughout his career, which started in 1979 - the same year SBS launched, with SBS World News following just after.

With SBS World News, public broadcaster SBS was founded with the aim of servicing and highlighting multicultural Australia. The Feed was a twist on the news programming the station is known for, with a cast of presenters and producers covering stories relevant to younger Australians.
The Feed was part of a new wave of SBS programming that included scripted series such as The Family Law and Sunshine, which was set within the South-Sudanese Australian community.

With Y2K in the rear view, it was time for for something noice, different, unusual. Enter Full Frontal alumni Gina Riley and Jane Turner’s hugely popular Kath & Kim, a cross between the mockumentary and sitcom formats.

Kath & Kim followed a mother and daughter combo as they negotiated life in middle-class Melbourne. The year it ended, East West 101 began airing on SBS and presented a clash of cultures based on real police cases in Sydney.

East West 101was an extremely influential police drama for its inclusivity. Starring Don Hany and Aaron Fa'aoso, it was based on the real-life experiences of Sydney detectives. Similarly Underbelly became a massive hit for channel Nine, with all seasons based on notorious crime cases.

With its first season focusing on Melbourne's gangland wars, Underbelly has been one of Australia's enduring crime shows with the anthology series switching up the setting, characters and crimes per season.

The music video for 'My People' opens with The Presets on what appears to be the surface of the moon, before the duo become duplicated over and over. The aesthetic of the clip and their sound directly influenced The Black Eyed Peas hit 'Boom Boom Pow'.

'Boom Boom Pow' marked a huge shift for hip hop act The Black Eye Peas. The video clip, song and album The E.N.D saw them move into electronica, which front man will.i.am said was due to his exposure to The Presets while filming X-Men Origins: Wolverine in Australia.

Several tracks off The Presets album Apocalypso hit big towards the end of 2007 and duration of 2008, which was when The Black Eyed Peas member will.i.am was filming a supporting role in X-Men Origins: Wolverine. It was directed by Tsotsi (2005) filmmaker Gavin Wood.

South African crime drama Tsotsi (2005) won the Oscar for Best Foreign Language Film at the 2006 Academy Awards, the same year another African-set crime drama won big: Rachel Weisz for best supporting actress in The Constant Gardener.

Nominated for four Academy Awards, The Constant Gardener was adapted from the 2001 John le Carré novel of the same name. A former spy, several of his books have been made into award-winning films including The Spy Who Came In from the Cold .

The first John le Carré adaptation for the big screen, The Spy Who Came In from the Cold starred Richard Burton in a role that continued a streak where he was nominated for an Academy Award three years in a row including for lead actor Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf? .
Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf? was an Academy Award-winning film based on the classic play of the same name. Nicole Kidman won an Oscar for her portrayal of Virginia Woolf in The Hours.

The Spy Who Came in from the Cold

links.text: While heralded as a new star on the horizon, Hepburn went onto appear in several box office flops before securing the rights to the remarriage comedy, The Philadelphia Story and firmly returning to box office glory.

Hepburn “lined up on the side of trousers for women” during a time when women could be arrested for wearing pants in public. Dietrich often challenged gender conformity on and off the screen, with Morocco famous for Dietrich performing cabaret in a man's tailcoat.

In Martin Scorsese's biopic of Howard Hughes, Hepburn was portrayed by Cate Blanchett, who won the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress, marking the first instance where the portrayal of an Academy Award-winning actress itself won an Academy Award.
No stranger to portraying real world leading ladies, Cate Blanchett also starred in the suspenseful historical drama Elizabeth in the title role of Queen Elizabeth I of England.
Blanchett once more flexed her biopic muscles in I'm Not There, this time, however, portraying Bob Dylan alongside five other actors all depicting different facets of Dylan's public personas.

Mrs. America is a miniseries about the political movement to pass the Equal Rights Amendment in the US. Loosely based on conservative Phyllis Schlafly (Blanchett) who led an unexpected backlash. Fellow Australian, Rose Byrne stars as Gloria Steinem in the story of the 1970s culture wars.

Marlene Dietrich shot to international acclaim in Germany's first feature-length talkie The Blue Angel directed by Josef von Sternberg, who brought Dietrich to Paramount. Dietrich and Sternberg would work on seven films together before their collaboration ended in 1935.

name: Wearing the pants, ladies who lead

links.text: Christmas Crackers, a 1945 amateur film shot and edited by Australian soldier John Sprod utilised a Cine Kodak. It chronicles his experiences returning home from his service overseas during World War 2.
Attack Force Z is an Australian film depicting the exploits of the elite Z Unit during World War 2. It is most notable for featuring early performances from Mel Gibson and Sam Neill.
Australia's Secret Heroes is a three-part documentary series that uncovers the stories of the Z Unit by tasking their descendants to complete a recreation of their training regime.

Phillip Noyce was originally set to direct Attack Force Z, but left the production after disputes with the producers. His upcoming film Rats of Tobruk explores the tales of the legendary WW2 Australian Africa corps division.
The tale of this division was originally told in the 1944 production starring Chips Rafferty, Grant Taylor and Peter Finch.

Harking back to early cinema, when filmmakers hitched cameras to trains so audiences could experience exotic travel, Daniel Crooks' artwork stitches together slow-moving landscapes and was filmed on disused railway tracks. It's similar to the slow TV phenomenon exemplified by Bergensbanen.
While Bergensbanen is an antidote to fast-paced TV, A Slow Year is a reaction to the fast pace of contemporary videogames. Deliberately meditative, the game slows itself to a kind of digital poem.

A Slow Year explores ideas of time – primarily through watching the seasons go by – Christian Marclay's The Clock connects with time from a granular rather than seasonal perspective, engaging audiences minute by minute through a hundred years of screen history.

ABC's Play School has always featured a clock, with the original rocket and flower clocks assuming iconic status and their removal represented the end of an era. Subsequent clocks have now become symbolic of transience.

IMAX goes back to 1967 when a group of Canadian experimental filmmakers debuted a retelling of the Theseus myth, In The Labyrinth, which was groundbreaking for using 35 mm and 70 mm film projected simultaneously on to multiple screens: a precursors to IMAX technology.

In The Labyrinth inspired filmmaker Norman Jewison to recreate similar techniques in The Thomas Crown Affair a year later. However, to expand their appeal, over the next 30 years IMAX became known for their documentaries like T-Rex: Back To The Cretaceous.

IMAX succeeded with large-scale documentary films to appeal to student and museum crowds but also mainstream audiences because of the impressive visuals. James Cameron was one of the first directors to realise the potential of the format with Ghosts of the Abyss.

In the wake of the box-office breaking Titanic, Cameron teamed up with Bill Paxton for Ghosts of the Abyss which saw them explore the sunken wreck for the first time. The documentary was shown in IMAX 3D, as was Cameron's biggest hit: Avatar.

Avatar, which was converted to IMAX 3D in post-production, is credited with solidifying IMAX's status in a competitive theatrical market according. It hit cinemas a year after The Dark Knight, which was the first narrative feature partially shot in the format.
The Dark Knight director Christopher Nolan wanted to shoot in IMAX for years before successfully doing so. Later, Adele's song 'Hello' would be the first music video filmed with IMAX cameras.

'Hello' made Adele the first artist in history to shoot a music video for IMAX. Another groundbreaking female is Cathy Yan whose movie Birds of Prey was released in IMAX and made her the first Asian American woman to direct a superhero blockbuster.

nodes.title: Birds of Prey (and the Fantabulous Emancipation of One Harley Quinn)

links.text: Costume designers Tim Chappel and Lizzy Gardiner took home the Academy Award for Best Costume Design for their work, like this pom-pom wattle dress, in The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert.
Parts of Priscilla have been editing into Soda_Jerk's mashup masterpiece, TERROR NULLIS, which like Priscilla, interrogates Australia's national character.

Drag culture has a long Australian history, gaining world attention with 1994's Priscilla Queen Of The Desert. The documentary Between A Frock And A Hard Place explores the production of Priscilla through discussion with its stars and producers.

Though they've got almost exactly the same premise – three drag queens on a cross country trip – both films were developed independently. While Priscilla was released first, To Wong Foo was already in production.

The soundtrack for Between A Frock And A Hard Place was recorded by Sydney music producer Paul Mac, who also created the soundtrack for Black Divas, which documents Australia's first Miss First Nations competition.

In Black Divas, the queens are told by their competition hosts: "Good luck, and don't f**k it up". This iconic line comes from RuPaul's Drag Race, now in its 11th year of exporting American drag culture to the world.
In 2015, Kitty Powers auditioned to be RuPaul's Drag Race UK ambassador. Kitty Powers is an English drag queen and game developer, who appears as herself in this dating simulator game.

The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert
To Wong Foo, Thanks for Everything! Julie Newmar
Between a Frock and a Hard Place

links.text: Poitras’s doco about NSA whistleblower Edward Snowden made her a US government target, reflecting the danger documentarians face telling stories, something also represented by How To Let Go... producer Deia Schlosberg, who was arrested while making a doco on the Dakota Pipeline protests.

Schlosberg’s arrest typifies police overreach, an issue explored through the exaggerated lens of Minority Report’s ‘pre-crime’ unit. The film depicts a future where arrests occur before a crime has been committed, thanks to the visions of a trio of psychic siblings.

Instead of imagining a future where people are condemned on suspicion and unsubstantiated claims, The Lives of Others simply goes back to Soviet-ruled East Germany in 1984. In the film, a Stasi agent surveils a playwright and an actress, but instead of condemning them for dissent, comes to care for them from afar.

Mr. Robot explores political and social dissent in a contemporary setting, taking inspiration from real-world hacker groups like Anonymous to tell the story of a mentally fragile hacker drawn into a battle with big business and government forces over the soul of America.

Although a rich topic for film and TV hacking had not featured as a prominent and powerful videogame mechanic before Watch Dogs, a third-person game where players remotely hack into an array of infrastructural systems to succeed in the game.

nodes.title: How to Let Go of the World and Love All the Things Climate Can't Change

links.text:
Kitty Green has stated that the "subject matter [she loves] to explore is women and their representation in the media." Patsy Ramsey was highly criticised in the media for her behaviour post death of her daughter with many outlets posturing that she had murdered her own daughter due to jealousy.

Similarly, in the death of Azaria Chamberlain, the case on which Evil Angels is based, Lindy Chamberlain, was accused of murdering her daughter and the media greatly sensationalised her guilt and non "stereotypical" behaviour post event.

The case of Azaria Chamberlain has since been used as an example of how media sensationalism and bias can influence a case. The findings of the inquest were broadcast live on television—a first in Australia.

The trial of Ted Bundy, one of America’s most notorious serial killers, was the first ever case to be televised nationally in the US. Conversely to Ramsey and Chamberlain, Bundy was, and still is, portrayed as charming and handsome in media. He was often described as "Kennedyesque" and "All-American".

The Vietnam conflict is largely considered the first ever televised war as many reporters were able to report on the realities of war first hand. This increased news coverage offered some of the first footage Americans would see of the war and is often attributed to undermining public support of the conflict. Hearts and Minds was released during the conflict and is a polarizing film that reviewers call either a masterpiece of political/documentary filmmaking or anti-war propaganda.

The game Orwell is hugely political and comments heavily on the power of media in influencing public opinion. In the game you have access to the use of an “Influencer” tool allowing you to create fabricated narratives you can leak on to social media, mainly through “Blabber”, the game’s equivalent of Twitter. Through this the player can spread a story that destroys public opinion on topics and the reputation of influential people who oppose the government.

Perhaps one of the most interesting examples of the power of the media is the 1938 radio broadcast of Orson Welles, War of the Worlds based on the novel of the same name by H.G Wells. The program has become famous for supposedly fooling its listeners into believing that a Martian invasion was actually taking place prompting claims of panic and mass hysteria.
Episode 290 "War of the Worlds" of popular show American Experience recounts and examines the impact of the infamous broadcast.

nodes.title: Conversations with a Killer: The Ted Bundy Tapes

links.text: Prior to Pokémon Go’s launch in 2016, game developer Niantic had released another location-based game, Ingress. A lot of the real-world information used for Pokémon Go was repurposed from this game.

In 2016 Swinburne University developed a location-based game designed for councils to increase social connection. Users were rewarded with unlockable augmented/mixed reality artworks throughout Melbourne.

Wayfinder Live encourages users to explore the streets of their cities for discoveries in a similar to street artist Invader's mosaic space invader works. Invader's projects were captured in his self-made short documentary Art4Space.

The OA, created by Brit Marling and Zal Batmanglij, uses a fictitious game called Q Symphony, its development and its effect on users as a major storyline. Q Symphony is a location based game with mixed reality rewards, much like Wayfinder Live

By the time Banksy's documentary Exit Through the Gift Shop was released in 2010, artists like Banksy and Invader had achieved cult-like status and exploring streets for their works had become a very common activity.

The affordability and accessibility of the Portapak enabled a video art revolution, coinciding with Second Wave feminism. Martha Rosler's Semiotics of the Kitchen challenges domestic stereotypes through a satirical Julia Childs-like cooking video.

38 years later, Russian activists and musicians Pussy Riot harnessed the ease of access to equipment and video hosting platforms to share a performative demonstration through music video "Punk Prayer - Mother of God, Chase Putin Away!". It was banned in Russia for criticising ties between church and state.

Kurdish Iranian refugee Behrouz Boocchani used an iPhone to create a documentary inside the Manus Island detention centre, smuggling the footage to filmmaker Arash Kamli Sarvestani. Like Pussy Riot, access to smaller, portable recording devices helped Boochani challenge political institutions.

Drawing attention to social and humanitarian issues in Australia crossed into videogames thanks to accessible open source coding, which was used to create Escape from Woomera, a game that exposed the desperate situation and dehumanising effects of detention.

nodes.title: Punk Prayer - Mother of God, Chase Putin Away!
Chauka, Please Tell Us The Time

links.text: Anamorphic artworks distort perspectives of history, both literally and metaphorically. France’s Napoleon III (who features in the anamorphic drawing display) and Italy’s Mussolini both suspended political freedoms to seize power. Kentridge’s work concerns Mussolini’s invasion of Ethiopia and highlights the recurring nature of history.

The idea of historic recurrence is taken up in the Italian mockumentary Sono Tornado/I’m Back (2018) which follows the premise that Mussolini has returned to present-day Italy where he is welcomed with enthusiasm.

Jim Carrey infuriated Mussolini’s granddaughter with an anti-fascist tweet of Mussolini and his lover Clara Petacci’s corpses. Bruce Almighty warns of the chaos unleashed by the selfish misuse of illegitimate power when Jim Carrey’s character inherits god-like power.

In an unsettling seduction scene, Carrey channels his god-like power to the accompaniment of Barry White’s 'Never Gonna Give You Up', a song that is also used in Baby Driver as a counterpoint to Buddy’s (Jon Hamm’s) performance of aggressive male power in the café scene.

Hamm is most renowned for his portrayal of Don Draper in Mad Men so is no stranger to channelling masculine aggression in an on-screen role. Mad Men gained positive recognition for including five women writers in its writers’ room of 11 individuals.

That Mad Men was recognised for including five women in its writers’ room of 11 highlights the power imbalance in film and TV production. Russian Doll, written and directed by an all-female team, represents shows creating more inclusivity and diversity in production teams.
Judy & Punch shows a remote town whipped into a frenzy over the supposed presence of witches, like in the iconic film adaptation of Arthur Miller's The Crucible.
Both Tilly (The Dressmaker) and Judy (Judy and Punch) are out for revenge in a small town in these two contemporary Australian feminist revenge films.

In both of these tales, a woman avenges the wrongs done against her family. In The Dressmaker, these are recent injustices, in Good Omens Anathema Device uses her ancestor Agnes Nutter's Nice and Accurate Prophecies to save the world.

These two contemporary prestige TV series are part of a growing trend for high-budget, online-first adaptations of existing properties involving fantasy and the supernatural. Oh, and they both have witches.
Very, very different takes on teenagers attending a wizarding academy.
Whereas The Crucible uses witch trials as an analogy for McCarthyism, Good Omens uses it to explore the excesses of religious fanaticism.

name: Judy and Punch and many more

links.text: The Jinx and Thin Blue Line are both documentaries that have gone beyond simply reporting on events and have instead become instrumental in rectifying a miscarriage of justice.
The Thin Blue Line and The Innocent Man both investigate cases of false convictions based on investigator and prosecutorial misconduct, as well as eyewitness misidentification.

Both The Innocent Man and When They See Us cover cases where false confessions and then convictions were elicited from susceptible suspects after repeated interrogation without counsel. In both cases, the suspects were easily manipulated due to age or low IQ.

Prejudice often plays a significant role in the targeting and conviction of suspects, as shown in both these works. The Central Park Five were all young black men, and the San Antonia Four were four openly gay women during a time of prolific homophobia.

In 2017, Southwest of Salem was nominated for an Emmy Award for Outstanding Social Issue Documentary. Crime + Punishment, a documentary looking at the real lives and struggles of black and Latino NYPD officers, won the same award in 2019.

nodes.title: Southwest of Salem: The Story of the San Antonio Four
The Jinx: The Life and Deaths of Robert Durst

links.text: In Her Story, players interrogate a woman suspected in the disappearance of her husband through an interactive full-motion video (FMV) narrative. One of its inspirations was the infamous interrogation scene in Basic Instinct.
In Her Story, players search through hours of recorded interviews to piece together a murder cold-case. Similarly, John Cho's character in Searching
The 2019 ABC online TV series Content goes further, telling a series of stories within one smartphone, using the viewer's literacy of social media as part of the storytelling.

While the stories of Content are very contemporary, Camille Henrot's Grosse Fatigue attempts to tell the history of the universe, through an unfolding combination of online images and footage from museum collections, remixed live in desktop windows.
Between 1934 and 1955, Natalie Kalmus was the colour supervisor on over 400 films made using the Technicolor process, including The Wizard of Oz.

Made in technicolor, Vertigo’s colour scheme was integral to the narrative. In 1983, Martin Scorsese was horrified by how degraded the film's colours had become, inspiring him to establish the Film Foundation to restore cinema.
Scorsese had simulated the look of 2 and 3 strip Technicolor techniques in The Aviator using digital technologies.

Celebrated American actor, radio announcer and voice artist Arthur 'Art' Gilmore lent his talents to the trailer for Vertigo, as well as An Evening with Fred Astaire, one of the first major TV shows to be recorded on colour videotape.

While An Evening with Fred Astaire might have ushered out the black and white era of TV, Zach Smothers reimagines and rebuilds classic black-and-white American TV shows such as I Love Lucy, revitalising them with vivid colours.
Like Smothers' work, Peter Jackson's digital restoration of WWI footage includes colorisation and even goes further to have actors voicing the comments made by the men.
Experimental filmmakers from Victoria, the Cantrills experimented with colour separation in The City of Chromatic Dissolution, shot on deteriorating film stock.

SAM (System Administration Maintenance), the AI in Observation, is directly influenced by the malevolent AI system HAL in Stanley Kubrick’s 2001: A Space Odyssey and gives players the chance to command the space station’s technical functions via data displays.

VFX technician Douglas Trumbull started work on 2001 by animating the futuristic ship’s data displays before designing the hallucinatory Stargate sequence. Over a decade later he contributed to the VFX of Ridley Scott’s Blade Runner.

The production design and neo-noir sensibility of Blade Runner have been cited by Batman Begins director Christopher Nolan as being an influence on his dark, brooding superhero movie, often credited with kicking off a slew of more realistic superhero films.

Like Blade Runner’s urban neon blight, George Miller’s Mad Max helped establish on-screen settings for dystopian stories with its apocalyptic wasteland. Director Edgar Wright recently commented that modern cinematic dystopias are either inspired by one of the films.

There are, however, other types of dystopias. Ryan Griffith’s Cleverman doesn’t just contemplate a broken future, but uses sci-fi and dystopian tropes to comment on the historical treatment of First Nations peoples, some of who consider white settlement apocalyptic.

While not a remake, Netflix’s gritty Jessica Jones' brooding tone and similar neo-noir style owes debt to Batman Begins, but was groundbreaking itself for featuring a complex, female superhero lead that paved the way for others to follow.

name: Evil AI, dystopias and production design

links.text: Each dog puppet in Isle Of Dogs was required to be built in at least three different sizes – sometimes five – to show scale in various scenes. Kim Kong was one of the lead animators and also worked on another dog-themed animated feature, Frankenweenie.

Kong is a world-renowned stop-motion animator and has contributed to some of the key films in the genre, including Tim Burton's feature adaptation of his 1984 short Frankenweenie and Aardman's beloved Chicken Run.

Chicken Run was the first feature from Aardman Animations, most famous for their Wallace and Gromit shorts. Their early work was influenced by Rankin/Bass, a production company who popularised stop-motion animation in the 60s, 70s and 80s with films like Mad Monster Party.

Better known for their seasonal specials, Mad Monster Party was one of Rankin/Bass's few adult-targeted features. The technique used to animate the puppets was similar to that pioneered by German filmmaker Lotte Reiniger in her fairytale retellings like The Frog Prince.

Reiniger's animation of characters in The Frog Prince was often a meticulous process, requiring repositioning frame-by-frame. The classic Brothers Grimm fairytale was later adapted for the big screen by Disney in 2009 with The Princess and the Frog.

Directed and written by the duo of Ron Clements and John Musker, The Princess and the Frog marked Disney's brief return to traditional animation before CGI films like Tangled and Frozen gained popularity.

Paulette McDonagh was a pioneering Australian filmmaker. Her third film The Cheaters was made as a silent film on the cusp of the arrival of sound. Retrofitted scenes with added sound failed to make the film a success.

Singin' in the Rain highlights the challenges faced by silent film actors when sound was introduced. Vocally challenged silent movie star Lian Lamont’s voice is overdubbed by the mellifluous tones of ingenue Kathy Selden.
The single from the hit album of the same name showcases the stylish duo who were subsequently shamed by the revelation that they didn’t sing their own vocals.
Celebrities compete for the honour of presenting the best lip-synced performance, which Milli Vanilli may have had a good shot at.

In Candice Breitz’s 30-channel video installation, Italian fans of Madonna sing all the tracks on the Immaculate Collection album. In the gallery, their separately recorded voices join in a characterful harmony.

The titular protagonist performed enthusiastically to audiences in the mistaken belief she has a beautiful singing voice and the people around her create a protective bubble to support her in her delusion.

nodes.title: Paulette McDonagh on the set of The Cheaters
Milli Vanilli: Girl You Know It's True (1989)

links.text: Yorgos Lanthimos cited The Draughtsman's Contract as a key influence on The Favourite – with its black and white costumes designed by Sandy Powell, biting dialogue and use of natural light, it's not hard to see why.
Michael Nyman's score from The Draughtsman's Contract was reused in Tristram Shandy: A Cock and Bull Story, another fast-paced UK period film.
Tristram Shandy, a fictional film about the making of a fictional film, borrows soundtrack from 8 1/2, another iconic fictional film about the making of a fictional film.
Fellini's depiction of a tortured artist was referenced many times in Todd Haynes' Bob Dylan biopic. Multiple scenes in I'm Not There are direct remakes of those from 8 1/2.
Both of these Todd Haynes films use a combination of colour and black and white to separate different time periods.

In The Favourite, Sandy Powell created black and white costumes for a colour film. In Wonderstruck, she crated costumes in colour to be shot in black and white. To test if the costumes would work on film, she took photos on her phone and applied a monochrome filter.

nodes.title: Abigail (Emma Stone) costume from The Favourite

name: Making films in black and white

links.text: Olivia Colman's performance as Queen Anne wasn't her last as a monarch – she also appears as Queen Elizabeth II in seasons three and four of Netflix's The Crown.
Before she played a young Queen Elizabeth II in The Crown, Clare Foy previously played Anne Boleyn in the TV series adaptation of Hilary Mantel's novel Wolf Hall.
The tale of King Henry VIII was less reverentially depicted in the indie videogame Fit For A King, with the tagline "Marry Everything. Execute Everything. SPEND IT ALL."

Clare Foy wasn't always such a sure bet – she (alongside Game of Throne's Emilia Clarke) unsuccessfully auditioned for a supporting role in Belle, inspired by the true story of Dido Elizabeth Belle, Britain's first black aristocrat.

Amma Asante's follow-up to Belle, A United Kingdom, tells the true story of Seretse Khama, heir to the throne, and later President of Botswana, who, in the 1940s, while studying in the UK, met, and later married, Ruth Williams, to great controversy

nodes.title: Queen Anne (Olivia Colman) costume from The Favourite

links.text: The Lumière brothers The Arrival of a Train at La Ciotat (1896) was one of the first films exhibited theatrically. Legend has it that the audience were terrified and ran to the back of the theatre as the life-sized train approached.
Martin Scorsese's Hugo (2011) was set at a Paris train station at the dawn of the 20th century in a wink to the Lumière brothers and pays tribute to the magic of early filmmaking and cinema.

Hugo was Scorsese's first and only 3D film to date and is a love letter to the moving image and cinema's first filmmakers. The movie starred actress Helen McCrory, who was one of the villains in season two of Penny Dreadful (2014–16).

One of the show's best episodes of Penny Dreadful (2014–16) was directed by Toa Fraser and took place in one room, with a showdown between Eva Green and Rory Kinnear. Fraser is best known for The Dead Lands (2014).

New Zealand rising star Te Kohe Tuhaka featured in both the film and TV versions of The Dead Lands as antagonist Wirepa. Yet he showed his comedic side in Find Me A Māori Bride, a mockumentary series that spoofs dating reality shows.

Jessica Sanderson directed two episodes of Find Me A Māori Bride's first season, yet her start in the industry was actually in front of the camera. She played a teenage girl in Warwick Thornton's critically acclaimed Samson and Delilah.

Thornton is one of Australia's most important filmmakers, with Samson and Delilah sweeping the Cannes Film Festival. He made a rare appearance as an actor in the short Bear from Aussie film collective Blue-Tongue Films.

nodes.title: The Arrival of a Train at La Ciotat

links.text: Before making a world of bugs for Hollow Knight, game designer Ari Gibson previously created a world of cats as director of animated short film The Cat Piano.
The side-scrolling exploration of Hollow Knight is chiefly inspired by Zelda II. Team Cherry drew on its world-building and spell-slinging combat mechanics.

Zelda creator Shigeru Miyamoto regards Zelda II as the only creative failure of the franchise. BoJack Horseman creator Raphael Bob-Waksberg has been open about his own creative failings as a showrunner, specifically in the colourblind casting of Alison Brie as Vietnamese American Diane Nguyen.

The Cat Piano, narrated by Nick Cave, features a cat detective solving the mystery of disappearing cats. Blacksad: Under the Skin is a point-and-click adventure of a 1950s-era cat detective solving a grisly murder.

The world of Blacksad is filled with anthropomorphic animals, just like Netflix series BoJack Horseman. Although BoJack's colour palette is much brighter and cartoony, the emotional tone of the show is much bleaker.

nodes.title: Zelda II: The Adventure of Link

name: City of animals (Hollow Knight - Production Design)

links.text: This cabinet in The Story of the Moving Image shows an Odd Studio team member transforming into a witch through practical make-up and prosthetic effects. In 2016, Odd Studio won the Best Hair and Make Up Academy Award for Mad Max Fury Road.
You can find out more about make-up and special effects in artist and costume designer Edie Kurzer's display in the Federation Square foyer.

Like the silicone scars on the War Boys that contributed to Odd Studio’s Oscar win, the prosthetic scars Heath Ledger wore to create the Joker’s savage smile helped the actor’s Oscar-winning transformation into the Crown Prince of Crime in The Dark Knight.
Fellow Australian actor Nicole Kidman also won an Academy Award for a performance highly assisted by prosthetics – she was virtually unrecognisable as Virgina Woolf in The Hours.

While Heath Ledger and Nicole Kidman took home Oscars for transformative performances, Catherine Martin has won more Oscars than any Australian for transforming actors through threads and sets. Her first two wins for Costume and Production design were for Moulin Rouge!

Kidman wore a prosthetic nose while playing Virginia Woolf but it definitely wasn’t as terrifying as the one fellow Oscar-winner Angelica Huston donned in Nicolas Roeg's adaptation of Roald Dahl's The Witches.

The Witches was one of the last films that puppeteer and filmmaker Jim Henson personally oversaw before his death and the effects were done by his company The Creature Shop. Similarly, Henson conceived of the puppet-performed sitcom Dinosaurs a year before his death.

When Martin won her second pair of Oscars for The Great Gatsby, she overtook fellow Australian costume designer Orry-Kelly, who had won three between 1952–60, including one for the Billy Wilder’s classic Some Like it Hot.

In creating the visual effects of the Spinners in Blade Runner, VFX supervisor Douglas Trumbull reused a lens flare technique he developed on Close Encounters of the Third Kind, which makes the models look more realistic.

Aside from the influential dystopian setting, Blade Runner is lauded for its striking visual effects, particularly the ‘spinners’ – hi-tech cars that soar through the streets and the sky. Spinner models were filmed against a black screen and then superimposed on the model shots of LA.
Spielberg's Close Encounters of the Third Kind had the working title of Watch The Skies, as a reference to the closing lines of Howard Hawkes' 50s sci-fi classic The Thing from Another World.

Before Close Encounters..., Douglas Trumbull cut his teeth creating pioneering effects for Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey, for which Trumbull claims Kubrick created 200 times the amount footage seen in the final cut.
Kubrick's use of miniature models in 2001: A Space Odyssey gave way to creation of large scale sets with fully-wired lighting in his later film, The Shining.

When the studio requested Ridley Scott recut Blade Runner with a 'happy ending', the director asked his friend Stanley Kubrick if he could use some of the helicopter-shot B-Roll used for the opening of The Shining, which made it into the sci-fi classic.

Not only is Doctor Sleep a sequel to Kubrick's film, both feature curious miniatures that echo the main character's emotional state. The hedge maze model in The Shining, symbolising the twisted mind, and the town replica in Doctor Sleep, symbolising Dan's attachment to his childhood.

nodes.title: Close Encounters of the Third Kind

links.text: Blade Runner had two videogame tie-ins. The first, in the mid-80s, was a run-and-gun arcade game with little to do with the film. The second is a point-and-click detective game, taking place in the same world and unpacking many of the film's themes and plot points.

The neo-noir cityscape of Blade Runner was a key influence on Pokémon Detective Pikachu. To achieve this, cinematographer John Mathieson, who had previously worked with Ridley Scott, shot on 35mm film, and used as many practical effects as possible.

To achieve the noir look of futuristic Los Angeles, Ridley Scott filmed on the New York Street set of Warner Bros backlot. A staple of hundreds of films, the New York Street set instantly recalls many noir and gangster films, including Angels with Dirty Faces.
Detective Pikachu is a point-and-click detective game, a genre that reached its peak in the 90s, with titles like Grim Fandango and Blade Runner.
Pokémon Detective Pikachu (the film) is an adaptation of the 3DS game Detective Pikachu.
In Detective Pikachu, Justice Smith searches his father's empty apartment, where a television is playing a clip from Angels with Filthy Souls, a fictional gangster film created for Home Alone.

The title of Home Alone's film-within-a-film Angels with Filthy Souls (and its equally fictional sequel, Angels with Even Filthier Souls) both reference the 1938 James Cagney gangster film Angels with Dirty Faces.

The 1997 Blade Runner game was one of the first to include a procedurally generated ending, where the outcome of the case is different each time you play it. Similarly, Zany Begg's artwork The Beehive uses an algorithm to determine the order of scenes.

nodes.title: Special effects in Blade Runner (Hades landscape)

links.text: Edie Kurzer's costume design for Judy & Punch involved several tests to ensure the fake blood on Judy's showed up correctly on camera. In Kimberley Pierce's Carrie, many tests of the iconic blood scene were done, to make it flow as perfectly as possible.

The high-gloss, flowing blood of Carrie calls to mind the 'Elevator of Blood' sequence from The Shining, which also involved weeks of preparation. Stanley Kubrick couldn't bring himself to watch the sequence being filmed, in case something went wrong.

To get the 'Elevator of Blood' sequence past the censors, Kubrick claimed that the red liquid was actually cordial. In Bram Stoker's Dracula, Francis Ford Coppola makes the blood look as inviting and drinkable as possible... like cordial.

Creating the dramatic flow of blood in The Shining involved maintaining the pressure of the blood inside the elevator. For the iconic blood in Sanjuro, Kurosawa used a hose of blood so high-pressured that actor Tatsuya Nakadai was nearly knocked off his feet.

Sanjuro's fake blood was a mix of chocolate syrup, for colour, and carbonated water, for movement. While Australian zombie flick Little Monsters also used a commercial drink (instant coffee) as a blood stand-in, it was for the opposite effect – to be as gritty as possible.
Quentin Tarantino references a number of samurai films in the Kill Bill series, and the Sanjuro blood flow crops up when O-Ren Ishii decapitates a Yakuza clan boss.

From Software's love letter to traditional Japanese combat, Sekiro, uses bursts of blood as a key part of the game mechanic, combining the release of figurative pressure (from defeating an enemy) with the release of literal pressure (of blood).

Little Monsters is a RomZomCom, or Romantic Comedy with Zombies. The first film in this genre was Edgar Wright's Shaun of the Dead, which also involved costume designers carefully adding incremental amounts of blood to the one costume – a continuity nightmare!
By using forced perspective The Lord of the Rings similarly manipulates depth to create the illusion that Gandalf is physically larger than hobbit Frodo. This effect is known as an Ames Room.

Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory employs the same effect yet instead of making people appear larger or smaller than others, here it is used to create a false sense of distance between the end of of a corridor and the other.

TV show The Time Tunnel likewise uses optical tricks, in this instance to create a sense of infinite motion and time travel. Representing the Tic-Toc time machine, a painted backdrop of black and white curves spirals inwardly to imply "the infinite corridors of time".

Time and attempts to control time is explored in The Gardens Between where instead of manipulating character movement, players have the ability to control time. It examines memory, friendship and nostalgia in a surreal dream like world of magical islands.

Perception, time and memory are also explored in Memento. The film unfolds in reverse chronological and follows Leonard, who suffers from having no short term memory, finding his wife's killer. To cope, he uses polaroids and tattoos as mental cues to decipher the complicated narrative.

Like Memento, sci-fi short La Jetée relies on photographs to investigate time and memory. Made up almost entirely of still photographs and an unseen narrator, La Jetée mines the main character's deep-seeded memory to send him back in time.
