The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring

links.text: Shadow play sets were used in combination with magic lanterns to create horrifying shadow shows called phantasmagoria. F.W. Murnau’s Nosferatu merges this spooky, shadowy aesthetic with the moody darkness of German Expressionism to create the terrifying vampiric scenes.

In videogame Alan Wake, players use light to battle demons called The Taken, which draw their visual style from the the kind of murky monsters that scared Victorian audiences in early phantasmagorias.

Apart from the visual style of phantasmagorias, Alan Wake also takes a lot of inspiration from David Lynch's Twin Peaks, particularly bizarre happenings in a small town. Not only that, it has many direct references, including an achievement called 'Damn Fine Cup of Coffee'.

Nosferatu's lead bloodsucker is Count Orlok (Max Schreck), who was based on Bram Stoker's Dracula. Count Orlok himself similarly passed on his popularity by inspiring What We Do In The Shadows' 8000-year old vampire, Petyr (Ben Fransham).

Wellington Paranormal continues exploring the supernatural happenings in Wellington, New Zealand, and is set in the same fictional universe as What We Do In The Shadows. Both shows are mockumentaries created by Jemaine Clement and Taika Waititi.

nodes.title: Grand Théâtre Fantasmagorique shadow play set
What We Do in the Shadows

links.text: Children's programming shifted in the 90s, with shows like Johnson & Friends kickstarting the decade with a premise like Toy Story: toys that come alive once their human owner isn't around, brought to life in the show by puppets.

Johnson & Friends was a big hit for ABC and was syndicated globally, with additional episodes commissioned for the US. The ABC also greenlit The Adventures Of Blinky Bill a few years later, based on the books by author Dorothy Wall.

While Blinky Bill was the cuddly kind of marsupial, the animals in The Ferals are anything but. These edgy, punk-rock rodents and cats still managed to strike a chord with audiences and were beloved by kids in the 1990s.

The first season of Blinky Bill featured a strong environmental message, just like animated feature FernGully, which was released around the same time. Environmentalism also featured in teen drama series Heartbreak High as students protested global warming.

Heartbreak High was unusual for Australian programming at the time as it was a teen-targeted show - performed by mostly teen actors - that tackled racism, homophobia, youth homelessness, sexuality and more. It was a spin-off of The Heartbreak Kid.

Alex Dimitriades played Nick in both the film and TV spin-off. Nick Lathouris, Doris Younane and Scott Major also appeared in both the film and TV series, and William McInnes starred as Southgate in the movie before going on to find fame in Blue Heelers.

Blue Heelers is one of Australia's most successful police procedurals and the equally most-awarded show in Logie history. It set up a formula of following the lives of emergency professionals that shows like All Saints followed.

All Saints was the Australian answer to ER as it focused on the Ward 17 staff at All Saints hospital. Although he was better known for comedic roles, Eric Bana made one of his first appearances on the show.

The popularity of the Pathé-Baby system, including the home projector, meant that many professional cartoons were released on 9.5mm format. This was one of the earliest ways in which people could bring the beloved mouse mascot into their homes.
Pathé Films hired the famous cartoonist Rube Goldberg to create animated cartoons for their newsreels. This rare footage shows him working on one of these early animations.

Astro Boy, which began life as the kami-shiki show Mighty Atom in 1957, was the most famous creation from Osamu Tezuka. He was highly influenced by Disney and the western style of animation due to repeatedly watching the reels on his father's Pathé-Baby 9.5mm projector.

Astro Boy is originally created by Dr. Boynton to replace his dead son, before being disowned. In Steven Spielberg's A.I., Haley Joel Osment stars as David, a robot built to be adopted by a woman whose real son is in cryo-stasis.

A boy with special powers and uneasy parental relationship is also central to Stanley Kubrick's The Shinning, with son Danny possessing supernatural powers that help him escape his father. A.I. was also originally a collaboration between Spielberg and Kubrick, but the latter died before it was made.

The Simpsons arcade in the Cartoon connections display is based on the longest-running sitcom in TV history – The Simpsons, which has been screening since 1989. It’s also been the basis of over 25 videogames!

Two years before Konami made The Simpsons arcade game, they translated another popular cartoon into an arcade videogame – Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. The two games feature the same game mechanics and almost identical play style.

Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles started as a comic book, but it’s been on screens since the 1987 cartoon. While the videogame and cartoon were light-hearted, the live-action film that came out a year later was closer to the dark tone of the comic.

The villainous Shredder and his Foot Clan’s hideout is set in the same abandoned cement factory that was used as the set for Dinohatton in the live-action Super Mario Bros. movie, another beloved property that's been videogames, TV series and a movie... that was critically panned.

The Simpsons spoof videogames all the time. Thrillhouse's 'Bone Storm' is a Mortal Kombat satire, while Crash Bandicoot is parodied as 'Dash Dingo'. Perhaps the meanest rib is the arcade version of Kevin Costner’s Waterworld that appears in episode “The Springfield Files”.

The negative reception of Waterworld in cinemas didn't stop them adapting the property for consoles and computers. Too bad the negative criticism followed across forms, with the Virtual Boy version in particular derided as one of the worst videogames of all time.

During Waterworld's troubled production, Buffy the Vampire Slayer creator Joss Whedon was flown to the set and spent seven "weeks of hell" doing rewrites on the script, in which he "accomplished nothing".

One of the films that appears in the Spectacle section of Moving Minds is of Rodney King being assaulted by the LAPD. The film was the first 'viral' video of police brutality and led to unrest across the city of Los Angeles.

San Andreas is a substitute for Los Angeles in GTA: San Andreas. Set in 1992, the game's end missions deal with the acquittal of two corrupt cops, which sets off a series of riots throughout the city in a story that draws inspiration from the Rodney King incident.

Spin features hijacked pirate satellite feeds from the 1992 US presidential campaign, inadvertently capturing candid footage of media personalities and politicians spinning the story of the riots – captured while they believe they're off-camera.

Falling Down explores issues of race and class in Los Angeles during the 1990s. The tension of the 1992 Los Angeles riots – sparked by the acquittal of the officers in the Rodney King trail – is present in the movie, which was actually filmed during the riots.

Like Falling Down, Boyz n the Hood reflects the political, racial and social issues of LA in the early 1990s but focuses on the African American experience, offering a more nuanced representation of life impacted by gang violence, oppression and inequality.

Twenty-four years after Ice Cube's film debut in Boyz n the Hood, his son Shea 'O Jackson played him in the N.W.A. biopic Straight Outta Compton, which features a dramatisation of the LA Riots. N.W.A.'s hit "F**k Tha Police" embodied the tension between authorities and minorities.

The Magnaphonic Projector helped usher in the era of "talkies", with this one used at the rural Tallangatta cinema. Up until the 1930s the theatre had mainly played silent films like Charlie Chaplin’s The Kid.
Written, directed, and produced by Chaplin, the multi-faceted performer also starred in The Kid as The Tramp. Arguably his most popular character, he also appeared in Modern Times.

Modern Times was supposed to be Chaplin’s first talkie, but he abandoned dialogue that he had prepared for the film as it went into production. It was also the last time he appeared as The Tramp. Richard Attenborough made a feature about his life, Chaplin.

Based on Charlie Chaplin’s own autobiography, Chaplin starred Robert Downey Jr. as the title character in a biopic that charted his career and personal life. Kevin Kline played Douglas Fairbanks, who like Chaplin was one of the early movie stars and appeared in The Mark of Zorro.

The Mark of Zorro was seminal to the genre of swashbuckling adventures and was the first time the vigilante Zorro – played by Fairbanks – was seen on screen. Almost 80 years later, Antonio Banderas had his Hollywood breakthrough with The Mask of Zorro.

It wasn’t until the one-two punch of Desperado and The Mask of Zorro that Banderas cemented himself as a Hollywood star. The character of Zorro was a large inspiration for Batman co-creator Bill Finger, with a reference to this appearing in Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice.

Posters for The Mark of Zorro appear in the background of a Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice scene and refer to comic book lore that speaks to the character of Bruce Wayne being hugely influenced by the character when he was a child.

nodes.title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice

links.text: Varda's early film Cleo from 5 to 7 is a portrait of a woman in Paris, portraying everyday experiences to reveal a character's inner life. It features cameos by Jean-Luc Godard and Anna Karina.

The Gleaners and I serves as social commentary and reflexive insight into the filmmaker, who appears combing her hair or filming her hands. These interludes were expanded in the The Beaches of Agnes, which chronicles Varda’s own career and life.

In 1962, Varda married director Jacques Demy, most well known for his musical The Umbrellas of Cherboug. The couple remained together until Demy's death in 1990, and his absence is revealed in photographs in Varda's autobiographical film.

Before she made Cleo from 5 to 7, Varda's first film was La Pointe Courte, a stylistic precursor to the French New Wave. Varda used a combination of documentary and fiction, which became a recurring theme in her work.

Directed by Jean-Luc Godard and starring Anna Karina, Pierrot le fou is one of eight films the couple made together during their marriage and after, with Karina frequently referred to as Godard's muse.
La Pointe Courte preceded the French New Wave films, such as Hiroshima Mon Amour, directed by Alain Resnais – who also edited Varda's first film.

nodes.title: Agnès Varda in Les Glaneurs et La Glaneuse (The Gleaners and I)

links.text: Popular films such as The Story of the Kelly Gang would regularly tour the country via travelling distributors. At times films would be re-edited to remove scenes that might be bothersome to different audiences, censoring the film's original narratives.

Booksmart was similarly re-edited for content when it was screened on US airline Delta. Controversially same-sex love scenes as well as references to female sexuality were removed or muted for the screenings, angering director Olivia Wilde and many Booksmart fans.

James Cameron's Titanic also faced cuts when a scene featuring Kate Winslet’s exposed breasts was deemed culturally insensitive to China's ban on pornographic content. Cameron felt it was better to extend the cultural impact of the film and so cut the scene for the Chinese release.

Arab American Anti-Discrimination groups demanded that lyrics to 'Arabian Nights' be changed because of its portrayal of Arabic people as violent barbarians. "Where they cut off your ear/If they don't like your face" became "Where it's flat and immense/and the heat is intense".

After test screenings of Babe: Pig in the City, proved too scary for children, director George Miller similarly needed to re-edit. Removing or lessening the intensity of scenes where the animal stars were put in situations dramatically close to death.

South Park: The Stick of Truth videogame was also edited for its Australian release. Objectionable scenes which included alien probing were replaced with an image of a crying Koala bear and written text explaining what was removed from the original scene.

links.text: Founder of Bophana Center, Rithy Panh is one of Cambodia’s most celebrated filmmakers. His 2013 documentary The Missing Picture was nominated for an Academy Award and uses archival newsreel footage with claymation to trace the director’s personal history and family past under the Khmer Rouge.
Golden Slumbers also explores a lost history, uncovering the Golden Age of Cambodian cinema through the recollections of Cambodian cinephiles, directors and actors.

Based on the memoir by Loung Ung, First They Killed My Father is a historical drama that follows the survival of Ung during the Khmer Rouge reign. The film was directed by Angelina Jolie, co-produced by Rithy Panh, and features an entirely Cambodian cast.

The Killing Fields was based on the real-life experiences of two journalists, Dith Pran and Sydney Schanberg. The role of Pran was played by Haing S. Ngor, a doctor and survivor of the Khmer Rouge regime, who won an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor, one of only two non-professional actors to do so.

Don’t Think I’ve Forgotten uses archival footage and interviews with musicians to retrace the history of Cambodia’s rock’n’roll music scene of the 1960s and early 70s, featuring a soundtrack of Khmer pop music preserved by Bophana Center.

Also directed by Davy Chou, Diamond Island is a feature film following a young teenage boy who leaves rural Cambodia to work on a construction site. Dreamy and meditative, the film explores family dynamics and contemporary life in Cambodia.
Directed by Sally Ingleton, The Tenth Dancer tells the story of Cambodia’s royal ballet dancers, as they resurrect the art form in the wake of the Khmer Rouge regime.

nodes.title: Don't Think I've Forgotten: Cambodia's Lost Rock and Roll

links.text: Chimerica (2019) follows a fictionalised story of a photojournalist who took the original Tank Man photograph, seeking the man’s identity 20 years later. The series explores themes of journalistic integrity and fake news.

Based on Graham Greene's novel, and a reprisal of the 1958 film, The Quiet American depicts the breakdown of French colonialism in Vietnam from the perspective of a journalist, based on Greene’s own experiences as a war correspondent.

Also focusing on journalistic integrity, Shattered Glass (2003) dramatises the true story of reporter Stephen Glass, whose articles for The New Republic in the 1990s were found to be fabricated, prompting a scandal over the magazine’s ethics.

Political thriller The Post (2017) tells the true story of journalists at The Washington Post attempting to publish the Pentagon Papers, regarding the US government’s decades-long involvement in the Vietnam War and French Indochina.

Writer of The Post, Josh Singer, also wrote Spotlight (2015), a drama about The Boston Globe’s ‘Spotlight’ team, and their investigations into widespread child sex abuse by Roman Catholic priests in Boston.
Journalists at The Washington Post were famously represented in All the President’s Men (1976), the critically acclaimed film about the Watergate scandal that brought down Richard Nixon presidency.
You will see me creator Sari Braithwaite directed the visual essay film [CENSORED] (2018), compiling a montage of clips removed from feature films by Australian censors between 1951 and 1978.

Artist duo Soda_Jerk’s controversial TERROR NULLIUS (2018) also mines Australian cinematic history to create a mash-up of scenes that offer a searing critique of Australia’s systemic racism and refugee policy, which was built on the lie of terra nullius.

Arthur Jafa’s first foray into visual art, Love is the message, the message is Death (2016), achieved critical acclaim and crystallised the collective experience of black America through a similar use of montage and mash-up of found footage, home movies and pop culture.

Compiled from archival footage, accompanied with voiceover by director Adam Curtis, HyperNormalisation (2016) also uses montage to explore corporatisation, conspiracy theories and cyberspace in the modern world.

Michael Moore’s music video for Rage Against the Machine’s ‘Testify’ (2000) features clips of then presidential candidates George W Bush and Al Gore, spliced together with found footage of modern industrialisation, cities and conflicts in a style reminiscent of the one HyperNormalisation would adopt years later.

nodes.title: Love Is the Message, the Message Is Death

links.text: Black Man’s Houses is a documentary that captures the struggle for recognition of Tasmanian Aboriginal people in their fight to reclaim the unmarked graves of their Ancestors who were removed from their lands and taken to Wybalenna on Flinders Island.

In 2017, Julie Gough, a Tasmanian Aboriginal artist and descendent of Dalrymple Briggs who successfully petitioned for her mother to be released from Wybalenna in 1841, visited and filmed sites across Tasmania where colonial violence was perpetrated against Aboriginal people.

This documentary investigates what happened to Malcolm Smith, an Aboriginal man who died while incarcerated. Director Richard Frankland was an Investigator for the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody from 1987–91, which influenced production of this film in 1992.

This 1996 short film is based off Frankland’s experiences investigating the Royal Commission. The lead character Shane drives through the night and is haunted by flashbacks of prison cells and grieving family members he has witnessed on the job.

A musical documentary that looks at Australia’s over-representation of Indigenous people in prison through song. The lyrics of the songs came from interviews with the participants and convey the realities of life for Aboriginal people who are incarcerated.

From the album Reclaim Australia, AB Original’s clip for ‘Report to the Mist’ condemns police brutality and Aboriginal deaths in custody. Taking matters into their own hands, an alliance of Blackfullas free young brothers from the wrath of the police.

Bill Onus is one of the first known Aboriginal filmmakers with a recently discovered silent 1946 film credited to him. Bill documented Aboriginal life on film, and was a trailblazer in self-representation. Some films from his family archive feature in the Memory Garden display.

Aunty Essie Coffey became the first Aboriginal woman to direct a documentary with My Survival as an Aboriginal. It's one of the first times an Aboriginal person had determined how their community was portrayed - following the legacy of Uncle Bill Onus.

She Who Must Be Loved captures the life of director Erica Glynn’s mother; Freda Glynn. Glynn played an intrinsic role in Aboriginal media; including the establishment of CAAMA and Imparja. The film is a personal portrait that uncovers the history of the Glynn family.

Reality TV show Family Rules follows Daniella Rule and her nine daughters as they navigate their daily lives in Perth. The show gets up close and personal and paints a lively portrait of the Rule family through all their challenges and changes.

Gurrutu’mi Mala (My Connections) is an artwork by Gutiŋarra Yunupiŋu that conveys his connections to family and country. In the film, Yunupiŋu communicates in barrkungu wanga (language from a distance) which is a Yolngu sign language used in the Yirrkala community.

In Family Rules, each of the ten women in the family have their own aspirations, interests and annoyances. In Rachel Perkins adaptation of Radiance, the three female protagonists are also very different; connected only through their mother and family secrets.

nodes.title: The Koorie Oral History Program and the Bill Onus family archive

links.text: Set in the summer of 1979, Super 8 (2011) is about a group of children making a zombie movie using Super 8 film cameras, whose make-believe veers into reality in a film that celebrates the joy of home movies.
In Me and Earl and the Dying Girl, the central characters recreate scenes from famous movies using a range of cameras, including a 16mm Bolex camera that was frequently used by amateur filmmakers.
A frequent trope of horror movies, home movies are central to the plot of Sinister, in which the protagonist, a true-crime writer, discovers a box of family Super 8 movies depicting murders.
The Blair Witch Project is synonymous with the use of found footage in horror films. Its realistic marketing campaign famously sparked debates about whether it was a documentary or fictional film.
In Sarah Polley's personal documentary Stories We Tell (2012), she recreates family home movie footage, provoking controversy over blurring the line between reality and fiction.
Released in the same year as The Blair Witch Project was American Beauty (1999), which also features a focus on camcorders with the character Ricky (Wes Bentley) obsessively filming his surroundings.

For the documentary Amy, centred on the life of singer Amy Winehouse, director Asif Kapadia sifted through hours of interviews, performances and archive footage, particularly candid moments captured by her friends in home movies.

nodes.title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl

links.text: Basically Black was an all-Indigenous comedy show that only ever aired its pilot episode on ABC. Almost 30 years after Basically Black aired, First Nations skit show Black Comedy has gained much success with its hilarious and uncompromising portrayal of what it is like to be Black in Australia.

Bush Mechanics is a look into the humour and genius of a collective of Walpiri people who miraculously fix cars that seem beyond repair, using only tools found in the Central Australian desert. The show is much loved for its ingenuity and tongue-in-cheek humour.

One of the writers and stars of Black Comedy, Nakkiah Lui also wrote and starred in Kiki and Kitty. The series follows Kiki as she navigates life with her new frenemy Kitty; the personified version of her vagina, played by Elaine Crombie.
Catriona McKenzie, who directed Kiki and Kitty also directed 2018 series Wrong Kind of Black, a hilarious and heartbreaking story of afro bearing, flare wearing DJ Monty Pryor and his brother Paul.

Never Stop Riding is also set in the desert but the cast use horses instead of cars. This short by Peter Mungkuri, Alec Baker and Kunmanara (Jimmy) Pompey embraces the Indulkana community's history of horse riding, and their love of cowboy and western films.

A gold heist is central to Never Stop Riding, but in Sally Riley's Confessions of a Headhunter, two cousins steal bronze statue heads – sawed from figures like Captain Cook – determined to replace colonial monuments and re-instate one that honours their Noongar ancestors.

Tony Albert’s artwork reinterprets Miley Cyrus’ ‘Wrecking Ball.’ In the film, Albert swings in on a wrecking ball, knocking down monuments of Captain Cook. This comedic work reflects the contemporary movement to remove colonial monuments, questioning how we memorialise some and silence others.

name: Laughing in the face of adversity

links.text: Daniel Boyd uses ‘lenses’ to create small portals for colour and imagery to shine through. Dark negative space creates contrast, raising questions around how we perceive dark vs light. VIDEO WORKS creates an infinite cosmos from these, where colour and form create a moving image.

Ali Gumilya Baker uses darkness in down among the wild men / colonial imagination. Not just in a literal sense by using shadows, but thematically by looking at the darkness of Australia’s past by questioning and redressing how history has been told.

Julie Gough uses shadows in The Promise, which like Baker’s work encourages audiences to reconsider the history they’ve been told. Using a chair and a shadow casting LED, Gough shines a light on Australia’s violent treatment of First Peoples.

First Australians tells the history of colonisation in Australia from the perspective of First Peoples. Rachel Perkins' series reveals the violence and the genocidal tactics of the colonial government during first contact and the ongoing effects into the current day.

Gough’s The Silenced assesses colonialism and its impact on First Peoples by focusing on the Aboriginal children who were stolen from their families in the 1800s and forced to work. The records of these children were often buried and hidden from sight.

Larissa Behrendt’s documentary film exposes the extreme rates that First Nations children are currently being taken from their families. Following the 2008 apology for the Stolen Generations administered by Kevin Rudd, the rate of Indigenous children being removed has increased.

Servant or Slave follows five Aboriginal women who were stolen from their families and forced into domestic labour, interrogating government policy in the removal of children, the control of wages, and the abuse endured by many to expose an unspoken part of Australia’s history.

Truth-telling is at the core of Fiona Foley’s Out of the Sea Like a Cloud, which looks back to first contact of the Badtjala people with colonisers; using the oldest documented song to tell their story of the sighting of the 1770 Endeavour ship’s voyage.

Song is used to retell history in Looky Looky Here Comes Cooky, directed by Steven McGregor and presented and co-written by Steven Oliver. Six musicians perform original songs that challenge the dominant dialogue surrounding the legacy of Captain Cook's HMB Endeavour, 250 years on.

nodes.title: down among the wild men / colonial imagination
Out of the Sea Like a Cloud

links.text: 'Leaps and Bounds' features a rooftop performance with stunning vista of Melbourne. Michael Lindsay-Hogg’s fly on the wall documentary not only captures The Beatles’ famous rooftop concert but also depicts what some call be the beginning of end for the group.

The stunning production design and jukebox musical stylings of Baz Luhrmann’s Moulin Rouge! give audiences dazzling spectacle in every scene. The skyline of Paris providing the ultimate backdrop for the lover’s romantic first meeting.

The Paris horizon also features in the charmingly animated The Aristocats. Proving that the romantic musical is not just for humans the film expertly weaves together comedy and jazz music with an energetic plot.

Melbourne’s beachside suburb of St Kilda is gloriously depicted as the backyard for a group of friends sharing the same apartment block in The Secret Life of Us. Their friendships, careers and intertwined romances often playing out on the apartment’s rooftop.

Set high against the vast Hong Kong cityscape, the climax of Infernal Affairs is utterly gripping. With the truth about to be revealed, Chan and Lau find themselves fighting for their real identities both determined to come out on top.

nodes.title: Leaps and Bounds – Paul Kelly and the Coloured Girls

name: Raising the Roof: on-screen levity on rooftop

links.text: At a time when special effects were in their infancy, F.W. Murnau relied heavily on shadow and silhouette to create the menacing vampire Count Orlock in his unauthorised adaptation of Dracula. Cinematographer Fritz Arno Wagner’s haunting use of light brought nightmarish horror to the silver screen.

Alfred Hitchcock brought a similar sense of physiological menace to the bathroom scene in Psycho. Only seen in silhouette through the show curtain, the killer’s terrifying image drew upon Hitchcock’s background in German Expressionism gained from his time at UFA Babelsberg Studios in Berlin in 1924.

Inspired by images of a severe dust storm in Sydney in 2009, cinematographer Roger Deakins shot Ryan Gosling’s ‘K’ dramatically silhouetted against the orange haze of a post-apocalyptic Las Vegas. The vivid photography depicting K as both inexplicably apart of and separated from this eerie other place.

Steven Spielberg truly captured the magic of silhouette with his enchanting bicycle flight set against the backdrop of the full moon. Instantly iconic, the image became the logo representing his production company, Amblin Entertainment.

Where best to hide an easter egg but in a silhouette? Often concealing references to the Disney universe in their films, it's no surprise that Jock the Scottish terrier from Lady and the Tramp can be found hiding amongst the hyenas of Pride Rock.

Her films are known for breathtaking visual storytelling with characters often situated within majestic landscapes. Jane Campion brought her signature style to the small screen in Top of the Lake, using silhouette to dramatically position protagonists within the grandeur of the New Zealand environment.

nodes.title: down among the wild men / colonial imagination

name: The drama and nuance of silhouette

links.text: Betty White knows the power of advertising, especially during a US Super Bowl. Her appearance in the 2010 Snickers commercial re-launched the then 88-year old’s career leading to an Emmy-winning hosting gig on Saturday Night Live and a role on sitcom Hot in Cleveland.

Cementing Super Bowl advertising as marketing gold garnering as much attention as the game itself, Apple’s “1984”, almost didn’t go to air. While hated by the board of directors and the then CEO, Apple went ahead with the Ridley Scott directed commercial which was quickly hailed as a masterstroke.

David Lynch’s “Welcome to the Third Place” for the launch of Play Station 2 sits somewhere between Twin Peaks and Eraserhead. Based on the premise that the console was a gateway to a mysterious otherworld, Sony had certainly hired the right director for the task.

Long before she was an Academy Award winner, Cate Blanchett landed the role of Tim Tam star. The original wisher of the never-ending packet of Tim Tam’s, Blanchett featured in a series of commercials for Arnott’s in the mid-1990s.

Blanchett wasn’t the only A-lister to get her start in commercials, long before the glitz, long before the models, a keenly fresh-faced Leonardo DiCaprio starred in Japanese ads for the Honda Civic. Seemingly enjoying car spots, DiCaprio went on to do commercials for Suzuki.

The Anti-Cancer Council also used star power. Warren Mitchell was a huge star in the 1960s, famous for playing bigoted cockney Alf Garnett in the BBC sitcom Till Death Do Us Part and the Anti-Cancer Council harnessed his abrasive charisma in a series of anti-smoking ads.

name: Short films that sell: the power of TV advertising

links.text: The negative effect of social media on society and its platforming of misinformation was explored in Netflix's documentary The Social Dilemma, which features former engineers and employees from the major social networks who now regret the impact of the products they helped develop.

The Truman Show rang the alarm on reality TV (despite it being in its infancy) and seemingly predicted our current society, defined by broadcasting ourselves and our constructed reality while living with constant digital surveillance.

Speeches like these from Donald Trump, before right-wing insurgents stormed the Capitol building in Washington DC, demonstrate the threat of wilfully dismissing the truth. Despite there being no evidence that Joe Biden wasn't fairly elected, #stopthesteal swept across social media and inspired protests.

The Cleaners took a look at the bad side of social media platforms through the experiences of moderators who are consistently bombarded with unfiltered content that users upload to social media platforms including racist, sexist, homophobic, alt-right and adult material.

Popular social media site Reddit banned their channel r/thedonald, one of the key channels supporting Trump and the alt-right movement. The subreddit was banned for promoting hate-speech. This foreshadowed Trump himself being banned from Twitter and Facebook in early 2021 for inciting violence.

After Donald Trump incited the mob to riot through the Capitol building, they did just that. Despite the criminal activity they were undertaking, they adhered to keeping within the velvet guide ropes (at least initially) as if they were on a legitimate tour of the building.

After Trump was banned from Twitter and Facebook for inciting violence, many alt-right supporters (including white supremacist group The Proud Boys) began using an alternative app called Parler. Google and Apple suspended the app from their stores in early 2021 for also inciting violence.

name: Fake news: too little too late

links.text: Magic lanterns were often used by clergymen to project a visual representation of biblical stories. These cautionary tales aimed to keep viewers on a righteous moral path or protect them from danger, in the same way that fairytales like Little Red Riding Hood do.

Little Red Riding Hood from 1922 is one of Disney’s first attempts at animating a fairy tales – something they’d eventually be world famous for. Fifteen years after releasing the black-and-white short, their first animated feature came out.

Little Red Riding Hood doesn’t only turn up on cinema screens, but also game consoles. The beloved fairytale was adapted into a psychological horror drama by developers Tale of Tales called The Path, where players are meant to take the wrong turn.
While Snow White was certainly one of the very first animated feature-length films, it wasn’t the very first. That honour belongs to The Adventures of Prince Achmed.

Fairytales and myths (like Prince Achmed, which is based on stories from One Thousand and One Nights) have long inspired filmmakers, including Alice Guy Blache, who made the world’s first narrative film based on the Cabbage Patch Fairy.
One of the stories in One Thousand and One Nights that Prince Achmed incorporated is Aladdin, which Disney famously turned into a beloved animated feature in 1992.

Beloved Australian children's show Round the Twist often featured fantastical stories told in a modern Australian setting. Some, like the episode 'The Cabbage Patch Fib', were based on fairy tales. In this episode, Ronson finds a baby and learns how hard parenting can be.
