Die Abenteuer des Prinzen Achmed (The Adventures of Prince Achmed)
Round the twist: the cabbage patch fib

name: Cautionary tales and magic lantern projectors

links.text: In Yahoo Serious' antipodean reimagining of Albert Einstein's origin story, Icehouse's iconic hit plays over a montage as Albert (Yahoo) departs Tasmania for the mainland. A second video clip of Icehouse's 'Great Southern Land' was filmed for the film's American release.

Young Einstein spoofs a number of films and one of the most iconic Australian movies to get the Yahoo Serious treatment is The Man from Snowy River, with a scene of Albert riding down a mountain much like Jim's (Tom Burlinson) famous ride.

The Man From Snowy River is based on the short poem by Banjo Paterson, who aside from inspiring Snowy River, has over 66 soundtrack credits, including Stanley Kramer's On the Beach, which features "Waltzing Matilda" and presents Australia as the end of the world – literally.

While The Man From Snowy River reinforces the Australian myth of the underdog, Soda_Jerk's TERROR NULLIUS recuts and remixes Australian film and TV (including Snowy River) to resist the social, political and cultural myths that exclude our diverse national identities.

TERROR NULLIUS also dispels the myth of the man behind Mad Max. Mad Max: Fury Road's Furiosa (Charlize Theron), leads a female biker gang, including Nicole Kidman in BMX Bandits, against the original Max (Mel Gibson) after the audience hears Gibson's real-life misogynist vitriol levelled at his ex-partner.

Puberty Blues is based on Australia's first coming-of-age novel written by Gabrielle Carey and Kathy Lette. It follows two teenage girls over a Sydney summer and instead of putting another Australian myth on a pedestal, it reveals the male chauvinism of the surfie subculture.

While post-WWII filmmakers often imagined a world devastated by nuclear war, today the climate crisis poses a very real threat to Australia. Frustration with the Morrison government's lack of a climate policy was expressed at the G20 meeting in 2021.

Combining John Harvey’s passion for stage and screen, he produced Stephen Page’s film Spear, the story of a young First Peoples man, Djali, on a journey of self-discovery told primarily through movement and dance, which was adapted from Bangarra Dance Theatre’s production Skin.

John Harvey has also lent his talents to the small screen, directing Mutti Mutti songman Kutcha Edwards in Kutcha’s Carpool Koorioke, which adapts the Carpool Karaoke format for a musical tour through Wurundjeri country featuring First Peoples musicians.

Djali is played by Hunter Page-Lochard, who also starred as another young Indigenous man on a journey of self-discovery, but this time it’s to discover his superpowers in Cleverman, which was ground-breaking for Indigenous self-representation by being the first TV show about an Indigenous superhero.
Stephen Page and John Harvey also worked on Sand – as director and producer respectively – a chapter in the cinematic adaptation of Tim Winton’s The Turning.

Yolngu actor Rarriwuy Hick’s breakout role was as Latani in Cleverman from 2016. In 2018, she took up the iconic role of Ruby Mitchell in Wentworth and collaborated with the writers to better represent the Indigenous experience.

Hick appeared in the sixth season of Wentworth alongside longtime friend Leah Purcell, who played Ruby’s older sister Rita Connors in Wentworth. Not only had Purcell directed Hick in Cleverman, they’d both also appeared in Redfern Now.

My Brilliant Career was a brilliant start for Armstrong’s own career, with her first feature garnering Palm d’Or and Academy Award noms. It sticks to the feminist spirit of the Miles Franklin’s novel on which it’s based by featuring many women in key creative roles.

Though Armstrong’s career had seen her make films in Australian and Hollywood, her most well-known feature is another adaptation of a novel, the hit Oscar-nominated (Best Costume, Score and Actress for Winona Ryder) 1994 adaptation of Little Women.

With the 1994 version of Little Women beloved by many, fans wondered what Armstrong made of Greta Gerwig’s remake. Taking too Twitter, the Australian director praised it’s “brave new structure” and “fantastic cast”, calling it “Little Women for this generation”.

Judy Davis earned two BAFTA awards forher breakout role in My Brilliant Career. In her acclaimed 40-year career, she’s since won countless awards, including eight AACTA Awards, two Golden Globe Awards and three Primetime Emmy Awards. Most recently she appeared in TV show Ratched.

Though better known for her features and historical movies, Armstrong has also directed a number of documentaries, including this concert of Bob Dylan’s 1986 True Confessions tour performance in Sydney.

After gaining rave reviews in Sharp Objects, Eliza Scanlen appeared in Gerwig’s Little Women. In the same year, she was the lead in Shannon Murphy’s debut coming-of-age dramedy Baby Teeth, which like Armstrong’s first feature, received rave reviews and film fest nominations.

nodes.title: Hard to Handle: Bob Dylan in Concert

links.text: George Miller revolutionised action movies when he brought Mad Max to the screen in 1979. In the 40 years since, he’s continued to push the boundaries of filming action for the screen, blending high-octane spectacle, iconic characters and inspires storytelling.

While best known as a writer and director, Miller has also contributed to TV as a producer in the early 1980s. The Dismissal miniseries dramatized the events leading to Gough Whitlam’s dismissal as prime minister.

Miller also served as a producer on a number of other Australian film productions, including Dead Calm, the iconic thriller starring Sam Neil, Billy Zane and Nicole Kidman, which helped launch the latter’s Hollywood career.

Based on a book of the same name, none other than Orson Welles had tried unsuccessfully for years to make an adaptation of Dead Calm, called The Deep, which is now lost, like many believed Welles’ last film The Other Side of the Wind was.
Speaking of movies that have been hard to make, or just movies about making movies, the story behind making Orson Welles' own masterpiece Citizen Kane is told in David Fincher's Mank.

The last Mad Max film, Fury Road, bagged six Oscars at the Academy Awards, but George Miller already has an Oscar to his name. Demonstrating his diverse approach to screen stories, the director won an Academy Award for Best Animated Feature with Happy Feet.

But George Miller is no stranger to Oscar nominations, he’s also been nominated for Best Original Screenplay for drama Lorenzo’s Oil, but also for Best Picture and Best Screenplay for Babe, the family-favourite film.

nodes.title: The Other Side of the Wind

links.text: Acclaimed Australian director Fred Schepisi’s first feature was The Devil’s Playground, a semi-autobiographical film about a boy growing up in a Catholic school. The film explores with the “myriad of ways men deal with sexual repression in the Catholic church”, according to film critic Luke Buckmaster.

After his debut, Schepisi directed the controversial The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith. The film follows an Indigenous man (Tom E Lewis), who murders a white family and goes into hiding. Though acclaimed at the time, it raises questions of whether white filmmakers should tell Indigenous stories.

Warwick Thornton’s Sweet Country has a similar premise: an Indigenous man kills a white stockman and goes on the run. However, Sam (Hamilton Morris) is a sympathetic character who kills only out of self-defense and Thornton, as a First Peoples director, is better suited to tell the story.

American audiences interpreted The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith as a western, which led to Schepisi being offered the chance to direct Barbarosa, starring Willie Nelson and Gary Busey, which kicked off Schepisi’s Hollywood career.

After over 20 years directing dramas, comedies and even a sci-fi film, Schepisi turned his attention to TV with the 2005 miniseries Empire Falls, which won a Golden Globe for Best Miniseries or Television Film and received seven Emmy nominations.

Empire Falls was the last time that legendary actor Paul Newman appeared on-screen. Philip Seymour Hoffman, who appears in Empire Falls, was also in Nobody’s Fool with Newman. Both are based on novels by Richard Russo.

After 60-year career, another legendary actor, Jessica Tandy, last appeared on-screen in Nobody’s Fool. Like Newman, Tandy was an Oscar winner, receiving the Academy Award for her performance in Driving Miss Daisy, directed by Schepisi’s contemporary, Australian Bruce Beresford.

Warwick Thornton’s acclaimed debut feature film won the Caméra d’Or at the Cannes Film Festival. Interpreted as a response to Kevin Rudd’s apology to the Stolen Generation in 2008, Thornton has said “for the Samson and Delilahs of the world [sorry] doesn’t mean shit.”

An element of Samson and Delilah is the teen characters stealing a car to escape their government-controlled community. Movement is also at the heart of his film installation work Mother Courage, which featured an elderly Indigenous woman travelling in a van between galleries, selling her art.

At the heart of Samson and Delilah is a teenage romance, similar to Romeo and Juliet. However, despite its confronting themes that explore the conditions and treatment of First Peoples and their communities, it’s an essentially hopeful film, unlike Romeo and Juliet.

Samson and Delilah’s two leads, Rowan McNamara and Marissa Gibson, are not professional actors. Similarly, the cast of Amman Abbasi’s debut feature Dayveon, a coming-of-age tale in Arkansas, are also non-actors. Both films tell a universal story in a specific location.

While Samson and Delilah paints a bleak portrait of the conditions some First Peoples teens live in, Little J and Big Cuz presents the titular characters’ Nan’s house as a gateway to explore community and Country. Filmmaker Beck Cole worked on both.

Baz Luhrmann isn’t the only Australian director to tackle the works of the bard. Justin Kurzel (Snowtown) directed Michael Fassbender and Marion Cotillard in a 2015 adaptation of Macbeth, which was a less flamboyant and stylised adaptation than Luhrmann’s Romeo and Juliet.

While most audiences today know Eric Bana as one of Australia’s most successful Hollywood exports, his career took off on the small screen in the Australian sketch comedy show Full Frontal, where he did impersonations of Hollywood heavyweights like Arnold Schwarzenegger and Sylvester Stallone.

While Bana had proved his comedic chops in Full Frontal (and The Castle), his career launched into the stratosphere when he played notorious Australian underworld figure Mark “Chopper” Read in Chopper. Read supposedly suggested Bana play him after seeing him in Full Frontal.

In a memorable performance, Vince Colosimo starred alongside Bana in Chopper as underworld figure Neville Bartos. Eight years later, Colosimo would again play a famous Melbourne gangster when he brought Alphonse Gangiatano to life in the hit series Underbelly.

After proving his crime credentials on Chopper, a critically acclaimed hit across the world, director Andrew Dominik then directed Brad Pitt as another famous outlaw in The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford.

The criminal world and pathological characters seem to suit Andrew Dominik, who 12 years after The Assassination of Jesse James directed two episodes of season two of Netflix's true-crime series Mindhunter, based on FBI agent John E Douglas' career catching serial killers.

Like Bana, Australian actress Anna Torv has also made it big in the US. She stars as the staunchly principled Dr Wendy Carr in Mindhunter, but returned home to play another strong female character in Foxtel’s political thriller Secret City.

A year after Mindhunter, Netflix dropped another hit crime series based on real events. Eric Banner returned to the small screen, and to playing pathological criminals (like Chopper) when he starred as real-life con-man John Meehan.

nodes.title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford

links.text: One of the films that blurred the line between information, spectacle and ultimately propaganda was the Kokoda Front Line! newsreel. Photographer Damien Parer and director Ken G Hall restaged several combat scenes and asked viewers to join the war effort.

Eleven years after Kokoda Front Line!, Queen Elizabeth II the came to Australia on a highly publicised Royal tour. It was all captured by newsreel camera crews who followed the royals around Australia, which was made into the country's first colour doco The Queen in Australia.

Two years later, TV finally arrived in Australia – just in time for the 1956 Melbourne Olympics. All three Melbourne TV stations aired it and it was the first Olympic Games outside of Europe and America. It was a truly nationwide spectacle.

TV later played a huge role in uniting the country once again, but this time behind the anti-war effort in response to the ongoing conflict in Vietnam. Footage of the conflict was nightly beamed into households across the country.

While broadcasts of the Vietnam War helped turn public opinion against the war, footage of the 'Tank Man' protestor during pro-democracy demonstrations in China is censored in the country to suppress public dissent, despite being one of the most iconic images of the 20th century.

nodes.title: Royal tour of Queen Elizabeth II

links.text: Gotye’s global chart-topper swept the airways, award shows and YouTube when it was released in 2011. It’s catchy tune, stop-motion animation video and heartfelt lyrics made it a phenomenon, spawning hundreds of online covers, captured by Gotye in the mash-up, 'Somebodies: A YouTube Orchestra'.

Natasha Pincus not only directed ‘Somebody that I used to know’ and oversaw its iconic stop-motion animation, she got her start directing another Australian music legend – Paul Kelly – for his song 'God Told Me To', which saw shot on 35mm film.

One of the first parodies in a long list of homages, remixes and covers was Walk Off the Earth’s version featuring five people playing the song on one guitar. While it hasn’t had as many views at the original, the 188 million it’s achieved isn’t bad.

It wasn’t just amateur musicians who saw the potential of ‘Somebody that I used to know’, with the song (like many hits) reinterpreted and performed inTV musical Glee. Rather than represent a dissolving relationship, in Glee it expressed the estrangement between two brothers.

In 2014, ACMI presented Spectacle: The Music Video Exhibition, which featured ‘Somebodies’ as an example of a song that was adopted by the internet through parodies and covers to become a pop cultural phenomenon. In the same section were parodies inspired by Beyonce’s ‘Single Ladies’.
Of course, the song's pop cultural cache and immense popularity meant that it was performed on Glee, not once but twice.

Even Beyonce has her inspirations. The iconic dance routine for 'Singles Ladies', which Beyonce worked on with Frank Gatson Jr, was inspired by a routine choreographed by Broadway legend Bob Fosse on The Ed Sullivan Show called 'Mexican Breakfast'.
One of the three dancers in the 'Mexican Breakfast' routine is Gwen Verdon, Fosse's wife. In the miniseries Fosse/Verdon, the couple are played by Sam Rockwell and Michelle Williams.

nodes.title: Somebody that I used to know
Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)
Somebody That I Used to Know - Walk off the Earth

links.text: An Inconvenient Truth (2006) documented Al Gore's campaign to educate people about global warming, presenting a lecture featuring alarming statistics, scientific evidence and footage of environmental degradation.

Blue Planet II, presented by veteran nature documentarian David Attenborough, highlighted the preponderance of plastic in the oceans. The series has been credited with raising awareness of plastic pollution and influencing environmental policy, through the impact known as the "Blue Planet effect".
Animated children's film Happy Feet had an environmental message as its backdrop, exploring overfishing and pollution, with critics describing it as propaganda.
Conservation legend David Attenborough features in Edie Kurzer's ode to the Australian bush in the natural history diorama in the Federation Square foyer.

The genre cli-fi (climate change fiction) explores the impact of environmental destruction, and has been seen in disaster films such as The Day After Tomorrow, in which catastrophic weather events lead to a new ice age.

Before Happy Feet, children’s film FernGully portrayed the effects of deforestation, as the magical inhabitants of an Australian rainforest fight loggers and a pollutant force called Hexxus to save their home.

Directed by Bong Joon-ho, Snowpiercer imagines a world in which attempts to rectify global warming through geo-engineering have resulted in the Earth being covered in ice, and a group of humans survive on a train endlessly encircling the globe.
Interstellar’s journey into space and through time is predicated on the Earth’s slow decline, and the search for an inhabitable planet to save humankind.

The Syrian Civil War has been documented in countless videos and images online, particularly people being rescued from the rubble of buildings destroyed by air strikes. The short documentary The White Helmets follows the volunteer group of the same name.

Citizen journalist Waad Al-Kateab captured her family's lives operating a hospital under siege in Aleppo. Her footage was anonymously shared on a YouTube channel and by mainstream news sources, and subsequently made into a documentary dedicated to her daughter Sama.

The documentary City of Ghosts provides an in-depth look at Syrian media activist group Raqqa Is Being Slaughtered Silently, a collective of people hiding undercover, on the run and in exile due to their reporting of ISIS's activities.

Silvered Water, directed by Ossama Mohammed and Wiam Simav Bedirxan, is compiled from footage filmed on mobile phones and uploaded to YouTube by anonymous users, creating a visual archive of the multiple experiences of people in Syria.

Director Matthew Heineman followed his documentary with A Private War, a biographical drama exploring the life of war correspondent Marie Colvin, played by Rosamund Pike, who was killed in Syria in 2012.

A documentary about Marie Colvin was released in the same year, Under the Wire focuses on the reporter's final assignment covering the siege of Homs in Syria. Colvin and colleague Remi Ochlik were killed in a targeted attack on a media centre.

Like Kokoda Front Line!, Why We Fight: Prelude to War also won an Oscar for Best Documentary in 1943. Directed by Frank Capra, a Hollywood director, the film was the first in a series of seven that sought to both inform and inspire American audiences.

The experiences of Australian troops on the Kokoda Trail were dramatised in the feature film Kokoda, showing the chaotic and grim realities of frontline warfare. Many scenes were shot with handheld cameras, as the original war photography would have been.

Frank Capra described his shock at watching Leni Riefenstahl's The Triumph of the Will, which served as propaganda for the Nazi cause. Capra made his films in direct response to the persuasive techniques of the German film.

Hollywood actors were also called upon to star in American propaganda films. In the short recruitment film Winning Your Wings, James Stewart plays a dashing pilot encouraging audiences to join the air force.

Set in England during WWII, Their Finest follows a female script writer with a British Ministry of Information film team, making a morale-boosting film about two girls assisting with the evacuation of Dunkirk in their own small boat.

The evacuation of thousands of Allied soldiers from a beach in France in 1940 has been dramatised in many films, including Atonement (2007), known for its five-minute tracking shot following James McAvoy's wounded soldier amidst the devastation on the beach.

nodes.title: Why We Fight: Prelude to War

links.text: The video clip for 'Native Tongue' (2018) – like Mo'Ju herself – incorporated the artistic practice of a myriad of different cultures, including vocals from the Pasefika Vitoria Choir. Stan Walker paid homage to his culture in 'New Takeover' (2017).

For his song 'New Takeover', Stan Walker paid tribute to his Māori heritage and featured dancers from the Hawaiki TŪ theatre in the music video. Walker has also appeared in several films, including Taika Waititi’s Hunt For The Wilderpeople.
Written, directed, producer and starring Taika Waititi, Hunt For The Wilderpeople featured a breakout performance from Māori actor Julian Dennison who also voices a character in The Strange Chores.

Landing a number of Hollywood roles while he was still just a teenager, Julian Dennison brought the character of Pierce to life in The Strange Chores. The supernatural animated series comes from two of the producers of Bluey.

Bluey is set in Brisbane, Australia and follows the adventures of a family of Blue Heelers. It became a global children’s TV phenomenon since it debuted and is executive produced by Daley Pearson who was also behind Robbie Hood.

Set in Alice Springs, Robbie Hood plays on Robin Hood’s central premise of stealing from the rich to give to the poor as it follows the adventures of an Indigenous teenager. The series is directed and co-written by Dylan River, who worked on Sweet Country.

Serving as second unit director on Sweet Country was a family affair for Dylan River, whose father Warwick Thornton directed the Australian classic. They also both worked on the Mystery Road TV series.
One of the works featured in Moving Worlds' VFX super cut is Thor: Ragnarok which has a number of visually stunning VFX scenes.
Framestore, the studio responsible for many of the VFX in Thor: Ragnarok also worked on the VFX of the Black Mirror episode 'USS Callister' including the creature Arachnajax and the ship itself.
The slow-mo demise of the Valkyries in Thor: Ragnarok was overseen by VFX studio Rising Sun, who cut their superhero teeth doing the acclaimed slow-mo VFX in X-Men: Days of Future Past.

One of the most visually stunning (and heartbreaking) scenes in Thor: Ragnarok details the demise of the Asgardian Valkyries against Hela. The last Valkyrie (Tessa Thompson) appears again in Thor: Love and Thunder atop a pegasus.

The famous slow-mo scene in X-Men: Days of Future Past featured speedster Quicksilver, who was played by Evan Peters. The character also featured in the MCU’s Avengers sequel but was played by Aaron Taylor Johnson.

Avengers: Age of Ultron also introduced Quicksilver’s sister, Wanda Maximoff (Elizabeth Olsen), who went on to star in subsequent MCU movies and the first Marvel-produced TV show, WandaVision. The events of Ultron are key to the show’s setting.

In WandaVision, Monica Rambeau (Teyonah Parris) is the character who investigates the show’s strange reality. She first appeared as a child (played by Akira Akbar) in Captain Marvel, which Rising Sun also provided VFX for.
Infinity, the online world that plays an integral part of the story in 'USS Callister' is based on the highly anticipated but widely criticised videogame No Man's Sky.

nodes.title: Valkyrie costume with sword, sheath and daggers

links.text: Versions of Robert Wiene's proto-horror film featured extensive tinting to communicate suspense, sickness and madness, with the frames bathed in midnight blue, eerie orange and envious green.

Robert Wiene's silent German Expressionist film about a hypnotist forcing a sleepwalker to murder is considered the first horror movie and inspired the Hollywood horrors of the 1930s and 40s, including Dracula.

The success of early horror films inspired the strange angles and shadows common in German Expressionism to be adopted by film noir to portray a pessimistic world bristling with crime, anti-heroes and femme fatales. John Huston’s The Maltese Falcon is considered a landmark early work in the genre.

Seventy years after The Maltese Falcon gave flight to film noir, the genre hit videogames in 2011 with the release of Team Bondi and Rockstar Games' L.A. Noire, a murder mystery set in post-WWII Los Angeles.

While film noir thrillers of the 1940s and 50s dealt primarily with psychological treachery and duplicity, spiritual successors like Robert Altman's neo-noir The Long Goodbye focused on sociological issues of the post-Vietnam and post-Watergate era.

L.A. Noire has been criticised for its lack of female representation. Miss Fisher's Murder Mysteries wouldn't face the same accusation and inverts many film noir tropes to celebrate an independently wealthy, female private detective.

Set during the same time period, L.A. Noire and L.A. Confidential share the same noir themes and explore the grimy underbelly of the City of Angles. Many of the characters in L.A. Noire are similar to those in L.A. Confidential, including police captains in both media using the phrase "boyos".

Pioneering filmmaker Georges Méliès used multiple exposures to create the special effect of multiple, floating heads. Likewise, American filmmaker Buster Keaton used camera tricks and techniques to multiply himself in The Playhouse.
By 1999, digital wizardy had advanced to the point that The Matrix could CGI hundreds of Hugo Weavings' Agent Smith into one scene.
The Matrix borrows heavily from Hong Kong martial arts films like Twin Dragons, where special effects let Jackie Chan play identical twins.

As visual effects got easier and cheaper, stories could explore doubling characters. Orphan Black, a sci-fi show about cloning, features multiple versions of the same actress, Tatiana Maslany, on screen.
Both Orphan Black and Manifesto showcase the transformative ability of their stars, with Cate Blanchett and Tatiana Maslany each playing over a dozen characters in their respective works.

nodes.title: Georges Méliès in Un homme de têtes (The Four Troublesome Heads)

links.text: CATARACT (concrete) presents a barrage of small everyday moments, asking you to try and pay attention to everything at once, not unlike I'm Google by Dine Kelberman, which arranges an endless rabbit-hole of mundane photos found on Google Images.

CATARACT asks the viewer to focus on small moments of life despite a deluge of others. Portraits in Dramatic Time allows you to focus one small moment at a time, by presenting it in extreme slow motion.

Shia Labeouf's extended livestream became a long-form video portrait of sorts, not unlike Alan Rickman's appearance in Portraits in Dramatic Time, where he makes a cup of tea in extreme slow-motion. Both projects reflect on their subject's celebrity, and our study of their tiniest actions.

'Actual Cannibal Shia Labeouf' is just one of Labeouf's contributions to the meme economy. He took the internet by storm in 2017 with a vanity/art project that involved him live-streaming his own face while watching all of his movies in one 72-hour sitting.

Just as I'm Google smashes together images based on visual rhymes, creating an unending flow of seemingly disparate things, the music video for Rob Cantor's 'All I Need Is You' harnesses the short, repeating power of GIFs to create a beating heart for its song.

The majority of clips used in 'All I Need Is You' were filmed specifically for the song by director Randall Maxwell. Love Is The Message is cut to Kanye West's 'Ultralight Beam', but the compilation of footage came first.

Rob Cantor is perhaps best known for his song "Shia Labeouf", which imagines the actor as a cannibal, stalking and killing unwary campers. If that sounds like a mean joke, it's a joke that Labeouf was in on, making a Citizen Kane-esque appearance at the end.

Love Is The Message smashes together 100 years of representations of black life. Aria Dean's video essay 'Eulogy For A Black Mass' compares contemporary blackness with the life cycles of memes, narrating found online footage.

nodes.title: Love Is the Message, the Message Is Death

links.text: In a courtroom scene in Charlie's Country, David Dalaithngu's character addresses the judge in his native language Yolngu-Matha. In 2012, the Aboriginal Interpreter Service staged a mock trial entirely in Yolngu-Matha in the Supreme Court of Darwin, with minimal translation available for a white defendant.
A famed dancer himself, Dalaithngu also narrated the 2018 VR work Carriberrie, which presented traditional and contemporary Indigenous dances from around Australia.

Just as Ten Canoes was inspired by anthropological photos of Ramingining from the 1930s, Barry Jenkins' Oscar-winning Moonlight was inspired by Earlie Hudnall Jr's 1970s portraits of African American communities in the American south.

As filming on David Dalaithngu and Rolf de Heer's film The Tracker wrapped, Dalaithngu invited de Heer to his home of Ramingining to discuss making a film there. This new film would become Ten Canoes.
David Dalaithngu and Rolf de Heer would go on to collaborate on a number of other projects, including Charlie's Country.
Moonlight's structure, crossing the boundaries of three different time periods was inspired by Taiwanese director Hou Hsiao-hsien's aptly-named 2005 film Three Times.

Filmmaker John Hillcoat, who directed The Proposition, a bleak endeavour with a journey at its centre, also directed the adaptation of Cormac McCarthy's critically acclaimed The Road. Guy Pearce, star of The Proposition has a small role in The Road.

Aside from being one of Australia's most unique and acclaimed musicians, Nick Cave has also carved out a career as a screenwriter. Along with The Proposition, he also penned the adaptation of Lawless, a Depression-era bootlegging tale that likewise features outlaws.

The Proposition and Sweet Country are both historical revenge films (the latter depicting revenge against the Indigenous character, Sam Kelly, by white colonialists) set in the Australian outback that draw on the iconography and themes of the western genre.

In Sweet Country, an Indigenous man suffers racist violence from a white WWI veteran. The Southern Cross tattoo, like war, is seen as part of white Australian identity but is now associated with racism. In Thornton's doco, he reclaims the constellation and its ties to Indigenous culture.

Indigenous rapper, writer and actor Adam Briggs appears in We Don't Need a Map. Like Thornton, he has resisted white colonial narratives in his career. In 'January 26', with his group AB Original, he challenges the meaning of Australia Day.
Tom Hardy stars in both Lawless and Mad Max: Fury Road.

Charlize Theron has a small but important role in The Road, appearing as the mother to Kodi Smit-McPhee's child, who goes on the road with Viggo Mortensen's character. Six years later Theron would have a more central role in another apocalyptic film, Mad Max: Fury Road.

Director, screenwriter, producer, actor. There was nothing Lois Weber couldn't do. She was one of the first auteurs in cinema, who explored taboo (at the time) social issues like drug use and abortion in her films. One of her biggest hits was Suspense.

Weber's Suspense used split-screen and employed a triangular technique to show a couple’s phone call while an intruder creeps into the house. The Boston Strangler also used split-screen to juxtapose the killer approaching the door of his victims, unaware inside.

Similarly, Brian De Palma uses a split screen to show different perspectives of a murder in Sisters, continuing the tradition of using split screens to create suspense in thrillers. Not to mention De Palma uses the technique in nearly all of his films!

In the same year that De Palma released Sisters, Richard L Bare released Wicked, Wicked, another thriller with slasher elements that took the technique even further by presenting the whole film in split-screen and even gave it a new name – "Duo-Vision".

Director Mike Figgis took the split-screen premise and raised it in his 2000 film Timecode. Four interconnected stories, shot in one take each, are presented simultaneously in a four-way split-screen.

While Wicked, Wicked's slapstick shlock revolved around the murder of women, Lauryn Hill's split-screen video for 'Doo-Wop (That Thing)' celebrates strong women and New York's African American community. The split-screen here connects eras, representing a neighbourhood in 1967 and 1998.

32 years before Lauryn Hill starred in her split-screen video, another female musician starred in a split-screen film – 60s singer and icon Nico. Andy Warhol's experimental film about celebrities and the famous Chelsea Hotel employs split-screen throughout its entire run-time.

The four-way split-screen that defines the style of Timecode might be hard for some people to follow, but players of Mario Kart 64 would have no problem keeping up with the action. The groundbreaking game made four-player split-screen gaming standard.

Young men from Yuendumu travel through country, facing challenges with zany good humour and keeping their cars going with inventive bush repair techniques. Malcolm also features whacky ingenuity and re-purposed vehicles including a car that divides in half.

Demonstrating the winning combination of Warlpiri humour and car culture, Ngapa Jukuurpa (Water Dreaming) is painted on an old Ford ZF Fairlane in the Bush Mechanics' final episode, which has been replicated in The Story of the Moving Image.

Malcolm's childlike perspective is highlighted through the playful discordance of compositions by the Penguin Cafe Orchestra, including Perpetuum Mobile. In Mary and Max, this repetitious piece communicates the main characters' innocent dreams for a better life.

The hand-made claymation technique used in Mary and Max foregrounds the process of creation in a very human way making it the perfect medium for animating the improvised and do-it-yourself creativity of the Bush Mechanics.

The Bush Mechanics series and more recent claymation are PAW media productions, a company specialising in producing media in language. PAW media’s documentary, Aboriginal Rules, focuses on the Yuendumu footy team that featured in the Bush Mechanics episode 'The Chase'.

Football is an important part of many Aboriginal communities and relates to marngrook, a traditional Indigenous football game. The Marngrook Footy Show is a sports entertainment panel show that offers an Indigenous perspective on the Australian Football League (AFL).

The Marngrook Footy Show foregrounds the achievements and contributions of Indigenous AFL players, while the documentary The Australian Dream focuses on the experience of AFL legend Adam Goodes to expose of the racism faced by Indigenous players.

name: Culture and identity on the Australian screen

links.text: The Power of Love was the first 3D film, which used the red-and-green anaglyph system. Audiences could choose different endings by peering through only the red or green lens. Black Mirror: Bandersnatch also had alternate endings powered by an algorithm.

Bandersnatch presents a meta-narrative with themes of control and staying in touch with reality, much like Sam Esmail's dystopian hacker TV show Mr Robot. The second season slogan was 'Control is an illusion'.
Like El Camino was a standalone continution of a popular series, Bandersnatch was one of Black Mirror. Both debuted on Netflix.
Like fans weren't ready to say goodbye to Alf, nor were Breaking Bad fans ready to say goodbye to Jesse Pinkman (Aaron Paul), who got his own Netflix movie spin-off.

Alf ran for four season in the late 80s, with a spin-off talk show produced with Alf as host. It only lasted seven episodes, but it featured some notable guests, including Bryan Cranston, would later star in prestige TV hit Breaking Bad.

The Eric Andre Show is billed as a talk show from "another reality", much like the other realities and mental states explored in shows like Bandersnatch and Mr Robot. Breaking Bad alum Krysten Ritter appeared as a guest on this parody talk show.

Episode six of season two of Mr Robot features a sequence where protagonist Elliot(Academy Award-winner Rami Malek) dreams of being in a low-budget sitcom, featuring a cameo from late-80s sitcom mascot Alf.

nodes.title: El Camino: A Breaking Bad Movie

links.text: Travis Bickle (Robert De Niro) spends a lot of time going to the movies in Martin Scorsese's Taxi Driver. They're not the kind of movies you'd take a date to, but he does anyway, demonstrating his misinterpretation of human relationships and his isolation.
Inglourious Basterds' climax takes place in a movie theatre, where combustible celluloid is used to put an end to the Third Reich in Quentin Tarantino's alternative history fantasy.

Before settling into the director's chair, Tarantino wrote the screenplay for True Romance, which was directed by Tony Scott and stars Christian Slater and Patricia Arquette as Clarence and Alabama, who meet at the movies.

Brad Pitt plays Nazi-scalper Aldo Raine in Inglorious Basterds. Fifteen years earlier he stared as Louis in Interview with the Vampire, who also goes to the movies to watch his first sunset since becoming a vampire, when cinema is invented.

Todd Phillips's gritty origin story of the Batman villain features a scene where Arthur Fleck (Joaquin Phoenix) sneaks into a movie to confront Thomas Wayne. Not only is there a movie in the movie, but Joker is a thinly veiled rip-off of Taxi Driver.

Robert De Niro also starred as another unhinged criminal, Max Cady, in Martin Scorsese's remake of Cape Fear. A key scene takes place in a screening of Problem Child, where Cady obnoxiously laughs and smokes cigars.

Scorsese's got a thing for cinemas. The meetings between mob boss Frank Costello and his mole inside the police force take place in a movie theatre. In one scene, the mole is tracked to a movie and chased through the streets.
Not only does Leonardo Dicaprio stars in both The Departed and The Aviator, both films feature his characters, Billy Costigan and Howard Hughes, in the glow of a projector's light.

name: Movies in movies in a movie museum

links.text: Data Tapestry is a commissioned data artwork for the National Gallery of Victoria’s (NGV) Melbourne Now exhibition. The work creates a departure point for thinking about our contemporary city through ecological, demographic, and systems data sourced from the greater Melbourne region.
Because of its cultural and cinematic impact, 2001 (and Blade Runner for that matter) are two of the most connected works in the entire Constellation, which is represented by Entities.

Legendary special effects master and director Douglas Trumbull oversaw the VFX in Blade Runner, but he also worked on Stanley Kubrick’s 2001, where he designed the Star Gate sequence, which set the standard for how we visualise space travel.

One of the godfather’s of sci-fi tropes is Ridley Scott’s Blade Runner, which helped establish the look and feel of a smog-choked, neon-lit near future. It also features machines that have grown sentient like algorithms might one day….
The tech, neo-noir dystopia of Blade Runner shares a similar mood and atmosphere as the world of Shadowrun.

While Data Tapesty presents different themes of Melbourne city, like ftraffic accidents and trees Aaron Koblin’s data-visualisation Flight Patterns takes a national scope, presenting every airline flight over North America in a 24-hour period.

While data-visualisations rely on algorithms and web-technologies to create their mesmerising sights, algorithms have also been used by filmmakers to create robot scripts like Sunspring, which Oscar Sharp and Ross Goodwin made by inputting sci-fi scripts into a machine learning algorithm.

Alice Guy-Blaché was a trailblazing French director, producer and screenwriter. She made hundreds of films between 1896 and the 1920s, including the first fictional film with a scripted narrative, La Fée aux Choux (The Cabbage-Patch Fairy).

Alice Guy Blaché’s gender-swap silent comedy Les Résultats du féminisme reveals how women filmmakers have been critiquing gender roles and expectations since the beginning of cinema. While an original print may be hard to find, it's available on YouTube.

Some think The Cabbage-Patch Fairy is a lost film, but it’s so similar to Guy Blaché’s later works, others believe it never existed. If it did, and later films are remakes, it’s like Bruce Gyngell’s Welcome to Television, which wasn't recorded and was remade a year later.

Much of early TV is lost because it was live. Taped TV content has also disappeared because videotape was expensive and reused whenever possible. Many early Doctor Who episodes are missing, though audio survives due to home viewers making recordings.

Economic issues also led to the loss of more than 200 of Georges Méliès’ films, which were burnt to produce materials for boot heels during WWI. However, his missing films keep being discovered, like Match de Prestidigitation (1904) in 2016.

Nam June Paik’s Something Pacific has been deliberately erased and renewed over time. It features TVs buried outside in grass and an interactive video wall inside, with the video wall periodically renovated and updated with new technologies while the artefacts outside decay.

Videogames can also become obsolete when consoles and systems age. Online emulators are often used to save games but this process decontextualises them, sometimes separating them from their initial meaning, like Wanted! Monty Mole (1984), which was a response to a mining strike.

Rithy Panh’s The Missing Picture tries to create context and history – the missing visual evidence – of both Cambodia’s culturally rich past and the Khmer Rouge’s violence. He uses a range of techniques to render what was lost including clay figures and dioramas.

'The Tale of the Three Brothers' in Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 invokes Reiniger's silhouette animation style. Animation supervisor Dale Newton has cited Reiniger as a direct influence on the animation.

The all-silhouette 15th century battle scenes in Francis Ford Coppola's Bram Stoker's Dracula directly reference Reiniger's animation style. Later Coppola reinvents Reiniger's puppets during a scene in an early movie-slash-arcade.

Animation pioneer Lotte Reiniger's The Adventures of Prince Achmed is widely recognised as the first animated feature film and was groundbreaking in its use of silhouette stop-motion animation. Reiniger was inspired by the dreamy horrors of Paul Wegener like The Golem.

Silhouette, shadow and projection also plays a key role in the first vampire movie – Nosferatu – which is also an unauthorised adaptation of Bram Stoker's Dracula. In a famous scene, the vampire Count Orlok's shadow is seen gliding up a set of stairs before he attacks Ellen in her sleep.

While Count Orlock is a substitute for Dracula in Nosferatu, Olrox (get it) in Castlevania: Symphony of Night is inspired by the iconic cinematic vampire. In Japanese media he's even just plainly called Orlok.

nodes.title: Die Abenteuer des Prinzen Achmed (The Adventures of Prince Achmed)
Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1

links.text: To create the breathtaking landscapes in Blade Runner, Ridley Scott used miniatures, forced perspective and camera tricks. It's the same approach taken by Spindly Figures and Benchmark Models to create the miniature set in Story of the Moving Image.

Ridley Scott's science-fiction classic Blade Runner was considered groundbreaking for its use of miniatures to create the film's futuristic urban landscapes. Weta Workshop in New Zealand used the same techniques for the sequel some 35 years later under the supervision of miniature artist Alex Funke.

Funke won two Academy Awards for his work with Weta on Peter Jackson's The Lord Of The Rings (2001–03) trilogy, which combined computer graphics and practical miniatures to create the world of Middle-earth.

The Lord Of The Rings (2001–03) was just one high-concept franchise released during this period that utilised miniatures, with the Star Wars prequels expanding on the same technology George Lucas relied so heavily upon during the making of the first trilogy.

With segments of the Star Wars prequels shot in Sydney, Australia, so too was The Matrix (1999–2003) trilogy, where the term bigatures first rose to prominence because the miniatures built were so large: around a tenth scale, compared to forty-eighth scale like on Blade Runner: 2049.

The concept of The Matrix's bigatures featured in Edgar Wright's buddy cop parody Hot Fuzz (2007), which had a final showdown between characters in a model village based on the film's fictional town of Sandford, Gloucestershire.

Hot Fuzz's miniatures were shown on screen as part of the plot, however, audiences never saw Stanley Kubrick use of an Overlook Hotel miniature which he used in pre-production on The Shining (1980) to measure exact lighting specifics.

nodes.title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers
Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace

links.text: Overwatch was the creation of long-standing international videogame developer Blizzard Entertainment, who are also known for the hugely successful Warcraft series, which was adapted into a feature film in 2016.

Warcraft was thought to be the film that could break the videogame-to-movie curse, but unfortunately it was poorly received and barely scraped back its budget. It was directed by Duncan Jones, who became beloved by sci-fi fans for Moon.
Moonwas the directorial debut of Jones, who was born Zowie and later changed his name. He was the son of Angie and David Bowie, the latter who famously played the Goblin King in Labyrinth.

Labyrinth is one of Bowie's most enduring acting roles, but as a musician he was groundbreaking for his use of moving image to create characters and enhance his storytelling, highlighted in the documentary concert film Ziggy Stardust and the Spiders From Mars.
A lover of storytelling in all its forms, Bowie was just as comfortable in Ziggy Stardust and the Spiders From Mars as he was voicing the character of Lord Royal Highness in SpongeBob SquarePants.

SpongeBob SquarePants was just one of the animated phenomenons developed by the creative duo of Merriwether Williams and Kate Boutilier. The Emmy Award-winners were responsible for decades worth of childhood favourites, including Rugrats.

Cree Summer voiced the Rugrats character Susie in both the series and the movies. One of the most prolific voice actors of her generation and few women of colour working in the industry, she had her live-action breakout with A Different World.

As Denise Huxtable, Lisa Bonet was the star of Cosby Show spin-off A Different World and would have an eclectic movie career, including in Stephen Frears' High Fidelity. Twenty years later, her daughter Zoe Kravitz would star in a TV version of High Fidelity.

nodes.title: Ziggy Stardust and the Spiders From Mars

links.text: Director Taika Waititi promoted Jojo Rabbit by posting a version of the 'Hitler Finds Out About...' meme on his Instagram. Made by Waititi, this version of the meme shows Hitler finding out he's portrayed in Jojo Rabbit by Waititi, who is Jewish and Polynesian.

'The Hitler Finds Out About...' meme involves recaptioning one of the final scenes from Downfall, where actor Bruno Ganz portrays Hitler reacting furiously to news that Germany is soon to be defeated.
As a young actor, Bruno Ganz also appeared in the 70s Nazi-hunting romp The Boys From Brazil alongside Gregory Peck, Laurence Olivier and Lilli Palmer.

The bizarre sci-fi plot of The Boys From Brazil, which involves Hitler clones spread throughout the world, is exactly the sort of hammy World War II schlock film parodied by Australian series Danger 5.

While Danger 5 went quite far in its Nazi-parodying ways, it never reached the lows of British sitcom Heil Honey I'm Home!, in which Adolf HItler and Eva Braum live next to a Jewish couple. It was cancelled after one episode.
The camp portrayal of Hitler in Heil Honey I'm Home wouldn't be out of place in the fictional musical 'Springtime for Hitler' in The Producers.
Mel Brooks' The Producers is used as the springboard for a discussion about the ethics of satirising Nazis in this excellent video essay from Hugo Award-Nominated YouTuber Lindsay Ellis.

nodes.title: Mel Brooks, The Producers and the Ethics of Satire about N@zis

links.text: The Dishonored world incorporates both clockwork and supernatural themes and design elements. The “Good Hunting” episode of Love, Death & Robots draws on these same themes, with a shapeshifting fox that later morphs into a steampunk assassin.
Many Love, Death & Robots episodes deal with the complex issues surrounding artificial intelligence (AI). Similarly, Ex Machina explores the nature of AI and what we perceive to be "human".

Motoko, the cyborg protagonist in Ghost in the Shell, questions the nature of identity in an increasingly digital world, while the main antagonist in the film, The Puppet Master, is a form of sentient AI.
The 2017 remake of Ghost in the Shell garnered huge criticism and accusations of whitewashing after Scarlett Johansson starred as a character of Asian heritage.

The Ghost in the Shell soundtrack was composed by Clint Mansell, who also contributed to the score for Mass Effect 3. AI and tech are vital to the Mass Effect world, with the series antagonists a mixed race of synthetic/organic starships.

Edie Kurzer crafted the costumes for Judy & Punch, which reimagines the classic puppet show of Punch attacking his wife Judy and their child. Gone Girl the discovery of Punch and Judy puppets as a character is being framed for the murder of his wife.

David Fincher's Gone Girl was based on the best-selling book by Gillian Flynn, who wrote a series of crime novels that featured complicated women at the centre. Her first book was adapted into the television series Sharp Objects.

Sharp Objects starred Amy Adams as a troubled journalist who returns to her hometown to investigate the murders of teen girls. Flynn – who wrote the novel it's based on – also wrote the screenplay for the show, as well as Widows.

Steve McQueen's critically acclaimed Widows was based on the British TV series of the same name. The premise sees the widows of three criminals take on their final heist. The original was so popular, it was adapted and spun off several times globally.

Widows was the brainchild of prolific writer Lynda La Plante and key British producers Verity Lambert and Linda Agran. It was unusual at the time for featuring four female leads, including Ann Mitchell whose character Dolly got her own spin-off She's Out.

She's Out picked up several years after the events of the TV series, with Dolly (Mitchell) having just been released from prison. Mitchell made a small cameo in the 2018 remake, which starred Jon Bernthal who also appeared in Wind River.

Wind River explores the real-life issue of murdered and missing indigenous women in North America. Actress and activist Tantoo Cardinal starred in the film. She wrote, directed and acted in the short Stories from the Seventh Fire about Native-Canadian storytelling.
Thomas Edison helped establish cinema as an art-form and mass entertainment. Many of his early films were short and showed everyday activities like riding a bicycle.

Directed by Thomas Edison, Bicycle Trick Riding No.2 (1899) lasts for just under a minute and features cycling stuntman Neidert performing tricks. It's one of the earliest examples of the moving image. Edison would later go on to be played by Benedict Cumberbatch in The Current War.

The Current War is a dramatised version of the race between inventors to deliver the electric power delivery system, featuring Edison, George Westinghouse, Nikola Tesla, and other historic figures. It was directed by Alfonso Gomez-Rejon, who also did The Town That Dreaded Sundown.

The Town That Dreaded Sundown was a remake of the 1976 slasher of the same name, based on the true story of the Texarkana Moonlight Murders. Unlike the original, Gomez-Rejon's film was staged like a play with long, continuous shots and seasoned theatre actors like Denis O'Hare from True Blood.

True Blood was considered the start of 'peak TV' thanks to its ability to examine issues of race and sexuality through a genre lens. Directing and writing several episodes was groundbreaking filmmaker Angela Robinson, who got her start with the action-packed comedic short D.E.B.S.

One of the few openly gay and black women directors in Hollywood, Robinson broke through with the short D.E.B.S, which was adapted into a feature of the same name. Following schoolgirls groomed to be spies, But I'm A Cheerleader filmmaker Jamie Babbit also contributed to the script.

Babbit's hit about a cheerleader sent to conversion therapy explores the lesbian experience like much of her work during a pivotal time for queer cinema. Kei Shu's A Queer Story came out two years earlier and is one of the first Hong Kong films about queerness.

A Queer Story competed at the Sundance Film Festival in the same year as Strays, Vin Diesel's directorial debut. It came off the back of his acclaimed short Multi-Facial (1995) about an actor struggling to make it due to his multi-ethnic appearance.

First Australians was co-directed and narrated by Rachel Perkins, daughter of activist Charles Perkins and founder of Blackfella Films, which has produced a number of acclaimed films, documentaries and TV shows.
Rachel Perkins' first feature was Radiance, based on the 1993 play written by Louis Nowra and starring Deborah Mailman, Rachel Maza and Trisha Morton-Thomas.

Deborah Mailman also appeared in The Sapphires. Based on a play by Tony Briggs drawn from the real-life story of his mother and aunt, the film follows a group of Yorta Yorta singers who toured Vietnam in 1968.

Miranda Tapsell, who appeared in The Sapphires, co-wrote and starred in the romantic comedy Top End Wedding. Tapsell has also released a book entitled Top End Girl and has her own podcast, Pretty for an Aboriginal, with Nakkiah Lui.

Before appearing in The Sapphires, Jessica Mauboy made her acting debut in comedy musical Bran Nue Dae, a film adaptation of the semi-autobiographical musical written by Jimmy Chi in 1990, which was also directed by Rachel Perkins.

Making his feature film debut in Bran Nue Dae, Hunter Page-Lochard went on to star in the acclaimed TV series Cleverman, a futuristic drama created by Ryan Griffen to provide a tale of Aboriginal superheroes for his son.

Actor Uncle Jack Charles had a recurring role in Cleverman and was the subject of the documentary Bastardy, which explored his eventful life and career in film and theatre. Charles is often referred to as the grandfather of Indigenous theatre.

Uncle Jack Charles had a cameo appearance in Mystery Road, a western-influenced detective story set in rural New South Wales. Starring Aaron Pedersen, the acclaimed film generated a sequel and spin-off TV series. The first season of the TV series was directed by Rachel Perkins.

Documentarians develop camera techniques to access, interpret and compose notions of truth. Direct cinema, which Albert and David Maysles’ interpreted as an intimate ‘fly-on-the-wall’ style was used in their acclaimed film Grey Gardens, which foresaw the techniques used in reality TV.

In 2013, Jinkx Monsoon brilliantly impersonated Little Edie from Grey Gardens, who has become a queer icon, on an episode of Ru Paul's Drag Race featuring segment 'Snatch Game', itself a parody of TV quiz show Match Game.

The Kardashians have also been impersonated on Ru Paul's Drag Race, and Khloe Kardashian has featured as a celebrity guest judge. The Kardashians are known for their reality TV show and have leveraged an entire empire off their public personas.

Kim Kardashian appears in husband Kanye West's music video 'Famous', which controversially included the apparently naked bodies (wax figures) of celebrities Taylor Swift, Anna Wintour, George W Bush and Rihanna, amongst others.
TV drama UnREAL follows a producer on a reality dating show, revealing the machinations and manipulations of 'reality' behind such shows as The Bachelor and Love Island.

Gillian Wearing's work is inspired by documentary and reality TV. By putting herself in the frame of her work, she questions the superficial aspects of how we relate to each other through media, the nature of performance, and the line between our public and private lives.

Where Kim Kardashian and her sisters have capitalised on the rise of social media, the film Ingrid Goes West explores the dark underbelly of platforms like Facebook and Instagram as Aubrey Plaza's character obsesses over and stalks influencer Taylor.

Isle of Dogs uses the simple principle that scaled-down objects look life-sized filmed up close. Just as Wes Anderson shunned CGI animation, The Neverhood was created when 3D videogames were the next big thing. Instead it used stop-motion animation to create a unique platformer.

With the rise of CGI and 3D engines, unreal creatures and worlds were mostly computer-generated. Practical effects weren’t finished though. Peter Jackson’s first Lord of the Rings film used forced perspective, different sized actors and camera tricks to make the Hobbits look small.

Lord of the Rings also used a range of detailed miniature sets to shoot many of its fantasy locations. Using detailed miniatures wasn't a new idea, and Blade Runner used the technique with astonishing effect to bring a futuristic LA to life.

The neon-noir world of Blade Runner drew inspiration from Fritz Lang’s Metropolis, which depicted a city with buildings soaring into the sky and pioneered many of techniques still used to depict sci-fi worlds; large-scale background paintings, miniature sets, animation and forced perspective.

You might notice some similarities between Metropolis and the underwater city of Rapture where Bioshock is set. Both were inspired by New York art-deco buildings and feature similar architecture and sci-fi city features. Bioshock also proves the creative possibilities of 3D game engines to design impossible worlds.

nodes.title: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring

links.text: The first affordable consumer VR system was the ill-fated Virtual Boy for the Nintendo Game Boy, which could only produce red and black coloured images and was commercially unsuccessful. Virtual Boy Wario Land was however considered the best game on the platform.
Red Alarm was one of the launch titles for the Virtual Boy, and one of the few titles released that utilised 3D polygonal graphics. Due to hardware limitations these were wireframe models.
Red Alarm attempted to emulate VR flying scenes from The Lawnmower Man, a film that brought VR into the public consciousness.

At the climax of The Lawnmower Man, Jobe leaves the real world to enter VR permanently as a non-physical being. This is echoed in San Junipero, where VR becomes a permanent refuge for people after death.

Likewise, Upload explores life after death. Set in 2033, humans have developed the ability to "upload" themselves into a virtual afterlife of their choosing. Nathan dies prematurely and gets uploaded to the very expensive Lake View, finding his choices controlled by some still living.

Based on the 1982 original, Tron Legacy follows Sam as he searches for his long lost father entering 'the grid'. Rather than using traditional headgear as a means into a virtual world, main character Flynn is digitised and uploaded into a computer mainframe.
Phenakistoscope discs spin to give the illusion of motion on the spot. The corridor fight from Inception spins but keeps the camera in one spot to create the illusion of shifting gravity.

Nolan's showstopping fight sequence was filmed in a 100-foot rotating corridor, with the camera fixed in place. This was a huge leap from the rotating room set that allowed Fred Astaire to dance on the ceiling in Royal Wedding.
Lionel Richie hired Royal Wedding director Stanley Donen thirty years later to recreate the rotating room effect for his catchy music video.

It's said that everything Fred Astaire did, Ginger Rogers did backwards in heels. In Walking the wall, Angela Tiatia endures attempting to walk up a wall in heels, while making constant eye contact with the audience, demanding they witness her contortion.
In Gravity Rush, the hero Kat can bend gravity to her will, running up walls and falling from great heights and fiercely does so in a leotard and heels.

The key mechanic of The Gardens Between is rewinding time, and the game explores the importance of friendship. Chang utilises the rewinding of time in her 2001 work In Love to similarly explore familial love.
Michael Haneke's Funny Games also makes use of the rewinding time technique, deviating by breaking the fourth wall in a controversial and confronting manner to explore the destruction of family.
The music video for Alt-J's 'Breezeblocks', similarly to Funny Games, shows a very violent act while reversing film and time itself, which leads to a shocking reveal at the end of the clip.

Nolan's thriller Memento structures the entire film in reverse, slowly revealing to the viewer key information that illuminates the previous scene. This leads to a shattering climax similar to that of the 'Breezeblocks' video clip.

In it's ninth season, iconic sitcom Seinfeld aired one of its most adventurous episodes 'The Betrayal' – an episode told in reverse. The editing structure was identical to that of Nolan's Memento, and predated it by three years. The title of the episode refers to the Harold Pinter play.

Though better quality, Betamax lost the Format War due to the accessibility and affordability of VHS. In The Simpson's episode 'Itchy & Scratchy: The Movie', Snake steals a Betamax VCR only to realise, "Oh no! Beta!", presumably because it won't play his VHS tapes.

The Simpsons episode, 'Itchy and Scratchy: The Movie', features a spoof of Disney's famous Steamboat Willie cartoon, with Itchy playing the Mickey Mouse role, but with murderous intentions and a Tommy gun.
It was after seeing The Jazz Singer – the first film to feature synchronised sound dialogue – that Walt Disney was inspired to put a synched soundtrack in his next cartoon – Steamboat Willie.

Disney's iconic animation style is one of the first popular moving image cartoons. The famous company's famous characters appear in the Kingdom Hearts videogame series, which has a level rendered in the Steamboat Willie style.
Kingdom Hearts brings together the Disney animated world with the Final Fantasy videogame and the main character Sora, who first appeared in Kingdom Hearts, later appeared World of Final Fantasy.

The place supercut features both Van Diemen's Land (2009) and The Hunter (2011), which explore Tasmania's untamed bush as character, something that Jennifer Kent's The Nightingale also does, with the darkness of the bush reflecting the darker recesses of human nature.

An Aboriginal boy guides two white schoolchildren through the blistering Outback in this Australian New Wave classic, but it's not just the landscape that's lethal, with the prejudice of white Australians far more dangerous than the terrain.

Darryl Kerrigan's home is his castle and he'll do anything to defend it, including fighting greedy developers. A breakout hit in 1997, The Castle presented suburban Australia with side-splitting humour, endless heart and unforgettable one-liners.

While The Castle is a classic, it presents a particularly white Melbourne suburban experience. Redfern Now, by contrast, explores the lives of First Peoples in Sydney's Redfern. Stephen Curry also has roles in both.

While Redfern Now explored contemporary suburban stories of First Peoples in Sydney, TV show Sunshine examines the South Sudanese Australian immigrant experience in Melbourne and presents another facet of Australia's evolving national identity.

An Indigenous guide also leads the audience through white prejudice, oppression and brutality in Jennifer Kent's The Nightingale, where the oppressed First Peoples man Billy (Baykali Ganambarr) and Irish convict Claire (Aisling Franciosi), chase British forces into a labyrinthine bush that represents the latter's demise.

The Outback is again a place of prejudice in The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert, with the queer crew of the famous bus confronted by small-mind mentalities. But the desert is also a source of hope and freedom, with the characters finding common humanity and community on the road.

Over 30 years after starring as the young boy in Walkabout, David Dalaithngu again appeared in a film about traversing the Outback. In Rabbit-Proof Fence, Dalaithngu plays Moodoo, an Aboriginal tracker chasing three young Indigenous girls escaping a native settlement to return to their Country.

nodes.title: The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert

links.text: Directed by Eddie Martin, All This Mayhem tells the story of two brothers from Melbourne, Ben and Tas Tappas, during the glory days of professional vert skateboarding in the 1990s. The documentary features archival footage, as does Dogtown and Z-Boys.

Tony Hawk appears in archival footage of skateboarding competitions in All This Mayhem, though he declined to be interviewed in the film. In 1999, he released a video game, Tony Hawk's Pro Skater, that became a hugely successful franchise.

Dogtown and Z-Boys, directed by Stacy Peralta, charts the rise of the Zephyr skateboarding team in Southern California in the 1970s using archival Super 8 footage. The feature film Lords of Dogtown, also written by Peralta, dramatises the story.

This Ain't California explores skateboarding subculture in East Germany in the 1980s. Though the documentary claimed to feature original Super 8 film, it was later revealed that the subject, Denis Paracek, was a fictional character played by a contemporary skateboarder.

Bing Liu's debut film, Minding the Gap, is a documentary about three skateboarders and their personal experiences of family violence. Though it appeared to be centred on three best friends, the film's subjects only became friends during the filming process.

Unlike the male-dominated Lords of Dogtown, Skate Kitchen, directed by Crystal Moselle, portrays an all-female skate crew in New York City. The film was inspired by the real-life collective and members of the group play fictionalised versions of themselves.

Larry Clark's controversial film Kids, written by Harmony Korine, also featured non-professional actors and skaters in their first acting roles, with Chloe Sevigny and Rosario Dawson both making their debut in the drug-fuelled and sexually exploitative depiction of teenage life.

The Olympic Games have historically offered an opportunity for technological developments in filmmaking, including the motion picture techniques employed by Leni Riefenstahl in her visually dazzling, yet politically controversial, documentary about the 1938 Berlin Olympics.

The 1964 Tokyo Olympics were also captured with impressive filmmaking techniques in the documentary Tokyo Olympiad, directed by Kon Ichikawa, who used multiple cameras, telephoto lenses and slow motion to capture the drama and poetry of the athletes and crowds.
While investigating the world of illegal doping in sports, filmmaker Bryan Fogel uncovered Russia's state-sponsored Olympic doping program, revealed in the gripping documentary Icarus.

Competition and controversy run high in the Olympic Games. Loosely based on real events, I, Tonya, chronicles the life of figure skater Tonya Harding and her connection to an attack on rival Nancy Kerrigan prior to the Winter Olympics.

Another film based on real events is Munich, a historical drama exploring the aftermath and retaliation to the terrorist attack at the 1972 Olympic Games, which resulted in the death of 11 athletes from the Israeli team.
Also loosely based on real events, comedy Cool Runnings follows the Jamaican bobsled team as they prepare for the 1988 Winter Olympics despite never having seen the snow.

In the lead up to the 2000 Sydney Olympics, Australian mockumentary series The Games, starring John Clarke, Brian Dawe and Gina Riley, satirised the internal politics, bureaucratic ineptitude and corruption of the Sydney Organising Committee.

nodes.title: Olympia Part One: Festival of the Nations

links.text: The documentary Bellingcat: Truth in a Post-Truth World explores the journalism collective and the way they use open-source intelligence to investigate events in warzones and conflicts.
Social media accounts can now be used as part of criminal investigations. The film The Social Network dramatises the origins of website Facebook, founded by Mark Zuckerberg in 2003.
Whistleblower Edward Snowden released classified documents on the CIA's global surveillance program, raising privacy concerns. Snowden was the subject of Laura Poitras' documentary Citizenfour.

Laura Poitras also released a documentary, Risk in 2016, about Julian Assange, the controversial leader of WikiLeaks, in a film that explored the difficult ethics of documentary making. Feature film The Fifth Estate dramatises the life of Assange.

Benedict Cumberbatch stars as Julian Assange in The Fifth Estate, and also plays mathematician and computer scientist Alan Turing in The Imitation Game. The drama tells the story of an MI6 team, led by Turing, breaking the Enigma code during WWII.
Critically panned thriller The Circle follows Emma Watson working for a cult-like technology and social media company that touts transparency as a guise for the invasion of privacy.
British TV series Black Mirror (2011–present) explores modern society’s use of and dependence on technology, set in a dystopian near-future with a dark and satirical tone, like The Circle.

nodes.title: Eliot Higgins, the founder of investigative journalism group Bellingcat, London
Bellingcat: Truth in a Post-Truth World

links.text: The Black Power movement emerged in the late 1960s and early 70s. It was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to Gary Foley. Fellow Indigenous activist Bruce McGuinness helped strengthen activism and filmmaking with Black Fire.

Gary Foley co-wrote and appeared in the stage show Basically Black, the first Aboriginal stage production, which was adapted into a TV show in 1973 that was later censored by the ABC for being too political.
Though it debuted 40 years after Basically Black aired, Black Comedy owes a debt to the original Indigenous sketch show by being another program written and performed by and all Indigenous cast.

In the late 1970s, non-Indigenous filmmakers wanting to support Indigenous Rights released films on Black Australia to mixed success but Backroads, made in close consultation with Gary Foley, was groundbreaking for tackling racism and giving First Peoples a say in how they were portrayed.

The 1980s saw Indigenous activism and Black Power gain prominence in mainstream screen and pop culture, with activist Gary Foley appearing in the cult classic Dogs in Space, playing the character Barry, who was based on him.

Also in the 1980s, Gary Foley appeared in the family favourite TV show A Country Practice. This pop culture moment, although brief, arguably reached a much wider audience than protests and demonstrate the power of screen culture as a tool of activism.

nodes.title: Indigenous Voices on the Screen with Professor Gary Foley

name: Black Power through film and TV

links.text: While the TV miniatures represent the spaces and places that Australians watched TV throughout history, the deconstructed TV in Edie Kurzer's display in the Fed Square foyer symbolises the fractured nature of TV watching today.

News and variety TV shows have been a staple of the Australian small screen since its arrival in the 1950s. The longest-running Australian news program is Four Corners, which has been running since 1961 and features award-winning investigations and documentaries.

Ten years after Four Corners premiered, nightly stalwart A Current Affair debuted with Mike Willesee as host and it also featured Paul Hogan with comedic social commentary. Though now considered a 'tabloid' show, rather than hard-hitting journalism, it remains popular.

News and comedy have always been part of Australian TV, often enjoying a complimentary relationship. We're not sure how much ACA host Ray Martin felt when Eric Bana launched his career spoofing the news presenter on Full Frontal, in character as bogan Poida.

Debuting the same year as A Current Affair was another long-running staple of Australian screens, Hey Hey It's Saturday. Based on the English variety show of the same name, it kept families entertained with comedy skits and iconic characters.

Plucka Duck was one of the most popular characters in Hey Hey It's Saturday, probably because he gave away prizes. In Edie Kurzer's display in the Fed Sq foyer, you can catch a peek of him among the other iconic characters.

One of Micallf's most famous characters on Full Frontal was Nobby Doldrums, a huge fan of 7.30 Report presenter Kerry O'Brien, who insinuates himself to be on the program by agreeing to be interviewed about anything.

Videogames and Us features the godfather of computing, Alan Turing, who created the imitation game, now known as the Turing Test, to determine if computers could behave like humans. It’s an early basis for AI – something explored in Ex Machina.

In 1962, MIT students made a computer game called Spacewar! from data stored on punched paper tape. When Atari founder Nolan Bushnell saw the two ships battling across a digitised starfield, he was inspired to develop and release Atari’s first arcade machine, Computer Space.

In Richard Fleischer’s Soylent Green, which came out two years afterwards, a Computer Space arcade machine painted white can be seen in Simonson’s apartment. It’s meant to be a futuristic entertainment unit and is the first video game to appear in a movie.

In Soylent Green, set in 2022, over population and pollution strangle earth and people survive on synthetic food – Soylent Green. The factory where the food’s made is the real-world El Segundo oil refinery in California, which inspired the miniature sets in Blade Runner, set in 2019.

While Pris is one of the most iconic dangerous and highly sexualised AI androids in movies, the trope goes right back to the beginning of cinema with Fritz Lang’s groundbreaking Metropolis featuring Maria, who appears as a typical robot and a sensual woman.

Blade Runner's philosophical questions around AI are said to have influenced the reimagined Battlestar Galactica, with star of both, Edward James Olmos even hypothesising they’re set in the same universe, with BSG a Blade Runner prequel.

The AI androids in BSG, Cylons, are led by the malevolent Six (Tricia Helfer), a highly sexualised AI who manipulates human characters. Halo also features a female AI named Cortana, but she’s benevolent and guides the players… until she goes insane and becomes highly sexualised, particularly in Halo 4.

Ava (Alicia Vikander) in Ex Machina is an AI android who gradually gains consciousness and represented as both dangerous and highly sexualised – a common trope of AI in movies that is exemplified by Pris (Daryl Hannah), the pleasure model replicant in Blade Runner.

The music video for the title track of The Avalanches’ debut album took home the Best Video at the 2001 MTV Europe Music Awards. It follows two miners who emerge from a black-and-white world into a colourful dance audition, based on the scene in Flashdance.

While ‘Since I Left You’ proved the Avalanches could make fun-loving, quikry film clips, their collaboration with Soda_Jerk The Was (2016) took things further, remixing famous scenes from cinema, TV and music videos into a seamless musical trip, which visually relfects the band’s use of sampling.

The Was begins by following the Japanese couple (Youki Kudoh and Masatoshi Nagase) from Jim Jarmusch’s Mystery Train episode ‘Far from Yokohama’. The Was starts with the Memphis setting of Jarmusch’s film, featuring other characters like Edward Scissors hands superimposed into the action.

The Was features characters from The Warriors (1979) sharing a train with Saturday Night Fever’s (1979) Tony Manero (John Travolta). Manero also appears in Hell’s Club, another video that remixes iconic characters together and features Saturday Night Fever’s titular song.

Artist duo and remix maestros Soda_Jerk took their penchant for reappropriating iconic cinema characters to new levels in TERROR NULLIUS, their 2018 artwork commissioned by ACMI. Rather than a celebration like ‘The Was’, TERROR NULLIUS is a condemnation of mainstream Australian identity.

Hell’s Club is part of a long moving image tradition of remixing and repurposing content to create new meaning and perspectives. One of the first instances was Charles A Ridley’s Schichlegruber - Doing the Lambeth Walk (1941), which ridiculed Nazis by soundtracking their propaganda videos with a jaunty tune.

While Ridley’s Lambeth Walk had a political point to make, sometimes remixing is done simply for entertainment and to illuminate clichés and tropes, like Duncan Robson’s Let’s Enhance, a supercut of film and TV show characters ‘enhancing’ surveillance footage with non-existent technology.

nodes.title: Since I Left You – The Avalanches

name: Remix and resistance (Since I left you)

links.text: Renowned costume designer Sandy Powell brought characters to life with her work in The Favourite by Yorgos Lanthimos. The Greek filmmaker gave viewers a surreal, dystopian version of courtship in The Lobster.

The Lobster was largely considered Lanthimos's breakthrough film and was nominated for a Best Original Screenplay Academy Award. His partner, Ariane Labed, received a thank you in the film. She starred in the critically acclaimed Attenberg.

Attenberg was written, directed and produced by Athina Rachel Tsangari whose work has influenced indie fillmakers the Duplass Brothers and Richard Linklater. Both she and the star of Attenberg – Labed – appeared in Linklater's Before Midnight.
Before Midnight was the conclusion to the Before trilogy, which was the brainchild of Linklater, Ethan Hawke and Julie Delpy, and spanned several decades. Linklater also toyed with time in Boyhood.
Boyhood was filmed over the course of 12 years, charting the course of couple's relationship as played by Patricia Arquette and Ethan Hawke. Arquette also starred in television mini-series The Act.

The Act followed a mother with Munchausen syndrome by proxy – played by Arquette – who was eventually killed by her daughter's boyfriend. The true story fascinated America and was examined in Mommy Dead And Dearest by documentarian Erin Lee Carr.
